summary: [/INST] The study aims to identify specific psychosocial clusters of variables that are specific to the onset and maintenance of chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia. The hypothesis is that specific psychological factors (clusters of high number of early traumatic events, high levels of central sensitization, and specific traits and defense mechanisms) characterize FM, CM, and VU groups compared to controls.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of two different mattresses in preventing pressure ulcers in bedridden patients. The mattresses used in the study are a massage mattress with a cube/block system and a viscoelastic pressure sore prevention mattress with an orthopedic support surface. The study is conducted in a hospital setting and the participants are bedridden patients who are at risk of developing pressure ulcers. The primary outcome measure of the study is the number of patients who develop pressure ulcers during the four-week follow-up period. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of the hospital.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of exercise with augmented reality glasses on metabolic parameters, anthropometric measurement values and quality of life in children aged 10-12 with type 1 diabetes. The study will be conducted in a single center with a parallel group design. The study will include 40 children with type 1 diabetes who meet the eligibility criteria. The children will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will receive exercise with augmented reality glasses, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures are changes in HbA1c levels, body mass index, and quality of life. The secondary outcome measures are changes in insulin dose, blood glucose levels, and lipid profile. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks. The results of the study will provide evidence on the effectiveness of exercise with augmented reality glasses on metabolic parameters, anthropometric measurement values and quality of life in children with type 1 diabetes.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on anxiety management before abdominal surgery. The study will be conducted in a tertiary hospital in Turkey. The study will include 96 patients who will undergo abdominal surgery. The patients will be randomly assigned to three groups: the intervention group, the control group, and the placebo group. The intervention group will watch a virtual reality video with mobile virtual glasses, the control group will watch the same video without virtual glasses, and the placebo group will not watch any video. The anxiety level will be measured using the Visual Anxiety Scale (VAS-A) and a smart wristband with stress level measurement feature before and after the video. The study will be conducted between March and December 2023. The results of the study will provide evidence on the effectiveness of virtual reality in managing preoperative anxiety.

[/INST] The study is a single-arm prospective interventional study that aims to evaluate the clinical performance and safety of Suture-TOOL for abdominal wound closure in men and women undergoing elective open abdominal surgery for benign or malignant colorectal disease through midline incision. The study will measure the proportion of patients with Suture length/Wound length (SL/WL) ratio ≥ 4, stitch count, number of sutures used, incision closure time, surgeons’ comfort with the device during closure, and surgeons’ satisfaction with the final closure result. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

[/INST] The Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma is a study that aims to evaluate the immune characteristics of patients with salivary gland carcinoma. The study will use a liquid immune profile-based signature (LIPS) and tumor-associated lymphocytes (TAL) to characterize the immune matrix of patients. The study will also use immunophenotyping, cytokine analysis, metabolomic analysis, and microbiomic analysis to assess the immune, metabolic, and microbiomic states of patients. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 5 years and will involve the collection of stool, saliva, and blood samples from patients. The study will evaluate the changes in the immune matrix, immune cell distribution, cytokine expression, metabolic state, and microbiomic state of patients from baseline to the end of the study period. The study will also assess the relationship between the immune characteristics of patients and their clinical outcomes.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to determine the compliance of individuals with multiple sclerosis to the Mediterranean diet, the impact of walking on quality of life, and the relationship between these two. The study will be conducted with 100 individuals diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. The study will be conducted in the Neurology Department of Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The study will use the Mediterranean Diet Adaptation Scale (PREDIMED) to determine the compliance of individuals with multiple sclerosis to the Mediterranean diet. The Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale will be used to determine the quality of life of individuals with multiple sclerosis. The 12-item MS Gait Scale will be used to determine the impact of walking on the quality of life of individuals with multiple sclerosis. The Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) will be used to determine the disability status of individuals with multiple sclerosis. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice Guidelines. The study will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] The SIIT-CD study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, controlled study that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools in patients with Crohn's disease. The study will compare the clinical response rate at week 24 between the intensive induction regimen and the standard induction regimen.

[/INST] The study titled "The Preference of a Culturally and Linguistic Diverse (CALD) Population for Second Line OAB Therapy: a Discrete Choice Experiment" is a questionnaire-based study that aims to determine the preferences of a culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) population for second-line therapy for overactive bladder (OAB). The study will involve patients with OAB who are adults and do not have a history of sacral neuromodulation (SNM) or botulinum toxin A (Botox) treatment. The study will be conducted in Australia and will involve a discrete choice experiment (DCE) questionnaire. The DCE questionnaire will ask patients to choose between two fictive therapies, each option coming with its own characteristics related to SNM and Botox. The study will measure the patients' preferences for the different characteristics of the two fictive therapies. The study will be conducted over a period of one hour.

[/INST] The study is a three-arm pragmatic randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness, feasibility, acceptability, and cost of the use of continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) in people with type 1 diabetes in South Africa. The study will compare the use of CGM in a continuous manner (arm 1), intermittent manner (arm 2), and standard of care (arm 3). The study will evaluate the impact of continuous and intermittent CGM use on blood glucose levels in comparison to standard of care in people living with type 1 diabetes. The study will also evaluate the impact of continuous and intermittent CGM use on the variability of blood glucose concentrations related to diabetes, unplanned visits to outpatient clinics and/or hospital related to diabetes complications, quality of life of recipients of diabetes care and their caregivers (where applicable), acceptability and feasibility of continuous and intermittent CGM use from a healthcare provider, recipients of care and care givers perspective, and cost of continuous and intermittent CGM use from a user and provider perspective.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of fractionated stereotactic ablative body radiotherapy (SBRT) with a focal boost on the dominant intraprostatic lesion (DIL) in patients with localized prostate cancer. The study will assess the biochemical progression-free survival and local control at 3 years, as well as the incidence and severity of acute and late urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events. The study will also evaluate patient-reported outcomes and quality of life assessment using the International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) and Expanded Prostate Index Composite-26 (EPIC-26) short form.

[/INST] The SMILER study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a serious game (SG) in improving the quality of life and reducing the symptoms of asthma in children. The SG will be designed to promote physical activity and will be tailored to the child's motor skills. The study will compare the effectiveness of the SG to standard asthma treatment. The primary outcome measure will be the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and the secondary outcome measure will be the Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita). The study will also measure the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of acute and chronic stress on Pavlovian-to-instrumental transfer (PIT) in individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) and healthy controls. The study will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure neural activation in the mesolimbic system, a brain region involved in reward processing. The study will also use behavioral tasks to measure PIT effects and cognitive control. The study will investigate the effects of acute stress on neural activation and behavioral measures of PIT, as well as the effects of chronic stress on behavioral measures of PIT. [/INST] Flow and Grow - The Ideal Time to Wean CPAP Off In Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants is a clinical trial that aims to determine the optimal time to wean infants born with extremely low birth weight off continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). The study will compare a standardized maintenance/weaning protocol to routine care in infants born at < 30 weeks gestational age. The primary outcome measure is the number of infants with CPAP/NIS weaning failure. The study will also assess the number of stimulation events per 24 hours, length of hospital stay, rate of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids and antibiotics, number of infants with a need for re-intubation, total duration of positive pressure respiratory support, number of infants requiring supplemental oxygen, number of infants experiencing pulmonary air leaks, number of infants with nasal deformities, time to establish full tube feeds, time to establish full oral feeds, number of infants with nosocomial infections, number of infants with intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH) grade III-IV and/or periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) and/or ventriculomegaly on cranial ultrasound, number of infants with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), rate of weight gain, and number of infants with adverse events. The study will enroll infants born at < 30 weeks gestational age who are on CPAP at 34 weeks postmenstrual age and have a FiO2 of 0.3 or less. The study will randomize infants to either a standardized maintenance/weaning protocol or routine care. The study will be conducted at four Neonatal Intensive Care Units within the Rady Children's/University of California, San Diego network. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Frexalimab (SAR441344) in adults with nonrelapsing secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS). The study will enroll participants with a previous diagnosis of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) in accordance with the 2017 revised McDonald criteria and a current diagnosis of SPMS in accordance with the clinical course criteria revised in 2013. Participants must have documented evidence of disability progression observed during the 12 months before screening. The primary outcome measure is time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression (cCDP) confirmed over 6 months. The secondary outcome measures include time to onset of composite cCDP confirmed over 3 months, time to onset of individual components of the composite, confirmed over 3-months or 6-months, time to onset of confirmed disability improvement (CDI), number of new and/or enlarging T2hyperintense lesions per scan as detected by MRI, percent change in brain volume loss as detected by MRI scans at the end of study (EOS) compared to Month 6, change in cognitive function at the EOS compared to baseline as assessed by symbol digit modalities test (SDMT), change from baseline in multiple sclerosis impact scale 29 version 2 (MSIS-29v2) questionnaire scores over time, change from baseline in patient reported outcome measurement information system (PROMIS) Fatigue multiple sclerosis (MS)-8a over time, annualized relapse rate during the study period assessed by protocol defined adjudicated relapses, number of participants with adverse events, serious adverse events, AEs leading to permanent study intervention discontinuation and AE of special interests (AESIs), number of participants with potentially clinically significant abnormalities (PCSAs) in laboratory tests, ECG, and vital signs during the study period, change from baseline in serum Ig levels over time, change from baseline in plasma neurofilament light chain (NfL) levels over time, Frexalimab plasma concentration over time, and change from baseline in other clinical measures. The study will have a duration of 2

[/INST] The study is a comparative study between modified Millard and Mishra techniques in unilateral cleft lip repair. The study is a randomized controlled study. The study is conducted on 63 infants with unilateral isolated cleft lip aged from 2-6 months. The infants are divided into three groups. Group A: control group, Group B: infants with unilateral cleft lip had modified Millard technique repair, Group C: infants with unilateral cleft lip had mishra technique repair. The study is measuring surgical repair unilateral cleft lip measurements. The measurements are vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtral length. The study is conducted at 3 months post operative.
[/INST] Endoscopic Management Of Controlled Colo-cutaneous Fistula As A Complication of Acute Sigmoid Diverticulitis: A Randomized Controlled Trial

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary approach to early diagnosis of heart failure. The study will compare the effectiveness of a screening program that includes a case-finding algorithm, a patient information package, and a follow-up visit with a control group that receives usual care. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants diagnosed with heart failure according to the European Society of Cardiology 2021 guidelines. The study will enroll participants aged 40 years or older who have at least two additional risk factors for heart failure. The study will be conducted in Canada and will involve 100 participants in each group. The study will be conducted over a six-month period.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study that aims to evaluate the effects of propofol dose according to lean body weight by evaluating patients with a body mass index below 35. Patients who will be operated under general anesthesia will be included. Patients with propofol allergy or contraindicated to propofol are included in the study. In order to decide and try the most appropriate weight-based scalar for propofol dosing for anesthesia induction to be evaluated by specifying patients who need additional propofol during intubation in the study, Ingrande et al. 80 patients with a mean body mass index [BMI] between 18-35 and Bispectoral index (BIS). ) monitorization, propofol infusion (100 mg/kg/hour) will be started according to total body weight, and the infusion will be stopped with a BIS value between 50 and 40, and the elapsed time will be recorded. Routine anesthesia applications will be performed with neuromuscular blocker applied. The total dose of Propofol given; the dose applied to kilograms will be calculated according to TBW, IBW and LBW. And the relationship between the doses given and the body mass index will be evaluated.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort design that aims to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of letermovir for CMV prophylaxis in heart or lung transplant recipients. The study will compare subjects exposed to letermovir for CMV prophylaxis with those who received standard valganciclovir prophylaxis in the two years before the study began (referred to as the pre-intervention period). The primary outcome measure is CMV viral load, and the secondary outcome measures include the proportion of days during which appropriately renally-dosed prophylaxis, frequency of acute cellular rejection, proportion of subjects who develop CMV resistance, proportion of subjects who develop neutropenia, proportion of subjects who develop severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count less than 50,000/microliter), proportion of subjects with unplanned discontinuation of MMF or azathioprine, and number of subjects with incorrect renal dosing at any point during the planned prophylaxis period.

[/INST] The PHYSIOSCORE is a tool developed to assess the complexity level of physical therapy care in hospitalized patients. It consists of 106 items divided into three domains: respiratory, imaging, and neuromuscular. The PHYSIOSCORE was developed in three phases. In phase 1, the committee comprised ten specialist physical therapists with more than ten years of experience in hospital care. The questionnaire validation construct was performed using the Delphi technique, and the consensus was defined with a minimum percentage of at least 75% agreement as important or essential. In phase 2, the interrater agreement and reliability were established following a prospective and observational single-center study. In phase 3, the clinical validation of the instrument was performed in two stages. Initially, the PHYSIOSCORE was applied to assess the level of attention and complexity of physical therapy care by one professional. Then, a second physical therapist with at least five years of experience performed respiratory and neuromuscular physical therapy. The time spent evaluating respiratory and neuromuscular physical therapist care and registering electronic medical records were all timed.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of selective adjuvant therapy for HPV-mediated oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) based on residual circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) levels. The study will enroll patients with HPV-positive OPSCC who are candidates for surgery (TORS) and have positive ctDNA levels prior to surgery. After TORS, all patients will be stratified into one of three risk groups based on pathological criteria and ctDNA levels. The low-risk group will be observed (no radiation) per standard of care (SOC). The intermediate-risk group (intermediate pathological features and negative ctDNA) will also be observed (no radiation) per the experimental arm. The high-risk group will receive adjuvant treatment (RT +/- chemotherapy) per SOC. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) at 2 years post-last treatment. The secondary outcome measures include rate of recurrence at 1 year post-TORS with negative ctDNA, rate of salvage for locoregional recurrence (LRR) after TORS, LRR at 2 years post-last treatment, overall survival (OS) at 2 years post-last treatment, number of participants free from distant metastases at 2 years post-last treatment, number of participants with grade 2/3 xerostomia at 1 year following completion of treatment, patient scores from the MDADI at 1 year following completion of treatment, PEG-tube rate at 2 years following completion of treatment, and recurrence in all patients (Groups 1, 2 and 3) stratified by group and post-TORS ctDNA levels at 1 year post-TORS.

[/INST] The study is a single-institution prospective phase 2 trial comparing ultra-hypofractionated whole breast irradiation (WBI) to ultra-hypofractionated partial breast irradiation (PBI) in breast cancer patients. The study aims to assess the acute and late toxicity of the two radiotherapy regimens, local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, and cosmetic outcome. The study will use the Harvard score for breast cosmesis and the EORTC QLQ-BR23 questionnaire to assess cosmetic outcome and quality of life, respectively. The study will enroll breast cancer patients who have undergone breast-conserving surgery and have been recommended to receive adjuvant radiotherapy. The study will randomize patients to receive either ultra-hypofractionated WBI or ultra-hypofractionated PBI. The study will use an ultra-short course of radiotherapy with 26Gy in 5 fractions. The study will assess acute toxicity at 1-6 months after RT and late toxicity at 6-60 months after RT. The study will also assess local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, and distant metastasis occurrence at 3, 5, and 10 years.

[/INST] The study is a prospective study of patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (R/R MM) to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of digital health coaching (DLC) and its potential to augment existing standards of care for patient support. Patients enrolled in the program will be assigned to a health advisor who will act as an educator and accountability partner, supporting patients as they experience treatment for R/R MM. Throughout the engagement, patient reported outcomes (PROs) will be collected at multiple time points to assess the patient status and will be used to explore relationships between medical management, health related quality of life (HRQoL), and engagement in the program. Findings from this study will establish feasibility of a DLC intervention for individuals with R/R MM and provide greater insight into their symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being through the integration of patient reported, wearable and clinical data.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study that aims to explore the effect of a 4-week 10-20 g/day WholeFiberTM intervention on fecal calprotectin, IBD-complaints, QoL, serum inflammatory markers, gut microbiota and SCFA in patients with CD and UC. The study will include 12 patients with mild to moderate IBD complaints who will receive WholeFiberTM for 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure is change in fecal calprotectin. The study will also explore the effect of the intervention on IBD-complaints, QoL, serum inflammatory markers, gut microbiota and SCFA. The study will provide valuable information on the effect of a fiber-rich intervention on fecal calprotectin and other outcomes in patients with IBD.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of the porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) in combination with coronally advanced flap (CAF) for the treatment of localized gingival recessions. The study will include 20 patients with at least one gingival recession that meets the inclusion criteria. The patients will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups: the control group, which will receive CAF alone, or the experimental group, which will receive CAF in combination with PADM. The primary outcome measure is the reduction in gingival recession height, which will be measured at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months after the intervention. The secondary outcome measure is the thickness of the keratinized tissue, which will be measured at the same time points. The study will be conducted in four centers in Brazil.

[/INST] The study is a randomized crossover clinical trial that aims to compare the changes in heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients undergoing conventional physical exercise and in a virtual environment during hemodialysis sessions. The study will compare the effects of conventional physical exercise and virtual reality exercise on heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients before and during hemodialysis sessions. The study will also compare the relative effectiveness of conventional physical exercise and virtual reality exercise in improving heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients before and during hemodialysis sessions. The study will assess heart rate and respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, systemic blood pressure, laboratory tests, as well as the Kidney Disease Quality of Life Short Form questionnaire, the Beck Anxiety and Depression Inventory, and the International Physical Activity Questionnaire in all groups.

[/INST] The study is titled "Analysis of the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients under invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning trial" and is a prospective observational study. The study aims to analyze the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients under invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning trial. The study will include patients who are intubated and mechanically ventilated for more than 48 hours, have a readiness-to-wean ability, and have a decision by the clinician in charge of the patient to perform a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT). The study will measure the intensity of dyspnea using the Dyspnea Visual Analog Scale (D-VAS) and the Mechanical Ventilation Respiratory Distress Observation Scale (MV-RDOS) during the SBT. The study will also measure ventilatory variability using respiratory rate, tidal volume, and respiratory rate/tidal volume ratio during the SBT. The study will analyze the relationship between ventilatory variability and the intensity of dyspnea and the ability to successfully wean from mechanical ventilation.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the outcome of a modified mini-incision approach versus the conventional approach for carpal tunnel release. The study is conducted in Egypt and is double-blinded. The study includes 60 patients with primary carpal tunnel syndrome who are randomized into two groups: a modified mini-incision group and a conventional group. The modified mini-incision group undergoes a longitudinal mini-incision started just above the proximal flexor wrist crease and extended for 1.5-2 cm in a proximal direction. The conventional group undergoes a longitudinal incision created between the thenar and hypothenar eminences along the longitudinal axis of the ring finger. The primary outcome measure is improvement in carpal tunnel syndrome associated pain according to the visual analogue scale for pain. The secondary outcome measures are pillar pain, recurrence of neuropathic symptoms, and operative time. The study is ongoing and is expected to be completed in 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effectiveness of action observation therapy in patients with mild cognitive impairment. The study will compare three groups of patients: those who observe the therapist, those who observe patients without cognitive impairment, and a control group. The intervention will last for 5 weeks, and the primary outcome measure will be the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score. The study will also measure changes in activities of daily living, functionality, upper limb dexterity, balance, and gait. The study will use the Fugl-Meyer scale, Barthel index, Box and block test, Berg Balance Scale, and 10 Meters Walking Test to measure these changes. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of central line placement using an ultraportable ultrasound device to conventional ultrasound. The study includes patients who are scheduled to have a right or left jugular central venous line placed preoperatively or in the ICU. The primary outcome measure is the length of the procedure, which is defined as the time in seconds between the beginning of the ultrasonographic scan after placement of the sterile protection device and the beginning of fixation of the catheter to the skin after ultrasound verification confirming its correct position. The study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of ultraportable ultrasound devices for central line placement.

[/INST] The study is a randomized sham-controlled prospective study that aims to evaluate the efficacy of Er:YAG laser therapy in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars in respect of vulvar pain and scar tissue healing. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study will include 20 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or the sham comparator group. The experimental group will receive three sessions of Er:YAG laser therapy at intervals of 15-21 days, while the sham comparator group will receive the same procedure but with a sham handpiece. The primary outcome measures are the rate of change of pain and the rate of scar tissue healing. The secondary outcome measures are the rate of improvement in sexual function and the incidence and severity of device-related adverse events. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the local ethics committee.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of upper limb somatosensory discrimination therapy to upper limb motor therapy in children and adolescents with unilateral cerebral palsy. [/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to understand the profile of the gut microbiome in adult patients diagnosed with gallstone disease and its relationship with patient outcomes. The study will collect data from 75 adult patients presenting to East Kent University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust Hospitals with newly diagnosed gallstone disease following confirmatory imaging investigations. Data will be collected from electronic patient records including clinical history and diagnostic investigations, anthropometry, blood and imaging results (if taken as part of routine clinical care) for the initial presentation and subsequent readmissions/planned follow-up timepoints. Stool samples will be collected from patients either during admission or at home at each timepoint. Samples will be returned by post to the research team where they will be stored and analysed. Patients will have a sample collected at time of diagnosis and then at 6 monthly intervals whilst awaiting cholecystectomy. A pre-operative sample will be required within 6 weeks of any surgical intervention. Following cholecystectomy an immediate post-operative sample (within the first week) will be collected as well as a sample at 6 months.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective cohort study that aims to investigate the association between the initial APRI value and the development of SALD in adult patients with sepsis during their ICU stay. The study included 1,000 patients from the MIMIC IV database and 1,000 patients from the authors' own hospital. The study found that the initial APRI value was associated with the development of SALD in adult patients with sepsis during their ICU stay. The study also found that the initial APRI value was associated with the 30-day mortality rate in adult patients with sepsis during their ICU stay.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the immunogenicity and safety of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and older with different immunization programs. The study will enroll 100 participants who will receive two doses of the investigational vaccine or placebo. The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse events after two doses of the vaccine given intramuscularly according to different immunization programs. The secondary outcome measures are the laboratory markers of immunity after two doses of the vaccine given intramuscularly according to different immunization programs, including the geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibodies against the Omicron variant (XBB) after vaccination with the investigational vaccine, the positive conversion rate of the Omicron variant (XBB) of the new coronavirus after vaccination with the investigational vaccine, the GMT of neutralizing antibodies against the prototype novel coronavirus strain, the Omicron strain (BA.4/5, BF.7) after two doses of vaccine candidate, the GMI of the prototype new coronavirus strain and the Omicron variant (BA.4/5, BF.7) after two doses of investigational vaccine, the positive conversion rate against the prototype Omicron variant (BA.4/5, BF.7) after two doses of study vaccine, the GMT of neutralizing antibodies against the prototype novel coronavirus strain, the Omicron strain (XBB, BA.4/5, BF.7) after two doses of vaccine candidate, the GMI of the prototype new coronavirus strain and the Omicron variant (XBB, BA.4/5, BF.7) after two doses of investigational vaccine, and the positive conversion rate against the prototype Omicron variant (XBB, BA.4/5, BF.7) after two doses of study vaccine. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study aimed to examine the effect of early skin-to-skin contact on mother-infant attachment and traumatic birth perception. The study was conducted as a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment model. The sample consisted of 350 women who applied to the Training and Research Hospital in the city center of Batman between December 2021 and May 2022 and who agreed to participate as the study group (n:175) and the control group (n:175). The experimental group was told how to apply skin-to-skin contact. Skin-to-skin contact was initiated within the first minutes of normal delivery and skin-to-skin contact was applied to the mothers for a minimum of 15 minutes. The maternal attachment scale was completed 1 month after birth by telephone interview. The control group received standard midwifery practices and labor follow-up. The results of the study showed that skin-to-skin contact had a positive effect on maternal attachment and traumatic birth perception.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, randomized, controlled, double-blind, single-center study that was approved by the Ethics Committee and followed the Consolidated Reporting Trials Standards (CONSORT). The study included 54 patients undergoing elective lumbar discectomy who were randomized into two groups: the first group underwent sacral erector spinae plane block (ESPB) at the end of surgery, while the second group did not receive any block. The blocks were performed in the operating theatre before the patient woke up. A patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) device was given to both groups, and VAS scores were assessed for 24 hours. The study found that ESPB significantly reduced pain scores and opioid consumption in the first 24 hours after surgery compared to the control group.

[/INST] The study is titled "Development and Validation of a Noninvasive Multimodal Ultrasound-Based Imaging Biomarker for Myofascial Pain" and aims to develop and validate a non-invasive multimodal ultrasound-based imaging biomarker for myofascial pain (MP). The study will recruit healthy normals, participants with MP without trigger points (TPs), participants with MP with latent TPs, and participants with MP with active TPs. The primary outcome measure is the diagnosis of one of the four MP-related categories, which will be determined by standardized clinical examinations at the first study visit. The secondary outcome measure is the presence of substantial MP, which will be determined by the standardized clinical examinations at the first and second study visits. The study will use ultrasound imaging to measure the echogenicity of latent and active TPs, the dynamic spatial-temporal tissue deformation quantified by strain tensors (compression, extension, and shear) in the thoracolumbar fascia and multifidus muscle, and the viscoelastic properties of the fascia and muscles measured by ultrasound shear wave elastography. The study will use deep learning to integrate these measurements into a predictive biomarker and use established validation methods to test its ability to predict MP. The study will determine the sensitivity and specificity of the biomarker to classify the myofascial components of pain, as well as the response to treatment (a diagnostic and predictive marker).

[/INST] The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial is a two-arm, blinded, randomized controlled trial that aims to estimate the effect of an adapted telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use at 3 months among opioid-naïve adult Emergency Department (ED) and urgent care patients with musculoskeletal pain. The study will use a block stratified randomization by the subject's age (18-40 years; 41+ years) and will be conducted and analyzed according to the CONSORT guidelines. The intervention will consist of an interactive video (15 minutes) given to the patient after an ED/urgent care visit that provides essential pain treatment information and encourages patients to discuss treatment options with their ED/urgent care provider. The video will be sent as a link to the patient's email. Participants will be asked to send back answers to the multiple-choice questions posed during the video and/or confirm having watched the video within 5 days (at most) of their acute care visit or discharge from the ED. The primary outcome measure will be the combined pain severity and interference scores from the Brief Pain Inventory-short form (BPI-SF) at 3 months. The secondary outcome measures will include pain severity and interference on the BPI-SF, opioid use during the past week, PROMIS measure: physical function-4, PROMIS measure: global health-physical 2a, healthcare utilization, number of visits to ED/urgent care, and number of visits to non-ED or urgent care physicians. The study will be conducted in the Emergency Departments of Centre Hospitalier Val-de-Travers, Switzerland. The study is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is a single-group assignment intervention study that aims to evaluate the impact of a neuro-linguistic program on the academic performance of primary school students in Lebanon. The program is designed to improve children's communication skills, self-confidence, and self-awareness and to help them improve their learning outcomes. The program consists of four sessions for teachers and two sessions for children. The study will measure the impact of the program on the academic performance of primary school students, including their strengths and difficulties progression, concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning. The study will also assess the triggers, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder symptoms, and their effect on behavior and academic performance of schoolchildren. The study will be conducted in Lebanon and will involve 130 children and 12 teachers. The study will be conducted over a period of two months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the use of the ECOX teaching tool to the control group in improving the final grade of medical students in emergency service OSCEs. The study also evaluates the value of the ECOX tool in reducing anxiety and improving student know-how. The study is conducted in the emergency department of a French university hospital. The study is designed to have two arms: the control group and the ECOX interventional group. The control group will take part in the ECOS of the departments scheduled at the end of their internship. Students will use the various revision methods usually offered to them by the faculty or in the emergency department, apart from the ECOX tool. The ECOX interventional group will use the ECOX tool available in the emergency department to practice before taking the on-duty OSCEs. The ECOX tool is a box with various ECOX grids and a stopwatch. The grids are divided into three parts: the starting situation, the expected answers, and the time limit. The study will evaluate the final grade of medical students in emergency service OSCEs and the average STAI-Y (State-Trait Anxiety) scores between the two groups. The study will also evaluate the average scores on the behavioral assessment during the service ECOS between the two groups. The study will be conducted over a period of ten weeks.
[/INST] The Effects of Pulmonary Hypertension Web-Based Health Care Program on Symptom Management, Social Support, Activity Tolerance, and Quality of Life in Patients With Pulmonary Hypertension.

[/INST] The study is titled "Effects of Long Term Ventilation Support on the Quality of Life of ALS Patients and Their Families". The study is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the quality of life of ALS patients and their families who choose long-term mechanical ventilation support with those who decline it. The study will use the Quality of Life Scale, Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire, Kidsscreen-27, Zarit Burden Interview, EQ-5D-5L, Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis assessment scale - 5 items (ALSAQ-5), and Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire to measure the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. The study will be conducted in Norway and will last for 21 months.

The study will be conducted in patients with cSDH who are undergoing surgical evacuation and will use subdural ECoG monitoring to detect spreading depolarization. [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of annual and semiannual infusions of ocrelizumab in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) who have been treated with ocrelizumab for at least 18 months and have been free of relapse for the same period. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesions on MRI at 24 months compared to the inclusion MRI. The study aims to determine if semiannual infusions of ocrelizumab are non-inferior to annual infusions in terms of the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesions on MRI at 24 months.

[/INST] The SPARCOL study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) to standard resection for early stage colon cancer in elderly frail patients. The primary outcome measure is the change in patient-reported postoperative recovery, measured by the Quality of Recovery 15 (QoR-15) questionnaire. The secondary outcome measures include changes in exercise capacity and physical condition, quality of life, frailty, duration of surgery, blood loss, intraoperative complications, conversion rate, rate of complete resection margin, assessment of histopathological risk factors, long-term oncological outcomes, adverse events, length of hospital stay, 90-day mortality, hospital readmissions, rate of secondary standard resection, and rate of stoma creation. The study is conducted in Denmark and is expected to be completed in 2024.

[/INST] Nebulised hypertonic saline (NHS) is a treatment that involves inhaling a solution of saline through the nose or mouth using a nebulizer. The study is a phase 2 open-label pilot study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of NHS in decreasing respiratory exacerbations in people with neuromuscular disease (NMD) or neurodisability. The study will recruit participants who have a diagnosis of NMD or neurodisability by a physician, are aged 5 years or older, and have a history of at least one respiratory exacerbation requiring antibiotic treatment in the past 12 months. The study will compare the number of respiratory exacerbations requiring antibiotic treatment between the NHS group and the control group. The study will also measure lung clearance index, forced oscillation technique, lung ultrasound, electrical impedance tomography, airway inflammation, and bacterial diversity. The study will be conducted over a period of 52 weeks, with participants receiving NHS or placebo treatment for 52 weeks. The study will also assess the ease of airway clearance, health-related quality of life, patient and main carer treatment satisfaction, family impact, and health economics. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a case-control study that aims to investigate the prevalence of sexual violence in patients with paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia. The study will use a combination of self-report questionnaires, structured interviews, and blood samples to assess the prevalence of sexual violence in these patients. The study will also investigate the relationship between sexual violence and other factors such as personality traits, psychiatric comorbidities, and impulsivity. The study will use a combination of self-report questionnaires, structured interviews, and blood samples to assess these factors. The study will also investigate the relationship between sexual violence and treatment outcomes in patients with paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia. The study will use a combination of self-report questionnaires, structured interviews, and blood samples to assess treatment outcomes.

[/INST] The study is titled "Development of Activity MRI (aMRI): Direct Comparison to PET in Human Subjects" and is a single-arm study that aims to characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in tumor versus normal brain. The study will assess the validity of aMRI as a metabolic imaging approach via direct comparison with a standard metabolic imaging approach, ¹⁸FDG PET. The study will also characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in the various normal appearing brain sub-regions unaffected by tumor, in comparison to ¹⁸FDG PET. The study will also compare how the aMRI metabolic parameter kᵢₒ*V within disease lesions change with different disease types, their disease stage, and their treatment status.

[/INST] The study is a cluster randomized trial designed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The interventions include a multi-pronged clinical decision support (CDS) with a patient portal message, an interruptive advisory upon chart entry as a notification to clinicians on GDMT consideration, and a best practice alert (BPA) that includes a GDMT order set. The study will also evaluate the independent and incremental benefits of education with other interventional approaches. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with HFrEF who have a new GDMT HF medication class added, or an upward dose titration of an existing GDMT HF medication, within 30 days of the index visit. The secondary outcomes are the proportion of patients with HFrEF who have a new prescription for SGLT2i and/or ARNI or a switch from ACEi/ARB to ARNI within 30, 60, and 90 days of the index visit.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) alone and ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy in patients with upper ureteric stones. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients cleared from ureteric stones at 4 weeks. The study includes patients with a single ureteric stone ranging from 6-15 mm in size, a history of less than 6 months, and no previous unsuccessful ESWL. Patients with urinary tract infection, multiple ureteric stones, a ureteric stricture distal to the stone, concomitant use of calcium channel blockers or alpha-adrenergic antagonists, and abnormal coagulation profile are excluded from the study.

[/INST] The study is a phase IV interventional study on the treatment of tracheal stenosis after percutaneous tracheotomy. The study includes patients with tracheal stenosis after percutaneous tracheotomy. The primary outcome measure is the rate of successful decannulation after intervention up to discharge from inpatient treatment. The secondary outcome measures are technical success, reintervention(s), type of intervention, clinical success, and additional treatment. The study is conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based psychiatric intervention for people who inject drugs (PWID) in Vietnam. The intervention will be compared to a control group of PWID who are free of a psychiatric disorder. The primary outcome is the viral exposure score, which is a measure of the risk of HIV and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. The secondary outcomes include the severity of substance use score, quality of life score, and the incidence of psychiatric disorders in the control group. The study will also assess the cost of the specialized community-based psychiatric intervention and the effectiveness of HIV treatment. The study will use a combination of quantitative and qualitative approaches to identify structural or clinical factors that condition access to care and explain the lack of therapeutic effectiveness in the population of the study. The study will be conducted in Hai Phong, Vietnam, and will enroll 200 PWID diagnosed with a psychiatric disorder and 400 PWID free of a psychiatric disorder. The study will have a one-year follow-up period.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of conventional endodontic treatment with that of endodontic treatment combined with photodynamic therapy in patients with apical lesion. The study will have three parallel arms: the first is the placebo group which will receive conventional endodontic treatment (ET) and a simulated treatment with the equipment in which no radiation will be emitted; the second group will receive conventional ET associated with PDT with diode laser at 660 nm, fluence 10 s/canal; and the third group will receive conventional ET associated with PDAT with laser at 660 nm, 20 s/canal. The photosensitizer used in the PDT will be methylene blue. Clinical and radiographic examination of all the patients will be used to obtain baseline values (T0) and values 6 months post-treatment (T1). The presence and size of apical lesion will be assessed at T0 and T1, the percentage reduction of the lesion will be calculated and the PAI index will be used as a scoring system to assess the lesion. The success rate will be assessed for each group 6 months after completion of the treatment. Disinfection of the root canals will be assessed by analysis of colony formation (ufc/ml); biological samples will be taken with paper cones inserted into the root canals to the apical region at two moments: Baseline (before treatment, T0); after instrumentation with PDT (experimental groups) and without PDT (placebo group). Adverse events will be analysed; a serious adverse event for this study is any unfavourable odontological event that the investigators believe to bear a causal relation with the experimental intervention.

[/INST] The study is titled "Psychiatric Orders in Psychoanalytic Treatment of ASD" and is a case study of a patient with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who was treated with a combination of psychodynamic psychotherapy, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and medication. The patient was a 30-year-old male who had been diagnosed with ASD at the age of 18. He had previously been treated with antidepressants and CBT, but had not seen significant improvements in his symptoms. The patient was referred to the study by his psychiatrist, who was also a co-author of the study. The patient was treated with a combination of psychodynamic psychotherapy, CBT, and medication, including sertraline and duloxetine. The patient was followed up for 90 days, during which time he was assessed using various questionnaires and scales to measure his symptoms and progress. The study found that the patient showed significant improvements in his symptoms of anxiety, depression, and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) after the treatment. The study also found that the patient's self-esteem and social behaviors improved significantly after the treatment. The study concluded that the combination of psychodynamic psychotherapy, CBT, and medication was effective in treating the patient's symptoms and improving his quality of life.

[/INST] The DIAMOND study is a pilot, prospective, single-arm, open-label, phase II study designed to primarily assess the ability of blood-based liquid biopsy using NGS to monitor disease progression to Trastuzumab-deruxtecan (T-DXd) in patients with histologically confirmed diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the breast with evidence of either locally advanced disease not amenable to resection or radiation therapy with curative intent or metastatic disease not amenable to curative therapy.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effectiveness of Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) in reducing post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms in earthquake-affected individuals in Türkiye. The study will compare the effectiveness of CPT to the control group receiving enhanced care as usual (E-CAU). The study will use a one-on-one online format of CPT and will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Check List for DSM-5 (PCL-5). The study will also measure the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7), World Health Organization (WHO) Well-Being Scale, Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), and Kessler Psychological Distress Scale (K-10) as secondary outcome measures. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee.

[/INST] The study is titled "Perceived Quality of Family Planning Counseling and Its Determinants Among Reproductive Aged Women in El-dakhla District, New Valley Government, Egypt" and is a cross-sectional study. The study aims to assess the quality of family planning counseling and its determinants among reproductive-aged women in El-dakhla District, New Valley Government, Egypt. The study will use a questionnaire to collect data from 423 women who have received family planning services in the past year. The questionnaire will include questions about the women's socio-demographic characteristics, family planning practice, facility factors, and quality of contraceptive counseling. The study will use the Quality of Contraceptive Counseling (QCC) scale to measure the quality of family planning counseling. The QCC scale is a validated and client-centered based scale that measures the quality of care received by women during family planning visits. The scale includes three interrelated aspects of counseling quality: information exchange, interpersonal relationship, and disrespect and abuse in contraceptive counseling. The study will use a semi-structured interview administered questionnaire which includes: Socio-demographic characteristics of women Family planning practice: This will include number of living children, current use of FP method and its type, and suggested causes of discontinuation of FP, previous contraceptive use, and reason for the visit 3-Facility factors such as gender of providers, qualification of providers, type of the health facility. 4-Quality of contraceptive counseling (QCC) scale: it is a 22-item scale which measures the quality of care received by women during family planning visits. It includes : 1) information exchange, 2) interpersonal relations, and 3) disrespect and abuse in contraceptive counseling. The information exchange subscale consists of ten items, the interpersonal relationship subscale consists of seven items, and the disrespect and abuse subscale consists of five items.

[/INST] The PIVCO study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the efficacy of two ablation strategies for persistent atrial fibrillation (AF). The first strategy is pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) only, and the second strategy is PVI plus additional ablation of the posterior wall of the left atrium, mitral isthmus line, and roof line. The primary endpoint is the recurrence of AF (or atrial tachycardia, AT) lasting >30 seconds as assessed using repeated 7-day ECG Holter monitoring in patients without anti-arrhythmic drugs (AADs) during the entire post-blanking follow-up, i.e., starting three months after the index procedure. The secondary endpoints are the first recurrence of on-AADs AF/AT lasting >6 minutes during the post-blanking follow-up period, number of hospitalizations and emergency out-patient visits related to AF/AT recurrence, worsening of heart failure, or other cardiovascular diseases, number of electrical cardioversions, proportion of patients on AADs at the end of follow-up, PFA-related complications, assessment of the quality of life using standardized instruments (AFEQT, EQ5D), feasibility of achieving a complete block of the mitral isthmus and PWI using PFA, proportion of patients with delayed conduction into LAA after mitral line, number of patients that underwent repeated ablations during follow-up.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a home visiting program in reducing child maltreatment and improving child health and development. The program is based on the Partners for a Healthy Baby curriculum, which is a home visiting program that focuses on improving parenting skills and reducing risk factors for child maltreatment. The program is delivered by paraprofessionals who are trained to provide the curriculum. The study will use a cluster randomized design, with the unit of randomization being the home visiting agency. The study will use a variety of measures to assess the effectiveness of the program, including the Conflict Tactics Scale, the Parenting Sense of Competence Scale, the Abidin Parenting Stress Index, and the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers. The study will also use administrative data from the home visiting agencies to assess program implementation. The study will be conducted in New Mexico, United States.

[/INST] The study is a phase I clinical trial to assess the safety and immunogenicity of the malaria vaccine candidate RH5.1 soluble protein in Matrix-MTM using two dosing regimens. The study will enroll healthy adult volunteers aged 18 to 50 years who will receive three or two doses of RH5.1 soluble protein with Matrix-M at different doses. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of solicited local/systemic reactogenicity signs and symptoms for 7 days following each vaccination. The secondary outcome measures are the occurrence of unsolicited adverse events for 28 days following the vaccination, change from baseline for safety laboratory measures for 28 days following vaccination, and serum ELISA response, quantitative antigen-specific IgG antibody levels (µg/mL readout) over time.

[/INST] The study is a monocentric, 18-months, randomized, rater-blinded study to evaluate the influence of a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment plan with integrated mobile palliative care and telemedicine on the baseline to 18-months change in the QoL of individuals with MSA compared to a sex-, age- and disease-duration matched historical European MSA cohort, whose data is stored at the Medical University of Innsbruck. The study includes 46 individuals with MSA fulfilling all the inclusion and none of the exclusion criteria. Upon collection of written informed consent, the recruited individuals will be instructed to complete a falls protocol referred to the month preceding the baseline visit, as well as a blood pressure (BP), bladder diary for up to 72 hours prior to the baseline visit. They will subsequently undergo a baseline examination including a comprehensive clinical, psychological and neuro-rehabilitation assessment, as well as an online semi-structured interview aimed at pinpointing the individual therapeutic needs and healthcare preferences. In case additional examinations are needed, these will be carried out on the same day of the baseline visit or, if not possible for individual or appointment reasons, at the earliest possible time point within the given timeframe as outlined in the visit schedule. Upon completion of the baseline visit and examinations, the individualized therapeutic plan, including mobile palliative care offer (for wheelchair-bound individuals) and guidance for self-practiced physio-, speech and occupational exercises will be prepared based on a standardized operational protocol drafted by the study team on the basis of published consensus recommendations, scientific evidence and principles of good clinical practice and adapted to the individual healthcare preferences and therapeutic needs. Six, 12 and 18 months after the baseline visit, in-person visits will be scheduled, including a comprehensive clinical, psychological and neuro-rehabilitation re-assessment of the individual therapeutic needs. Therapeutic adaptations will be made following the standardized operational protocol and adapted to the individual healthcare preferences. At month 1, 7 and 13, follow-up phone calls will be scheduled to verify the compliance with the individualized treatment plan and identify barriers to its application. At month 1, 7, 13 and 18, the study participants will be invited to complete online

[/INST] The study is a genetic study that aims to identify genetic variants associated with response to growth hormone treatment in children with idiopathic short stature. The study will compare the genetic variants of children who are good responders to growth hormone treatment with those of children who are poor responders. The study will also identify the genes and pathways that are enriched with genetic variants associated with response to growth hormone treatment.

[/INST] The study "Impact of Neurochecks on Sleep in Critically Ill Adults" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of neurochecks on sleep in critically ill adults. The study will compare the effects of hourly neurochecks to every-other-hour neurochecks on sleep efficiency, wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, arousals, and sleep quality. The study will enroll adult patients who are status post uncomplicated elective coiling of unruptured cerebral aneurysm and are able to communicate in English. The study will use neurochecks, which are brief neurological examinations, to assess the level of consciousness and alertness of the patients. The study will use the Richards Campbell Sleep Questionnaire to assess subjective sleep quality and the American Academy of Sleep Medicine criteria to assess arousals. The study will use the sleep diary to assess sleep efficiency, wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, and arousals. The study will use the neurocheck frequency as the intervention and the primary outcome measure will be sleep efficiency. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will enroll 40 patients. The study will be randomized and blinded. The study will be completed within 24 hours of enrollment. The study will be conducted in Canada and will be published in a peer-reviewed journal. The study will contribute to the understanding of the impact of neurochecks on sleep in critically ill adults.

[/INST] The study is titled "Ascertaining the Radiologic Prognostic Importance of Extranodal Extension on Imaging (iENE) in Head and Neck Cancer" and is part of the Evaluation Prognostic and Predictive Indicators in Head and Neck Cancer (EPIC) program, run under the auspices of the Head and Neck Inter Group (HNCIG). The study aims to evaluate the prognostic significance of extranodal extension (ENE) on imaging (iENE) in head and neck cancer. The study will assess the accuracy of radiologists in identifying iENE, the prognostic significance of iENE, and the utility of various existing standardized diagnostic classification systems in diagnosing iENE. The study will also measure interobserver variability amongst radiologists in grading radiographic ENE and the impact of standardized criteria on this variability. The study will use endpoints such as overall survival rates, recurrence rates, diagnostic accuracy of various radiographic features of iENE with pENE, diagnostic accuracy of published standardized classification systems with pENE, and interobserver variability measured by Cohen's kappa. The study will be conducted over a period of 31 months, from January 1, 2021, to December 31, 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness and safety of bedside bone biopsy versus conventional bone biopsy in patients with diabetes and DFU with a suspicion of DFO. The primary outcome is the remission of DFO at 12 months, which is defined by a composite criterion of an epithelialized ulcer for 28 consecutive days and absence of local inflammation and/or stabilization or improvement of radiologic abnormalities and no need for surgery of the foot to treat DFO during follow-up. The secondary outcomes include clinical efficacy, microbiological results, and adverse events. The study will also assess the costs and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) associated with the two procedures.

[/INST] The study is titled "African Americans (AA) Communities Speak" and is a proof-of-concept prototype of a community-developed training program for clinicians caring for older AA patients with serious illnesses. The program is designed to address three key elements in enhancing the provision of equitable care: 1) culturally concordant care, 2) systemic racism, and 3) implicit bias management. The program is developed using community-based participatory research (CBPR) in two geographically diverse regions: Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York. The study aims to adapt the program to urban-dwelling Southern and Northern older AA adults using an established platform of CBPR in two geographically diverse regions: Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York. The study will conduct a cluster randomized trial in which they will randomize training times to 1 of 4 start dates using a stepped wedge design to accommodate the training of all clinicians and to mitigate the effect of secular trends. The primary outcome will be patient/family's perception of therapeutic alliance using The Human Connection Scale. Secondary outcomes will be family-reported goal-concordant care, and clinicians' knowledge of cultural values, awareness of implicit bias, and confidence to change practice.

[/INST] The study is a research project that aims to assess the genetic and molecular profiles of head and neck cancers. The study will include two groups of patients: one with oropharyngeal or oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma with a positive HPV diagnosis and the other with a negative HPV diagnosis. The study will analyze 87 hotspot genes, full-length analysis of 48 genes, copy number analysis of 43 genes, and gene fusion (inter and intra genic) of 51 genes. The study will be conducted on biopsy samples to define the molecular profile of head and neck tumors. The study will be conducted in one day.

[/INST] The study is a validation of visual analog scales to measure satisfaction and well-being at work. The study aims to validate the scales by assessing their reliability and validity. The study will include 100 participants who will complete the scales at two time points, once at inclusion and once one week later. The scales will be assessed for their internal consistency, construct validity, and convergent validity. The study will also assess the test-retest reliability of the scales by comparing the scores at the two time points.

[/INST] The study is titled "Soft Tissue Contour and Radiographic Evaluation of Ridge Preservation Using Different Techniques". The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of different techniques for alveolar ridge preservation. The study will include 40 patients who will undergo tooth extraction and will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: no treatment, bone particle graft covered with a subepithelial connective tissue graft, bone particle graft covered with a vascularized interpositional periosteal connective tissue graft, bone particle graft covered with a collagen membrane, and bone particle graft covered with a Cytoplast. The primary outcome measures are soft tissue alternation and hard tissue alternation, which will be assessed using cone-beam computed tomography data and STereoLithography files. The secondary outcome measures are keratinized tissue width changes and patient satisfaction, which will be assessed using a periodontal probe and a questionnaire, respectively. The study will last for 12 months.

[/INST] The study is titled "Study of Pro-inflammatory Cytokines in Case of Essure® Contraceptive Implants" and is conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study is designed to compare the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients with Essure® contraceptive implants and in control patients with endometriosis or adenomyosis. The study will measure the level of cytokine IL10 in peritoneal fluid through study completion, an average of 4 months. The study will include three groups of participants: Essure group, control with no endometriosis/adenomyosis, and control with endometriosis/adenomyosis. The Essure group will consist of patients who underwent removal of the Essure® contraceptive implant, while the control with no endometriosis/adenomyosis group will consist of patients who underwent benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery and with no diagnosis of endometriosis or adenomyosis. The control with endometriosis/adenomyosis group will consist of patients who underwent benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery and with diagnosis of endometriosis or adenomyosis. The study will compare the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients with Essure® contraceptive implants and in control patients with endometriosis or adenomyosis.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective and prospective cohort study of patients with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) and autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) infected with COVID-19. The study aims to compare the difference in the incidence of COVID-19 infection, disease severity, clinical biochemical indicators, hospital stay, and prognosis between UDCA treated and non-UDCA treated patients. The study will also investigate the impact of UDCA on the occurrence, incidence, and prognosis of COVID-19 infection.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of prone position training on postoperative pulmonary complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older with a clinical diagnosis of colorectal cancer. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the prone position training group or the control group. The prone position training group will receive prone position training daily in the hospital, three times a day, and about 1 hour each time, for at least 3 days before surgery. The control group will receive standard perioperative care without any prone position training. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs), which includes pneumonia, atelectasis, pleural effusion, respiratory failure, and unplanned intubations. The secondary outcome measures include arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2), extubation time, peak airway pressure, arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), oxygenation index (OI), and time to ambulation. The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT statement and the Standard Protocol Items: Recommendations for Interventional Trials (SPIRIT) guidelines.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/II, open-label, single-arm clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 oral liquid combined with pemetrexed + cisplatin therapy in patients with advanced inoperable or metastatic EGFR wild-type non-small cell lung cancer. The study will determine the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) and recommended dose level (RDL) in the first cycle of combination use with pemetrexed + cisplatin therapy. The study will also determine the overall response rate (ORR) after at least 1 cycle of combination use in BLEX 404 + pemetrexed + cisplatin therapy.

[/INST] The AGE SELF CARE study is a pilot study that aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a virtual group visit program for pre-frail older adults. The program, called AGE SELF CARE, is designed to promote healthy aging through group visits that focus on chronic disease management, healthy lifestyle education, home adaptation, and anticipatory guidance. The program consists of eight weekly 90-minute virtual group visits led by an aging expert. The study will evaluate the recruitment rate, completion of testing, attendance, completion of home practice log, participant satisfaction, and proportion lost to follow-up. The study will also assess frailty index, loneliness, self-reported health, physical activity, self-efficacy, depression, anxiety, sleep, and physical performance. The study will be conducted at the BWH Osher Clinical Center for Integrative Medicine, a collaboration between BWH and Harvard Medical School. Participants will be community-dwelling adults aged 65 years and older who are pre-frail during the initial study visit.
