[/INST] The PREPARE-iVAC Trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccines in kidney transplant recipients. The study will compare the immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccines in patients who continue to receive MMF/MPA and those who replace MMF/MPA with everolimus. The study will also evaluate the safety of everolimus compared to MMF/MPA in kidney transplant recipients. The study will be conducted in seven participating study sites in the Netherlands. The study will include 120 kidney transplant recipients who will receive the bivalent original/Omicron BA.4-5 COVID-19 mRNA vaccine (Comirnaty, I.M.) and will be followed for 84 days after vaccination. The study will also include an optional herpes zoster vaccination arm. The primary outcome of the study will be the virus-neutralizing capacity of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies. The secondary outcomes of the study will include the SARS-CoV-2 antibody concentration, SARS-CoV-2 specific T-cell response, varicella zoster specific antibodies, varicella zoster specific T-cell response, and solicited local and systemic adverse events. The study will also evaluate the safety of kidney transplant recipients, including changes in estimated glomerular filtration rate and proteinuria during the study. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study has been approved by the local ethics committees of the participating study sites.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes in patients with burns. The study will include 60 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the study group or the control group. The study group will receive resistance exercises in addition to their physical therapy program and medical treatment, while the control group will receive their physical therapy program and medical treatment. The study will use a resistance exercise program that will consist of seven exercises: triceps press, biceps curl, lat pull down, calf raise, leg press, leg extension, and sit-ups. The program will be done three times a week for eight weeks. The study will measure the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes in patients with burns by comparing the plasma liver enzymes level (AST and ALT enzymes) between the study group and the control group before and after the intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of two months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of upper trapezius stretching on neck pain, range of motion, and disability in patients with cervical spondylosis. The study will compare the effects of upper trapezius stretching with standard care. The study will include 60 participants aged 40-65 years with a diagnosis of cervical spondylosis confirmed by an orthopedic specialist. The primary outcome measures are changes in neck pain intensity and neck range of motion. The secondary outcome measure is changes in neck disability index. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, with a 4-week intervention period and a 3-month follow-up period. The study will use a parallel assignment model, with participants randomized to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive upper trapezius stretching, while the control group will receive standard care. The study will use a single-blinded design, with the participants blinded to the intervention they receive. The study will be conducted in China.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Tecarterapy on the performance of amateur athletes. The study will include 30 participants between the ages of 18 and 30 who are active in sports such as athletics and field sports that involve sprinting, such as soccer, basketball, and rugby. The study will compare the effects of a single 25-minute Tecarterapy procedure with a sham procedure on the performance of the participants in terms of sprinting, jumping, and isometric leg extension. The primary outcome measure will be the change in 30-meter sprint time, and the secondary outcome measures will be the change in electromyographic activity during sprinting, jumping, and isometric leg extension. The study will use the mDurance® system device to measure electromyographic activity. The study will be conducted at the University of Granada and will last approximately 6 months. The results of the study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of Tecarterapy on the performance of amateur athletes and may contribute to the development of new training and rehabilitation methods in sports medicine.

[/INST] The study is titled "Cell Free DNA Quantification in Patients With Endometriosis Followed With Medical Assistance to Procreation" and is conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study is a non-randomized controlled trial with two parallel arms. The primary purpose of the study is basic science. The study is designed to measure the cell free DNA rate in serum in patients before they start IVF stimulation, cell free DNA rate in follicular fluid the day of punction, number of oocytes reaching the metaphase II, fragmentation rate, number of cells at day 2, number of cells at day 3, blastulation rate at day 5 of developement, number of clinical pregnancy in both groups, and number of live birth in both groups. The study is expected to be completed by 2023.

[/INST] The study is a prospective comparative study that aims to compare the treatment outcomes of fully edentulous patients with maxillary implant overdentures retained by either bars or Locators. The primary outcome is the change in marginal peri-implant bone level 10 years after placing the overdenture. The secondary outcomes are implant and overdenture survival, peri-implant mucosa health, and patient satisfaction. The study will include patients who were referred to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 10 years ago because they experienced problems with their conventional denture. The patients will be treated with four dental implants in the edentulous maxilla and an overdenture retained by either bars or Locators. The study will evaluate the change in marginal peri-implant bone level, implant and overdenture survival, peri-implant mucosa health, and patient satisfaction at the 10-year evaluation period.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a designed exercise program on pain and quality of sleep in patients with sickle cell disease anemia. The program includes diaphragmatic breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and a combination of stretching, stabilization, and strengthening exercises of the pelvic-lumbar region. The study will recruit 50 adult patients with sickle cell disease anemia who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or control group. The experimental group will receive the designed exercise program, while the control group will not receive any exercise program. The primary outcome measure is the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, and the secondary outcome measures are the Visual Analog Scale for pain, the WHOQOL-BREF, the Fatigue Scale, and the Perceived Stress Scale. The study will use the T-test and repeated measures analysis of variance to compare the mean values within and between the two groups. The study will be conducted in Saudi Arabia and is expected to last for 6 weeks. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is a two-armed pragmatic trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of a referral for cognitive stimulation therapy (CST) to standard of care in improving cognition in patients with mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia. The study will recruit participants aged 18 years or older who have a diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia and a Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score between 10 and 26. Participants will be randomized to either the intervention group, which will receive a referral for CST, or the control group, which will receive standard of care. The primary outcome measure will be cognitive decline measured by an increase in the MoCA score from baseline to follow-up. The secondary outcome measures will be cognitive improvement measured by a decrease in the MoCA score from baseline to follow-up, referral acceptance rate, participant attendance, and participant attrition. The study will use a parallel assignment design and will be open-label. The study will be conducted in the United States and will involve 12 sites. The study will have a duration of 12 months and will involve 240 participants. The study will be funded by the National Institute on Aging.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational cohort study with one measurement time on admission. The aim of the study was to assess anxiety and depression levels of patients with physiological as well as with pathological DeMeester scores. Furthermore, the modulation of anxiety on the severity of reflux symptoms such as fullness, heartburn and dysphagia is examined.

[/INST] The study is a single-arm clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a self-guided personalized treatment for women with disordered eating. The treatment involves two weeks of smartphone self-monitoring and two self-guided modules of personalized treatment delivered directly to the participant's smartphone. The primary outcome measures are changes in disordered eating symptoms, anxiety, depression, clinical impairment, and quality of life. The study is currently recruiting participants aged 18-65 years who endorse significant disordered eating and own a smartphone or tablet. The study is not masked and is conducted in Canada.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of the CAD-EYE system in detecting neoplastic lesions in patients with Lynch syndrome to the current standard of care, indigo carmine chromoendoscopy. The primary outcome measure is the adenoma detection rate (ADR), which is the number of adenomas detected per patient. The secondary outcome measures include the detection rates of specific lesions, diagnostic performance of CAD-EYE, rate of resect and discard strategy, and time of colonoscopies. The study will also evaluate the feasibility of a resect and discard strategy in Lynch syndrome. The study will compare the ADR between the CAD-EYE group and the indigo carmine chromoendoscopy (CE) group. The study will also compare different procedure times between the two groups. The study will be conducted over an average of 2 years.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study conducted at nine children's hospitals in the Western Pediatric Surgery Research Consortium. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of a contrast-based protocol in assisting in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO). The study included 314 patients aged 1-20 years who were diagnosed with ASBO and underwent a trial of nonoperative management (NOM) on hospital admission. The contrast-based protocol involved administering enteral contrast to patients and monitoring them for progression of contrast to the colon on X-rays at 8-12 hours and 24 hours after contrast administration. The study found that the contrast-based protocol was not effective in assisting in the management of pediatric ASBO. The study also found that the use of contrast did not increase the risk of adverse events.

[/INST] The study is a phase 1, single-center, open-label, randomized, parallel group, single-dose study to compare the pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous itepekimab administered with an autoinjector versus a prefilled syringe in healthy participants. The study aims to assess the pharmacokinetic parameters of itepekimab, including Cmax, AUClast, AUC, tmax, t1/2, CL/F, and Vss/F. The study also aims to assess the incidence of treatment-emergent anti-itepekimab antibodies responses and the number of participants with adverse events (including injection site reactions), serious adverse events (SAE), and adverse events of special interest (AESI). The study will enroll healthy participants aged 18 to 65 years and will randomize them to receive a single subcutaneous dose of itepekimab administered with an autoinjector or a prefilled syringe. The study will assess the pharmacokinetic parameters of itepekimab at baseline up to EOS (approximately Day 141). The study will also assess the incidence of treatment-emergent anti-itepekimab antibodies responses and the number of participants with adverse events (including injection site reactions), serious adverse events (SAE), and adverse events of special interest (AESI) at baseline up to EOS (approximately Day 141).

[/INST] The study is a multi-site, open-label, randomized, three-arm, 8-week, prospective observational study to evaluate the use of P12 electronic nicotine delivery system (ENDS) among U.S. adult smokers. The study will be conducted at multiple sites geographically dispersed within the U.S. and will include pre-screening, a screening and enrollment visit (SEV), a baseline assessment period (BAP), an actual use period (AUP), and a close out period (COP). The study will include 12 cartridge variants (six flavor variants in two nicotine concentrations, 1.5% and 5%) and subjects will be provided with the Study IP for ad libitum use over a 6-week actual use period in their real-life/naturalistic environments. Subject-reported consumption of the Study IP, Combustible cigarettes, and other TNP will be assessed (including, but not limited to, ENDS, smokeless tobacco, and other combustible tobacco products). The study will include four study visits: screening and enrollment visit (SEV), baseline assessment period (BAP), an actual use period (AUP), and a close out period (COP).

[/INST] The study is a phase IV, open-label, randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab monotherapy with subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppressive therapy in the treatment of moderate to severe Crohn's disease. The study will enroll 158 patients who will be randomized to either the monotherapy or combination therapy group. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients in corticosteroid-free clinical remission and endoscopic response at week 26. The secondary outcome measures include the proportion of patients in clinical remission and response, the proportion of patients achieving clinical response, the proportion of patients in symptomatic remission, the proportion of patients achieving minimally clinically important difference in quality of life, the proportion of patients in biochemical remission, the proportion of patients achieving histological healing, the proportion of patients with perianal disease in clinical remission and response of their perianal disease, the proportion of patients with extraintestinal manifestations at week 26 as compared to baseline, and the proportion of patients developing anti-drug antibodies against infliximab at week 26. The study will be conducted in 12 centers in France and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a pharmacokinetic study of rivaroxaban and apixaban in cancer patients. The study aims to describe the pharmacokinetic profile of rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation from a real-world setting. The study will identify factors (age, weight, renal function, co-morbidities, etc) influencing the pharmacokinetic profile of rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation from a real-world setting.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, crossover trial that aims to evaluate the bronchodilator response in patients with bronchiectasis. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Val-de-Sud in Switzerland. The study will include 30 patients with bronchiectasis who will undergo spirometry testing before and after receiving salbutamol or placebo. The primary outcome of the study will be the change in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) after salbutamol compared to placebo. The study will also assess the effect of age, sex, bronchiectatic disease, use of inhaled steroids, history of allergy, baseline FEV1, history of pseudomonas, and bronchiectasis severity on the bronchodilator response.

[/INST] The study is titled "Sex, Hormones and Identity Affect Nociceptive Expression" and aims to investigate the relationship between gender identity, hormones, and pain sensitivity. The study will recruit 120 participants, including cisgender men, cisgender women, transgender men, transgender women, and transgender men plus testosterone and transgender women plus estrogen. The study will involve quantitative sensory testing, blood draws, and questionnaires related to pain, quality of life, social support, and discrimination. The primary outcome measures are experimental heat and pressure pain thresholds, temporal summation, and conditioned pain modulation. The secondary outcome measures are sleep quality, depression, social support, discrimination, hormone levels, immune cell number and cytokine production, community connectedness, bodily pain, quality of life metrics, body image, gender role expectation of pain, and adverse childhood events. The study will be conducted at the University of California, San Francisco.

[/INST] The study is a feasibility study to evaluate the feasibility of a technology-enriched stroke rehabilitation model in an acute stroke unit. The study will assess the acceptability of the intervention, recruitment and attrition rates, adherence to sessions, and the duration of time spent on activities within the 'technology enriched rehabilitation space'. The study will use wearable activity monitors to measure movement repetitions. Audio-recorded semi-structured interviews will be completed with participants, family/carers, and NHS staff to collect qualitative data on the acceptability of the intervention.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, controlled, crossover clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) on respiratory discomfort in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) treated with non-invasive ventilation (NIV). The study will be conducted in a day hospital setting and will involve 20 patients with ALS who will be randomized to receive either IVR or music therapy. The primary outcome measure will be the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort (scale A1 of the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile (MDP) questionnaire) of patients with ALS at the stage of respiratory failure treated with NIV. The secondary outcome measures will be the effect of IVR on the sensory and emotional components of dyspnea (scales QS and A2 of the MDP questionnaire) of patients with ALS at the stage of respiratory failure treated with NIV, the effect of music therapy on the sensory, affective, and emotional components of dyspnea (scales QS, A1, and A2 of the MDP questionnaire) of patients with ALS at the stage of respiratory failure treated with NIV, the evolutionary profile of the sensory and affective components of dyspnea under the effect of IVR and music therapy, and the effect of IVR and music therapy on respiratory discomfort in terms of preference through a post-exposure questionnaire after the two interventions. The study will also evaluate the acceptability of IVR by a subjective questionnaire of six questions using a 7-point Likert scale. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of sodium valproate on clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke. The study will include patients aged 18-75 years who have been diagnosed with acute ischemic stroke and have a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 4 or higher. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: low-dose sodium valproate group, high-dose sodium valproate group, or placebo group. All patients will receive conventional treatment for stroke, and those in the sodium valproate groups will receive intravenous infusions of sodium valproate at a dose of 10 mg/kg or 20 mg/kg within 3 days of admission. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with a favorable outcome, defined as a modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score of 0-2 at 90 days. The secondary outcome measures include the detailed distribution of mRS scores at 90 days, the proportion of patients with a favorable outcome at 30 days (defined as an mRS score of 0-2), the detailed distribution of mRS scores at 30 days, the NIHSS score at 3 and 7 days, changes in lesion volume from baseline to day 7, and length of hospital stay. The study will provide important information on the efficacy and safety of sodium valproate in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke.

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of a virtual coach to standard weight loss tools in promoting weight loss in patients with obesity and ventral hernia. The study will enroll patients between the ages of 18 and 90 with a BMI of 30 or higher and a diagnosis of obesity. The study will use a MyChart-enabled virtual coach to aid preoperative weight loss. The primary outcome measure is the average net amount of weight loss per group, and the secondary outcome measures are the number of interactions with the virtual coach, quality of life, and satisfaction with the virtual coach. The study will last for 6 months.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of nebulized umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes in the treatment of moderate, severe, and critically ill COVID-19 patients. The study will enroll 100 patients who meet the inclusion criteria and are randomly assigned to the experimental or control group. The experimental group will receive nebulized umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes twice a day for five days, while the control group will receive nebulized saline solution twice a day for five days. The primary outcome measure is symptom remission time after atomization medication, and the secondary outcome measures include improvement of serum inflammatory markers, length of hospital stay, recovery time (nucleic acid turned negative), and CT review and comparison. The study will provide new insights into the treatment of COVID-19 and contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this disease.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the clinical effectiveness of calcium silicate-based sealer and epoxy resin-based sealer in single-visit root canal treatment. The study included patients with irreversible pulpitis who had teeth diagnosed with irreversible pulpitis by electrical and thermal tests. The teeth must have healthy periodontal tissue and sufficient clinical teeth crown for isolation with a rubber dam. The study excluded patients who were pregnant, had a systemic disease requiring antibiotics or had an allergic reaction, had maxillofacial pathology, cellulitis, occlusal trauma, and temporomandibular disorders, had endodontic periodontal lesions, periodontal abscesses, had roots internally or externally resorbed, cracked or broken, had had failed endodontic treatment, or the root canal could not be controlled for leakage, and had no opposing teeth.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the immunogenicity of two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui ® and Cecolin ®) versus imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years old. This study is a multi-center, open, prospective cohort study with a total of 3,000 subjects recruited. According to the HPV vaccine that the participants received in the previous period, they were divided into 1,000 people in the domestic bivalent HPV vaccine group (Wozehui), 1,000 people in the domestic bivalent HPV vaccine group (Cecolin), and 1,000 people in the imported HPV vaccine group. Three immuneogenic blood was collected in all subjects 30-60 days, 12 months (window period ± 1 month) and 36 months (window period ± 1 month) after the last dose of either the domestic bivalent HPV vaccine or the imported HPV vaccine, which was used to perform HPV type 16 and 18 neutralizing antibody testing. The aim of this study was to evaluate the immunogenicity difference between two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines and imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years.

[/INST] The study is titled "Feasibility of Integrating Homeopathic Approach in a Comprehensive Cancer Center" and is a prospective observational study. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of integrating homeopathy as a supportive approach for cancer patients in a comprehensive cancer center. The study will evaluate three main ingredients: obtaining the main concerns of patients who agree to utilize this method, patient acceptance of this supportive approach reflected in obtaining and self-administering the remedies as prescribed, and obtaining retrospective subjective information from patients through validated quality of life questionnaires. The study will be conducted at the Division of Oncology in Rambam Health Campus, and the participants will be cancer patients who are treated at the division and who are 18 years of age or older. The study will evaluate the feasibility of a supportive approach, including evaluating reasons for patients to use the approach. The primary outcome measure will be the feasibility of a supportive approach, and the secondary outcome measure will be quality of life-level of distress. The study will be conducted over a period of 6-12 weeks.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, non-randomized, open-label study to evaluate the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheter and midline. The study will include adult patients hospitalized at the CHM or CHUA, with a central venous device (implantable chamber, central venous jugular, femoral, subclavian, PICCline, dialysis catheter) or a Midline and having catheter-related bacteremia. The primary outcome measure is the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheter and midline. The study will evaluate the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheter and midline.

[/INST] The trial is a phase 3, open-label, randomized study to compare the efficacy and safety of odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide versus rituximab in combination with lenalidomide therapy in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) as assessed by independent central review (ICR) in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and participants with indolent lymphoma. The secondary outcome measures include odronextamab concentrations in serum, incidence of anti-odronextamab antibodies (ADA) to odronextamab over time, incidence of neutralizing antibodies (NAbs) to odronextamab over time, best overall response (BOR) as assessed by investigator review, duration of response (DOR) as assessed by investigator review, PFS as assessed by investigator review, complete response (CR) as assessed by independent central review (ICR), BOR as assessed by ICR, overall survival (OS), event free survival (EFS) as assessed by ICR, DOR as assessed by ICR, time to next anti-lymphoma treatment (TTNT), incidence of treatment emergent adverse events (TEAEs) for odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide versus R2, severity of TEAEs for odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide versus R2, overall change from baseline in patient reported outcomes (PROs) as measured by scores of European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality-of-Life Questionnaire (EORTC QLQC30), overall change from baseline in PROs as measured by scores of Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Lymphoma Subscale (FACT-LymS), overall change from baseline in PROs as measured by scores of Patient Global Impression on Severity (PGIS), overall change from baseline in PROs as measured by scores of Patient Global Impression on Change (PGIC), overall change from baseline in PROs as measured by scores of EuroQoL 5 Dimensions 5 Levels (EQ

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Proliverenol supplementation in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study will have 4 groups of treatment, each group consisting of 20 subjects with the treatment regimen for 12 weeks. The eligible subjects will be randomly allocated to receive study medication (treatment 1 or treatment 2) for 12 weeks of treatment, in a double blind fashion. The subjects will be evaluated for treatment efficacy at baseline and at intervals of 4 weeks over the 12-week course of therapy. The safety profile of study medication other than vital signs and adverse event will be measured at baseline and end of study. The primary outcome measure is the changes of serum ALT and AST from baseline to week 4, 8, and 12 of study treatment. The secondary outcome measures are USG examination for Controlled Attenuated Parameter (CAP) and Transient elastography (TE) measurement at baseline and week 12 of study treatment, and Aspartate transaminase (AST) to alanine transaminase (ALT) ratio at week 4, 8, and 12 of study treatment.

[/INST] The study is titled "Impact of Ozone Application in Periodontal Treatment" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study is designed to compare the effectiveness of non-surgical periodontal treatment with or without ozone therapy in patients with periodontitis. The study will measure probing pocket depth, plaque index, gingival index, and bleeding on probing at baseline and 3 months after treatment. The study will also measure the proportion of bacterial species and inflammatory parameter levels in gingival crevicular fluid at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months after treatment. The study will be conducted in Norway and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a case-control study that aims to compare the expression of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in pterygium tissue with normal conjunctiva tissue. The study will use immunohistochemistry to evaluate the expression of these proteins in tissue samples from 30 patients with pterygium and 30 patients with normal conjunctiva. The study will use primary antibodies against CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin to evaluate the expression of these proteins in the tissue samples. The study will use IBM SPSS version 26.0 for statistical analysis.

[/INST] The TINO study is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in older adults. The study will recruit three groups of participants: young adults, healthy older adults, and frail older adults with recurrent respiratory tract infections. The study will collect nasal and blood samples from the participants at baseline and after 3 months to analyze the frequency, phenotype, function, transcriptomic cluster composition, clonality, and stability of T cells. The study will also analyze the concentration of nasal and systemic cytokines, other immune populations, respiratory tract microbiota profiles, and the presence of asymptomatic viral infections. The study will investigate the effect of sex on aging-related changes in nasal and blood immune populations and the frequency of antigen-specific T cells in the nose and blood after infection. The study will provide insights into the mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in older adults and their role in respiratory infections.

[/INST] The study titled "Platelets to Lymphocytes Ratio and Monocytes to Lymphocytes Ratio as Predictors of Response to Treatment in Cirrhotic Patients With Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis" is a diagnostic study that aims to evaluate the platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio as predictors of response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. The study will include 100 participants, including cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and normal individuals. The primary outcome measure is the platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio as predictors of response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. The study will be conducted from April 19, 2023, to April 30, 2024.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study that aims to evaluate whether point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) performed by emergency medicine physicians (EM physicians) increases diagnostic accuracy in patients with dyspnea compared to routine assessment. The study will include adult patients presenting to the emergency department (ED) within the highest or second highest triage category and any of the following: shortness of breath, oxygen saturation less than 90% on room air, respiratory rate more than 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation less than 95% on room air. The study will exclude patients in whom inclusion in the study will delay urgent interventions and patients who are discharged from the ED without hospital admission.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of respiratory training and relaxation techniques in reducing heart dose during adjuvant radiotherapy for left-sided breast cancer. The study will compare the use of these techniques to standard care. The primary outcome measure is the maximum dose to the heart (Dmax) during deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) radiotherapy. The secondary outcome measures include quality of life, heart dose, and left anterior descending artery dose. The study will also evaluate the impact of the intervention on clinic workflow metrics and patient satisfaction with the R&R intervention. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valais in Switzerland.

[/INST] The study is a phase IB trial that aims to determine the safety and tolerability of a quadruplet regimen of canakinumab, tislelizumab, nab-paclitaxel, and gemcitabine in combination for the treatment of pancreatic cancer. The study will enroll patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, a type of pancreatic cancer, and the treatment will be administered in cycles of 28 days. The study will evaluate the number of dose-limiting toxicities, the number of patients who proceed to surgical resection, the overall response rate, the R0 resection rate, the progression-free survival, and the overall survival. The study will also evaluate the number of delays or changes in outcome of surgery that is attributed to study drug.

[/INST] The study is a stepped wedge design that aims to develop and test a digital supported peer navigation intervention to improve mental health services access for youth. The intervention is a mobile app that provides mental health resources, referrals to local resources, and navigation support. The study will test the effectiveness of the app in increasing mental health service utilization among youth. The study will also examine the feasibility and acceptability of the app among youth and their caregivers.

[/INST] The study is a double-blinded, randomized, comparative-placebo trial to compare and evaluate the effectiveness of intra-myometrial oxytocin injection and intra-myometrial tranexamic acid injection in reducing the risk of postpartum bleeding after cesarean section in primigravida at term. The study will be conducted in the Kasr Al-Ainy Hospital, Maternity Hospital, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt, during October 2021 to October 2022. After the Ethical Research Committee approval on study protocol, fifty primigravida women at term pregnancy, undergoing elective cesarean delivery will be divided and allocated randomly into two groups after fulfillment eligibility criteria. Fifty women will be included in this clinical study at admission to the labor ward. Written informed permission will be acquired following advising about this study and potential implications. A history in details and clinical examination will be done to rule out general health problems. Vaginal and Abdominal examinations will be done. Routine preoperative investigations and obstetric ultrasound examinations will be done for all women to ensure that all inclusion criteria were present. The computer will be used for randomization to allocate the patients into two equal groups. Randomization cards will be produced, sealed and stored; sequentially black wrappers will be numbered. The hospital pharmacy is producing packages, and physicians and nurses were unaware of their contents. For the entire length of the trial, all study personnel and participants are blinded to therapy. A senior registrar will execute a cesarean section before the commencement of research, which performs at least 300 cesarean sections. All cesarean section will be operated via spinal anesthesia; the abdomen will be entered through the Pfannenstiel incision. The sealed envelope is carried to the operating room and transferred without informing the researcher or the patients about their contents. The anesthesiologist is administering the medication (Oxytocin or tranexamic acid). After fetal birth and before placental delivery, patients assigned to the oxytocin group (n = 25): 5 I.U of oxytocin (syntocinone 5 I.U/1ML NONARTIS-EGYPT) shall be watered

[/INST] The Innovation for Small-scale Experiments: ReceptIVFity Test is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a vaginal microbiome test called ReceptIVFity Test in improving the chances of pregnancy in women undergoing IVF or IVF/ICSI treatment. The test is designed to determine the vaginal microbiome profile of women of European origin and provide them with a predicted chance of achieving a pregnancy in the current cycle. The test also provides women with a physician decision group, which postpones treatment until a switch to a favorable ReceptIVFity microbiome profile. The primary outcome measure of the study is the rate of successful pregnancy, which is defined as a pregnancy with a positive heartbeat at 12 weeks of gestation. The secondary outcome measures include the number of successful IVF or IVF/ICSI cycles per patient, scores of the SDM-Q-9 questionnaire for patient satisfaction, and the total costs of all received treatments within the study period. The study is designed to last for three years and will include women of European origin who are naïve to IVF or IVF/ICSI procedures and are willing to provide a vaginal swab with the ReceptIVFity test. The study will also include women of non-European origin who will be included in the observational part of the study.

[/INST] Determining the Lipid Lowering Effect of Fenugreek Seed Tea is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed consumed as a tea in patients with hyperlipidemia without diabetes over an 8-week intervention period. The study will recruit 114 participants who will be randomized into two groups: fenugreek seed tea or control black tea. The primary outcome is the mean change in serum triglycerides, and the secondary outcomes are the mean changes in total-cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, non-HDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, plasma apolipoprotein B, and microRNAs. The study will be conducted at the Centre for Public Health, Queen Mary University of London, and the results will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, open-label clinical trial that aims to investigate the role of pioglitazone hydrochloride in vascular transcriptional remodeling in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery. The study will assess the change in S1P content in HDL, SPHK1 expression in the internal thoracic artery, and S1PR1 expression in the saphenous vein before and after treatment with pioglitazone hydrochloride.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, open-label, crossover, single-dose, single-center, pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic study of three new coated beads formulations of glucose and caffeine and one uncoated beads formulation of glucose and caffeine in healthy obese subjects. The study is designed to evaluate the pharmacokinetic parameters of glucose and caffeine and the pharmacodynamic parameters of glucose and caffeine. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference on Harmonization (ICH) guidelines for Good Clinical Practice (GCP).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of using celluloid matrix tapes and oral tapes as a simple and cheap method for proper positioning of the tongue on reducing the palatoglossal airway shadow error in panoramic imaging. The study will be conducted in the Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology Department of Tabriz University of Medical Sciences, Iran. The study will be conducted on 270 patients who will be randomly divided into three groups. The first group will receive no intervention, the second group will receive fruit leather, and the third group will receive celluloid matrix tapes. The patients will be asked to hold the given strips on their tongues during the imaging procedure. The primary outcome measure will be the effect of using different strips on reducing the palatoglossal airspace shadow error in panoramic imaging. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Tabriz University of Medical Sciences.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the acute effect of kinesio taping and extracorporeal shock wave therapy on pain level, lower extremity functionality and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis. The study will be conducted in three groups: ESWT, ESWT and KT, and placebo/sham ESWT. ESWT will be applied at 10 Hz frequency, 2.5 Barr energy and 2000 shocks/session. KT will be applied after ESWT and the tape will be asked to remain for a week. The study will use the visual pain scale (VAS) score, lower extremity functional scale score and plantar fascia flexibility to evaluate the clinical follow-up of the patients.

[/INST] The study titled "Establish the Couple Intervention Program for Adults With Autism Spectrum Disorder" is a single-arm clinical trial that aims to establish a couple group therapy program for adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and their partners. The program is designed to improve communication, empathy, and socialization skills. The study will be conducted in China and will involve 20 couples, with one person of each couple having either an ASD diagnosis or an autism spectrum quotient score above or equal to 26. The couples will be assessed using the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule, Autism Spectrum Quotient, Empathy Quotient, Social Responsiveness Scale, Quality of Socialization Questionnaire, and other measures. The study will last for 6 weeks, and the primary outcome measure will be the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule. The study will be conducted in Chinese, and the results will be published in a Chinese journal.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of an individually tailored exercise program on physical function, quality of life, and orthostatic intolerance in patients with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) and post-COVID-19 condition. The study will compare the effects of the exercise program to those of standard care. The study will also evaluate the effects of the exercise program on orthostatic intolerance, quality of life, and physical function.

[/INST] The BRANT study is a multicenter, randomized, open label, blinded endpoint, parallel controlled trial with the primary null hypothesis that, in patients with acute BAD-related stroke, there is no difference in the proportion of excellent outcome in those treated with intravenous Tirofiban compared with those treated with standard antiplatelet therapy based on guideline when subjects are randomized within 48 hours of stroke onset. The primary outcome is to determine whether intravenous tirofiban (a loading dose of 0.4ug/kg/min*30min followed by a maintenance dose of 0.1ug/kg/min*47.5h) is effective in increasing the proportion of excellent functional outcome (mR: 0-1) at 90 days, when initiated within 48 hours of onset. The active comparator is standard antiplatelet therapy based on guideline. The subjects' eligibility will be assessed by site investigator prior to accessing the Randomization Module, which is generated via the dynamic block randomization method. Only certified and trained personnel can access the randomization website, who will get the information of treatment (ie, Tirofiban or standard antiplatelet therapy) after the subject has been determined eligible. The subjects will be randomized 1:1 (Tirofiban: Standard antiplatelet therapy). The clinical and safety events will be re-examined by the Clinical Event Committee (CEC), who are blinded during all procedures. The primary outcome will be assessed by well-trained senior neurologists blinded to the treatment. The secondary outcomes include excellent functional outcome at 7 days, early neurological deterioration, NIHSS score at 7 days and 90 days, Barthel index score at 7 days and 90 days, ischemic stroke, stroke, TIA, composite endpoint, major bleeding, serious adverse events, adverse events, all-cause death, changes in hemoglobin, changes in the count of red blood cell, changes in the count of white blood cell, changes in the count of platelets, changes in alanine transaminase, changes in aspartate aminotransferase, changes in direct bilirubin, changes in indirect bilirubin, changes in concentration of Na, changes

[/INST] The Allometric-Pace Study is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the effects of different pacing rates on patients with sinus node dysfunction (SND). The study will compare the effects of a lower rate of 75 bpm (PLR group) with a lower rate of 60 bpm (control group) on patients with SND. The primary outcome measure is the quality of life of the patients, which will be assessed using the SF-36 questionnaire score within three months after the surgery. The secondary outcome measures are cardiac functional changes, such as left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), and the correlation of elevated blood pressure and bradycardia. The study will be conducted on patients who are at least 60 years old and have a resting sinus heart rate of 60 bpm or less, or an average heart rate detected through a 24-hour dynamic electrocardiogram of 60 bpm or less. Patients with a history of heart failure, persistent or chronic atrial fibrillation, or a secondary cause of hypertension will be excluded from the study. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of telemedicine and in-person treatment for OSA patients. The study will evaluate the effects of telemedicine on blood pressure, sleep quality, and cost-effectiveness. The study will also examine the subtypes of OSA and their response to treatment.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the influence of communication between nursing staff and patients on the analgesic response following caesarean section. The study will be conducted in the maternity ward at Carmel Hospital. The study population will include patients who are about to undergo an elective caesarean section under spinal anesthesia. The dependent variable is the treatment efficacy, based on the changes in the intensity of the patient's pain one hour after the administration of analgesic. The Self-Consciousness Scale (SCS-R) and the Short suggestibility scale (SSS) will be used to assess relevant personality traits.

[/INST] The ALPINE study is a prospective cohort study that aims to identify novel molecular, immune, and clinical biomarkers to improve the sensitivity and specificity of lung cancer screening beyond what is achieved with conventional risk prediction models and low-dose CT scanning. The study will use proteomics, metabolomics, genomics, and immune repertoire characterization performed on peripheral bloods. The study will run for 5 years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telepharmacy on clinical outcomes of patients with arterial hypertension. The study will compare the acceptance and clinical importance of interventions carried out by the pharmacist between the telepharmacy and in-person (control) groups. The study will also evaluate patient adherence to medication treatment in the teleconsultation group and in person, as well as patient satisfaction in the teleconsultation group and in-person consultation. The study will compare satisfaction between the telepharmacy and in-person (control) groups. The study will be conducted over a period of three months.

[/INST] The ICU LIBERATION Study is a multicenter, international observational study that aims to investigate the current epidemiology and treatment strategy given to patients with ARDS who require ventilators at high frequency. The study will clarify the actual implementation of ICU care for ARDS patients and evaluate how the implementation of evidence-based ICU care is associated with patient outcomes.

[/INST] The Effect of Pomanox® on Skin Ageing (POMASKIN) is a randomized, parallel, placebo-controlled, triple-blind clinical trial with a 1:1:1 ratio between interventions. The study is designed to evaluate the effect of consuming two doses of Pomanox®P30 on hyperpigmented skin spots in humans. The secondary objectives of the study are to evaluate the effects of consuming two doses of Pomanox®P30 on other parameters related to skin ageing (wrinkles, elasticity, erythema index, hydration, pores, acne and keratin), on different markers of collagen and hyaluronic acid metabolism, oxidative stress, the anti-glycan effect and the inflammatory system, and on the composition of the intestinal and skin microbiota. The study will be conducted with 66 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of the three groups: 367 mg Pomanox group, 700 mg Pomanox group, or control group. The study will last 85 days, with a pre-selection visit, a visit at the beginning of the study, two follow-up visits, and an end of study visit. The primary outcome measure will be the change in skin melanin index. The secondary outcome measures will be the change in skin wrinkles, hydratation, elasticity, erythema index, pores, acne and keratin, the markers of collagen and hyaluronic acid metabolism, oxidative stress, the anti-glycan effect and the inflammatory system, and the composition of the intestinal and skin microbiota. The study will be conducted in Barcelona, Spain.

[/INST] The study is titled "Prostate Medication, Metabolism and Gut Microbiota" and is a non-randomized controlled trial. The study aims to investigate the effects of prostate medication on gut microbiota and metabolism. The study will include two cohorts: a benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) cohort and a prostate cancer (PCa) cohort. The BPH cohort will include men who are treated with 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (finasteride, dutasteride, or combination of dutasteride and tamsulosin), and the PCa cohort will include men who are treated with LHRH antagonist (degarelix). The study will collect samples of gut microbiota and metabolites prior to starting medication and after 2 months of medication use. The study will also collect samples of PSA and prostate size before and after 6 months of medication use. The study will investigate the effects of prostate medication on gut microbiota and metabolism, and the effects of these changes on PSA and prostate size.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, single-arm, non-randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the use of magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) as a diagnostic test for glioma. The study will enroll patients with glioma who are scheduled for surgery and will undergo MRS examination before and after surgery. The primary outcome measure is the correlation between the IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion status derived from ex vivo analyses in tumor tissue samples and the concentrations of 2-hydroxyglutarate and cystahionine measured by MRS. The secondary outcome measures are the correlation between the 1p19q codeletion status derived from ex vivo analyses in tumor tissue samples and the diffusion MRI metrics, the correlation between the changes in concentration of 2-hydroxyglutarate, cystathionine and choline and the changes in tumor volumes and the clinical response, and the correlation between the diffusion MRI and amide proton transfer signal changes and the changes in metabolism, tumor volumes and the clinical response. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will enroll 100 patients. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients. The study is a single-arm trial with a combination of hydroxyurea and thalidomide as the intervention. The primary outcome measure is the frequency of good responders, responders, and non-responders at 1-3 years on combination therapy. The secondary outcome measure is the comparison of XmnI polymorphism with outcome among patients who completed 1-year, 2-years, and 3-years of combination therapy. The study is conducted in Thailand and is currently recruiting participants.

[/INST] The study aims to determine the current practice in primary care for venous leg ulcer management and availability of services to onward referral. The study will also determine the current practice for diagnosis and management of suspected venous leg ulcers in vascular scientist departments across the UK. The study will use a questionnaire-based approach and a Delphi consensus to collect data. The study will collect data from primary care practitioners and vascular scientists. The primary outcome measure for primary care practitioners is to determine the current practice in primary care for venous leg ulcer management and availability of services to onward referral. The primary outcome measure for vascular scientists is to determine the current practice for diagnosis and management of suspected venous leg ulcers in vascular scientist departments across the UK. The study will collect data for 3 months and 6 months. The study will use a questionnaire with multiple choice and free text boxes for answers, the answers will be analysed qualitatively. A consensus will have been achieved when a 70% agreement has been reached on answers to set questions.

[/INST] The study is titled "Enhancing Prospective Thinking in Early Recovery" and is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment model. The study is designed to test the effectiveness of a virtual reality avatar intervention in reducing drug use days, increasing abstinence, and improving other outcomes related to prospective thinking and future orientation in individuals with stimulant use disorder. The study will use a virtual reality avatar to help participants visualize their future selves and the consequences of their current actions. The study will use a virtual reality park experience as a control condition. The study will use a combination of self-report measures and biological markers to assess the effectiveness of the intervention. The study will have a study day visit, a 30-day follow-up visit, and a 6-month follow-up visit. The primary outcome measures will be reduced drug use days, increased length of abstinence, increased abstinence, increased future self-identification, increased future time perspective, and increased delayed reward preference. The study will use a virtual reality avatar to help participants visualize their future selves and the consequences of their current actions. The study will use a virtual reality park experience as a control condition. The study will use a combination of self-report measures and biological markers to assess the effectiveness of the intervention. The study will have a study day visit, a 30-day follow-up visit, and a 6-month follow-up visit. The primary outcome measures will be reduced drug use days, increased length of abstinence, increased abstinence, increased future self-identification, increased future time perspective, and increased delayed reward preference.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the stability of short implants (6 mm) with standard implants (10 mm) placed in the posterior maxilla after sinus floor elevation. The study includes 16 patients with a single edentulous site in the posterior maxilla. The available bone height below the maxillary sinus should be 7-8mm. The primary outcome measure is the crestal bone level, which will be assessed by periapical standardized radiographs at 1 year.

[/INST] The study is a phase I, open-label, dose-escalation study of WJ-MSC infusion as GVHD prophylaxis in patients undergoing haploidentical HSCT. The study aims to determine the maximum tolerated dose of WJ-MSC infusion and to evaluate the safety and efficacy of WJ-MSC infusion in preventing GVHD. The study will enroll patients with AML/ALL/SMD/SMP or lymphoid neoplasm requiring allogeneic stem cell transplantation in complete remission. Patients will receive WJ-MSC infusion at a dose of 1.5 × 106 cells/kg/infusion for 3 weekly infusions. The primary endpoint of the study is to determine the maximum tolerated dose of WJ-MSC infusion. The secondary endpoints are to evaluate the safety and efficacy of WJ-MSC infusion in preventing GVHD. The study will also evaluate the incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, toxicity-related mortality, relapse incidence, overall survival, and GvHD and relapse-free survival.

[/INST] The study is titled "A Rapid Diagnostic of Risk in Hospitalized Patients Using Machine Learning" and is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a machine learning algorithm called eCARTv5 in reducing mortality rates in hospitalized patients. The algorithm is designed to predict the risk of clinical deterioration in patients and alert healthcare providers to intervene early to prevent adverse outcomes. The study will compare the effectiveness of eCARTv5 to the standard of care in reducing mortality rates in hospitalized patients. The study will be conducted in multiple medical-surgical units in hospitals that implement the algorithm in their electronic health record (EHR) and hospitals that do not implement the algorithm. The study will track the hospital mortality, total hospital length of stay (LOS), ICU-free days, and ventilator-free days of patients who have an elevated risk score during hospitalization. The study will track these outcomes for 12 months.

[/INST] The ASSET-PPD is a pilot RCT that will evaluate the effectiveness of a novel intervention to reduce maternal perinatal depression. The intervention will target fathers and will include four prenatal modules and two postpartum review sessions. The modules will address key correlates of PND with the largest effect sizes by targeting fathers' prenatal and postpartum family involvement, mental health psychoeducation, interparental communication and relationship skills, and balanced division of family tasks. The study will enroll 50 parent dyads (100 individuals total, 25 romantic or non-romantic partners per arm). If we assume 5% attrition at each phase, we anticipate analyzable data for between 20-25 parent duos per arm. The primary outcome measure will be maternal depression, measured by the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated (IDS-SR16). The secondary outcome measures will be maternal anxiety, measured by the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7-item (GAD-7), breastfeeding, measured by the FeedCat Tool (FT), infant affect and mood regulation, measured by the Infant Behavior Questionnaire- Revised (IBQ-R), and parent-infant interaction quality, measured by the Parent-Child Early Relational Assessment (PCERA).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of a digital mental health intervention, Moodivate, in addressing unmet psychosocial needs of individuals living with cancer. Participants with elevated depressive symptoms, defined as a score of ≥ 10 on the PHQ-9, were recruited and randomly assigned to either the treatment as usual (TAU) or Moodivate group. The TAU group received educational material about mood management available via the EHR with the suggestion to discuss questions with their oncology provider. The Moodivate group was instructed to utilize Moodivate regularly, at least once per day, for the treatment of depressed mood among cancer survivors. Participants in the Moodivate group received a download code to download the Moodivate mobile application. The primary outcome measure was accrual, defined as the proportion of Illic eligible for the trial who accrued to the study. The study duration was 6-7 months or until recruitment was reached.

[/INST] The study is a pilot trial that aims to evaluate algorithms for detecting subcutaneous insulin pump malfunctions in type 1 diabetes patients. The study will involve three phases: phase 1 will involve collecting data on glycemic trends and insulin administration in free-living conditions for one month; phase 2 will involve inducing hyperglycemia by suspending insulin infusion and monitoring the resulting hyperglycemia; and phase 3 will involve retrospectively analyzing the collected data to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting insulin suspension. The study will use a single-group assignment model and will not be masked. The primary outcome measure will be the sensitivity of the algorithms in detecting insulin suspension, and the secondary outcome measure will be the false positive per day. The study will be conducted in a single center and will involve 10 participants. The study will be completed by the end of 2023.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Funk It Cycle Bites on premenstrual syndrome (PMS). The study is a single-group assignment with an open-label design. Participants will be asked to consume one Cycle Bite per day for four months. The primary outcome measure is the change in symptoms of PMS, which will be assessed using the Premenstrual Symptoms Screening Tool (PSST). The secondary outcome measures include changes in acne, pain levels, mood stability, energy levels, and participant enjoyment of the product. The study will be conducted over four months, and participants will be asked to complete surveys at baseline and at the end of the study. The study will be conducted in the United States, and participants must be female, aged 18-40, have a regular menstrual cycle, and be willing to consume the test product with a ginger flavor. Participants will be excluded if they have any unstable or uncontrolled medical or psychiatric illness, any uncontrolled chronic disease or condition, a history of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), endometriosis, premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), or undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, are taking hormonal contraception or exogenous sex hormones (estrogen, testosterone, progesterone), are taking any prescription medication or supplements that target the menstrual cycle or PMS symptoms, are pregnant, breastfeeding, trying to become pregnant, or have been pregnant in the past 12 months, have any known severe allergic reactions, or any allergies of any severity to any of the test product's ingredients.

[/INST] The Value of a Risk Prediction Tool (PERSARC) for Effective Treatment Decisions of Soft-tissue Sarcomas Patients is a clinical trial that aims to assess the use of a personalized risk assessment tool (PERSARC) in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices in high-grade extremity Soft-tissue Sarcoma patients compared to usual care. The study will use a parallel cluster randomized trial design, with a co-primary outcome of decisional conflict and informed choice. The study will assess the use of PERSARC in multidisciplinary tumour boards and in patient consultations. The study will also assess the use of PERSARC in terms of satisfaction with/added value of PERSARC and barriers and facilitators for the integration of PERSARC in treatment decision-making processes during patient-clinician encounters. The study will use a combination of questionnaires, interviews, and audio-recording/observation of consultations to assess the use of PERSARC. The study will be conducted in the Netherlands and will involve 120 patients with high-grade extremity Soft-tissue Sarcoma. The study will assess the use of PERSARC at one week, three months, six months, and 12 months after the treatment decision. The study will also assess the cost-effectiveness of PERSARC.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the prevalence of early childhood caries (ECC) in Jordanian children and its associated risk factors. The study also examined the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride (SDF) as a caries control material and its acceptance among parents of children with ECC. The study was a cross-sectional epidemiological study that included children who attended kindergartens in Jordan. The children were examined to determine the prevalence of ECC in Jordan. A sample of children with ECC was randomly assigned to receive a single application of 38% SDF or no intervention. The children were followed up for one year. The study found that the prevalence of ECC in Jordanian children was high and that SDF was effective in preventing and arresting new and existing caries cavities. The study also found that the acceptance of SDF among parents of children with ECC was high.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ABRYSVO vaccine against RSV-related LRTI hospitalizations in older adults. The study will use a test-negative design and a retrospective cohort design to estimate the vaccine effectiveness (VE) of ABRYSVO against RSV-related LRTI hospitalizations.
