The study will also estimate the VE of ABRYSVO against RSV-related LRTI hospitalizations in high-risk groups, such as those with CHF and COPD. The study will use logistic regression to adjust for confounding factors, such as age, sex, race/ethnicity, and chronic medical conditions. The study will use Cox proportional hazard regression to estimate the VE of ABRYSVO against RSV-related LRTI hospitalizations. The study will also describe the demographic, clinical, and laboratory characteristics (i.e., viral subgroup) and disease severity of any RSV events among vaccinated individuals. The study will use descriptive statistics to describe the demographic, clinical, and laboratory characteristics (i.e., viral subgroup) and disease severity of any RSV events among vaccinated individuals. The study will use Cox proportional hazard regression to estimate the VE of ABRYSVO against all-cause LRTI hospitalizations, stratified by age, frailty index, and chronic medical condition risk category. The study will use Cox proportional hazard regression to estimate the VE of ABRYSVO against all-cause LRTI hospitalizations, separately for outpatient visits (without subsequent hospitalization or ED visit within 14 days) and ED events (ED without subsequent hospitalization). The study will use Cox proportional hazard regression to estimate the VE of ABRYSVO against all-cause LRTI hospitalizations, separately for hospitalizations and ED events (without subsequent hospitalizations). The study will use Cox proportional hazard regression to estimate the VE of ABRYSVO against all-cause respiratory, cardiac, cardiorespiratory

[/INST] The OSsIRIS study is a post-market clinical follow-up investigation to confirm the performance and safety of the bone substitute b.Bone in extremities and pelvis. The study will enroll patients with surgically created bone defects or bone defects/voids resulting from traumatic injury in the extremities and pelvis. The primary outcome measure is the radiographic healing/union after surgery. The secondary outcome measures are patient-reported pain and quality of life. The study will evaluate the safety of b.Bone during the clinical investigation period.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the prognostic significance of acute change in liver and splenic stiffness in patients with acute on chronic liver failure (ACLF). The study will enroll 200 patients with ACLF and will assess the change in liver and splenic stiffness at day 7 and day 14 from baseline at day 1. The study will also evaluate the association of baseline and change in liver and splenic stiffness with different etiologies of ACLF, severity of ACLF, pattern of organ failures, and changes in biochemical inflammatory markers. The study will use transient elastography (Fibroscan) to measure liver and splenic stiffness. The study will also use the Acute-on-Chronic Liver Failure (AARC) score, the CLIF-C ACLF score, the Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score, and the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score to assess the severity of ACLF. The study will use the Kaplan-Meier method to analyze the association of baseline and change in liver and splenic stiffness with transplant-free survival at 3 months. The study will be conducted at a single center and will have a follow-up period of 1 year. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study has been approved by the institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, triple-blind, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at a depth of 2mm versus 4mm for the improvement of glabellar lines. The primary outcome measure is the change in the severity of glabellar lines from baseline to 120 days after treatment using the Merz aesthetics scale. The secondary outcome measure is the incidence of any adverse effects of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at a depth of 2mm versus 4mm. The study will compare the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at a depth of 2mm versus 4mm for the improvement of glabellar lines using the Merz aesthetics scale.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of music therapy on anxiety in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy. The study will compare the effects of music therapy to standard care. The primary outcome measure is the change in anxiety before the first and third chemotherapy sessions, as measured by the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) etat score. The study will include patients with localized breast cancer who are eligible for curative surgery and who have not already received chemotherapy. Patients will be excluded if they have metastatic breast cancer, triple negative breast cancer, or if they are unable to understand French. The study will be conducted in France and will include 40 participants. The study will be conducted over a period of 5 months.

[/INST] The Optimization of Conditioning Regimen for HLA Matched HSCT in SAA is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study that aims to evaluate different conditioning regimens for HLA matched donor transplantation in severe aplastic anemia (SAA). The study will compare the Busulfan included group with the control group, which will not receive Busulfan. The primary outcome measure is failure-free survival, and the secondary outcome measures include the incidence of mixed chimerism, regimen-related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, the incidence of graft versus host disease, the incidence of CMV and EBV reactivation, the incidence of transplantation-related mortality, the probability of overall survival, and the incidence of transplantation-related mortality. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a phase 3, open-label, single-arm trial to test the safety and tolerability of fitusiran in participants with severe hemophilia A who previously received prophylactic treatment with emicizumab. The study will enroll male participants aged 18 years or older with severe congenital hemophilia A, with or without inhibitors, who are currently on the full labeled dose of emicizumab prophylaxis. The study will evaluate the safety and tolerability of fitusiran by monitoring adverse events, including bleeding events, and by assessing the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of fitusiran. The study will also assess the efficacy of fitusiran by measuring the peak thrombin generation, peak antithrombin levels, and annualized bleeding rate. The study will have a duration of approximately 19 months, including a fitusiran treatment period of up to 18 months and a follow-up period of up to 1 month.

[/INST] The study titled "Translation and Validation of Malay Version of painDETECT Questionnaire" is a cross-sectional study that aims to translate and validate the Malay version of the painDETECT questionnaire (PDQ-M). The study includes participants with neuropathic or nociceptive pain who are able to read and understand the Malay language, have been diagnosed with neuropathic or nociceptive pain by a clinician, have a stable disease condition, and have experienced pain for at least 4 weeks. The study involves administering the PDQ-M questionnaire and collecting socio-demographic data from participants. The primary outcome measure is the total PDQ-M score, which is measured within 2-5 weeks of completing the questionnaire. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and has been approved by the Medical Research Ethics Committee of Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a community-based complex exercise program for stroke patients. The program consists of a 6-week exercise program that includes aerobic exercise, strength and balance exercises, and stretching exercises. The study will compare the effects of the exercise program with those of daily life activities. The primary outcome measure is the 6-minute walk test, and the secondary outcome measures include the modified Rankin Scale, Berg Balance Scale, Functional Ambulation Category, Manual Muscle Testing, Timed Up and Go, grip strength, body composition, physical activity, Euro-Quality of Life-5 Dimension, Geriatric Depression Scale, sit to stand, flexibility test, and coordination test. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks, and the results are expected to provide evidence for the effectiveness of the community-based complex exercise program for stroke patients.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-finding study to evaluate the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV-552 in participants with mild Alzheimer's disease. Participants will be randomized to receive ABBV-552 Dose A, ABBV-552 Dose B, ABBV-552 Dose C, or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog 14) score from baseline to week 12.

[/INST] The study is an observational study that aims to evaluate cases of acute liver failure (ALF) and acute on chronic liver disease (ACLD) according to guidelines. The study will determine the most likely causes of disease in patients of each age, the complications of the disease, and the mortality and morbidity rates. The study will include patients who are 18 to 75 years old and have reduced consciousness, jaundice, abnormal liver function tests, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure. The study will exclude patients with known cardiac cirrhosis and known pre-existing renal disease. The study will use a variety of tools to collect data, including a thorough history, physical examination, laboratory tests, and imaging studies. The study will also use special scores to assess the severity of the disease and the risk of complications. The study will follow up with patients for two weeks after admission to the intensive care unit to assess their liver and kidney function, fluid overload, mortality, and morbidity rates.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study population consisted of 54 patients with bipolar disorder who were in the euthymic period. The study used the Brief Quality of Life in Bipolar Disorder Scale, Barratt Impulsivity Scale -11 Short Form, and Coping Attitudes Evaluation Scale to measure quality of life, impulsivity, and coping skills, respectively. The results of the study showed that impulsivity and coping skills were significant predictors of quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study concluded that interventions aimed at improving coping skills and reducing impulsivity may improve quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder.

[/INST] The study is a double-blind, randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the clinical performance of two different single-color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions with the control group (Filtek Z250, 3M), which is a multi-color composite resin material, using modified USPHS and FDI criteria. The study is designed to have a parallel assignment with a randomized allocation. The study will be conducted in a single center and the participants will be followed up for 36 months. The primary outcome measure is the clinical performance according to the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. The secondary outcome measure is the clinical performance of restorations according to the World Dental Organization criteria. The study will be conducted in Turkey.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effects of sugammadex and neostigmine on the time to neurological assessment after endotracheal intubation in critically ill patients. The study will enroll patients who are intubated with etomidate and rocuronium and are neurologically evaluable. The primary outcome is the time from administration of neuromuscular blocker to the first available neurologic assessment. The secondary outcomes are the time from administration of neuromuscular blocker to first available spontaneous eye opening, changes of Patient State index (PSi) values, changes of regional cerebral oxygen saturation (O3) values, time from intubation to extubation, total length of hospital stay, total length of intensive care unit (ICU) stay, in-ICU mortality, in-hospital mortality, and adverse events. The study will be conducted in Japan and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral weight loss intervention in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia. The study will compare the effectiveness of a telemedicine behavioral weight loss intervention with enhanced usual care in promoting primary prevention and uterine preservation in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia. The study will also evaluate the time to resolution of hyperplasia and the change in weight and cancer worry impact events scale. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 years.

[/INST] The study is a case series of four patients who underwent a new technique of subtotal cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. The technique involves making an incision in a safe zone at the junction of the infundibulum and the body of the gallbladder. The separation between the outer layer and inner layer was searched. This clear identification of the confluence between the cystic duct and the body of the gallbladder represents the way to determine if the procedure was safely completed using the current technique. After successful identification, the cystic duct was clipped. The inflamed posterior wall remained attached to the gallbladder bed of the liver. The primary outcome measure was the new technique of subtotal cholecystectomy. The study was conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study was approved by the ethics committee of the hospital. The study was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04123300).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to examine the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and virtual reality (VR) in supporting the physical rehabilitation of athletes who have undergone anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) surgery. The study will compare the effects of CBT+VR, VR, CBT, and control interventions on re-injury anxiety, kinesiophobia, poor rehabilitation adherence, and poor rehabilitation self-efficacy. The study will use a mixed factorial design model with four groups (intervention1-intervention2-intervention3, control) and will be conducted with 60 athletes who meet the inclusion criteria. The CBT+VR protocol will be applied to the first intervention group. Only the behavioral intervention part of the protocol in the VR environment will be applied to the second intervention group. The CBT protocol will be applied without the VR environment for the third intervention group. It is planned that for all intervention groups and the control group, there will be 10 sessions in total once a week, and each session will last 50 minutes. The scales will be filled in three more times. The data obtained will be analyzed with multi-level statistics. Whether the anxiety levels of the athletes increase in the VR environment will be monitored with the biofeedback system, which will provide concrete data as well as subjective scales.

[/INST] The study is titled "Analysis of a Stepped-Wedge Implementation of the PT-PENCIL Tool" and is a clinical trial that aims to analyze the effect of using the PT-PENCIL on the proportion of patients discharged home. The study is a stepped-wedge design, which means that the intervention is rolled out in a stepwise manner to different groups of patients over time. The study will also assess the reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL. The study will use an electronic clinical decision support tool to identify patients who may benefit from daily physical therapy and will analyze the effect of using the tool on the proportion of patients discharged home. The study will also assess the reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the tool.

[/INST] The study is a single-arm, prospective, exploratory study to evaluate the feasibility and effect of medical Tai Chi exercise healing in treating mCRC patients. The study aims to evaluate the adherence rates of the 7-form of medical Tai Chi exercise healing for mCRC patients and the effects of Tai Chi exercise on fatigue, sleep quality, quality of life, anxiety, and depression in mCRC patients. The study will enroll 30 eligible mCRC patients who will receive the 7-form of medical Tai Chi exercise healing for 8 weeks. The adherence rates will be measured by the number of tai chi sessions performed divided by the total possible tai chi sessions. The effects of Tai Chi exercise on fatigue, sleep quality, quality of life, anxiety, and depression will be measured by the Brief Fatigue Inventory (BFI), the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), EORTC - Quality of Life Questionnaire, self-rating anxiety scale (SAS), and self-rating depression scale (SDS), respectively.

[/INST] The Survivorship ECHO project is a study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an educational intervention on provider knowledge of cancer survivorship best practices. The study will assess provider knowledge of cancer survivorship best practices using pre- and post-enrollment surveys and evaluate implementation of survivorship best practices into clinical practice and documentation after enrollment in the Survivorship ECHO. The study will also explore the acceptability of the current structure of the Survivorship ECHO, barriers to accessing ECHO, and content, participant needs, and aspects of delivering the Survivorship ECHO platform using qualitative analysis.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of post facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization in improving range of motion in post-traumatic stiff elbow. The study will include 32 participants aged 18-35 years with a limitation of elbow joint range of motion greater than 30 degrees in extension and less than 120 degrees in flexion. The intervention will be performed for 4 weeks, 5 days a week, for 1 hour each day. The primary outcome measures are changes in numeric pain rating scale, range of motion of elbow joint flexion and extension, and range of motion of forearm supination and pronation. The secondary outcome measure is changes in disability. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary approach in the early diagnosis of heart failure. The approach involves the use of a handheld echocardiogram device with artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled report and a natriuretic peptide test. The primary outcome measure is the diagnosis of heart failure within 6 months from randomization. The secondary outcome measure is the diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) within 6 months and the use of guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) within 6 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of guided internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy (ICBT) for patients with moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. The study will compare the effectiveness of ICBT with usual care and will also assess the cost-effectiveness of ICBT. The study will include 300 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the ICBT group or the usual care group. The primary outcome measures will be depression severity, social phobia, and panic disorder symptoms. The secondary outcome measures will include health-related quality of life, work and social adjustment, anxiety severity, and system usability. The study will have three follow-up assessments at 14 weeks, 6 months, and 2 years after the start of treatment.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficacy of two ultrasound-guided regional anesthesia techniques, thoracolumbar interfascial plane block (TLIP) and erector spinae plane block (ESP), for perioperative analgesia in patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery. The study also compares the efficacy of these two regional anesthesia techniques with the control group, which received general anesthesia and local anesthetic infiltration of the incision site. The primary outcome measure is the sensory blockade area, assessed by the pinprick test, and the secondary outcome measures include the total amount of fentanyl used during surgery, analgesia nociception index (ANI) scores, total dose of morphine in 12 and 24 hours after surgery, and VAS scores at rest and on movement. The study also evaluates the side effects of these techniques, including vomiting/nausea, itchy, urinary retention, respiratory failure, and circulatory failure. The study is expected to provide evidence on the efficacy of ultrasound-guided regional anesthesia techniques for perioperative analgesia in patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery.

[/INST] The study is titled "Evaluation of MABOS for Improved Pulse Oximeter Accuracy in Patients of Color" and is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the accuracy of a novel pulse oximeter in patients of different skin tones. The study will also assess the safety and comfort of the novel pulse oximeter. The study will enroll 12 participants, who will wear the pulse oximeters for 90 minutes. [/INST] The study is a phase 1/2 study of interferon beta-1a (FP-1201) to prevent toxicities after CAR T-cell therapy. The study is designed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of FP-1201. The study will enroll patients with recurrent B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL), B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (B-NHL), or refractory B-ALL or B-NHL who are undergoing CAR T-cell therapy. The study will evaluate the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs), the incidence of adverse events (AEs), the incidence of cytokine release syndrome (CRS) and immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome (ICANS), the cumulative corticosteroid dose, the overall response rate, and the complete response rate. The study will also evaluate the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of FP-1201. The study will be conducted in the United States.

[/INST] The study is a phase III clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of camrelizumab plus chemotherapy and famitinib as neoadjuvant therapy in patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). The study will compare the pathological complete response (pCR) rate of the combination therapy to that of camrelizumab plus chemotherapy. The study will also assess the event-free survival (EFS), disease-free survival (DFS), distant disease-free survival (DDFS), and objective response rate (ORR) of the combination therapy. The study will enroll patients with early or locally advanced TNBC who have an ECOG performance status of 0-1 and adequate hematologic and organ function. The study will exclude patients who have a history of breast cancer, have received prior chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiation therapy within the past 12 months, or have a history of immunodeficiency or autoimmune diseases. The study will randomize patients to receive either the combination therapy or camrelizumab plus chemotherapy. The study will assess the pCR rate at up to approximately 24 weeks after the start of treatment. The study will also assess the EFS, DFS, and DDFS at least 2 years after the start of treatment and the ORR up to approximately 24 weeks and up to approximately 67 weeks after the start of treatment.

[/INST] The study is titled "Early Prediction of Postpartum Glucose Metabolism Abnormalities in Gestational Diabetes Mellitus Based on Gestational Metabolic Profile and Lipid Profile" and is a prospective cohort study. The study aims to identify the risk factors for postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) by analyzing their gestational metabolic profile and lipid profile. The study will enroll pregnant women with GDM who plan to give birth in the research center and have a gestational age of 24-28 weeks. The study will collect data on the participants' demographic characteristics, medical history, and blood samples. The blood samples will be analyzed for serum lipidomics and metabolomics, and the results will be used to identify the risk factors for postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with GDM. The study will follow up with the participants at 6-12 weeks postpartum to determine their postpartum glucose metabolism status. The study will use the OGTT to diagnose postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities and will collect data on the participants' demographic characteristics, medical history, and blood samples. The study will use logistic regression analysis to identify the risk factors for postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with GDM. The study will also use receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis to evaluate the predictive value of the identified risk factors for postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with GDM. The study will also use decision curve analysis to evaluate the clinical utility of the identified risk factors for postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with GDM.

[/INST] The study is titled "Assessment of Sleep Quality of Hospitalized Patients Treated With EEG-guided Protection Procedures: Application in Intensive Care Unit" and is a non-randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the effect of EEG-guided sleep protection on sleep quality, sleep fragmentation, environmental noise and environmental light, sleep interruptions by caregivers, sleep quality, workload assessed by nurses, patient agitation, performance of the algorithm, patient reported sleep quality, anxiety level, respiratory status, presence of delirium, and unit care length of stay. The study will be conducted in the medical intensive care unit of the University Hospital of Poitiers, France. The study will include 40 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the control or experimental group. The control group will receive usual care, while the experimental group will receive EEG-guided sleep protection. The primary outcome measure will be sleep quality, and the secondary outcome measures will be sleep fragmentation, environmental noise and environmental light, sleep interruptions by caregivers, sleep quality, workload assessed by nurses, patient agitation, performance of the algorithm, patient reported sleep quality, anxiety level, respiratory status, presence of delirium, and unit care length of stay. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 days, and the data will be collected using a tablet. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study has been approved by the French Ethics Committee (Comité de Protection des Personnes Sud-Ouest et Outre Mer III) and has been registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04901334).

[/INST] The study is a phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging, efficacy, and safety study of SAR441566 plus methotrexate (MTX) in adults with moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAR441566 plus MTX in adults with moderate-to-severe RA. The study will also assess the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of SAR441566. The study will be conducted in 12 countries, including the United States, Canada, and European countries. The study will enroll 240 participants who will be randomized to receive one of four doses of SAR441566 plus MTX or MTX placebo. The study will have a duration of approximately 149 days, including a 12-week treatment period and a 28-day follow-up period. The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of participants achieving at least 20% improvement from baseline in the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) score at week 12. The secondary outcome measures will include change from baseline in Disease activity score - C-reactive protein (DAS-28 CRP) at week 12, proportion of participants achieving at least 50% improvement from baseline in the ACR score at week 12, and number of participants with treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs), serious AEs (SAEs), and AEs of special interest (AESIs).

[/INST] The study is a single-arm prospective clinical performance evaluation of the in-vitro diagnostics medical device MagIA IBC for the combined screening of HIV, HBV, and HCV. The study will enroll 100 participants who will be tested for HIV, HBV, and HCV using the MagIA IBC test in capillary blood and other matrices (veinous blood, serum, and plasma). The primary outcome measure is the performance measurement for the diagnostics of HIV, HBV, or HCV, which will be assessed by calculating the ROC AUC for HIV, HBV, and HCV diagnostics. The secondary outcome measure is the concordance of the diagnostic results obtained when it is performed in different matrices (capillary blood, veinous blood, serum, and plasma). The study will be conducted at the Hôpital Européen de Marseille in France and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Endocalyx in patients with chronic heart failure. The primary objective is to assess whether Endocalyx reduces sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure. The secondary objectives are to evaluate whether Endocalyx will improve physical limitations and patient-reported outcomes such as fluid overload symptoms and quality of life. The study will enroll patients with chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF and HFmrEF according to ESC guidelines). The study will be conducted in 10 centers in the Netherlands. The study will last for 12 months. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of Endocalyx in patients with chronic heart failure.

[/INST] The study is titled "The Use of Nasogastric Tubes and Water-Soluble Contrast in the Management of Small Bowel Obstruction: A Feasibility Study". The study is a feasibility study that aims to determine the feasibility of using water-soluble contrast (WSC) in the management of small bowel obstruction (SBO). The study will compare the use of WSC to the use of saline in patients with SBO who have undergone nasogastric tube (NGT) placement. The study will also compare the use of NGT with WSC to the use of NGT without WSC in patients with SBO who have not undergone NGT placement. The study will use the Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS)-29 to assess the quality of life of the patients. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will enroll 100 patients. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The study will determine the feasibility of using WSC in the management of SBO and will provide data to inform the design of a larger randomized controlled trial.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a novel combination therapeutic strategy for chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. The study will compare the combination of anti-programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) antibody, nucleos(t)ide analogs (NAs), and pegylated interferon-alpha (Peg-IFNα) with NAs and Peg-IFNα. The primary outcome measure is the sustained hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) loss at 24 weeks after the end of treatment. The study will enroll patients with chronic HBV infection who are NAs-naive or NAs-experienced. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy and the long-term durability of the response.

[/INST] The study "Wound Healing Comparison of Simple and Continuous Suture Techniques in Oral Surgery" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the wound healing process after using simple or continuous suture techniques in oral surgery. The study will include participants who need full arch alveoplasty and have no smoking or complications about wound healing. The primary outcome measures are Laundry Healing Index-1, Laundry Healing Index-3, Laundry Healing Index-7, Early Wound Healing Score-1, Early Wound Healing Score-3, and Early Wound Healing Score-7. The study will also measure suturing time, knot looseness, pain at suture removal, and suture removal difficulty. The study will be conducted in China and is currently in the recruiting phase.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study that explores the feasibility and utility of in-home body weight support harness system use in children treated for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). The study is a single-group assignment with no masking. The study includes 10 participants who are treated with nusinersen, onasemnogene abeparvovec, or risdiplam. The study measures the impact of the body weight support harness system on motor and non-motor skills using a five-question likert-style survey, the Neuromuscular Gross Motor Outcome (GRO) scale, the Hammersmith Functional Motor Scale Expanded (HFMSE), the revised Hammersmith Scale (RHS), the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development 3rd ed. (Bayley-III), and the World Health Organization Motor Milestone Checklist. The study also measures the frequency and duration of harness system use using a harness use log. The study is ongoing and has not yet reported any results.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficacy and safety of DMEK (Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty) in patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence rate of at least one serious DMEK post-op complication, including rebulling, graft failure, graft rejection, and macular cystoid edema. The secondary outcome measures include the occurrence rate of intraocular hypertension, graft detachment (with or without rebulling), surgeon's subjective assessment of surgical complexity, duration of surgical procedure, evolution of visual results (corrected and uncorrected), evolution of refractive results, evolution of endothelial loss, evolution of corneal thickness, and evolution of posterior keratometry. The study will be conducted in 12 months.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, observational study that aims to assess the utility of measurements made at the point of the maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel to diagnose CTS. The study will include patients with CTS and healthy controls. The primary outcome measures are the difference in the diameter of the median nerve in the site of its maximal compression, the difference in the cross-sectional area of the median nerve in the site of its maximal compression, and the difference in the echogenicity of the median nerve in the site of its maximal compression between patients with CTS and healthy controls. The secondary outcome measures are the correlation of the diameter of the median nerve in the site of its maximal compression with the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire score and with the CTS electrophysiological severity grade in patients with CTS.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and symptom burden of tocilizumab in patients with multiple myeloma undergoing autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) following high-dose melphalan conditioning. The study will compare the use of tocilizumab to no tocilizumab in patients with multiple myeloma. The primary outcome measure is the MDASI questionnaire, which is a brief measure of the severity and impact of cancer-related symptoms. The study will also record adverse events according to CTCAE5.0. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to enroll 100 patients. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 years and 10 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of two methods of sperm selection, testicular sperm aspiration (TESA) and microfluidic sperm separation (MSS), in couples with high sperm DNA fragmentation undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) using intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI). The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate, and the secondary outcome measure is the number of utilizable blastocysts obtained. The study is currently ongoing and has not yet been completed.

[/INST] The study aimed to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance at the cervical, lumbal and scapular levels in archery athletes. The study included 40 archery athletes aged between 10 and 18, who have been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year. Demographic information and musculoskeletal system evaluations of the athletes were done. Performance of the athletes via Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test, Hand Grip Strength test; presence of scapular dyskinesia was evaluated via the Lateral Scapular Slide Test. Cervical region stabilization was evaluated via Craniocervical Flexion Test, scapular level stabilization was evaluated via Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, lumbar region stabilization was evaluated via Abdominal Drawing-in Test and Sahrmann's Core Stability Test. As the parameters related to stabilization, postures via Corbin Postural Rating Scale; balances via Stork Balance Test, Upper Extremity Y Balance Test; pain was evaluated via the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index. Shooting performances were evaluated with 72 target shootings and a total of 720 points.

[/INST] The study is titled "Adolescent Contraception: Communication Training Intervention to Engage Pediatrician-Adolescent-Mother Triads" and is a clinical trial that aims to improve communication between pediatricians, adolescents, and mothers during reproductive health encounters. The study will be conducted in three stages. In stage 1, the investigators will characterize communication content and styles of pediatricians and adolescent-mother dyads on contraception discussions with 50 real-life clinical encounters. In stage 2, the investigators will upload de-identified and anonymized vignettes to an AI communication training tool to develop and refine the tool through prompt engineering and performance evaluation with adolescent, parent, and pediatrician advisory boards. In stage 3, the investigators will test how an AI communication intervention tool can improve reproductive health encounters by comparing evaluation results of 50 pre-training and 50 post-training real encounters. The study will advance pediatrician communication training, empower adolescent sexual health, support mothers' priorities, and test how AI communication training chatbots can improve triadic interactions.

[/INST] The study is a population-based cohort study that aims to estimate the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo in the population overall and by important sociodemographic groups, including age, sex, ethnicity, and deprivation. The study will also perform a subgroup analysis in the vitiligo population to identify health-related disparities across people in different deprivation, sex, and ethnic groups. The disparities that will be considered are mental health conditions, healthcare utilisation, and work impact (time off work and unemployment). The study will use the OPCRD database to identify people with vitiligo and those without vitiligo. The study will use survival models to estimate the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo at age 80 years. The study will also use Cox proportional hazards models and generalised linear models to assess the association between baseline characteristics and the outcome of interest.

[/INST] The Effect of Self-efficacy and Relationship Through Behavior Modification by Hybrid Mode is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the effects and examine the behavior modification by hybrid in stress, self-efficacy, relationships, and conflict for caregivers. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two groups: the hybrid group and the self-learning group. The hybrid group received Atomic Habits (20-minute audiobook format), a role structure, and a game structure, online schedule reminders more than twice a week, and individual counseling sessions (online and physical) with one to two total interventions. The self-learning group received a description of the goals of the course and a reading of the Atomic Habits book. The study measures include Intervention Fidelity, Parenting Sense of Confidence, Parenting Stress Index: Short form, The Conflict Tactics Scales: Parent Version, Satisfaction Questionnaire, and Habit Schedule Record. The study is currently recruiting participants and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] Trotabresib is a novel small molecule inhibitor of the ATP-dependent topoisomerase II (TOP2) enzyme family. TOP2 plays a critical role in DNA replication and transcription, and its inhibition leads to DNA double-strand breaks and cell death. Trotabresib has potent in vitro and in vivo activity against a variety of cancer cell lines and tumor models, including those with TOP2A and/or TOP2B overexpression and/or TOP2B mutations. Trotabresib is currently in clinical development for the treatment of solid tumors, including breast cancer, non-small cell lung cancer, and ovarian cancer.

[/INST] The study aims to modify and adapt a validated program to be a culturally-relevant digital health tool for binge eating and weight management for Black women with obesity who binge eat. The study will conduct a randomized clinical trial to examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health appetite awareness + behavioral weight program in primary care. The study will recruit 120 participants who are over 18 years of age, have a BMI of 30 kg/m2 or higher, and report at least one binge eating episode weekly. Participants will be randomized to either the attention-control group or the experimental group. The attention-control group will receive the digital health tool and weekly psychoeducation emails about general wellness topics, discussion of binge eating, diet, and physical activity. The experimental group will receive the digital health tool and no intervention. The primary outcome measure is feasibility, which will be measured by the number of eligible adults screened for the study versus the number of persons who enrolled in the study. The secondary outcome measures are retention, attendance, and change in weight regain. The study will be conducted over 6 months.
[/INST] The Effect of Beetroot Juice Supplementation Dose on Neuromuscular Performance During Resistance Exercise

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of two different intra-abdominal pressure levels applied to patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia on 'Mechanical Power (MP)'. The study is designed to compare the mechanical power values of patients in two groups, one group with an intra-abdominal pressure of 12 mmHg and the other group with an intra-abdominal pressure of 14 mmHg. The mechanical power values of the patients; Before insufflation (baseline value), 0 min after insufflation, 15th min after insufflation, 30 minutes after insufflation, 45th minute after insufflation (if insufflation continues), 60th minute after insufflation (if insufflation continues), Intraoperative after insufflation will be measured with the following formula in the specified periods. MP = 0.098 x minute ventilation x [Peak inspiratory pressure - 0.5 x (Plateau pressure - Positive end-expiratory pressure)]

[/INST] The study "Evaluation of Magnetic Resonance Imaging as Alternative to Cone Beam Computed Tomography for the Assessment of Furcation Involvement in Molars" is a comparative study that aims to evaluate the use of MRI as an alternative to CBCT for the assessment of furcation involvement in molars. The study will include patients with FI grade II or III who need a CBCT and who are not pregnant. The study will use MRI to assess horizontal furcation defects according to Hamp 1975 and horizontal and vertical bone loss. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will be designed as a randomized controlled trial. The study will compare the results obtained from MRI to those obtained from CBCT. The study will use MRI as an alternative to CBCT for the assessment of furcation involvement in molars.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the plaque removal efficacy of electric and manual toothbrushes in children with ADHD and healthy children. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, with assessments conducted at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months. The primary outcome measure is the gingival index, while the secondary outcome measures are the Turesky modification of the Quigley-Hein Plaque Index, Approximal Plaque Index, and DMFT and dft indices. The study will also assess nutrition, diet, and tooth brushing habits of children and sociodemographic factors through a questionnaire.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, single-arm, open-label, non-randomized, multi-center study to investigate the feasibility and stability of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) for ventricular pacing in symptomatic bradycardia patients with a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead. The study will enroll 120 consecutive patients while considering a 20% dropout rate, an approximate sample size of 150 patients is needed. The study will use the Solia S lead with any BIOTRONIK Pacemaker Model: Solia S45/S53/S60 Manufacturer: BIOTRONIK SE & Co. KG. The study will evaluate the overall success rate of the implanted system, including Solia ventricular lead to sense and deliver pacing at 12-month post-implant. The study will also evaluate the changes of the left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), left atrial (LA), and left ventricular (LV) chamber size, tissue Doppler global longitudinal strain (GLS) from baseline.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the effectiveness of four different types of toothbrushes in reducing gingival inflammation in pregnant women. The four types of toothbrushes are: a sonic electric toothbrush, a hydrosonic toothbrush, a manual toothbrush with 5460 strands, and a manual toothbrush. The study will measure the incidence of gingival bleeding from baseline during pregnancy, as well as the effect on gingival bleeding, gingival inflammation, dental plaque, gingival attachment, periodontal pocket, and customer satisfaction score. The study will be conducted over a period of three months, with measurements taken at baseline, and at one and three months after the start of the study. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of yoga-based breathing styles on the human brain, with a focus on memory performance. Participants will complete a memory test while performing controlled nasal and oral breathing. They will complete a two-week training period after the test with daily nasal or mouth breathing training or no training at all, depending on the group assignment. The study will compare the nasal breathing group to the mouth breathing and the comparison group to see if the nasal breathing results in a significant improvement of the memory capacity.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of calisthenics exercises and pulsed electromagnetic therapy on liver function in patients with burn injuries. The study will include 120 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: a control group, a calisthenics exercise group, a pulsed electromagnetic therapy group, and a calisthenics exercise and pulsed electromagnetic therapy group. The study will use the following outcome measures: concentration of Alanine transaminase (ALT) and Aspartate transaminase (AST) enzymes in blood plasma. The study will be conducted over a period of three months.

[/INST] The Effects of an Oncology Tailored Nutritional Intervention on the Bioavailability and Immune-activity of PD-1 Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors in Patients With Lung Cancer is a feasibility study that aims to investigate the variability of clearance during a 12-weeks nutritional intervention period. The study will also investigate the feasibility for the subjects to comply with the study protocol and the feasibility of data collection. The study will enroll 50 patients with non-small cell lung cancer who are receiving anti-PD-1 treatment. The nutritional intervention will consist of two 200 mL bottles of study product per day. Blood for pharmacokinetic analysis and biomarker analysis will be withdrawn in a 5 mL serum tube. The primary outcome measure is the variability of clearance of pembrolizumab during a 12-weeks nutritional intervention period in NSCLC patients receiving anti-PD-1 treatment. The secondary outcome measures are the feasibility of recruiting 50 patients in 1.5 year for this study, the feasibility for the subjects to comply with the study protocol, and the feasibility of data collection.

[/INST] The study is a multi-omics big data analysis project that aims to explore the association between intestinal microbiota and cardiovascular and nervous system diseases. The project will collect blood and stool samples from patients with cardiovascular and neurological diseases and healthy individuals. The samples will be subjected to genome, transcriptome, metagenomic, metabolomic, and metaproteomic sequencing. The project will use machine learning methods to analyze the data and construct predictive models for early disease prevention and diagnosis. The study will contribute to the understanding of the mechanisms of cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial with two parallel groups, with an allocation ratio of 1:1. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of dietary counselling promoting adherence to the MedDiet as an adjuvant treatment of MDD, in adults diagnosed with MDD and elevated inflammation biomarkers. The main objective of the trial is to assess the effectiveness of dietary counselling promoting adherence to the MedDiet in decreasing depressive symptoms in adults diagnosed with MDD and elevated inflammation biomarkers. The study will use the BDI-II scale to measure changes in symptoms of MDD. The study will also measure inflammation biomarkers (IL-6 and/or CRP) to identify statistically significant variation of IL-6 and/or CRP concentrations in blood between baseline and other moments of assessment.

[/INST] The study is a community-based participatory research to support refugee parenting and improve family mental health in Tijuana, Mexico. The study will use a participatory research model to convene focus groups with community stakeholders to prioritize 3-5 parenting skills. Participants will be recruited and divided into 8 groups of 15. All participants will vote for 1-2 interventions from a list of 5 to revise and adapt to the local context through small group discussions and consensus building. Participants will complete baseline questionnaires anonymously. Half of the participants (Group 1, N=60) will be randomized to receive the adapted learning curriculum in groups of 15, twice a week for 4 weeks. At the conclusion of month 3, all participants will complete the same questionnaires as pre-intervention. These data will serve as post-intervention data for Group 1 and a second baseline for the remaining participants (Group 2). During month 3, Group 2 will receive a two-page handout on childhood nutrition in Spanish. They will serve as the control group for the first wave of intervention. Month 4: Group 2 will receive the same intervention as group 1 in month 3. At the conclusion of month 4, participants will complete the same questionnaires as pre-intervention. They will also complete open-ended feedback interviews. Month 5: Researchers will analyze all anonymous data and share preliminary results with the community through peer leaders. Month 6-7: Researchers will conduct a phone follow-up for all available participants (2 months post intervention) and collect data anonymously. Month 8: Researchers will again analyze the aggregate data and share results with the community. Month 9: Researchers will draft a manuscript, share final results with the community and nonprofit/academic partners.

[/INST] The study is a qualitative study that aims to understand and identify priorities for improving the healthcare experiences of people with incurable head and neck cancer (HNC) and their families. The study will involve interviews with patients and family carers, focus groups with healthcare professionals, and co-design workshops. The study will use a framework approach to analyse the data and identify key themes and priorities for improving the healthcare experiences of people with incurable HNC and their families.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of fluorescence imaging with indocyanine green (ICG) in endoscopic spinal surgery. The study will compare the use of ICG with no intervention or placebo in patients undergoing endoscopic spinal surgery for disc herniation. The primary outcome measure is the fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, and the secondary outcome measures include the fluorescence signal ratio of nerve root to back fluorescence, time taken to find the nerve root endoscopically, ICG-related adverse reactions, visual analogue pain scale (VAS) score, Oswestry disability index (ODI) score, surgical complications, length of surgery, and other terms related to the study. The study will be conducted in a single center and will enroll 120 patients. The study will evaluate the efficacy of ICG in endoscopic spinal surgery and provide evidence for the use of ICG in spinal surgery.

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of a home-based parenting support program called Parenting Young Children (PYC) for parents with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDDs). The program is designed to support parents in developing parenting skills and improving their relationship with their children. The program consists of structured coaching sessions lasting at least six months. The primary outcome measure is the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM), which assesses the performance and satisfaction of parents in their parenting role. The secondary outcome measures are the Parental Sense of Competence Scale (PSOC) and the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ), which assess parenting competence and child well-being, respectively. The study will compare the effectiveness of PYC to treatment as usual (TAU) provided by the social services. The study will be conducted in Sweden and will include 30 parents with IDDs. The study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of PYC and its potential to improve parenting skills and child well-being among parents with IDDs.

[/INST] The study is a prospective registry of patients undergoing surgery for male stress urinary incontinence. The study will collect information on patient characteristics, including age, weight, length, previous urological surgeries and other surgeries in the pelvic area, radiotherapeutic treatment of the prostate, and other co-morbidities. The surgical procedure for treatment of male stress urinary incontinence is according to standard practice. The patients will fill in the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire (ICIQ) Urinary Incontinence (UI) Short Form (ICIQ-UI Questionnaire SF), the EuroQol Group Questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) for the evaluation of the impact of incontinence on Quality of Life, and the Sexual Complaints Screener for Men (SCS-M), the Dyadic Adjustment Scale Italian version (DAS), the International Index of Erectile Function Questionnaire (IIEF-15) and the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) questionnaire before the operation, at 12 weeks after surgery and at yearly intervals up to and including year 5. The results of questionnaires will be entered into the database.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study that aims to collect blood samples, heart tissue, and clinical data from heart failure patients eligible for cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) and a control group of heart failure patients on medical therapy. The study will assess the patients at inclusion, 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months after CRT implantation or medical treatment. The study will analyze proteins, exosomal miRNA, and endothelial function in the blood samples and proteins, RNA, and contractility in the heart tissue. The study aims to identify biomarkers that can separate CRT responders from non-responders and identify biomarkers that can predict CRT response.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of vericiguat in heart failure patients who are intolerable to guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT). The study will compare the outcomes of patients who are intolerable to GDMT and those who are tolerable to GDMT. The primary outcome measure is all-cause mortality or worsening heart failure in 180 days. The secondary outcome measures are change in symptoms and signs of heart failure, change in N-terminal pro-B type natriuretic peptide, change in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), change in left ventricular end-diastolic diameter (LVEDD), change in left ventricular end-systolic diameter (LVESD), change in left ventricular fractional shortening (LVFS), change in systolic and diastolic blood pressures, change in blood potassium, and other terms related to the study.

[/INST] The study is titled "Behavioral Economic Strategies to Improve PRO Adherence" and is a randomized controlled trial with a three-arm design. The study aims to improve patient-reported outcome (PRO) adherence in patients with cancer receiving systemic cancer therapy. The study will test the effectiveness of behavioral economic strategies, including patient reminders and triage nurse alerts, to improve PRO adherence. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of expected PRO questionnaires completed per patient, and the secondary outcome measures include the percentage of patients with at least one note documenting PROs during the study period, the percentage of patients with at least one note documenting PROs per month during the study period, time to alert response (for arms 2 and 3 only), percentage of patients who trigger an alert for triage nurses (for arms 2 and 3 only), acute care utilization, treatment delays/modifications, and duration of therapy. The study will be conducted over a 3-month period.

[/INST] The ProgESC Study is a cross-sectional prospective study that aims to assess the level of prognostic awareness among patients with advanced cancer referred to the Enhanced Supportive Care (ESC) team at University College London Hospital. The study will also evaluate the relationship between patients' prognostic awareness and levels of psychological distress, quality of life, trust in medical professionals, and perceived quality of care. The study will use the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire to assess patients' prognostic awareness. The study will include 100 patients aged 18 and older with advanced cancer referred to the ESC team. The study will exclude patients who are younger than 18 years, have insufficient English language to complete questionnaires, have cognitive impairment, or are considered inappropriate to participate by the ESC team. The study will assess patients' prognostic understanding, perceived value of prognostic information, and other aspects of perceived quality of care. The study will use univariable and multivariable regression analyses to evaluate associations between sociodemographic or clinical variables and outcomes. The study will be the first prospective study to assess prognostic awareness among cancer patients referred to ESC services in a British setting. Identifying covariates for prognostic unawareness and psychological burden among patients with advanced cancer will inform the future development of strategies to improve care and communication with this patient group.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effect of direct-from-blood bacterial testing using the T2Bacteria® Panel to usual care on antibiotic administration and clinical outcomes in patients with bloodstream infections. The primary outcome is the time to last dose of intravenous vancomycin, and the secondary outcome is the time to last dose of systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic. The study is a pragmatic trial with parallel group assignment and open-label design. Patients are randomized to receive either direct-from-blood testing using the T2Bacteria® Panel or usual care, which includes blood cultures and intravenous vancomycin. The study is designed to evaluate the effect of direct-from-blood bacterial testing on antibiotic administration and clinical outcomes in patients with bloodstream infections.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of temperature-elevating armbaths in people with arterial hypertension. The study will include 50 participants who will be randomized to either an intervention group or a waitlist control group. The intervention group will be instructed to perform temperature-elevating armbaths for 8 weeks, while the control group will continue their treatment as usual. The primary outcome measure will be blood pressure, which will be measured at the beginning of the trial, after 8 weeks, and after 6 months. The secondary outcome measures will be health-related quality of life, sleep quality, heart rate, adverse events, changes in medication, and blood pressure after 8 weeks and 6 months. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study protocol has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of acupuncture on perceived stress and health in military service members and veterans. The study will compare the effects of manual standardized stress acupuncture (MSSA) and mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on perceived stress and health in military service members and veterans. The study will use a parallel assignment design and will be conducted over a period of four weeks. The study will use a mixed methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative measures. The quantitative measures will include the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS), the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI), and the Short Form (SF) Health Survey. The qualitative measures will include journal entries and focus groups. The study will be conducted in the United States and will include 120 participants who are active duty service members or veterans. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will be led by a team of researchers with expertise in acupuncture, mindfulness-based stress reduction, and clinical research. The study will be funded by the Department of Defense.

[/INST] The study is a prevalence study of persistent COVID-19 in Punta Arenas, Magallanes, and the Chilean Antarctic Region. The study will determine the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in a cohort of patients in Punta Arenas. The study will also assess the psychological profiles, sleep quality and disorders, standard laboratory parameters, inflammatory biomarkers, immunological repertoire associated with persistent COVID-19, and function of the musculoskeletal system of the patients. The study will use a cross-sectional design and will collect data through questionnaires, laboratory tests, and physical examinations. The study will recruit 100 participants aged 18 years or older who have had at least one positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-qPCR test from the COVID-19 database maintained by the SEREMI of Health in Punta Arenas between July 2022 and July 2023. The study will collect data at baseline and at 3, 6, and 8 months after enrollment. The study will use the Beck Anxiety Scale (BAI), D2-R test of attention, Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS), Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), COVID-19 related stress questionnaire based on the Perceived Stress Scale, normal activities and work productivity questionnaire, daily diaries, full blood count, serum chemistry test, interleukin-8 (IL-8), interleukin-1β (IL-1β), interleukin-6 (IL-6), interleukin-10 (IL-10), tumor necrosis factor (TNF), interleukin-12 (IL-12p70), DNA sequencing results, flow cytometry immunophenotyping, fatigue assessment scale (FAS), body composition analysis assessment, hand grip strength test, and maximum inspiratory pressure test (MIP test) to assess the outcomes of the study. The study will be conducted in Punta Arenas, Magallanes, and the Chilean Antarctic Region. The study will be conducted from July 2022 to July 2023.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial that compares the incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) at 24 hours from the occurrence of uncomplicated dural puncture (UDP) between two groups of obstetric patients. The first group receives an intrathecal catheter placement, while the second group receives a resiting epidural catheter after a UDP has occurred. The study also evaluates the intensity of PDPH at 24 and 48 hours from the occurrence of UDP, the quality of analgesia during labor, and the incidence of chronic pain at 1 and 3 months from UDP. The study also evaluates the number of unsuccessful attempts at placing the epidural or subarachnoid catheter, motor block, poor analgesia, caesarean section rate, and the incidence of chronic headache and chronic low back pain at 1 and 3 months from UDP. The study also evaluates the number of emergency room visits or hospital readmissions due to neurological symptoms related or possibly related to PDPH, and patient satisfaction. The study is conducted in Italy and is currently in the recruiting phase.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of two different matrix systems, a sectional matrix and a circumferential matrix, in restoring Class II cavities. The study is conducted on patients with tooth decay and good general health, aged 18 years or older, with fully erupted occluding premolar and molar teeth. The study is designed to have two groups, with one group receiving the sectional matrix and the other group receiving the circumferential matrix. The study is double-blind, with both the patients and the assessors being blinded to the group allocation. The primary outcome measure is the tightness of the proximal contact, which is assessed immediately after the procedure using dental floss. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is titled "Partners in Wellness: Evaluation of a Pay for Performance Program for High-Utilizers of Mental Health Services" and is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a pay for performance program in reducing the utilization of mental health services among high utilizers. The study is conducted in Santa Clara County, California, and involves 1,000 participants who are randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group receives the pay for performance program, while the control group receives usual care. The primary outcome measure is the total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services, and the secondary outcome measures include the total cost of acute psychiatric inpatient care, emergency psychiatric services, contract hospital, crisis residential facility, transitional residential care, residential care facility, institutes of mental disease, custody health, and incarceration. The study is ongoing and is expected to be completed in June 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of Culturally adapted Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CaCBT) and Culturally adapted Family Intervention (CulFI) compared to TAU in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with FEP in Pakistan. The study will include 390 participants with FEP from psychiatric units of hospitals in ten centres (i.e. Karachi, Lahore, Rawalpindi, Hyderabad, Qambar Shahdakot, Shaheed Benazirabad, Sukkur, Peshawar, Quetta and Multan). Consented participants meeting eligibility criteria will be randomised in a 1:1:1 allocation to CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU or TAU alone. Participants in CaCBT intervention group will receive 12-weekly one-to-one sessions. Participants in CulFI group will receive 10-weekly one-to-one sessions. Each CaCBT and CulFI session will last for approximately 1 hour. Sessions will be delivered by trained psychologists who will receive regular weekly supervision to maintain fidelity. Assessments will be carried out at baseline, months 3, 6, and 12 by trained, blinded assessors. Process evaluation will help to build the implementation knowledge base for proposed interventions across study settings. We will conduct economic evaluations (i.e., the cost-effectiveness and cost-utility analyses) of the CaCBT and CulFI interventions, as add-on to TAU.

[/INST] The study is a phase 1/2 clinical trial of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 bispecific CAR T cell therapy, in patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The study has two phases: a phase 1 dose escalation phase and a phase 2 expansion phase. The primary objective of the phase 1 dose escalation phase is to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of IMPT-314. The primary objective of the phase 2 expansion phase is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314 at the RP2D. The study will enroll patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma who have received at least one prior line of therapy. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, including the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs), overall response rate (ORR), complete response rate (CRR), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and duration of response (DOR).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of metabolic syndrome and its components on cognitive performance and physical activity level in middle-aged individuals. The study will include two groups: a group of individuals diagnosed with metabolic syndrome and a control group of healthy individuals. The study will assess cognitive performance using the MoCA, Stroop Test TBAG Form, Mini Mental State Examination, and evaluation of physical performance using the International Physical Activity Questionnare Short-Form and pedometer. The study will also evaluate metabolic syndrome severity score, waist circumference, blood pressure, triglyceride, HDL-C, fasting plasma level, and monreal cognitive assessment. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effectiveness of two brief digital interventions to increase vaccine uptake among adults with anxiety or depressive symptoms. The interventions are attitudinal inoculation, cognitive-behavioral therapy-informed intervention, and conventional public health messaging. The study will recruit undervaccinated participants with and without symptoms of anxiety or depression from the CHASING COVID Cohort, a large and geographically diverse community-based US cohort. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three intervention arms at a ratio of 1:1:1. The primary outcome is self-reported receipt of a COVID vaccine dose by 4 weeks post-intervention. The secondary outcomes are vaccine hesitancy post-intervention and self-reported receipt of a COVID vaccine dose by 6 months post-intervention. The study will use risk ratios to estimate and compare the proportion of participants in each arm who achieved the outcomes. The study will adjust for differences in measured pre-baseline variables to address potential imbalances and conduct a mediation analysis to better understand the intervention's mechanisms of action.

[/INST] The study examined the effects of binaural beat music on sleep quality, heart rate variability, and depression in older people with poor sleep quality in a long-term care institution. The study was a randomized controlled trial with two parallel arms: a binaural beat music group and a control group. The binaural beat music group listened to music with binaural beats embedded for 12 times over two weeks, while the control group listened to music without binaural beats embedded for the same amount of time. The primary outcome measure was the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), and the secondary outcome measures were heart rate variability and the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS). The study found that the binaural beat music group had significantly better sleep quality and heart rate variability than the control group, but there was no significant difference in depression.

[/INST] The study is a mixed methods implementation science study that aims to develop an understanding of the barriers and facilitators of a high level of fidelity that is sustainable for use by patients and health care providers. The study will evaluate the acceptability, safety, and sustainability of a personalised follow-up pathway for head and neck cancer patients. The study will use semi-structured interviews and cross-sectional surveys to collect qualitative and quantitative data from patients and healthcare providers. The study will also use focus groups to collect qualitative data from healthcare providers. The study will collect data on the acceptability of the pathway, the resources and the transition of care away from the 5-year follow-up pathway. The study will also collect data on the acceptability of the pathway, the resources and the protocol. The study will collect data on the experience of patients and healthcare providers within the personalised follow-up pathway. The study will also collect data on the barriers and facilitators that will influence the sustainability of this pathway, within the institution. The study will collect data on the safety of a personalised follow-up pathway within head and neck cancer. The study will collect data on the patient experience within the personalised follow-up pathway. The study will collect data on the service provider experience within the personalised follow-up pathway. The study will collect data on the sustainability of the personalised follow-up pathway.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the effects of intrathecal bupivacaine-dexmedetomidine and intrathecal bupivacaine-neostigmine in patients undergoing elective cesarean section.
