[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the performance of an air-polishing device in preventing white spot lesions (WSLs) and gingivitis among patients undergoing multi-bracketed fixed orthodontic treatment. The study will compare the air-polishing device with a conventional ultrasonic device in preventing WSLs and gingivitis during orthodontic treatment. The study will involve 60 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the air-polishing device or the conventional ultrasonic device group. The air-polishing device will be used every month, while the conventional ultrasonic device will be used every six months. The study will evaluate the prevalence of WSLs using the Quantitative light-induced fluorescence (QLF) method, gingivitis using standard clinical parameters, and the antimicrobial efficacy against several known periodontal pathogens and the host-response (inflammatory markers in GCF) will be measured by the qPCR assay and the multiplex immunoassay, respectively. The study will also evaluate patient acceptance, tooth sensitivity, total bacterial counts, and counts of six periodontal pathogens in subgingival samples from treated pockets, changes from baseline in clinical parameters, inflammatory markers in GCF from baseline, and treatment time. The study will last for two years.

[/INST] The Atrial Fibrillation Driver Study is a pilot project that aims to obtain tissue samples from patients undergoing cardiac or thoracic surgery and analyze them histologically and molecularly to study the role of atrial fibrosis in atrial fibrillation. The study will enroll up to 10 patients, including those with no history of atrial fibrillation, paroxysmal, and persistent atrial fibrillation. The tissue samples will be analyzed using immunohistochemistry, in situ hybridization, electron microscopy, collagen cross-linking, genome sequencing, miRNA and RNA sequencing, culture, RT-PCR, flow cytometry, and immunocytochemistry. The study will provide valuable insights into the role of atrial fibrosis in atrial fibrillation and potentially lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for this common and costly arrhythmia.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the effects of integrated and isolated resisted exercise on strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners. The study is conducted over 8 weeks and involves two groups of participants: one group performing integrated resisted exercises and the other group performing isolated resisted exercises. The primary outcome measures are endurance (sit-up test), power (vertical jump test), and strength (1RM maximum). The study is conducted in a gym setting and the exercises are designed to progress in difficulty over the 8-week training program. The study is expected to provide valuable information on the most effective training methods for improving strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of play-based therapy and functional communication training in children with speech and language delay. The study will enroll children aged 2-6 years with a comorbidity of behavioral disorder, autism, and ADHD. The study will use the Portage Guide to Early Education as the assessment tool for speech and language delay. The study will compare the effectiveness of play-based therapy and functional communication training in improving speech and language delay in children. The study will use the Speech Questionnaire as the assessment tool for speech and language delay. The study will compare the effectiveness of play-based therapy and functional communication training in improving speech and language delay in children. The study will use the Speech Questionnaire as the assessment tool for speech and language delay. The study will compare the effectiveness of play-based therapy and functional communication training in improving speech and language delay in children.

[/INST] The study is titled "Horyzons: Implementation and Integration in Clinical Practice" and is a mixed-methods study that aims to assess the barriers and facilitators of integrating a digital intervention, Horyzons, in outpatient mental health clinics in North Carolina. The primary objective is to assess the barriers and facilitators of integrating Horyzons, an evidence-based digital intervention, in outpatient mental health clinics in North Carolina that provide care to individuals with schizophrenia spectrum and other unspecified psychotic disorders. The primary aim is to evaluate and identify the unique barriers and facilitators in implementing Horyzons at each first episode psychosis (FEP) clinic as part of standard care and distinct implementation strategies. The secondary and tertiary aims are to evaluate client engagement with Horyzons and attrition as part of clinical care and assess the change in clients' psychological measures across in addition to their use of state-funded services (e.g., emergency department and social services) across the 12-month intervention. The study will recruit 20 clinicians and/or peer specialists from the FEP clinics and 50 individuals with FEP (i.e., first episode of a schizophrenia spectrum and other unspecified psychotic disorders). The study will assess the primary outcome measure, which is a qualitative summary of provider and peer support specialists (PSSs) participant feedback in post-treatment interview, and the secondary outcome measure, which is a quantitative summary of provider and PSS participant experience in post-treatment feedback. The study will also assess changes in engagement with Horyzons, changes in use of emergency and social services, and psychological measures across the 12-month intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

[/INST] The study is a phase I, open-label, non-randomized clinical trial to test the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of intravitreal single rising doses and multiple doses of BI 771716 in patients with geographic atrophy secondary to age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The study will enroll patients with GA secondary to AMD, with any GA lesion of minimum 1 disc diameter (minimum 2.5 mm2) in size, and unlimited maximum size. The study will have four experimental arms: BI 771716 low dose treatment group (single rising dose (SRD) part), BI 771716 treatment group (multiple dose (MD) part), BI 771716 medium dose treatment group (SRD part), and BI 771716 high dose treatment group (SRD part). The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of ocular dose-limiting events (DLEs) from drug administration until Day 8 in the SRD part, and the occurrence of drug-related adverse events (AEs) from drug administration until end of study (EOS) in the MD part. The secondary outcome measures are the occurrence of any ocular AEs in the study eye from drug administration until EOS in the SRD part, maximum serum concentration of BI 771716 after a single intravitreal (IVT) dose (Cmax) in the SRD part, area under the concentration-time curve of BI 771716 in serum over the time interval from 0 extrapolated to infinity (AUC0-∞) in the SRD part, time from dosing to maximum serum concentration of BI 771716 (tmax) in the SRD part, trough concentration of BI 771716 in serum in the MD part, and BI 771716 serum concentration in the MD part.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of furosemide-induced diuresis with matched dehydration to standard diuretic therapy in patients with acute heart failure and overt fluid overload. The study will use the RenalGuard device to deliver replacement fluid in an amount matched to the volume of urine produced by the patient. The primary outcome measure is daily serum creatinine measurement during study treatment for assessment of acute kidney injury occurrence. The secondary outcome measure is daily weight decrease during study treatment.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study to determine the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a self-guided mindfulness-based intervention in pediatric patients with idiopathic chest pain. The study will randomize 30 participants aged 12-18 years with idiopathic chest pain to either the standard of care control group or the mindfulness-based intervention group. The primary outcome measures are participant recruitment rate, retention rate, and mindfulness-based intervention program adherence. The secondary outcome measures are pain coping strategies, perceived stress, patient quality of life, and frequency and intensity of chest pain episodes. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Val-de-Suzanne in Switzerland.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2, randomized, double-blind, non-inferiority trial to evaluate the safety and immunogenicity of concomitant administration of the Novavax vaccine and a 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine in adults aged ≥60 years. The study will have four arms: an active comparator arm receiving the Novavax vaccine plus placebo, an active comparator arm receiving the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine plus placebo, an experimental arm receiving the Novavax vaccine plus the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, and a placebo comparator arm receiving placebo plus placebo. The study will enroll adults aged ≥60 years who are able and willing to comply with all study requirements, have received three COVID-19 vaccines, of which the third was a mRNA vaccine (BNT162b2 or mRNA-1273), and at least 16 weeks ago. The primary outcome measure is the immunogenicity of the Novavax vaccine, which will be assessed by measuring the antibody levels on day 28. The study will be conducted in the United States and is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/II trial of the combination of durvalumab and rintatolimod in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer. The primary objective of the phase I part of the study is to determine the recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of the combination of durvalumab and rintatolimod. The primary objective of the phase II part of the study is to determine the clinical benefit rate (CBR) of the combination of durvalumab and rintatolimod. The study will also explore the immunogenic effect of the combination of durvalumab and rintatolimod on the circulating and infiltrating immune profile.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blinded, and placebo-controlled clinical trial. The main objective is to analyze the potential effects of supplementation with the flavonoid diosmin on DOMS in humans. The study will consist of two experimental groups, made up of healthy individuals, who will perform an intense dynamic exercise protocol, as follows: 1) control group that will receive placebo supplementation (corn starch tablets at a concentration of 750 mg); and 2) intervention group that will receive supplementation with diosmin (tablets at a concentration of 750 mg). Treatment of study participants will occur orally, and everyone will ingest identical opaque capsules containing placebo or diosmin with water. The treatment protocol will be applied before the start (pre-treatment) of the intense dynamic exercise sessions, once a day, during the two days before, and on the day (immediately before) the execution of the exercise protocol. The primary outcome measure is muscle soreness, which will be evaluated by both digital algometer (in kilograms force; Kgf) and visual analogue (VAS) scale (in centimeters; cm), where 0 represents no pain and 10 the worst possible pain. The secondary outcome measures are muscle tissue damage through the evaluation of the creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels, plasmatic lipid peroxidation levels, plasmatic total antioxidant status, recovery of muscle function through the evaluation of the average and maximum torque of the knee extension for determining quadriceps strength (maximum voluntary isometric contraction; MVIC), recovery of muscle function through vertical jump height, bipedal and single-legged (unipedal) postural balance. The study will be conducted in Brazil.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study using the Netherlands CP register to collect data over a period of 4.5 years. The primary outcome measure is goal attainment scaling (GAS) in which achievement of individual goals can be quantified. Secondary outcome measures include: patient characteristics, treatment history, range of motion, spasticity, dystonia, scoliosis, selectivity, functional strength, gait analysis, questionnaires on activities and participation, treatment characteristics ITB including dosage, complications. A linear mixed-model analysis will be used to determine the development over time for the primary and secondary outcome measures, using time as a categorical variable. All analyses will be adjusted for possible covariates. Effect size (ES) Cohen's d will be calculated for all outcome measures. Univariable linear regression analysis for each potential variable influencing outcome will be conducted. Factors showing a p-value of ≤0.20 are then selected for input in a final model in which a multiple regression analysis using backward stepwise selection will be performed to identify the predicting factors. A p-value < 0.05 is considered statistically significant. Correction for multiple testing will be done by Holm correction of p-values.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on the risk of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) among high-risk pregnant women with low vitamin D levels. The study will be conducted in Pakistan and will include pregnant women with 7-11 weeks of gestation. The participants will be randomly assigned to receive either vitamin D supplementation (200,000 IU/week) for 4-6 weeks or placebo until delivery. The primary outcome of the study will be the incidence of GDM based on the International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups criteria after 75 g oral glucose tolerance test. The study will contribute to the understanding of the relationship between vitamin D and GDM risk through a well-designed randomized controlled trial with integrated approaches. The findings may inform clinical practice and public health recommendations for vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, multicenter, single-arm, open-label study to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Neuroguard IEP® Direct System for the treatment of carotid artery stenosis in subjects at elevated risk for adverse events following carotid endarterectomy (CEA). The study is being conducted in 10 centers in France. The study population will consist of subjects greater than or equal to 20 years of age and less than or equal to 80 years of age, who have been diagnosed with either de-novo atherosclerotic or post CEA restenotic lesion(s) in the internal carotid arteries (ICA) or at the carotid bifurcation with greater than or equal to 50% stenosis if symptomatic or greater than or equal to 70% stenosis if asymptomatic. The study will evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Neuroguard IEP Direct System for the treatment of carotid artery stenosis in subjects at elevated risk for adverse events following carotid endarterectomy (CEA). The study will evaluate the 30-day rate of Major Adverse Events (MAE), defined as the cumulative incidence of all stroke, myocardial infarction (MI) and death within 30 days of the index procedure.

[/INST] The study is a pilot trial conducted as a two-arm, parallel, single-blind, randomized controlled trial. The intervention group will receive supervised Nordic walking training and will be coached to practice independently. The control group will receive regular phone calls to discuss healthy lifestyle habits. The primary outcome measure is the effect size of the intervention, and the secondary outcome measures are adherence rate to the intervention, safety of the intervention, Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, Fear of Falling: FES-I, and Performance on the Four-Square Step Test (FSST). The study aims to test the feasibility and safety of the intervention, determine the distribution and effect sizes of outcomes to inform future sample size calculations, and explore participants' perspectives of the intervention.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a web-based intervention program for sexual and gender minority (SGM) youth. The program is designed to provide information and resources to SGM youth and their families, as well as to connect them with mental health services. The study will compare the effectiveness of the intervention program to a waitlist control group. The study will also examine the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention program.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficacy of propofol and remifentanil mixed solution for controlled analgesia and sedation in fiber colonoscopy with intravenous combined anesthesia. The study includes 100 patients who are scheduled for fiber colonoscopy. Patients are randomly assigned to either the controlled analgesia/sedation (PCAS) group or the intravenous combined anesthesia group. In the PCAS group, patients are given a loading dose of 3 ml of the mixed solution, followed by a continuous infusion of the mixture at a rate of 0.1 ml/kg/h. The examination can begin after the loading dose is completed. During the procedure, patients can press the self-control handle according to their sensation, with each press quickly pushing 1 ml of the medication. In the intravenous combined anesthesia group, patients are given intravenous slow infusion of fentanyl, midazolam, and propofol. The primary outcome measure is the auditory evoked potential (AEPI) before anesthesia, at the beginning of the examination, during endoscopy to the splenic curvature, ileocecal region, and at the end of the examination. The secondary outcome measure is the time from after surgery to OAA/S score reached 5 and Aldrete score reached 9.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, observational, confirmatory, single-center study in predicting the chronicization of radiation-induced acute intestinal injury based on the expression level of immune factors. The eligible patients who voluntarily sign the consent form will undergo NCRT and TME according to treatment guidelines. The primary outcome is the AUC of chronicization of RAII predicted by the prediction model. The secondary outcomes are accuracy, precision, specificity, and sensitivity of this prediction model in predicting chronicization of RAII.

[/INST] The Omicron BA.4/5-Delta COVID-19 Vaccine Phase I Clinical Trial is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study designed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and above. The study will assess the incidence of adverse events (AEs) and serious adverse events (SAEs) within 12 months after vaccination, as well as the incidence of adverse events of special interest (AESIs) within 12 months after vaccination. The study will also assess the geometric mean titer (GMT) of SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibody 14 days after vaccination.

[/INST] The study is a single-arm trial evaluating the safety and performance of the SEPIOLA system in patients with atrial fibrillation. The SEPIOLA system is an implantable device that is placed in the left atrial appendage to prevent blood clots from entering the bloodstream. The study will enroll patients with atrial fibrillation who are at high risk of stroke and have a suitable anatomy for the device. The primary outcome measure is the safety of the device and the procedure, which will be assessed by monitoring adverse events for 6 months. The secondary outcome measure is device success, which will be assessed by confirming the functional closure of the left atrial appendage at 45 days.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of motivational interviewing (MI) in improving therapeutic alliance, treatment adherence, and symptom severity in patients with psychosis in the acute phase. The study will compare the effects of MI with those of supportive conversations. The study will use the Scale to Assess Therapeutic Relationship (STAR), the Brief Adherence Rating Scale (BARS), the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), the Questionnaire to Measure the Motivation for Psychotherapy, and the General Self-Efficacy Scale as outcome measures. The study will be conducted in the Psychiatric University Hospital of Zurich, Switzerland, and is expected to last for one year. The study will enroll 100 participants who meet the inclusion criteria and are willing to provide informed consent. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference on Harmonization Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice.

[/INST] The study is a prospective study that aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the BileCAD test for diagnosing biliary tract carcinoma. The test involves analyzing bile samples from patients with suspected biliary tract carcinoma using low-coverage whole-genome sequencing and bioinformatics techniques to detect chromosomal instability. The study will compare the results of the BileCAD test with the results of pathological diagnosis and microbial culture. The study will also evaluate the consistency of the BileCAD microbial analysis results with the clinical microbial culture results. The study will also evaluate the sensitivity of the BileCAD test for different types and locations of malignant tumors.

[/INST] The aim of this study is to determine whether the success of lumbar plexus block applied in lower extremity orthopedic surgeries can be evaluated by Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS), which is used to measure tissue oxygenation.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the use of a digital platform for supporting the clinical effectiveness and integration of a task-shared psychosocial rehabilitation intervention for patients with schizophrenia in primary care settings in India. The study will compare the effectiveness of a psychosocial rehabilitation intervention delivered through a digital platform (COPSI plus mindLAMP) with that of a psychosocial rehabilitation intervention delivered through a traditional method (COPSI alone). The study will also evaluate the integration of the digital platform into the existing healthcare system. The study will use a self-report measure of disability (Indian Disability Evaluation and Assessment Scale) and other self-report measures of symptoms and functioning to assess the effectiveness of the interventions. The study will be conducted in India and will involve 240 participants with schizophrenia. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months and will involve two phases: a feasibility phase and a main trial phase. The study will be conducted in collaboration with the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France and the National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences in India. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant institutional review boards.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of three levels of digital training for addiction professionals to maximize treatment rates of opioid use disorder in families. The three levels of training are digital tutorial only, digital tutorial plus training materials, and digital tutorial plus training materials plus feedback and coaching. The primary outcome is CRAFT procedure fidelity, measured via audiotaped sessions with a standardized patient, coded per the CRAFT Coding manual. The secondary outcomes are CRAFT knowledge and program implementation potential. The study will also measure new treatment entry, which is the proportion of participants reporting that their client's loved one entered new treatment.

[/INST] The study is a prospective multi-center observational study that aims to describe the pattern of regional myocardial distribution of 3,3-diphosphono-1,2-propanedicarboxylic acid (DPD) SPECT uptake among patients with ATTRwt and ATTRm. It will investigate the clinical, biochemical and echocardiographic, including left ventricle longitudinal strain profile in ATTRwt and ATTRm. Moreover, the study will evaluate the presence and extent of DPD cardiac uptake among asymptomatic ATTRm variants carriers. The study will include consecutive patients who have Grade 1-3 cardiac DPD retention in scintigraphy. In addition, first-degree relatives of patients with ATTRm are going to be enrolled. Patients are going to undergo TTR gene sequencing to assess the presence of pathogenic variants associated with ATTRm. Both planar scintigraphy, SPECT and speckle-tracking echocardiography will be reviewed and interpreted using visual and quantitative approaches. The collected data will be analyzed statistically to verify research hypotheses. Approval from the local Bioethical Committee will be obtained before carrying out the study. All procedures performed are going to be in accordance with the ethical standards of the 1964 Helsinki declaration and its later amendments, or comparable ethical standards.

[/INST] The study is a single-group assignment study that aims to investigate the long-term symptoms of COVID-19 in children. The study will involve laboratory tests, questionnaires, and physical examinations to identify the symptoms of long-term COVID-19 in children. The study will be conducted in children aged 6 to 18 years. The study will be conducted in Russia, but the number of participants and the specific methods used are not provided. The study will be conducted over a period of one year. The primary outcome measure of the study will be the number of participants with long-term COVID-19 symptoms. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Samara State Medical University.

[/INST] The study is titled "Preoperative Perturbation Training to Prevent Falls After Total Knee Arthroplasty" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of preoperative treadmill-based perturbation training in reducing the rate of falls in older adults undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA). The study will recruit 378 participants who are scheduled for primary unilateral TKA and can commit to 4 additional study visits. The study will randomize participants into two groups: the training group and the education group. The training group will undergo 4 sessions of treadmill-based perturbation training over 2 weeks, while the education group will receive fall prevention education materials. The primary outcome measure is post-training trunk angle and angular velocity at recovery step completion. The secondary outcome measure is the fall rate during the first year after surgery. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Val-des-Francs in Quebec, Canada. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a single center, prospective, (1:1) randomized, unblinded, controlled study carried out in Germany according to Art. 74 MDR (PMCF study) or according to Art. 82 MDR / § 47 Para. 3 MPDG. The study examines the visual performance of the trifocal Hanita Lenses Intensity SL IOL (study lens) compared to the trifocal Alcon PanOptix IOL (comparison lens) in bilaterally implanted patients. Clinical investigations including patient-reported results from the test group will be compared with those from the control group. A total of approximately 58 patients will be included at 1 clinical center. Subjects participating in the study will attend a maximum of 10 study visits (1 preoperative, 2 operative and up to 7 postoperative) over a period of 3-7 months. Only patients who have age-related cataracts will be included in the study. To participate in this study, patients must be at least 18 years old at the time of screening and a maximum preoperative corneal astigmatism of 1.0 D is permitted. All patients who would like to take part in this study will receive an information interview and further detailed study information in written form. Before a patient is admitted, he or she must sign a consent form. The primary study endpoint is to investigate whether the binocular distance-corrected visual acuity achieved with the study lens for the distance, intermediate and near ranges is not statistically significantly inferior to the parameters achieved with the control lens. The entire study including data processing will be carried out in accordance with EN ISO 14155:2020 Clinical Investigation of Medical Devices for Human Subjects, EN ISO 11979-7:2018: Clinical investigations of intraocular lenses for the correction of aphakia, EU MDR 2017/745, MEDDEV 2.7.1 rev. 4 Clinical Evaluation: A Guide for Manufacturers and Notified Bodies, MPDG:2020: Medical Device Law Implementation Act, as well as applicable local regulations and the Declaration of Helsinki.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective, observational, single-centre cohort database analysis of the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery. The study will be conducted at the Princess Royal Hospital, Haywards Heath, UK. The study population will include adult patients who have sustained a unilateral hip fracture and received surgery (hemiarthroplasty, dynamic hip screw, cortical screws, proximal femoral nail) under low dose spinal anaesthesia (1.3 mls 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine) after fascia iliaca block + sedation, administered by the Chief Investigator (CI) between 3rd March, 2017 and 1st January, 2020. The study will measure the cohort mean (SD) mean non-invasive blood pressure (MAP) during the 2 hour duration (approximately) of anaesthesia and surgery for each patient. The study will also measure the cohort prevalence of hypotension variably defined as: fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline > 20%; fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline > 30%; fall in mean arterial pressure (MAP) from baseline > 20%; fall in mean arterial pressure (MAP) from baseline > 30%; lowest SBP < 90 millimetres of mercury (mmHg); lowest SBP < 100 mmHg lowest MAP < 70 mmHg; lowest MAP < 55 mmHg. The study will also quantify the cohort depth x duration area under curve product for hypotension after low dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery. The study will also describe any effects of propofol sedation and local anaesthetic nerve block and the effective cohort duration of spinal anaesthesia including number of augmentatory anaesthetic interventions required in mean (SD) time from spinal administration to surgical skin closure. The study will also correlate individual (a) hypotension (b) hypotension depth/duration product and outcomes (death at 30 days, length of stay in hospital).

[/INST] The study is titled "COVID-19 Transmission and Morbidity in Malawi" and is a prospective cohort study that aims to investigate the role of malaria and intestinal parasitic diseases in COVID-19 transmission and morbidity. The study will enroll 200 symptomatic individuals (index cases) and their household contacts (anticipated 700), as well as up to 600 vaccinees. The study will assess the innate immune phenotypes that differentiate uninfected Malawians from Western controls and whether those responses are protecting Malawians from infection and/or progression of disease. The study will also follow infected participants and vaccinees for up to 1.5 years to assess acquisition and longevity of antibodies induced by natural infection and SARS-CoV-2 vaccines.

[/INST] The Effect of Hot-Cold Application to the Bladder After Orthopedic Surgery on Postoperative Urinary Retention is a clinical trial that aims to determine the effect of hot-cold application to the bladder on postoperative urinary retention in orthopedic surgery patients. The study is a single-blind randomized controlled trial with an experimental group that will receive a hot-cold application to the bladder and a control group that will receive routine clinical care. The primary outcome measure is the prevention of postoperative urinary retention by applying hot-cold to the bladder in the first 6 hours of the postoperative period. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France and is expected to be completed by 2023.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, multicenter study that aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of a deep-learning integrated model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features based on high-concentration (370 mgI/ml) Iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT obtained within 14 days after the first onset of symptoms for quantitative prediction of (the first) recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 12 months follow-up period. The study will enroll 694 consecutive eligible patients with first episode of acute pancreatitis that recommended for iopromide 370 mgI/ml enhanced pancreatic CT scan within 14 days after onset of symptoms. The primary outcome measure is the sensitivity and specificity of the model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features to quantitative predict the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 12 months follow-up period. The secondary outcome measures are the total number of subjects who developed the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis (subjects with multiple recurrences, calculated and analyzed according to the time of the earliest recurrence) within 3, 6 and 12 months, the sensitivity and specificity of the deep-learning integrated model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features to quantitative predict overall recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 3 and 6 months follow-up period, the image quality of Iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT images obtained within 14 days after onset of symptoms, and the sensitivity and specificity of the model determined by radiomics features extracted from images with high quality scores (2-3 points). The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on the polycythemia in patients with obstructive sleep apnea. The study will compare the change in hematocrit in patients with polycythemia who are treated with CPAP to those who are not treated with CPAP. The study will also assess the change in hemoglobin, health-related quality of life, and the relationship between hypoxic burden and hemoglobin and hematocrit.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the vaginal axis on MRI in patients undergoing apical prolapse surgery. The study will include three groups of patients: those undergoing lateral suspension, pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation. The primary outcome measure is the vaginal axis on MRI at 4 months after the operation. The secondary outcome measures include prolapse symptoms, urinary symptoms, sexual functions, and quality of life measures. The study will use MRI to assess the vaginal axis and prolapse symptoms. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study will be randomized and controlled, and the participants will be blinded to the treatment allocation. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal and presented at international conferences.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of simulation training in electronic fetal monitoring management of midwifery students. The study will compare the effectiveness of simulation training with traditional teaching methods in terms of information evaluation forms, student satisfaction and self-confidence scales in learning, and self-efficacy scales in monitoring and management of electronic fetal monitoring. The study will also evaluate the simulation design scale immediately after the first and second simulation applications. The study will be conducted in a university in France and will involve 68 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or control group. The experimental group will receive simulation training in electronic fetal monitoring management, while the control group will receive traditional teaching methods. The study will use a pre-test and post-test design to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention. The primary outcome measures will be information evaluation forms, student satisfaction and self-confidence scales in learning, and self-efficacy scales in monitoring and management of electronic fetal monitoring. The secondary outcome measures will be simulation design scale immediately after the first and second simulation applications. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis methods. The results of the study will contribute to the development of effective simulation training programs in electronic fetal monitoring management for midwifery students.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective cohort study that aims to determine the outcome and predictors of mortality in critically ill patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation. The study will be conducted in Dessie Comprehensive Specialized Hospital from August 2023 to January 2024. The study will include all charts of critically ill patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation in the hospital during the study period. The primary outcome measure is the clinical outcome of critically ill patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation. The study will use a bivariate and multivariate analysis to determine the predictors of mortality in critically ill patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation.

[/INST] The TAILOR PCI trial is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficacy and safety of two different antiplatelet strategies for reducing bleeding complications in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The first strategy is DAPT de-escalation, which involves switching from a potent P2Y12 inhibitor (prasugrel or ticagrelor) to clopidogrel while maintaining aspirin. The second strategy is potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy, which involves maintaining the potent P2Y12 inhibitor (prasugrel or ticagrelor) and dropping aspirin. The primary outcome measure is the area under the curve (AUC) of thrombus formation measured by the Total Thrombus formation Analysis System (T-TAS) at 30 days. The trial aims to determine which strategy is more effective in reducing bleeding complications while maintaining ischemic efficacy.

[/INST] The study titled "Investigating Age-dependent Effects of Egg Intake on HDL and Immune Profiles" is a randomized crossover trial that aims to investigate the effects of egg intake on lipoproteins and immune profiles in young and older adults. The study will compare the effects of egg white, egg yolk, and whole egg intake on lipoproteins and immune profiles in young and older adults. The study will also compare the effects of egg white, egg yolk, and whole egg intake on lipoproteins and immune profiles in young and older adults. The study will use a crossover design, with each participant serving as their own control. Participants will consume 3 large egg equivalents of egg white, egg yolk, or whole egg per day for 4 weeks each, with a 4-week washout period between each intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the change in serum concentration of large HDL particles between the egg-free run-in period and the end of each intervention arm.
