[/INST] The study is titled "A Patient-Driven Augmented Reality-Based Rehabilitation System to Improve Upper Limb Amputee Outcomes" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a rehabilitation system that uses augmented reality and myoelectric pattern recognition to improve upper limb amputee outcomes. The system consists of an augmented reality head-mounted display, four SteamVR kinematic trackers, eight surface EMG electrodes, and a desktop computer. The study will measure the time to complete the GaMA Cup Transfer Task, the percentage time spent in grasp phase relative to the entire movement, and the capacity for myoelectric controls. The study will also measure the completion rate of the GaMA Cup Transfer Task, the ability to coordinate two degrees of freedom, and wrist activation. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of gastric electrical stimulation (GES) in preventing postoperative ileus (POI) in patients undergoing extensive surgery for colorectal or appendiceal cancer. The study will compare the time to first stool and whole gut and regional transit times in patients who receive GES to those who do not. The study will also assess the length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, need for surgical or radiological interventions, re-hospitalization within 30 days, time till initiation of postoperative systemic adjuvant chemotherapy, and 90-day mortality. The study will use a gastric pacemaker to stimulate the stomach and promote bowel motility. The study will be conducted in Denmark and will include 100 patients. The study will be randomized and double-blinded. The primary outcome will be the time to first stool, and the secondary outcomes will be whole gut and regional transit times, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, need for surgical or radiological interventions, re-hospitalization within 30 days, time till initiation of postoperative systemic adjuvant chemotherapy, and 90-day mortality. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of aromatherapy and music therapy on pain, anxiety, and vital parameters in patients with palliative care. The study will be conducted in three groups: music therapy, aromatherapy, and control. The music therapy group will listen to relaxing music for 20 minutes, the aromatherapy group will inhale lavender oil for 15-20 minutes, and the control group will not receive any intervention. The study will be conducted for three consecutive days, and the effects of the interventions will be evaluated using visual analog scale, facial anxiety scale, distress thermometer, Edmonton symptom diagnostic scale, and vital parameters. The study will be conducted in the palliative care service of a hospital in France.

[/INST] The Somatosensation Device Trial is a non-randomized crossover study that aims to test the effectiveness of a somatosensation device in enhancing feedback in lower extremities. The study will include participants with below-knee amputation or neuropathy in their lower limbs. The primary outcome measure is the Functional Gait Assessment, which will be assessed at baseline and during the intervention. The secondary outcome measures include the 10 Meter Walk Test, Mini-BESTest, Activities Specific Balance Confidence Scale, and Vestibular Disorders Activities of Daily Living Scale. The study will be conducted in the United States and is expected to last for 1 year.

[/INST] The study is a decentralized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the OtoBand device in treating vertigo symptoms. The study will enroll 36 participants in the moderate or worse (MoW) arm and 72 participants in the quality of life (QoL) arm. Participants will be randomized to use the OtoBand device or a sham device. The study will measure the change in vertigo severity during vertigo episodes and the change in VSS scores. The study will also measure the effectiveness of the device in providing temporary relief from vertigo symptoms.

[/INST] The Multistrain Probiotic OMNi-BiOTiC® Active for Upper Respiratory Tract Infections in Older People is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a probiotic supplement in reducing the incidence and duration of upper respiratory tract infections (URTI) in older people. The study will compare the incidence and duration of URTI in older people who take the probiotic supplement with those who take a placebo. The study will also measure changes in the concentration of leukocytes, neutrophils segm., lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, basophils in serum, changes in concentration of Immunoglobulin A (IgA) in serum, and changes in the concentration of leukocytes, neutrophils segm., lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, basophils in serum.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of Gong's and Kaltenborn mobilization techniques in the treatment of Adhesive Capsulitis. The study will involve 40-60 participants aged between 40-60 years who will be randomly assigned to either Group A or Group B. Group A will receive Gong's mobilization, while Group B will receive Kaltenborn mobilization. Both groups will receive routine physical therapy, including 15 minutes of electrical muscle stimulation with heat therapy. The study will follow a single-blind design, with the assessor remaining unaware of the treatment group assignment. The study will have three data collection points: baseline, the end of 1.5 weeks, and the conclusion of 3rd week. Outcome variables include pain assessment using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale, evaluation of function through the Shoulder Pain & Disability Index, and measurement of range of motion using goniometry.

[/INST] The study is a phase 3 clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin in combination with pembrolizumab versus chemotherapy in participants with previously untreated locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma expressing HER2. The study will enroll participants with histopathological confirmation of locally advanced unresectable or metastatic urothelial carcinoma, including UC originating from the renal pelvis, ureters, bladder, or urethra. Participants must have a HER2 expression of 1+ or greater on immunohistochemistry (IHC) and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance score of 0, 1, or 2 within 7 days prior to randomization. Participants will be randomized to receive either disitamab vedotin in combination with pembrolizumab or chemotherapy. The primary endpoint of the study is progression-free survival (PFS) per Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST v1.1) by blinded independent central review (BICR). The secondary endpoints include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (DOR), control rate (DCR), PFS per RECIST v1.1 by investigator assessment, number of participants with adverse events (AEs), number of participants with laboratory abnormalities, treatment discontinuation rate due to AEs, number of ECG abnormalities, change from baseline of left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), change from baseline to Week 16 in European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer core Quality of Life questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C30) Global Health Status (GHS)/QoL Score, time to Deterioration in EORTC QLQ-C30 GHS/QoL Score, time to pain progression, and number of electrocardiogram (ECG) abnormalities. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] Lactoferrin is an iron-binding glycoprotein that has anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and immunomodulatory properties. It is found in the milk of mammals, including humans, and is also present in tears, saliva, and mucous secretions. Lactoferrin has been shown to have beneficial effects in a variety of diseases, including respiratory infections, cancer, and autoimmune diseases. The study is a double-blind, randomized controlled trial that will be conducted in the ICU of the Centre Hospitalier Valadai in France. The study will enroll 650 patients who are critically ill and will be randomized to receive either lactoferrin or a placebo. The primary outcome of the study will be the 28-day mortality rate. The study will also assess the incidence of hypersensitivity reactions, the need for invasive mechanical ventilation, the duration of oxygen therapy, and the duration of ICU stay. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months and will be funded by the French government. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover trial of a chitin-glucan-based dietary supplement in patients with Crohn's disease in remission and having irritable bowel syndrome-like symptoms. The primary outcome measure is the subject's global assessment of relief responder rate. The study consists of a 2 to 3-week run-in period, followed by 4 weeks of treatment with either placebo or the chitin-glucan-based supplement, a 2 to 3-week washout period, and then a switch to the other treatment for another 4 weeks. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the chitin-glucan-based supplement in relieving symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome in patients with Crohn's disease in remission.

[/INST] The study is titled "Developing a Novel Biomarker for Response and Prognosis of HBV-related Hepatocellular Carcinoma Treated With Radiotherapy: Personalized Cell-free Virus-host Chimera DNA" and is a single-center, single-arm, open-label, phase II clinical trial. The study aims to develop a novel biomarker for response and prognosis of HBV-related HCC treated with radiotherapy. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will enroll patients with HCC who are HBsAg positive, have Child-Turcotte-Pugh class A-B liver function, and have received radiotherapy to the liver tumor as the main treatment. The study will retrospectively analyze the Capture-NGS analysis from HBV-related HCC patients and Vh-DNA specific PCR between pre- and post-RT. The study will also prospectively analyze the serial changes of serum vh-DNA copies of same junction clone from HBV-related HCC patients, the concordance of vh-DNA copies between serum and plasma samples, the serial changes of plasma vh-DNA copies of same junction clone associated with treatment response, and the clonality of recurrent HCC as the original or a de novo one for post-radiotherapy patterns of failure. The primary outcome measure is the retrospective analysis of the Capture-NGS analysis from HBV-related HCC patients. The secondary outcome measures are the retrospective analysis of the Vh-DNA specific PCR between pre- and post-RT, the prospective analysis of the serial changes of serum vh-DNA copies of same junction clone from HBV-related HCC patients, the concordance of vh-DNA copies between serum and plasma samples, the prospective analysis of the serial changes of plasma vh-DNA copies of same junction clone associated with treatment response, and the clonality of recurrent HCC as the original or a de novo one for post-radiotherapy patterns of failure. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 years and 1 month. The study will enroll 30 patients. The study will begin on January 1, 2023,

[/INST] The study aimed to develop an online individual intervention program to help women with breast cancer make sense of their experiences and to test the effectiveness of the program. The program was based on the Meaning-Making Model and principles of meaning therapy. The program consisted of eight individual sessions, each lasting approximately 60 minutes. The sessions focused on helping participants identify the meaning of their breast cancer diagnosis and how to find new positive meanings in life despite the limitations of the diagnosis. The program was compared to a waitlist control group, and participants were assessed before and after the intervention, as well as at a two-month follow-up. The results showed that the program was effective in improving meaning in life, posttraumatic growth, and psychological flexibility, while reducing automatic meaning-making efforts, intrusions, and avoidance. The study concluded that the Meaning-Centered Coping Program is an effective online intervention that can help women with breast cancer make sense of their experiences and improve their psychological health.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to investigate the nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level in people who have undergone a major dysvascular lower limb amputation. The study will assess nutritional intake, diet quality, nutritional status, muscle mass, muscle strength, body mass index, physical activity level, and quality of life. The study will also assess mortality, wound healing, and potential level of functioning. The study will be conducted in the Netherlands and will include 100 participants. The study will last for 9 months, and participants will be assessed at 5 weeks, 6 months, and 9 months post-amputation. The study will use a combination of self-reported questionnaires, accelerometers, and anthropometric measurements to assess the outcomes. The study will provide valuable information on the nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level in people who have undergone a major dysvascular lower limb amputation.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the feasibility of a home-based trial with digital technologies in patients with type 2 diabetes and albuminuria. The study will assess the participants' perspectives towards the feasibility of participation in a trial at home with digital technologies, the number and percentage of urine collections not received at the laboratory or unable to be analysed, the number and percentage of missed blood pressure measurements, the number and percentage of missed body weight measurements, the treatment adherence, and the individual UACR response to empagliflozin. The study will also assess the individual systolic blood pressure response to empagliflozin, the individual body weight response to empagliflozin, the individual eGFR response to empagliflozin, the individual fasting plasma glucose response to empagliflozin, and the (additive) treatment effects finerenone on UACR, systolic blood pressure, body weight, eGFR, and fasting plasma glucose.

[/INST] The study aimed to investigate the effects of high-intensity interval training on physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance among college male ice hockey players in China. The study utilized a randomized controlled trial design, with two groups: an experimental group that underwent high-intensity interval training and a control group that underwent traditional technical skill training. The training program lasted for 12 weeks, and the study measured the participants' maximal oxygen uptake performance, endurance performance, power performance, agility and skill performance, passing and shooting performance, and tactical performance before and after the training program. The results of the study showed that high-intensity interval training was effective in improving the physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance of college male ice hockey players in China.

[/INST] The Effect of Chlorhexidine on the Oral Microbiome, Salivary Pellicle Proteins and Vascular Function in Individuals with Dental Erosion is a double-blind, randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of chlorhexidine mouthwash on the oral microbiome, salivary pellicle proteins, and vascular function in individuals with dental erosion. The study will involve 24 participants who will be randomly assigned to receive either chlorhexidine mouthwash or a placebo mouthwash for 7 days, followed by a 12-week washout period. The primary outcome measure is the identification of salivary proteins via SDS-PAGE electrophoresis, and the secondary outcome measures include blood pressure measurement, endothelial function test, flow-mediated dilation, nitrate and nitrite in saliva and plasma, oxidative stress markers, and redox-related molecules via ELISA. The study will provide valuable information on the effect of chlorhexidine mouthwash on the oral microbiome, salivary pellicle proteins, and vascular function in individuals with dental erosion.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to explore whether a pain and coordination plan (PAC-plan) can reduce opioid use and improve quality of life in patients after accidental injury. The PAC-plan consists of three main elements: an opioid management plan upon discharge from the hospital, an appointment with the participant's regular GP within 2-4 weeks after discharge, and an opportunity for increased collaboration between GP and hospital specialists. The study will recruit patients from the Division of Orthopaedic Surgery at Oslo University Hospital. The primary outcome is opioid use 6 weeks after discharge, and the secondary outcomes are opioid use 52 weeks after discharge, pain, health-related quality of life, and other patient-reported outcomes. The study will use a prospective randomized controlled trial design, with allocation to the intervention or control group in a 1:1 ratio. The study will be randomized using permuted block randomization with various sizes of the blocks in random order. The study will be single-blinded, with the participants being blinded to their allocation. The study will be conducted in Norwegian.

[/INST] The study is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study that aims to compare the efficacy of guided antiplatelet therapy and standard antiplatelet therapy in intracranial aneurysm stenting. The study will include patients with unruptured intracranial aneurysms who will receive intracranial stenting and standard dual antiplatelet therapy for at least 5 days before stent implantation. The study will exclude patients with a history of allergy to aspirin, clopidogrel or ticagrelor, patients who used tirofiban prophylactically before surgery, and patients with high blood pressure, such as symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage or active gastric ulcer; or patients with bleeding tendency or coagulation dysfunction. The study will use a guided antiplatelet regimen based on LTA testing to adjust the antiplatelet drugs. The primary outcome measure is ischemic events, including ischemic stroke, transient ischemic stroke (TIA), and stent thrombosis, which will be measured 30 days after stent implantation.

[/INST] The study is titled "Relation Between Bone Mineral Density, Gross Motor Function and Quality of Life In Children With Cerebral Palsy". The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the relationship between bone mineral density, gross motor function, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will include 75 children with cerebral palsy who will undergo dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scans to assess bone mineral density, gross motor function measurement scale (GMFM) to assess gross motor function, and quality of life questionnaire for children (CP QOL-Child) to assess quality of life. The study will be conducted in the Rehabilitation Research Center, Faculty of Medicine, Cairo University. The study will be conducted over a period of one year, from January 2023 to December 2023. The results of the study will provide valuable information on the relationship between bone mineral density, gross motor function, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy, which can be used to develop effective interventions to improve the health and well-being of these children.

[/INST] Dopamine and Cognition is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the role of dopamine in cognitive processes, such as working memory, decision-making, and motivation. The study involves healthy volunteers who are administered a dopamine agonist, sulpiride, and undergo functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure brain activity during cognitive tasks. The study is designed to examine the effects of sulpiride on working memory gating, a process by which irrelevant information is filtered out of working memory, and on cognitive effort, a process by which individuals allocate resources to a task. The study also aims to investigate the effects of sulpiride on decision-making and motivation. The study is expected to provide insights into the role of dopamine in cognitive processes and may contribute to the development of new treatments for cognitive disorders.

[/INST] The HYGEF study is a cross-sectional study that aims to determine the prevalence of obesity and hypertension (HT) in a cohort of adolescents, perform genetic analyses to determine a link between specific polymorphisms of genes involved in the development of HT in adults like the Adducin genes and Endogenous Ouabain (EO) and HT and explore whether urine Na+/K+ excretion and urinary markers of inflammation and oxidative stress are linked to HT and cardiovascular risk in participants with the selected genotypes. The study will enroll adolescents in high schools in the north (Milan), center (Livorno) and south (Grottaglie) of Italy, to obtain a sample that could be representative of the Italian adolescents. During the visit at the high school investigators obtain questionnaires to have some information about eating habits, lifestyle and family history, two (or three in they were very discordant) blood pressure measurements, weight and height of the students, a sample of urine and a sample of saliva to extract DNA. Genotyping: On the basis of our previous genetic studies carried out in adult patients with hypertension and cardiovascular and renal related diseases, 15 SNPs located in 13 candidate genes have been selected: rs1045642 in ABCB1, rs4343 in ACE (angiotensin converting enzyme), rs4961 in ADD1 (alpha-adducin), rs4984 in ADD2 (beta-adducin), rs3731566 in ADD3 (gamma-adducin), rs11638442 in CYP11A1 (cytochrome P450 family 11 subfamily A member 1), rs1799998 in CYP11B2 (aldosterone synthase), rs2236780, rs6203 and rs10923835 in HSD3B1 genetic region, rs9536314 in KL, rs2254524 in LSS, rs4149601 in neural precursor cell expressed, developmentally down-regulated 4-like,

[/INST] The EPigenetic Consequences in Children of Intravenous vs Volatile Anaesthesia for Surgery (EPIVA) is a feasibility trial that aims to explore whether anaesthesia and surgery are associated with epigenetic changes in children, and whether the strategy used to maintain anaesthesia impacts any epigenetic changes observed. The trial will be conducted in children undergoing hypospadias surgery. The trial will randomize participants to receive maintenance of anaesthesia through either an intravenous approach (TIVA) or inhalational approach (using volatile agents). Blood samples will be taken from participants at baseline and at the end of the surgical procedure to measure epigenetic changes. The trial will assess the feasibility of conducting a larger trial and will identify which genes, pathways, and functional biological processes, may potentially be involved.

[/INST] The study is titled "Improvement of Laboratory Diagnostics in Hypothyroid Patients Using Levothyroxine" and is being conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study aims to investigate whether a variety of additional markers can improve laboratory diagnostics in patients with hypothyroidism using levothyroxine. The study will include a group of 100 patients with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, a group of 100 patients with hypothyroidism after thyroidectomy due to thyroid carcinoma, a group of 100 patients with hypothyroidism during treatment for Graves' Disease, and a group of 100 healthy euthyroid controls. The study will measure TSH, fT4, fT3, TT4, TT3, rT3, SHBG, acylcarnitines, and amino acids. The study will have a cross-sectional design and will measure the markers once. The study will be conducted in France and will be published in French. The study will not be registered in a clinical trial registry.

[/INST] The Palliative NonOperative Management in Selected Elderly With a Limited Life Expectancy Who Sustained a Hip Fracture study is an implementation project consisting of four phases. The primary objective is to implement palliative non-operative management (PNOM) in all Dutch hospitals as part of shared decision-making in a select group of frail patients with a hip fracture. The secondary objectives are to enrich the draft version of the PNOM protocol, test results of the PNOM protocol draft, develop educational modules for the curriculum of residents Surgery and Orthopedics, create awareness and a sense of urgency for PNOM implementation in this select group of patients by organizing PNOM informational sessions during annual conferences of the scientific associations involved, improve the PNOM protocol on a smaller scale based on implementation of the PNOM protocol in selected hospitals across the country, and facilitate the scaling up of the implementation of the PNOM protocol to all hospitals in the Netherlands that treat the targeted patient group. The study will use mixed methods in the different phases of the study. Phase 1: interviews with health care professionals and a panel from an elderly person's organization (i.e., patient representatives). Phase 2: Interviews with patient representatives, development of educational modules for hospitals and residents (Orthopedic) Surgery, and design of a website. Phases 3 and 4: Installation of a local implementation team, followed by PNOM protocol implementation. Data collection for patients eligible for PNOM by automated data extraction from the national hip fracture audit. In phase 3, the following additional data will be collected: 1) interviews with health care professionals in the hospital before and at 6 months after start of PNOM implementation; and 2) interviews with patients/proxy/next of kin about their view on the implementation.

[/INST] The study is titled "Physiological MRI for Precision Radiotherapy IDH-wildtype Glioblastoma" and is a single-group assignment study. The study is designed to generate proof-of-concept of using a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning for patients with brain tumours. The study will extend the clinical standard MRI session used for radiotherapy planning in 10 patients diagnosed with glioblastoma with advanced MRI techniques that assess oxygenation status and cell proliferation. The primary outcome measure is volume and location analysis of physiological and standard CTV. The secondary outcome measure is pattern-of-failure analysis of the physiological and standard CTV. The study will be conducted at the Erasmus MC - University Medical Center Rotterdam.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective cohort study that aims to compare the acceptance and effectiveness of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) vaccination in systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients who have undergone autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT) and those who have not undergone AHSCT. The study will compare the cumulative incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection after AHSCT as compared to non-AHSCT SSc patients, the proportion of SSc patients who refused vaccination during the study period, the cumulative incidence of symptomatic COVID-19 infection in SSc patients previously treated by AHSCT and in non-transplant controls, the time of onset of first COVID-19 infection (symptomatic or asymptomatic) diagnosed during the study period after completing at least two vaccine injections in SSc patients previously treated by AHSCT and in non-transplant controls, the severity of symptomatic COVID-19, and the proportion of SSc patients with at least one grade ≥3 adverse event after COVID-19 vaccination. The study will also assess the humoral response in SSc patients treated by AHSCT and in controls after mRNA vaccine against SARS-CoV.

[/INST] The proposed study is a stepped-wedge cluster randomized trial (SW-CRT) to evaluate the implementation of a novel eHealth intervention, CNH+, in NICUs in Canada. The study will compare the effectiveness of CNH+ to standard care in improving parental mental health and infant neurodevelopment.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the effects of physical activity on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age, and quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis. The study compares the effects of the Otago Exercise Program, which includes strengthening and balance exercises, with a control group that does not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures are lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance, upper extremity flexibility, agility, and quality of life. The secondary outcome measure is dynamic balance. The study is conducted over a 12-week period, with measurements taken before and after the intervention. The study is expected to provide evidence on the effectiveness of the Otago Exercise Program in improving physical fitness and quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to demonstrate the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a digital-based diet quality intervention for adolescents with overweight or obesity. The study will compare the effectiveness of a digital-based diet quality intervention with usual care in improving diet quality and meal timing. The study will use a two-arm pilot RCT design and will be conducted in the preparation phase of the Multiphase Optimization Strategy (MOST) framework. The study will recruit adolescents aged 14-17 years with overweight or obesity and at risk for diet quality that is low or in need of improvement. The study will use a digital-based diet quality intervention that includes five components: personalized goal, meal timing, nutrition skills, home food environment, and engagement strategies. The study will use text messaging to deliver the intervention. The study will collect data on diet quality and meal timing through three 24-hour dietary recalls at baseline and follow-up, and data on urinary Na and K through urine samples collected at baseline and follow-up. The study will use the Healthy Eating Index (HEI) 2020 to measure diet quality and proton NMR to measure urinary Na and K. The study will use a mixed-methods approach to analyze the data. The study will use qualitative methods to analyze the data on the feasibility of the digital-based diet quality intervention and the participants' experiences with the intervention. The study will use quantitative methods to analyze the data on the preliminary effectiveness of the digital-based diet quality intervention in improving diet quality and meal timing. The study will use the HEI-2020 to measure diet quality and proton NMR to measure urinary Na and K. The study will use descriptive statistics to analyze the data on the feasibility of the digital-based diet quality intervention and the participants' experiences with the intervention. The study will use independent t-tests and paired t-tests to analyze the data on the preliminary effectiveness of the digital-based diet quality intervention in improving diet quality and meal timing. The study will use the HEI-2020 to measure diet quality and proton NMR to measure urinary Na and K. The study will use the HEI-2020 to measure diet quality and proton NMR to measure urinary Na and K.

[/INST] The study is a controlled clinical study of predicting cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome (CHS) after carotid artery stenting (CAS) by using multi-parameter characteristics based on cerebral autoregulation. The study aims to analyze the incidence of postoperative complications such as CH and CHS within 1 month and to find the risk factors of CH. The study will enroll 400 cases of patients suffering from carotid artery stenosis. The investigators will perform transcranial doppler (TCD) on patients by Sonographer for identifying CH. The post-CAS imaging and parameters included the characteristics of stent and hemodynamic parameters by CDU and TCD. The primary outcome measure is postoperative CH will be defined in patients whose middle cerebral artery (MCA) mean velocity increased by more than 100% after carotid artery stent. The secondary outcome measure is CHS always occurs after CAS of high-grade carotid artery stenosis causing cerebral hemodynamic insufficience. CHS was defined as a clinical triad of ipsilateral head ache, seizures, and neurologic deficits in the absence of cerebral ischemia after a successful carotid stenting.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effects of a group-based, videoconference-delivered expressive writing program on emotional, social, and physical well-being among informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer. The study will use a crossover design, with participants receiving both the intervention and control conditions. The intervention will consist of four group-based expressive writing sessions led by a trained facilitator, delivered via videoconference. The control condition will be a waitlist control. The primary outcome measures will be psychological distress, general quality of life, and caregiver-specific quality of life. The secondary outcome measures will be depression and perceived stress. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, randomized, controlled single-surgeon trial that investigates the use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) in patients undergoing gender affirming mastectomy. Patients who meet the World Professional Association for Transgender Health (WPATH) guidelines for gender affirming mastectomy, are undergoing bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction, and are aged 18 years or older are eligible for the study. Patients are randomized into two groups, an experimental group receiving IV TXA and a control group that will not receive IV TXA. The experimental group will receive a loading dose of tranexamic acid (TXA) at a concentration of 1g/10ml over a period of 10 minutes, administered immediately following anesthesia induction. The primary outcomes are the presence of hematoma, seroma, and drain output, and time to drain removal. The secondary outcomes are thromboembolic events and wound complications. The study will be conducted at the University of California San Francisco and the data will be collected through patient interviews and medical records. The study will last for 3 months and the data will be analyzed using statistical methods. The results of the study will provide evidence on the effectiveness of intravenous tranexamic acid in reducing postoperative bleeding, hematoma, seroma, drain output, and time to drain removal in patients undergoing gender affirming mastectomy.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the efficacy of smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation in treating COVID-related smell loss. The study will use a 3-group design: Group 1) active smell training, Group 2) placebo smell training, and Group 3) active smell training plus trigeminal nerve stimulation. The study will use a combination of self-report questionnaires and objective psychophysical tests to assess olfactory function. The study will also assess the impact of smell loss on quality of life and other symptoms associated with long COVID. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 4 weeks, and 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be change in psychophysical olfactory function from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks. The study will also assess changes in other symptoms associated with long COVID, such as mood, sleep quality, and cognitive function. The study will be conducted in a double-blind design, with participants and investigators blinded to group assignment until the end of the study. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by an institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the clinical effect of acupuncture on primary insomnia. The study will compare the effects of acupuncture with those of a placebo acupuncture group. The study will use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and the Fatigue Scale-14 (FS-14) to assess the effects of acupuncture on sleep quality and fatigue. The study will also use the Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) and the Self-Rating Anxiety Scale (SAS) to assess the effects of acupuncture on daytime sleepiness and anxiety. The study will use polysomnography (PSG) and heart rate variability (HRV) to assess the effects of acupuncture on sleep architecture and autonomic nervous system activity. The study will also use the Self-Rating Depression Scale (SDS) to assess the effects of acupuncture on depression. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The SCARLET trial is a phase III clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy and safety of shorter chemotherapy regimens with standard chemotherapy regimens in patients with early-stage triple-negative breast cancer. The trial will evaluate the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate, distant relapse-free survival (DRFS), overall survival (OS), and distant relapse-free interval (DRFI) in patients who undergo neoadjuvant chemotherapy. The trial will also assess the patient-reported outcomes, including fatigue, physical function, and quality of life. The trial will compare the efficacy and safety of shorter chemotherapy regimens with standard chemotherapy regimens in patients with early-stage triple-negative breast cancer.

[/INST] The study is titled "Promoting Parent and Child Well-Being and Reducing the Need for Foster Care: An Evaluation of a One-Year, Home-Visiting and Case Management Program for People Using Substances During Pregnancy" and is a quasi-experimental study. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP) in reducing the need for foster care and promoting the well-being of parents and children. The study will use a quasi-experimental design to compare the outcomes of the PCAP group to a control group that received standard services. The study will use a combination of self-reported surveys and administrative data to measure the outcomes of the program. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the program in reducing the need for foster care, promoting parental well-being, and promoting child well-being. The study will also evaluate the cost-effectiveness of the program.

[/INST] The study is a comparative study of three optical measurement devices: Tomey OA-2000, Tomey CASIA2, and LenStar LS900. The study aims to evaluate the agreement between the test devices and the predicate device, as well as the precision of the test devices. The study will enroll three groups of participants: normal cohort, cataract cohort, and special eyes cohort. The normal cohort will undergo optical measurements by the three devices. The cataract cohort will also undergo optical measurements by the three devices. The special eyes cohort will undergo optical measurements by the three devices. The study will evaluate the agreement between each of the test devices and the predicate device by the mean difference and SD, the 95% limits of agreement (LOA), the Bland-Altman plots, and Deming regression for each subject population. The study will also evaluate the precision of the test devices by a crossed two-way random-effects analysis of variance (ANOVA) model. The study will list adverse events reported by subjects. The study will be completed through study completion, approximately 4 months.

[/INST] The study is a phase III, interventional, multicenter, open-label, randomized study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of zanubrutinib in combination with rituximab in untreated splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL) patients. The study will include a screening phase, a treatment phase, and a follow-up phase. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) at 3 years. The secondary outcome measures include complete remission rates, best response, time to next anti-lymphoma treatment, duration of response, overall survival, and treatment-emergent adverse events.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the efficacy of serratus anterior plane block (SAPB) and thoracic epidural (TE) in adult patients undergoing thoracotomy for cancer surgery. The study will include 74 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the SAPB or TE group. The primary outcome measure is postoperative total morphine requirement, and the secondary outcome measures are intraoperative fentanyl requirement, time to the first analgesia requested by the patient, postoperative pain, length of hospital stay, and patient satisfactory score. The study will use a continuous serratus anterior plane block and a thoracic epidural catheter for analgesia. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is titled "Enhancing Parent/Caregiver Engagement in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU): A Pilot Study of a PICU Journal Intervention." The study is a pilot study that aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a PICU journal intervention for parents/caregivers of pediatric patients admitted to the PICU. The journal is designed to provide parents/caregivers with information and support during their child's stay in the PICU. The study will assess the impact of the journal on parent/caregiver stress, care engagement, and depression and anxiety symptoms, as well as the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention. The study will also involve semi-structured interviews with parents/caregivers to gain a better understanding of their experiences with the journal. The study will be conducted at Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, Tennessee, and is expected to last for two years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) as a second-line intervention for adult smokers who do not quit with NRT. The study will compare the effectiveness of NRT with other interventions, including nicotine pouch, ENDS, and NRT. The study will evaluate the change in smoke exposure and smoking abstinence rates for NRT non-responders.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the effect of the flipped learning model on nursing students' asepsis knowledge and learning skills. The study was conducted with first-year nursing students of Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University Nursing Department. The students were divided into two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group was trained using the flipped learning model, while the control group was trained using the traditional method. The study was conducted between 11/11/2023 and 20/12/2023. The results of the study showed that the flipped learning model was effective in improving nursing students' asepsis knowledge and learning skills.

[/INST] The study is a prospective study to quantify the ability of Epitel's™ Remote EEG Monitoring System's (REMI™) to record electroencephalography (EEG) of seizure events in an ambulatory setting for extended periods (14 - 28 days). Patients presenting with questionable seizure characterization that are scheduling a conventional at home ambulatory EEG (Amb EEG) and who meet the study inclusion and exclusion criteria will be prescribed a REMI system. The purpose of this study is to demonstrate that the REMI system is able to record EEG data that clinicians can use to identify ictal events over extended periods, and that extended clinical EEG data is valuable in the diagnosis and treatment of seizure related symptoms.

[/INST] The study is a before-and-after study that aims to evaluate the observance of preoperative fasting time after a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting guidelines. The study will be conducted in a hospital in France. The study population will consist of adult patients undergoing a surgical procedure. The intervention will be a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting guidelines, which will be conducted through planned and repeated mandatory on-site lectures, reminder displays in surgical wards and consultations, individualized fasting cards for patients, and short message service reminders on preoperative fasting rules. The primary outcome measure will be the fasting time before surgery (liquid and solid). The secondary outcome measures will be the rate of oral carbohydrate intake in the 2 hours preoperative period, the rate of fasting duration superior to 12 hours (liquid or solid), the scale of preoperative anxiety, the scale of preoperative disomfort, the qualitative scale of preoperative thirst, the qualitative scale of preoperative hunger, the rate of preoperative nausea or vomit, the rate of postoperative nausea or vomit, the binary answer to the question on patient satisfaction toward communication and explanation about preoperative fasting, the French Quality of Recovery 15 score, the length of stay, and the Clavien-dindo classification of postoperative surgical complications. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the French Law on Informatics, Freedom, and Civil Liberties. The study has been approved by the French Ethics Committee Sud-Est VI.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effects of the Mentoring to be Active + Family (MPBA+F) intervention on physical activity outcomes and health outcomes among rural Appalachian 7th grade children who are overweight or obese. The intervention is a peer-mentoring program that targets increasing daily physical activity and replacing sugary drinks with water for hydration. The intervention is delivered virtually and includes 10 structured peer mentoring sessions, followed by a 6-month family reinforcement program. The study will recruit 288 children to participate, with half randomized to receive MPBA+F and the other half receiving a comparison program of 10 weekly, self-guided modules. The primary outcome measure is daily physical activity collected by accelerometry, and the secondary outcome measure is anthropometric (body composition- raw weight, BMI, body fat) using the Tanita 430-DCU Body Composition Analyzer. The study will be conducted over the course of two years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of ice massage and virtual reality animation on labor pain, duration of labor, and satisfaction with labor. The study will include 120 pregnant women who are in the active phase of labor (cervical dilatation of 6-8 cm). The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: ice massage, virtual reality animation, or control group. The ice massage group will receive ice massage to the hoku point (LI4 area) for 20 minutes, while the virtual reality animation group will watch a virtual animation of their choice for 20 minutes. The control group will receive standard care. The study will measure labor pain using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and labor duration using the Personal Information Form. Birth satisfaction will be measured using the Birth Satisfaction Scale - Revised (BSS-R). The study will also measure the duration of the latent phase (from cervical dilatation of 0-3 cm to cervical dilatation of 6-8 cm), the duration of the active phase (from cervical dilatation of 6-8 cm to cervical dilatation of 10 cm), the duration of the second stage of labor (from cervical dilatation of 10 cm to delivery of the baby), and the duration of total labor (from cervical dilatation of 0 cm to delivery of the baby). The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and is expected to last for 1 year.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to investigate the epidemiology of cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease in pediatric and adult liver transplant recipients in China. The study will include 100 participants who have received their first orthotopic liver transplant (the transplanted liver may be deceased donor or live donor graft) within 10 days prior. The participants will be followed up for 22 months after liver transplantation. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of clinically significant CMV reactivation or CMV disease within 12 months of transplantation. The secondary outcome measures are death, loss to follow-up survey, and participants asked to withdraw.

[/INST] The study is titled "Prism Adaptation Therapy (PAT) for Right Brain Stroke Rehabilitation" and is a non-randomized controlled trial. The study aims to develop a biomarker-based algorithm to identify patients with right brain stroke who are the best candidates for PAT. The study will enroll 180 participants with right brain stroke and spatial neglect, who will be divided into two groups: those who receive PAT and those who do not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measure is the severity of spatial neglect, as assessed by the Behavioral Inattention Test-conventional subtest (BIT-c). The secondary outcome measures are the severity of spatial neglect, as assessed by the Catherine Bergego Scale (CBS), and functional independence, as assessed by the Functional Independence Measure (FIM). The study will use neuroimaging biomarkers to predict the presence of spatial neglect and improvements in daily life function after PAT. The study will be conducted at three VA medical centers in the United States. The study is expected to be completed by September 2024.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study of liquid biopsy as a diagnostic tool for gliomas. The study aims to analyze blood samples from patients with brain lesions in the magnetic resonance images compatible with a glioma-like tumor to detect and quantify the circulating DNA (ctDNA) of tumor cells on it. The study will analyze the concentration of ctDNA found, the correlation between the results of the tissue samples and those of the blood samples, and the comparison of other variables such as time, money, and the impact on the patient (recovery time after biopsies, pain, sequelae, etc.) between the liquid biopsy procedure and the conventional tissue biopsy procedure. The primary outcome measure is circulating free DNA detection in blood samples of patients by means of a ddPCR.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a combination treatment of zimberelimab, quemliclustat, and chemotherapy in patients with borderline resectable or locally advanced pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The study will assess the incidence of adverse events, resection rate, progression-free survival, number of participants who develop clinically relevant pancreatic fistula, change in CA 19-9 levels, objective response rate, pathologic complete response rate, and overall survival. The primary outcome measure is the change in saliva cortisol from 5 minutes pre to peak post stress test. The primary outcome measures are changes in body mass index, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, LDL-cholesterol levels, glycemia levels, glycosylated hemoglobin in diabetic patients, and expired carbon monoxide in smokers. The secondary outcome measures include changes in physical activity, adherence to a heart-friendly diet, smoking reduction or cessation, self-efficacy, health locus of control, cardioprotective treatment adherence, and glucose control in diabetic patients. [/INST] The study is titled "The Diagnostic Accuracy of Pocket Size Ultrasound (PsUS) in the Detection of Pediatric Elbow Fractures" and is a feasibility study. The study aims to determine the feasibility of the study training and protocol for adequate image capture and the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound in the detection of pediatric elbow fractures. The study will involve 30 participants between the ages of 1-16 years old with isolated acute (less than 48 hrs) elbow pain. The participants will undergo a pocket-sized ultrasound exam of both elbows using a pocket-sized ultrasound device. The images will be categorized as positive, negative or equivocal for signs of fracture. The accuracy of the ultrasound exams will be determined by sensitivity and specificity, negative and positive predictive value, using X-ray or performance of bedside nursemaid reduction as gold standard comparison. The feasibility of the study training and protocol for adequate image capture will be determined by successful completion of adequate images obtain during ultrasound elbow exam which will be determine during internal review of images.

[/INST] The study is a non-invasive observational study employing a modified technique to obtain exhaled air from the ventilator tubes to perform a standard hydrogen breath test for SIBO diagnosis. Lactulose is used as a substrate. Specifically, each patient is administered 20 g of lactulose diluted in 400 ml of water through the nasogastric tube. Measurements are performed at 0-15-30-45-60-90-120-180 min from lactulose administration. During measurements, a valve attached to a collecting bag at the end of the expiratory limb of the breathing circuit, is kept open and the collecting bag is filled by several patient exhalations. After valve closure and bag isolation, the air is drawn by a 50 ml polyethylene syringe which is connected to the valve system to prevent losses and/or contamination. Then the air is blown into the breath hydrogen monitor and the expired hydrogen measurement is recorded. The hydrogen breath test is repeated at predetermined, protocol-based time intervals for all participants included in the study; 1st/day of admission, 3rd, 5th and 7th day of ICU stay. The 1st day measurement serves as a measure of eligibility, and patients exhibiting abnormal values of hydrogen breath testing at Day 1 are excluded from the study. An increase by more than 20 ppm of eH2 from baseline within 90 min was considered an abnormal measurement suggesting SIBO. Moreover, an increase by more than 12 ppm of eH2 from baseline within the first 30 minutes followed by a second rise within the next 15 minutes (double peak) was also considered an abnormal measurement suggesting SIBO. The primary objective of this study is assessment of the prevalence of SIBO on critically ill mechanically ventilated ICU patients. Secondary outcomes include investigation of the effects of SIBO on ventilator associated pneumonia, as well as ICU length of stay and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate in critically ill patients.

[/INST] The study aimed to investigate whether exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) is present following exercise in patients after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and if so, if it changes with exercise intensity. The study was a repeated measures and single-blinded randomized study. Thirty-eight patients 24 hours after TKA were randomly assigned to either low intensity exercises (LIE) group or high intensity exercises (HIE) group. An exercise program lasted for five days during the hospitalization period. Pain severity was assessed by Visual Analog Scale (VAS) (0-10 mm). Pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) were measured over quadriceps and biceps brachii and muscles immediately before and after exercise. The results showed that EIH was present following exercise in patients after TKA and it was not affected by exercise intensity.

[/INST] The Nigerian Breast Cancer Risk-Reduction Study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of risk assessment and counselling on adherence to risk reduction recommendations among female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwestern Nigeria. The primary outcome measures are adherence to breast screening practices and adherence to lifestyle risk reduction practices. The secondary outcome measures are perception of familial breast cancer risk, knowledge of familiar breast cancer risk, knowledge, attitude, and perception towards genetic testing and breast cancer aetiology. The study will use a questionnaire to collect data at baseline and at six months. The study will be conducted in Southwestern Nigeria and is expected to last for five years.

[/INST] The study titled "Serum Magnesium Level in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus" is a comparative study that aims to evaluate the serum magnesium level in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients. The study includes 100 participants, 50 of whom are type 2 diabetes mellitus patients and 50 of whom are healthy controls. The study is designed to compare the serum magnesium level between the two groups. The study's primary outcome measure is the serum magnesium level, which will be measured at the beginning of the study and after one year. The study will enroll 40 participants aged 60 years or older with sarcopenia, who will be randomly assigned to either the Ophiocordyceps sinensis extract group or the placebo group. [/INST] The study is a feasibility study to evaluate the existing 2Morrow Chronic Pain Self-Management Program, in the form of a mobile app, as a digital therapeutic for improving patients' pain self-management and function who suffer from chronic pain. The study will conduct a 2-arm randomized control feasibility study to evaluate: 1) the feasibility of using the mobile app and an optional activity tracker, 2) the feasibility of conducting a 2-arm trial, and 3) estimate the effect size for planning for a larger efficacy trial based on their primary outcomes. The intervention arm will test a mobile app that aims to help people reduce pain interference who have chronic pain, as well as mental health issues with depression and anxiety. Participants in the intervention arm will also have the option to sense health data with a tracker that integrates with the app, which will inform the feasibility of this feature. The primary outcome measure is the PROMIS Pain Interference Scale - Short Form 6b, which is a brief survey of patient's perceived pain interference in their ability to function. The study will measure the primary outcome at baseline, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after enrollment (and start of intervention in the intervention arm).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing two different surgical techniques for the creation of an intracorporeal neobladder during robot-assisted radical cystectomy. The experimental group undergoes a stentless procedure, while the control group receives a stented neobladder. The primary outcome measure is the rate of midterm complications, defined as any complication occurring within 6 months of surgery. The secondary outcome measure is the rate of perioperative complications, defined as any complication occurring within 7 days of surgery. The study is currently ongoing and has not yet reported any results.

[/INST] The Effects of Different Storage Conditions on Removable Retainers is a clinical trial that aims to compare the microbial colony counts, surface roughness, colour stability, and compressive strength of removable retainers stored in wet and dry conditions. The study will also evaluate the OHRQoL of participants storing their removable retainers in dry and wet conditions. The study will be conducted in Malaysia and will involve 24 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups: the first group will store their retainers in a dry retainer box, and the second group will store their retainers in a glass of clean tap water. The retainers will be stored in the same condition for three months, and the microbial colony counts, surface roughness, colour stability, and compressive strength will be measured at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. The OHRQoL of the participants will also be evaluated at 6 months. The study will use the following outcome measures: microbial colony counts, surface roughness, colour stability, compressive strength, and OHRQoL. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee. The results of the study will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations.

[/INST] The study is titled "Essential Connections: Hospital to Community Impacting Malnutrition Outcomes in Older Adults" and is a research project that aims to improve food security, quality of life, and reduce determinants of malnutrition in older adults. The study is a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design that will test the feasibility of a new model of continuity of nutrition care for sustainability and impact. The model has been developed to facilitate cross-referrals and transmission of structured nutrition care documentation from an acute care setting to a meal provision organization and then for the meal provision organization to use the referral data to increase delivery of nutrition care (medical nutrition therapy- MNT) and meals (medically tailored meals - MTM). The primary subjects for this study are adults older than 60 years of age with malnutrition, with particular emphasis on recruiting sites who serve individuals who are Black, Latino, Indigenous and Native Americans and individuals living in rural areas of the country. The components of the proposed new model of cross-referral, data reporting, and communication (including data transfer) from an acute care hospital to a meal provision organization and then for the meal provision organization to use the referral data to increase delivery of nutrition care (MNT, MTM) and meals have the potential to be scalable throughout the US. However, barriers and facilitators to data transfer and MNT/MTM provision, cost of implementation, and potential impact on outcomes must be evaluated for the model to be replicable. The results of this study will generate new data on the model of care feasibility, rates of malnutrition within older adults at the study sites, impact of MNT with MTM provision on food security, determinants of malnutrition, and quality of life to inform future scalability of the model.

[/INST] The study titled "Hemodynamic Effects of Modulating Circulating Ketone Bodies With 1,3-butanediol" is a randomized, crossover trial that aims to investigate the effects of 1,3-butanediol on cardiac output, stroke volume, heart rate, left ventricular ejection fraction, and circulating ketone bodies and fatty acids in patients with chronic heart failure. The study will enroll patients with chronic heart failure who are aged 18 years or older and have a left ventricular ejection fraction of less than 40%. Patients with diabetes or a hemoglobin A1c greater than 48 mmol/mol, significant cardiac valve disease, severe stable angina pectoris, severe comorbidity, or inability to give informed consent will be excluded from the study. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 hours, during which patients will be randomly assigned to receive either 1,3-butanediol or a placebo. The primary outcome measure will be cardiac output, which will be measured by left ventricular outflow tract velocity time integral and heart rate. Secondary outcome measures will include stroke volume, heart rate, left ventricular ejection fraction, and changes in circulating 3-hydroxybutyrate and fatty acids.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of subpectoral bupivacaine versus saline injections in reducing post-operative pain in patients undergoing reduction mammaplasty. The study will enroll patients aged 13-21 years who are undergoing bilateral reduction mammaplasty at Connecticut Children's Medical Center from January 1, 2022, to December 31, 2025. Patients will be randomized into two groups: the study group, which will receive subpectoral bupivacaine injections, and the control group, which will receive subpectoral saline injections. The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain score, which will be measured using a rating scale of 1-10. The secondary outcome measures are narcotic use, length of stay in the post-anesthesia care unit, and return to full activity. The study will be conducted at Connecticut Children's Medical Center and will be overseen by the study's principal investigator. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

[/INST] The study is titled "Evaluation of Radiobiological Effects in Skin Toxicities for Breast Cancer Patients With Pencil Beam Scanning Proton Therapy" and aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Spot Delete technique in reducing radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients undergoing proton therapy. The study will compare the extent of skin reactions in patients undergoing proton therapy with the Spot Delete technique to historical data from patients who did not receive this treatment. The study will use digital photographs, questionnaires, and assessment using the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) ver. 5.0 and the Radiation Dermatitis Severity (RDS) scoring system to assess radiation dermatitis. The study will also investigate the relationship between the linear energy transfer (LET) of the proton beam and skin reactions. The study will enroll 100 breast cancer patients who will undergo proton therapy with the Spot Delete technique and will be followed up for 10 weeks. The study will assess the reduction in radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients undergoing proton therapy with the Spot Delete technique compared to historical data from patients who underwent regular proton therapy without the technique. The study will also assess the relationship between the LET of the proton beam and skin reactions.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter, non-inferiority, randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of generic cetrorelix acetate versus reference cetrorelix acetate for ovarian stimulation using a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist protocol in women undergoing IVF. The study includes infertile couples who plan to undergo IVF/ICSI pregnancy treatment and sign an informed consent form. The study excludes subjects with untreated hydrosalpinges, moderate or severe endometriosis, recurrent spontaneous miscarriage, endometrial pathology, uterine malformations, etc. Endocrine diseases or other systemic diseases are also exclusion criteria. The study is designed to compare the cumulative live birth rate between the two groups. The study is randomized and double-blind. The study includes two arms: the experimental arm, which receives generic cetrorelix acetate, and the active comparator arm, which receives reference cetrorelix acetate. The study measures the cumulative live birth rate through study completion, an average of 18 months.

[/INST] The study is a phase I clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and tolerability of peposertib in combination with pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride in patients with advanced sarcoma. The study will also assess the pharmacokinetics of peposertib and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride when used in combination. The primary objective of the study is to determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride and peposertib. The secondary objective of the study is to assess the pharmacokinetics of peposertib and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride when used in combination. The study will also assess the objective response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival of patients treated with the combination. The study will enroll patients with advanced sarcoma who have progressed after at least one line of standard therapy. Patients will receive peposertib and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride in cycles of 28 days. The study will evaluate the safety and tolerability of the combination by assessing the incidence and severity of adverse events. The study will also assess the pharmacokinetics of peposertib and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride by collecting blood samples from patients at various time points during the study. The study will assess the objective response rate by evaluating the best overall response of patients to the combination. The study will also assess progression-free survival and overall survival of patients treated with the combination. The study will use Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) version 1.1 to assess the objective response rate. The study will use computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess the objective response rate. The study will use the Kaplan-Meier method to estimate progression-free survival and overall survival. The study will use log-rank tests to compare progression-free survival and overall survival between groups of patients. The study will use Cox proportional hazards models to assess the association between patient characteristics and progression-free survival and overall survival.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to examine the implementation strategy of a free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program to reduce back pain and improve quality of life among those with chronic back pain. The study will compare the effects of the t'ai chi and qigong program with usual care on pain levels, sleep, and quality of life among participants with chronic back pain. The study will use a prospective, randomized controlled trial with two groups: a t'ai chi and qigong exercise (treatment) group and a waitlist control group. The treatment group will receive the t'ai chi and qigong program, while the waitlist control group will receive the program after the study is completed. The study will use self-administered survey instruments to assess the primary outcome of low back pain, as well as associated outcomes of sleep and quality of life, including the Oswestry Disability Index, Visual Analog Scale for Back and Leg Pain, and SF-36, Short Form Health Survey questionnaire. The study will randomize 300 participants to one of the two groups and will conduct four surveys: a baseline survey sent three weeks before the start of the t'ai chi and qigong classes, an intermediate survey sent after Week 8 of the classes, a post-intervention survey sent the day after the last class, and a follow-up survey sent four weeks later. The study will use Fisher's exact test to analyze the statistical significance of cross-tabulated variables. The study will also conduct 25 qualitative interviews to assess the barriers and facilitators related to implementing the online t'ai chi and qigong intervention.

[/INST] The EMBOL-AF is a multicenter, international, observational study designed as a retrospective registry that will investigate the characteristics of systemic arterial embolic events after treatment of atrial fibrillation by catheter ablation. Due to the retrospective nature of the study, the registry is specially focused on cerebral embolism (stroke and TIA) because these are not only the most frequent and clinically relevant but also the most susceptible to underreporting. However, all embolism associated to AFAbl will be included. This study will gather all clinically relevant aspects and data of all cases of arterial embolism that have occurred over the last 5 years in the centers that will participate in the registry. Based on these reported cases, the incidence, management and outcomes of embolic events (particularly stroke and TIA) will be studied.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of electrical stimulation in accelerating the retraction of upper anterior teeth during orthodontic treatment. The study will compare the use of electrical stimulation to traditional retraction methods without any acceleration method. The study will assess the pain, discomfort, and patient-reported outcomes during the treatment. The study will also evaluate the time required for retraction and the patient satisfaction with the treatment.

[/INST] The study is a single-site, non-randomized prospective observational study of men with prostate cancer. The primary objective is to evaluate whether baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 (Aβ42/40) ratio is associated with cognitive decline in men upon starting Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT). The secondary objective is to evaluate whether ADT is associated with a decline in plasma Aβ42/40 ratio. The study will recruit two cohorts of participants: (1) participants with prostate cancer who are starting ADT (ADT Cohort) and (2) participants in remission from prostate cancer who have never received ADT (Prostate Cancer Control (PC) Cohort). Participants in the ADT Cohort will undergo cognitive assessments at baseline and at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after starting ADT. Participants in the PC Cohort will undergo cognitive assessments at baseline and at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after baseline. The study will also recruit study partner participants to complete cognitive assessments at baseline and at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after baseline. The study will measure the proportion of participants with cognitive decline, mean cognitive decline, and proportion of participants with cognitive impairment after ADT in the ADT Cohort. The study will also measure the mean cognition score and mean study partner-reported cognition score in both cohorts.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of high-dose cephalexin (1000 mg QID) to standard-dose cephalexin (500 mg QID) in treating cellulitis. The primary outcome is oral antibiotic treatment failure, defined as a change in antibiotic (change in class of oral antibiotic or step up to IV therapy) within 7 days due to worsening infection. The study will enroll 223 patients in each group and follow them for 30 days. The study will evaluate the efficacy of high-dose cephalexin in treating cellulitis and compare it to standard-dose cephalexin.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) in Turkish and to evaluate the effect of educational games on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children. The study was conducted in two stages. In the first stage, the current situation was determined by quantitative analysis of the data obtained with the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 years). In the second stage, a randomized controlled study was conducted to evaluate the effect of educational games on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children. The study was designed to be a randomized controlled study with a crossover assignment model. The study was conducted with children with type 1 diabetes aged 8-12 years. The experimental group received diabetes education through board games, and the control group did not receive any education. The study measured the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) in Turkish and the diabetes health literacy of children with type 1 diabetes aged 8-12 years who participated in the study. The scale was applied to the participants at the first meeting. Then, diabetes education was given to the participants through games. The scale was re-administered to the participants 1 and 3 months after the training. Participants were advised to play the game at least twice between follow-ups.

For implant placement, a linear incision of the edentulous ridge and an intrasulcular incision of the adjacent teeth will be made using a #15 scalpel blade and a #3 Bard Parker scalpel handle. Once this is done, a full-thickness flap will be raised and the alveolar ridge will be reamed, following the manufacturer's indications, to place a titanium implant (Phibo® Aurea Evolution) of adequate dimensions in the control group or a zirconia implant (Z system®) in the test group, checking that there is an adequate insertion torque of 30Ncm or more and a cover screw will be placed. Once the implant is in place, simple stitches with supramid monofilament 4/0 suture (Proclinic®) will be placed until the wound is closed. Finally, antibiotic treatment (Amoxicillin 750mg/8hours/7 days), analgesic and anti-inflammatory (Dexketoprofen 25mg/8hours/5 days and Metamizole 575mg/8hours/if pain persists) will be prescribed to all patients. Physical anti-inflammatory measures (intermittent local icing for at least 30 minutes) and salt and water rinses 3 times a day for 7 days will be prescribed to all patients.
