[/INST] The study aimed to determine the effect of a motivational interview-based online intervention program on smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels in nursing students. The study was conducted with nursing students who were at risk for smartphone addiction. The intervention group received a motivational interview-based online intervention program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The results showed that the motivational interview-based online intervention program had a positive effect on smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels in nursing students. The study concluded that motivational interview-based online intervention programs can be effective in reducing smartphone addiction and improving sleep quality levels in nursing students.

[/INST] The study is a randomized split-face trial that compares the efficacy of Potassium-titanyl Phosphate (KTP) Laser and KTP Laser combined with Ivermectin 1% Cream for the treatment of facial rosacea. The study is conducted in a single center and includes 20 participants with facial rosacea. The study duration is 16 weeks, and the primary outcome measure is the efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing erythema as assessed by Normalized Erythema Index (NEI). The secondary outcome measures include the efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing erythema as assessed by Skin Redness Index (SRI), Clinical Erythema Assessment (CEA), Physician Global Assessment (PGA), patient's satisfaction for the improvement of skin lesions as assessed by a 9-point anchored visual analogue scale (VAS), efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing telangiectasia severity as assessed by telangiectasia grading scale (TGS), efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing papules and papulopustules, efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing face swelling as assessed by the patient, efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing face redness as assessed by the patient, and efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing face purpura as assessed by the patient. The study is currently in the recruiting phase, and the estimated study completion date is December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective review of FDG PET data from a large cohort of patients with neurodegenerative diseases and head trauma. The study aims to characterize the different pathologies examined by studying regional metabolism in individual subjects and the functional activity of different brain circuits. The primary outcome measure is FDG PET, which measures brain areas of hypo or hyper regional metabolism in patients with neurodegenerative disease. The study was conducted over a period of 4 years.

[/INST] The CAR-CF study is a prospective, longitudinal cohort study that aims to provide comprehensive information on SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence changes over time and the subsequent clinical impact on people with cystic fibrosis (pwCF). The study will be conducted at participating cystic fibrosis centers over a 3-year period. Study participants will include pediatric and adult pwCF. For the UK section of the study, UK investigators in the European Cystic Fibrosis Society-Clinical Trials Network (ECFS-CTN) will be invited to participate. Participating investigators can enroll all eligible pwCF over a 12-month period. Participants will donate blood samples at their routine clinic visits. Blood samples will be collected at Day 0 (baseline), at Months 6, 12, 18, and 24 (to coincide with routine clinical reviews). Additional blood samples will be taken opportunistically every time the participant visits the clinic for blood draws. These blood samples could be related to, routine care, annual review visits, pulmonary exacerbations (PEx), CF complications, or when initiating new treatments (e.g. CFTR modulators). Serum from blood samples will be shipped to a central laboratory (Queen's University Belfast) for standardized measurement of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies. Alongside the blood samples, the investigators will also collect clinical data from the patient's health records and will input this data into the case report form (CRF). Clinical data will be collected in conjunction with routine care visits, according to local clinical practice. Investigators will collect data elements from information routinely recorded in the patient's medical records. Data will be collected at baseline, months 6, 12, 18, and 24 as per the study schedule, and at additional blood sampling time points as previously explained above. Data collection will include routine data available from CF clinic follow-ups including background demographic information, CF medical history, medications, exacerbation information, sputum microbiology, and clinical and lung function parameters. Information on SARS-CoV-2 infection history and vaccine receipt will also be collected. The maximum follow-up duration of participation in the study for each patient will be

[/INST] The study titled "The Use and Reproducibility of Duplex Ultrasound to Provide Indices of Left Common Iliac Vein Diameter, to Aid and Improve the Diagnosis of May Thurner Syndrome (MTS) in Patients Presenting With Unexplained Left Leg Swelling" is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the use of duplex ultrasound to measure the diameter of the left common iliac vein. The study will include two groups of participants: symptomatic and asymptomatic. The symptomatic group will undergo a vascular ultrasound scan of the left common iliac vein, while the asymptomatic group will not. The primary outcome measure is the diameter measurement of the left common iliac vein, and the secondary outcome measure is the inter- and intra-operator variation of the diameter measurement of the left common iliac vein. The study will be conducted over a period of six months.

[/INST] The Health-Related Quality of Life of the Patients With Symptomatic Convergence Insufficiency is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the health-related quality of life of patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency who have received visual training and those who have not. The study will use the EuroQol five dimensions questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) and the shortForm 6D (SF-6D) questionnaire to measure the quality of life scores of the patients. The study will compare the changes in the quality of life scores between baseline and 3 months. The study will also compare the changes in the quality of life scores between the two groups. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will involve a single session of standardized visual training. The study will include patients aged 8 to 15 years old who have symptomatic convergence insufficiency and a best-corrected visual acuity of 0.8 or better at distance and near. The study will exclude patients with constant strabismus, nystagmus, or vertical phoria at distance or near, developmental delay, ocular surgery, or myopia of more than -6.00 diopters. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy of indocyanine green (ICG) dye with blue dye for sentinel lymph node mapping in patients with early-stage vulvar cancer. The study will assess the detection rate of sentinel lymph nodes using ICG dye and blue dye at the patient level. The study will also assess the difference in the number of sentinel lymph nodes detected using blue dye and ICG dye when data is clustered at the hemi-pelvis level. The study will use a mixed-effects logistic regression model to account for the clustering effect and assess the significance of dye type using the Wald test or likelihood ratio test. The study will also create a 2x2 contingency table for sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value. The study will be conducted at Tufts Medical Center in Boston, Massachusetts, and is expected to enroll 100 participants. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, crossover trial that aims to compare the effects of different NMES protocols applied to the triceps surae muscle on evoked torque, muscle fatigue, sensory discomfort, and peripheral oxygen extraction. The effects of the types of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) protocols on the aforementioned outcomes will be evaluated in the same participant by randomizing the sequences of interventions for each visit in the laboratory. The study will consist of five sessions with seven days between them. In the first session, anthropometry, the maximum intensity level for each electrical stimulation protocol as well as the protocol sequence for each individual will be evaluated. From the second to the fifth session, the following will be considered: voluntary and evoked maximum joint torque of the triceps surae muscle, muscle fatigue through the evaluation of the H-reflex, M-wave, fatigue index, torque-time-integral and recruitment curve, peripheral oxygen extraction, electromyographic signals through RMS (root mean square) and median frequency, and level of sensory discomfort with the Visual Analog Scale (VAS). From the second to the fifth session will be composed by the following evaluation sequence: warm-up with six submaximal contractions with 6 seconds of duration and 10 seconds of rest between them; then the assessment of muscle fatigue; then two maximal isometric contractions, then two maximal evoked contractions; fatigue protocol at 20% of the maximum isometric contraction (this fatigue protocol will use the NMES sequence randomized in the first session; after the fatigue protocol, two maximum evoked contractions will be performed again; then two maximal isometric contractions and at the end, the muscle fatigue evaluation will be performed again. [/INST] The study is a single-arm trial that aims to evaluate the success rate of a new ultrasound-guided ilio-psoas tenotomy technique for treating hip injuries. The procedure involves using an ultrasound machine, a 3 mm Acufex hook blade, and a specific kit to perform the tenotomy under ultrasound guidance. The study will evaluate the success of the new technique by measuring the disappearance of the ilio-psoas conflict after surgery. The primary outcome measure is the success rate of the new technique, which will be assessed by the disappearance of the ilio-psoas conflict after surgery. The secondary outcome measures include pain experienced by the patient, the Oxford Hip Score, the Harris Hip Score, the Postel and Merle Aubigne score, the technical difficulty of the surgical procedure, the operative time, the installation time, the total blood loss, the length of hospital stay, the scarring after surgery, the impact of the patient's quality of life, the patient satisfaction with the results of the operation, the subjective value of the hip, the forgotten hip sensation, and the forgotten hip score. The study will also evaluate the early and late surgical complications related to surgery, the rate of patients requiring a stay in a rehabilitation center, and the number of patients requiring reoperation. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the analgesic efficacy of three different local anesthetic volumes used for thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) in patients undergoing thoracotomy. The study includes three groups of patients who will receive TPVB with 20, 25, or 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine. The primary outcome measure is pain scores assessed at several time points after surgery. The secondary outcome measure is morphine consumption for 24 hours after surgery. The study is double-blinded.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of vibration therapy on fatigue in patients with multiple sclerosis. The study will involve 40 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive vibration therapy in addition to standard rehabilitation, while the control group will receive standard rehabilitation alone. The primary outcome measure will be the Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS), and the secondary outcome measures will include the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS), the Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Functions (FSMC), the Borg Scale, the Medical Research Council Scale (MRC), the Multiple Sclerosis Quality of Life-54 (MSQOL-54) scale, and the Coping Orientation to Problems Experienced (COPE) questionnaire. The study will last for 12 months, and the participants will be assessed at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. The study will be conducted at the C.A.R.E.N. or Casazza facilities of the IRCCS Centro Neurolesi Bonino-Pulejo in Messina, Italy.

[/INST] The study is a phase I clinical trial that aims to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of osimertinib, cetuximab, and tucatinib in participants with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have acquired resistance to EGFR-tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI). The study is a dose-escalation study, and participants are given tucatinib 200mg orally BID, osimertinib 80mg orally daily, and cetuximab 250mg/m2 IV every 2 weeks of a 28-day cycle. The study is currently recruiting participants.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the diagnostic efficacy of transbronchial cryobiopsy (TBCB) with that of transbronchial lung biopsy (TBLB) for diagnosing lung transplant rejection. The study will enroll patients who have undergone lung transplantation and have unexplained pulmonary function decline, acute/chronic clinical lung injury, or new pulmonary infiltrates. The primary outcome measure is the diagnostic yield of TBCB for diagnosing lung transplant rejection, compared with that of TBLB. The secondary outcome measures include the incidence of complications, sample size, the number of alveoli in the biopsy sample, the number of blood vessels in the biopsy sample, the percentage of the area of lung parenchyma without artifacts in the biopsy sample, and the number of attempts to get five samples.

[/INST] The study is a longitudinal cohort study of monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies complicated by selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) diagnosed before 28 weeks of gestational age. The study aims to improve outcome prediction at the time of sFGR diagnosis and to evaluate the impact of sFGR on parental mental health and parent-to-infant(s) attachment. The study will evaluate the following outcomes: composite outcome, ultrasound parameters, prenatal and postnatal attachment, post-traumatic stress, and PARCA-R evaluation.

[/INST] TransHealthGUIDE is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a digital platform in improving mental health outcomes for transgender and gender-diverse (TGD) youth and their caregivers. The study will assess the impact of the platform on suicidal ideation, depression, anxiety, and perceived family acceptance. The study will also evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the platform.

[/INST] The study is titled "Phenotyping Patients with Alcohol and Cannabis Use Disorders Using the Addictions Neuroclinical Assessment" and is a clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of two different treatment approaches for patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) and cannabis use disorder (CUD). The study will measure the number of binge drinking days, cannabis use frequency, average drinks per day, amount of cannabis used per week, alcohol craving, cannabis craving, retention in treatment, depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, and quality of life. [/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of semaglutide on intracranial blood flow and brain-barrier permeability in patients with type 2 diabetes. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months and will involve the use of dynamic contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (DCE-MRI) to measure intracranial blood flow and blood-brain barrier permeability. [/INST] The study is a retrospective cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the prevalence of upper gastrointestinal diseases in patients younger than 50 years old who underwent gastroscopy and colonoscopy simultaneously. The study included patients with normal colonoscopy and patients with colorectal polyps diagnosed by colonoscopy. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence or occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases, including Helicobacter pylori, atrophic gastritis/intestinal metaplasia, reflux esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, peptic ulcer, gastric polyps, low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (LGIN), and high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGIN). The study is conducted in China.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the outcomes of two techniques for bone augmentation in the anterior maxilla: the screw tent pole technique and the autogenous bone block technique. The study aims to assess the amount of bone gain and bone quality in the two techniques after 6 months of surgery. The study also aims to evaluate the incidence of dehiscence in the two techniques. The study will be conducted in a single center in France. The study will include 20 patients who will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups. The study will use a parallel group design and will be single-blinded. The primary outcome measure will be the amount of bone gain, which will be assessed by comparing CBCT scans before and after 6 months of surgery. The secondary outcome measure will be the bone quality, which will be evaluated by bone core biopsy through bone trephine bur after 6 months of surgery. The study will also evaluate the incidence of dehiscence in the two techniques. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study has been approved by the French ethics committee.

[/INST] The study is titled "Evaluation of a CD4/CD8+ Interferon Gamma Release Assay for Monitoring Anti-Tuberculosis Treatment" and is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the use of a CD4/CD8+ interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) as a diagnostic test for monitoring anti-tuberculosis treatment. The study will include two participant groups: a control group of healthy subjects and a group of subjects with pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB). The study will measure the degree of correlation between changes in IFN-γ response in the first antigen tube (TB1) and the newly added antigen tube (TB2) and the reference standard of treatment response (culture conversion) in smear-positive and smear-negative/culture-positive PTB cases. The study will collect data at four time points: at time of diagnosis (t0), 30+4 days after anti-TB treatment initiation (t1), 2 months after anti-TB treatment initiation (t2), and at the end of the anti-TB therapy (6 to 9 months) (t3). The study will use IGRA as a diagnostic test for monitoring anti-tuberculosis treatment.

[/INST] The study is titled "Accuracy in the Evaluation of Brain Response to Mechanical and Radiofrequency Stimuli in Humans" and is a basic science study that aims to characterize brain response evoked by radiofrequency and pinprick stimuli in humans. The study is designed to be a non-randomized controlled trial with a single-arm intervention model and no masking. The study will be conducted at the Faculty of Engineering of the National University of Entre Ríos (FI-UNER) in Argentina.

[/INST] The study will characterize the biomechanical coupling of the brain to the skull in human volunteers with and without a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) using magnetic resonance elastography (MRE). MRE uses the MR scanner to measure the relative motion of brain and skull while the head is vibrated at specified frequencies. The study will apply MRE to characterize the skull-brain interface in 25 mild TBI patients with a history of acute TME (TME+), 25 TME-patients (mild TBI patients without TME) and 25 healthy controls. The study will determine whether local shear strain measures within the cortex during MRE are altered in TME+ subjects.

[/INST] The Effect of Pharmacist-Initiated Home Blood Pressure Monitoring on Blood Pressure Control in Women is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the impact of home blood pressure monitoring when used in addition to pharmacist care, compared to usual care, in women with blood pressure elevated above their target level. The study will recruit 368 participants who will be randomized to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive home blood pressure monitoring in addition to pharmacist care, while the control group will receive usual pharmacist care. The primary outcome measure is the difference in change in systolic blood pressure between the two groups at 24 weeks. The study will also assess the proportion of patients at their blood pressure target at 24 weeks, the percentage of home blood pressure readings recorded, adherence to medications, changes to antihypertensive medication regimen, lifestyle changes, consultant satisfaction, and the number of lifestyle changes made by a patient. The study will be conducted in community pharmacies throughout Ontario, Canada, and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of moderate alcohol consumption on heart function in patients with a recent myocardial infarction. The study will compare the effects of moderate alcohol consumption (1 standard unit per day) to abstinence (no alcohol beverages) on left ventricular ejection fraction in patients with a recent myocardial infarction. The study will include patients who have a recent myocardial infarction, are aged 18 years or older, and are capable of providing consent. The study will exclude patients who have a history of alcohol or substance abuse, a history of severe heart failure, or a history of organ transplant. The study will have a run-in period of 2 weeks, where patients will be asked not to drink any alcohol beverage. After the run-in period, patients will be randomized to moderate alcohol consumption or abstinence for 12 months. The study will measure the change in left ventricular ejection fraction between baseline and 12-month visit.

The study will use a randomized allocation method. The study will use a parallel assignment method. The study will use a single-blinded method. [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to explore the effects of aromatherapy on sleep quality and quality of life in older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community. The study will use the Chinese version of the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, the World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire -Taiwan Version and the World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire -old as research tools. The study will recruit 64 participants aged 65 or older from two community care bases. The study will measure the participants' sleep quality and quality of life before and after the intervention. The results of the study will provide evidence on the effectiveness of aromatherapy in improving sleep quality and quality of life in older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of two different methods of soft tissue augmentation, namely, a connective tissue graft (CTG) and a collagen matrix (CM) in patients undergoing dental implant placement. [/INST] The OptimizeD study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine whether different patients respond differentially to different treatments for depression. The study will use machine learning to develop a precision treatment rule (PTR) that will be used to generate a prediction of the optimal treatment for each patient. The study will compare the effectiveness of the PTR with the effectiveness of antidepressant medication (fluoxetine) and behavioral activation (Healthy Activity Program) in patients with moderate to severe depression. The study will also explore whether genetic predictors can enhance the prediction of treatment response.

The study will include patients with no coronary history presenting to the emergency room, to the assessment unit or having consulted in the cardiology department for suspicious chest pain that does not allow an acute coronary syndrome or angina to be excluded and: in whom the diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome has been ruled out on the basis of clinical, electrocardiographic, biological monitoring, or even by imaging (including coronary angiography), in accordance with recommendations and good practices in whom effort myocardial ischemia is rendered unlikely on the basis of a clinical and paraclinical evaluation (either ergometric or by functional imaging: scintigraphy, echography or stress MRI) wishing diagnostic care and primary prevention of coronary disease. The primary outcome measure is the unstable coronary plaque evolution description through calcium score variation. [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of deep transcranial magnetic stimulation (dTMS) targeting the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) in the treatment of adult anorexia nervosa (AN). The study will enroll 80 patients with AN who meet the diagnostic criteria of DSM-V and have a BMI of 13.0 kg/m2 or less. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the dTMS treatment group or the pseudo-stimulation group. The dTMS treatment group will receive real dTMS intervention targeting ACC, while the pseudo-stimulation group will receive sham dTMS intervention. Both groups will receive basic treatment. The primary outcome measure is BMI, and the secondary outcome measures include eating disorder examination questionnaire (EDE-Q6.0), eating disorder inventory (EDI-II), Beck depression inventory (BDI), Beck anxiety inventory (BAI), and self-assessed compulsive questionnaire for eating disorders (SR-YBC-EDS). The study will use fMRI to establish an efficacy prediction model and explore factors predictive of dTMS efficacy in AN patients. The study will last for 1 year and will be conducted in China.

[/INST] The SeDeN-p3 study is a cross-sectional study that aims to assess the acceptability of expanded newborn screening to parents in France. The semi-structured interviews will be conducted with parents of children with a confirmed diagnosis of a disease screened for in newborn screening and parents of children with a confirmed diagnosis of a disease not screened for in newborn screening. The study will be conducted in France and will include 4 groups of parents: parents of newborns, parents of children with a confirmed diagnosis of a disease screened for in newborn screening, parents of children with a confirmed diagnosis of a disease not screened for in newborn screening, and parents of children with a confirmed diagnosis of a disease not screened for in newborn screening who have a sibling with a confirmed diagnosis of a disease screened for in newborn screening. The study will assess the acceptability of expanded newborn screening to parents in France and will provide insights into the views and opinions of parents on the use of genetic testing in expanded newborn screening.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of replacing sugar-sweetened beverages with unsweetened sparkling water on sweetness perception and physiological measures in adolescents. The study will last for 12 weeks and will involve the consumption of unsweetened sparkling water and sugar-sweetened beverages. The primary outcome measure is the change in 2-hour glucose concentration, and the secondary outcome measures are the change in dietary consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages and unsweetened sparkling water, change in insulin sensitivity, change in glycemic variability, change in flavor perception of beverage sweetness, change in blood pressure, change in triglycerides concentrations, and change in waist circumference. The study will be conducted in the United States and will involve 100 participants aged 10-21 years. The study will use a mobile food record to collect dietary data and continuous glucose monitoring to measure glycemic variability. The study will use a randomized block design with a 1:1 allocation ratio. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be overseen by an institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, monocentric, double-blind, prospective study that aims to evaluate the early wound healing score (EHS) after the utilization of NOVOSYN® Quick versus MONOSYN® Quick suture material in resective periodontal surgery. The study will include 40 patients who will undergo resective periodontal surgery and will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups. The primary outcome measure is the EHS, which will be evaluated in 3 parameters: clinical signs of re-epithelization (CSR), clinical signs of haemostasis (CSH), and clinical signs of inflammation (CSI). The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial of coenzyme I for injection for the treatment of sudden sensorineural hearing loss. The study was conducted at a single center and included 40 patients who were randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group received conventional treatment plus coenzyme I for injection, while the control group received conventional treatment alone. The primary outcome measure was pure tone average, and the secondary outcome measures included speech recognition rate, tinnitus handicap inventory, and visual analogue scale of tinnitus loudness and ear fullness. The study found that coenzyme I for injection did not significantly improve hearing outcomes in patients with sudden sensorineural hearing loss.

[/INST] The study is a pilot project to evaluate the feasibility of including cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria in newborn screening programs. The study will involve a molecular genetic screening for cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria using dried blood spots from newborns. The screening will be performed using real-time PCR and next-generation sequencing. The study will also involve a follow-up of the screened newborns to determine the diagnostic yield and the clinical outcomes of the screened newborns. The study will also evaluate the cost-effectiveness of including cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria in newborn screening programs.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the rate of surgical site infection (SSI) in patients who underwent intra-abdominal surgery with and without negative pressure drainage. The study will be conducted in the Department of Surgery at Ramathibodi Hospital in Thailand. The patients will be randomized into two groups: the intervention group, which will receive negative pressure drainage, and the control group, which will not receive negative pressure drainage. The primary outcome measure is the rate of SSI at post-operative day 3, 5, 7, and 14. The secondary outcome measures are the length of hospital stay and the quality of life score. The study will use the 36-Item Short Form Survey Instrument (SF-36) to measure the quality of life score. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the Faculty of Medicine, Ramathibodi Hospital, Mahidol University.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study comparing the immune modulation effects of palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib with letrozole in early ER+/HER2- breast cancer. The study will collect tumor tissue, blood, and stool samples prospectively before treatment, at 2 weeks after treatment, and after 12 weeks of treatment at the time of surgery. Immune modulation effects will be compared between 3 treatment groups from breast tumor RNAseq analysis.

[/INST] The study is a pilot trial to evaluate the feasibility of implementing a dementia care intervention for people living with dementia (PLWD) and their caregivers in two home-based primary care (HBPC) practices. The intervention, Dementia Care Quality at Home, includes a standardized assessment tool to identify PLWD and caregiver needs, seven modules to optimize the well-being of PLWD and their caregivers, and regular team-based review of persons participating in the program to address care challenges. The study will assess the feasibility of the intervention by measuring the percentage of caregivers who complete baseline assessments, the percentage of caregivers who use educational materials and community resources, the ability of practices to identify potential patients/caregivers, the ability of practices to identify eligible patient/caregiver dyads, and the percentage of practice personnel who conduct assessments that rate assessments as feasible to use.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of resistance training and flexibility training on self-efficacy, symptoms, and maternal quality of life in postpartum depression. The study will be conducted on 36 postpartum females aged 20 to 40 years who are 6 weeks to 8 months postpartum and have a family history of depression. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the resistance training group or the flexibility training group. The resistance training group will receive resistance training twice per week for 8 weeks, while the flexibility training group will receive flexibility training of the same frequency and duration. The primary outcome measures are exercise self-efficacy, symptoms of depression, and maternal quality of life. The study will use the Exercise Self-Efficacy Scale, the Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale, and the Maternal Postpartum Quality of Life Questionnaire as subjective measurements. The study will use the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 25 for data analysis.

[/INST] The study is a cross-over clinical trial that compares the surface hardness and wear resistance of prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth. The study includes 12 participants who are completely edentulous and have a class I maxillomandibular relationship. The participants are randomly assigned to two groups, one group receives a complete denture with prefabricated artificial teeth, and the other group receives a complete denture with CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth. The study measures the surface hardness and wear resistance of the artificial teeth at insertion and after 3 and 6 months of use. The study uses Vickers's test to measure the surface hardness of the artificial teeth and 2D, 3D wear of denture teeth were measured using denture scanning and superimposition of the sanning at insertion to that after 3, 6 months using Exocad soft ware.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, randomized, open-label, multicenter clinical trial. The study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The study will randomize patients to receive either T-DXd or standard neoadjuvant chemotherapy (TCHP or PCHP). The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate in the HER2-enriched population. The secondary objectives of the study are to evaluate the pCR rate in the ER-positive and luminal population, the objective response rate (ORR) at three cycles, the overall survival (OS), the distant relapse-free survival (DRFS), the event-free survival (EFS), the objective response rate (ORR) at six cycles, the residual cancer burden (RCB), the breast conserving surgery (BCS) rate, the de-escalation of BCS, the de-escalation of axillary surgery, the rates of adverse events, the change from baseline in global health status/quality of life score on the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Core 30 (EORTC QLQ-C30) in all participants, the change from baseline in physical functioning score on the EORTC QLQ-C30 in all participants, the change from baseline in emotional functioning score on the EORTC QLQ-C30 in all participants, the axillary surgery, the rate of Sentinel Lymph Node detection, Targeted Axillary Dissection success and false-negative rates of these procedures in initially node-positive patients for each molecular group, and the rate of Sentinel Lymph Node detection, Targeted Axillary Dissection success and false-negative rates of these procedures in initially node-positive patients for the two patient groups of the initial randomization of TCHP versus T-DXd.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effects of using different anesthetics on the prognosis of primary tumors and its mechanism of action. The study includes patients who are 18 to 80 years old and undergo surgery for brain, liver, lung, or ovarian cancer. The anesthetics used in the study are propofol and sevoflurane. The study includes a follow-up period of 36 months after surgery. The primary outcome measures are overall survival, the presence of disease progression, and postoperative complications. The secondary outcome measures are Karnofsky performance status score and length of hospital stays. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference on Harmonization Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice. The study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT03900331).

[/INST] The study is a cluster-randomized controlled trial with a pre-test and post-test design. The study aims to develop and evaluate the effectiveness of an intervention to promote physical activity-related health competence (PAHCO) in nursing students. The intervention will be delivered by teachers or physical activity specialists. The primary outcome is physical activity-related health competence, and the secondary outcomes are physical activity enjoyment, quality of physical activity, general health status, work ability, and musculoskeletal complaints. The study will be conducted in nursing schools in Bavaria, Germany, and the intervention will be implemented over one year. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention at the end of the intervention and one year after the end of the intervention.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of Diosmin/Hesperidin combination on the clinical outcomes in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The study will compare the effects of Diosmin/Hesperidin combination with those of metformin and combined oral contraceptive (Yassmin) and Diosmin/Hesperidin combination with metformin and combined oral contraceptive (Yassmin) on the improvement of PCOS status, glycemic index, and patient's quality of life. The study will also evaluate the effects of Diosmin/Hesperidin combination on the improvement of PCOS status levels, inflammation, and glycemic index. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 months.

The study will also evaluate the detection speed, time spawns between the insertion of the NIR camera and the visualization of the nodule.
