The study will exclude patients who have previously received systemic treatments for lung cancer, patients who have received an investigational drug within 30 days or 5 half-lives prior to the first dose of cetuximab IRDye800, patients who have received class IA (quinidine, procainamide) or class III (dofetilide, amiodarone, sotalol) antiarrhythmic agents, patients who have evidence of QT prolongation on pretreatment ECG (greater than 440 ms in males or greater than 450 ms in females), patients who have hypersensitivity to Cetuximab-IRDye800, Cetuximab, or any of the excipients, patients who are pregnant, or

[/INST] The SPARROW trial is a multicenter, randomized controlled trial that aims to compare perioperative versus prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis after pancreatoduodenectomy (PD) in patients with a high risk for contaminated bile. The primary endpoint is the rate of clinically relevant organ/space surgical site infections (SSIs) within 90 days after surgery requiring a therapeutic intervention. The secondary endpoints include the rate of isolated SSIs, wound infections, postoperative pancreatic fistula, bile or enteric anastomotic leakage, post pancreatectomy hemorrhage, delayed gastric emptying, bacteremia, Clostridium difficile infection, major morbidity (Clavien-Dindo ≥III), reintervention, ICU admission, length of hospital stay, readmission, and in-hospital and 90-day mortality. The study will enroll adult patients undergoing PD with a high risk for contaminated bile, defined as patients with preoperative biliary drainage or an ampullary malignancy. Patients with a contraindication for the study antibiotics or a preoperative indication for antibiotics will be excluded. The study will randomize patients to either perioperative or prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis. The perioperative group will receive a single dose of 5-7mg/kg gentamicin followed by 2gr IV cefazolin and 500mg IV metronidazole every 4h of surgery. The prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis group will receive the same perioperative prophylaxis followed by five days of 1500mg IV cefuroxime and 500mg IV metronidazole thrice daily. The study will enroll 322 participants and follow them for 90 days. The primary outcome will be the rate of clinically relevant organ/space SSIs within 90 days after surgery requiring a therapeutic intervention. The secondary outcomes will include the rate of isolated SSIs, wound infections, postoperative pancreatic fistula, bile or enteric anastomotic leakage, post pancreatectomy hemorrhage, delayed gastric emptying,

[/INST] The study is a phase 2 basket trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a combination of sotorasib and panitumumab in patients with advanced solid tumors carrying the KRAS G12C mutation. The study will include patients with histologically confirmed locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors with KRAS G12C mutation detected through local next-generation sequencing analysis. The primary objective of the study is to assess the objective response rate (ORR) based on RECIST v1.1. The study will use oral sotorasib at a dose of 960 mg once daily with panitumumab administered intravenously (IV) at a dose of 6 mg/kg every 14 days, infused over 60 minutes (≤ 1,000 mg) or 90 minutes (> 1,000 mg). The study will have an objective response rate (ORR) based on RECIST v1.1 as the primary outcome measure. The study will be conducted in multiple centers in the United States.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of a novel volume-stable collagen matrix (VCMX) in the treatment of single gingival recession associated with non-carious cervical lesion partially restored. The study will include 20 patients, who will be randomly assigned to two groups: active comparator and experimental. The active comparator group will receive a restorative procedure with partial restoration of the apical margin placed 1 mm beyond the estimated position of the cementoenamel junction. The experimental group will receive the same procedure with the addition of a coronally advanced flap (CAF) and a volume-stable collagen matrix (VCMX). The primary outcome measure is the recession reduction (RecRed) measured through a periodontal probe. The secondary outcome measures are dentine hypersensitivity, patient-centered esthetic evaluation, oral health impact profile, patient discomfort, number of analgesics, percentage of complete combined defect coverage, modification of the root coverage esthetic score (MRES), clinical parameters, and adverse events. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of different nutritional support modes based on nutritional risk screening on postoperative nutritional status in patients with gastrointestinal cancer. The study will include 302 patients with gastrointestinal tumors who are admitted to the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University from July 2021 to June 2023. Patients will be divided into intervention group and control group based on nutritional risk screening. The intervention group will receive different nutritional support methods based on nutritional risk screening, while the control group will receive conventional nutritional intervention. The primary outcome measure is nutritional risk screening 2002 (NRS2002) score, and the secondary outcome measures include dietary energy intake, dietary protein intake, nutrient energy intake, nutrient protein intake, prealbumin, albumin, hemoglobin, BMI, fat-free body weight, grip strength, walking time, and quality of life. The study will last for an average of 1 year. The results of this study may provide a reference for the development of nutritional support modes based on nutritional risk screening for patients with gastrointestinal cancer.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effect of two different abutment-prosthesis connections on marginal bone loss and gingival sealing around dental implants. The study includes 20 patients who require two implants to restore molars, premolars, or a molar and premolar. The two abutment-prosthesis connections being compared are the Connect® abutment and the conventional multi-unit abutment. The primary outcome measure is marginal bone loss measured by standardized periapical radiography at 1 year. The secondary outcome measures are the relative abundance of microbial species in the peri-implant sulcus and the concentration of pro-inflammatory markers in the peri-implant sulcus, both evaluated by next-generation sequencing methods and multiplex techniques methods, respectively, at 1 year.

[/INST] The study is titled "Non-invasive Monitoring of Blood Flow in the Brain by Using a Wearable Ultrasound Patch" and aims to compare the measurements from a conventional transcranial Doppler probe and a wearable ultrasound patch on 60 participants. The primary outcome measure is the clinical feasibility of the measurements from the non-invasive ultrasound patch in comparison to a conventional transcranial Doppler probe. The study will measure the blood flow spectrum of different arterial segments, including the middle cerebral artery, anterior cerebral artery, posterior cerebral artery, vertebral artery, basal artery, internal carotid artery, and ophthalmic artery. The agreement of these two devices on peak systolic velocity, mean flow velocity, and end diastolic velocity of the measurements will be evaluated using the Bland-Altman plot. The study will last for 1.5 years.

[/INST] The study is a single-arm clinical trial that aims to evaluate the clearance rate of uremic toxins by hemodiafiltration with endogenous reinfusion (HFR) in maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients. The study will include 30 MHD patients who will receive HFR treatment. The primary outcome measure is the clearance rate of β2-microglobulin (β2-MG), indoxyl sulfate, and λ-free light chain (λFLC). The secondary outcome measures include the single-compartment urea clearance index (spKt/V), urea reduction ratio, other middle molecules and macromolecular uremic, serum albumin, branched chain amino acids, vitamins A, C, E, and the comfort of HFR treatment. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of HFR in MHD patients.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of multi-kinase inhibitors in combination with bevacizumab as adjuvant therapy in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) at high risk of recurrence after liver transplantation. The study will compare the one-year recurrence-free survival rate (1-year RFS rate) between the experimental arm, which receives multi-kinase inhibitors in combination with bevacizumab, and the control arm, which does not receive adjuvant therapy. The study will also evaluate the recurrence-free survival (RFS) duration, overall survival (OS), two-year and three-year RFS rates, graft survival, quality of life, incidence of adverse events and serious adverse events, and other outcomes. The study will enroll patients who have undergone liver transplantation for HCC within 4 to 8 weeks and have a confirmed pathological diagnosis of HCC and meet at least one of the following criteria: pre-operative imaging or post-operative pathological confirmation of exceeding the Milan criteria, presence of major vascular invasion, post-operative pathological confirmation of the presence of microvascular invasion, recurrence of HCC after liver resection and subsequent liver transplantation, or satellite nodules. The study will use multi-kinase inhibitors, including sorafenib, lenvatinib, or regorafenib, in combination with bevacizumab as the experimental arm and no adjuvant therapy as the control arm. The study will evaluate the one-year RFS rate, RFS duration, OS, two-year and three-year RFS rates, graft survival, quality of life, incidence of adverse events and serious adverse events, and other outcomes. The study will have a follow-up period of approximately 3 years. The study will be conducted in China and will enroll 200 patients. The study will be randomized and double-blinded. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study will be funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China. The study will be conducted in 14 hospitals in China. The study will be coordinated by the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study will be mon

[/INST] The study is a pragmatic trial that will evaluate the effectiveness of a supportive-expressive group therapy intervention for inpatients with limb loss. The intervention will be compared to treatment as usual. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention on depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms. The study will also evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention on self-efficacy. The study will be conducted at St. John's Rehab in Toronto, Canada. The study will recruit 65 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention or treatment as usual group. The intervention will be delivered by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals. The study will use a mixed methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative data collection methods. The quantitative data will be collected using questionnaires and interviews. The qualitative data will be collected using focus groups and interviews. The study will use a two-arm parallel group design. The study will be conducted over a two-year period. The study will be coordinated by a research coordinator. The study will be managed using the RedCap electronic data capture tool. The study will be analyzed using statistical software. The study results will be disseminated to the research community and the general public.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of 20% human albumin infusions on coagulation parameters in patients with decompensated cirrhosis of the liver. The study will enroll patients aged ≥ 18 years and ≤ 70 years with decompensated cirrhosis of any cause and S. Albumin ≤ 2.5 g/dl upon presentation. The study will compare the effects of 20% human albumin infusions on coagulation parameters with standard of care. The study will measure the change in clotting time, change in clot formation time, and change in maximum clot formation in both groups. The study will also measure changes in inflammatory parameters like ESR, CRP, IL-6, TNF-alpha, endothelial dysfunction like VWF, ADAMTS-13, and pulmonary function by Pulmonary function test with diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO). The study will also measure the adverse effects of Human Albumin Solution, change in the albuminome in both the groups, duration of hospital stay, and mortality at 28 days.

[/INST] The study is a prospective study that enrolled 65 patients with potentially operable non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) in stage III without driving gene EGFR/ALK mutation. The study lasted for 3 years, and the patients were followed up for 2 years according to the standard diagnosis and treatment path, with a total of 9 times of follow-up, all of which were 3-month follow-up plan of the standard diagnosis and treatment path, and the follow-up examination was conducted in accordance with clinical standards. The study aimed to evaluate the significance of MRD monitoring in patients with potentially resectable stage III NSCLC. The study was designed to include two arms. Arm 1 included patients who underwent complete resection, and Arm 2 included patients who underwent concurrent radio-chemotherapy. Both arms received immunotherapy alone or combined with chemotherapy. Peripheral blood samples from multiple nodes after neoadjuvant therapy, postoperative (if any), adjuvant therapy and follow-up were collected and analyzed by high-throughput sequencing in the target region. The primary outcome measure was disease-free survival (DFS) (RECIST) from operation or radiation to recurrence. The secondary outcome measures included overall survival (OS) from enrollment to death, the prediction of recurrence by positive MRD, pCR rate of MRD-negative patient, negative MRD rate in pCR patients, 2-year DFS of ctDNA-negative patients in operation group/inoperable group.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that compares the use of ciprofol and propofol for sedation in hypotensive ICU patients. The study aims to evaluate the proportion of patients meeting the RASS sedation target, the dosage of propofol or ciprofol during sedation, the dosage of norepinephrine during sedation, the duration of mechanical ventilation, the incidence of adverse events, the length of ICU stay, and the mortality rate. The study will be conducted at a single center and will include patients who are hypotensive and require sedation for comfort, safety, and to facilitate life support measures. The study will use ciprofol or propofol for sedation in hypotensive ICU patients. The study will use the RASS scale to evaluate the sedation level of patients. The study will also evaluate the dosage of propofol or ciprofol during sedation, the dosage of norepinephrine during sedation, the duration of mechanical ventilation, the incidence of adverse events, the length of ICU stay, and the mortality rate. The study will be conducted over a period of 28 days.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial with a 1:1 ratio comparing two groups of preterm infants with ulcerative necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) who require surgical treatment. The first group will undergo laparotomy only, while the second group will undergo laparoscopy and laparotomy. The primary outcome is the inflammatory response on Day 2 postoperatively, measured by the blood C reactive protein level. The secondary outcomes include the postoperative biological inflammatory response, postoperative mortality, postoperative bowel morbidity, postoperative re-intervention rate, length of hospital stay, and postoperative neurological morbidity. The study will evaluate the intermediate effectiveness of laparoscopy on the short-term evolution of preterm infants with NEC.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial of hair removal in the axilla for women using intense pulsed light (IPL) or diode laser. The study will have a total of 4 sessions, once a month for 4 months, with a follow-up at 30 days and 6 months after the end of the treatment. The study will use the Fitzpatrick scale to classify the phototype of the skin and the Self-Esteem Rosenberg Scale to assess self-esteem. The primary outcome measure will be the hair count, and the secondary outcome measures will be hair thickness, pain score, quality of life, satisfaction level score, and self-esteem scale. The study will be conducted in a single center and will have a sample size of 40 participants. The study will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio and will be double-blind. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the National Health Council Resolution No. 466/2012.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, observational study that aims to assess the evolution of plasma brain-derived tau (BD-tau) levels in acute ischemic stroke patients. The study will enroll 100 patients who present with a clinical diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke within 9 hours of symptom onset and a large- or medium-vessel occlusion confirmed by CT or MRI angiography. The study will assess BD-tau levels and other suggested markers of brain injury (e.g. NfL) every hour from admission to 48 hours after onset. Routinely collected clinical data including from neuroimaging will be collected throughout hospitalization. Clinical follow-up will be performed at 3 months. The primary outcome is the evolution of BD-tau levels. The secondary outcomes include ischemic core volume on CT perfusion, regional leptomeningeal collateral score on CT angiography, final infarct volume, infarct progression, 90-day functional outcome, 7-day functional outcome, early recurrent ischemic stroke, secondary intracerebral hemorrhage, and hemorrhagic transformation.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective analysis of the learning curve of radiologists in mastering contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) of the thyroid. The study included three groups of patients who underwent CEUS and ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of the thyroid. The training set included patients who underwent CEUS and FNA of the thyroid from January 2018 to December 2020. The internal test set included patients who underwent CEUS and FNA of the thyroid from January 2021 to May 2023. The external test set included patients who underwent CEUS and FNA of the thyroid from January 2022 to June 2023. The study aimed to evaluate the learning curve of radiologists in mastering CEUS of the thyroid by analyzing the area under the curve (AUC) of the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve, the number of cases, and the time of cases. The study found that the learning curve of radiologists in mastering CEUS of the thyroid was approximately six months.

[/INST] The study is titled "AI-Powered Artificial Vision for Visual Prostheses" and is a basic science study that aims to test the ability of different stimulus encoding methods to support simple perceptual and behavioral tasks in visual prosthesis patients. The study will use visual prostheses to produce visual percepts in patients either by directly stimulating electrodes or by asking them to view a computer or projector screen. The study will test the effect of stimulation strategy on the shape of phosphenes, pattern discrimination accuracy, and scene understanding performance. The study will use a single group assignment model and will not use masking. The study will use visual prostheses to produce visual percepts in patients either by directly stimulating electrodes or by asking them to view a computer or projector screen. The study will test the effect of stimulation strategy on the shape of phosphenes, pattern discrimination accuracy, and scene understanding performance. The study will use a single group assignment model and will not use masking.

[/INST] The study is titled "Surveillance of Regional Nodal Basins in Patients With Primary High Risk Cutaneous Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck" and is a clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of ultrasound surveillance of lymph node basins in patients with primary high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck. The study will compare the time to nodal metastasis between the ultrasound surveillance group and the historical controls. The study will also compare the time to local recurrence, disease-specific mortality, and overall mortality between the two groups. The study will use Kaplan-Meier estimates, a log-rank test, and Cox proportional-hazards regression to compare the outcomes between the two groups. The study will enroll patients with primary high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck and will follow them up for two years. The study will use ultrasound surveillance every six months and regular visits every three months to detect nodal metastasis. The study will also use medical records to collect data on local recurrence, disease-specific mortality, and overall mortality. The study will be conducted at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, Massachusetts, United States.

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the biochemical profile of saliva samples collected from infants with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux (GER) and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) undergoing 24-hour esophageal MII-pH. The study will identify any differences in the biochemical profile (pepsin and pepsinogen concentration, electrolyte concentration, such as sodium and HCO3-) of saliva samples collected from healthy, GER and GERD patients. The study will also investigate possible circadian variations in the biochemical profile (see above) of saliva samples collected at different time points during MII-pH performed in GER and GERD infants. The study will correlate the onset of symptoms and nutrition to any changes in the biochemical profile (see above) of saliva samples taken from GER and GERD infants. The study will identify the prevalence of GERD in a cohort of infants with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux.

[/INST] The NAMELS-18 study is a prospective open-label observational study that aims to compare the effect of Dulaglutide and Empagliflozin in liver fat fraction of diabetic patients after a year of treatment. The study will assess liver steatosis change in patients, percentage of those with >30% liver fat concentration reduction, and compare Empagliflozin group with Dulaglutide group and Control group. The study will also evaluate the impact of the medications used on glycemic control, weight loss, liver enzymes, lipids and the Fatty Liver Index (FLI), the Fibrosis-4 Index (FIB-4), as well as the Aspartate Aminotransferase to Platelet ratio Index (APRI) and the NAFLD Fibrosis Score (NFS).

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to assess the feasibility of surgical exposure of palatally impacted upper canines with an open-eruption technique using a surgical template. The secondary purpose of the study is to compare this method with the conventional free-hand surgical exposure. The study will include 20 patients per group, and the surgical template will be designed using OnyxCeph™ software. The template will be manufactured using fused deposition modeling (FDM) and will be used to guide the surgical exposure of the impacted canine. The study will also assess the success of the intervention, success of the open eruption technique, surplus costs of surgical planning and manufacturing the surgical guide, duration of the surgical intervention, postoperative pain, and intra- and postoperative complications associated with surgery.

[/INST] The Clinician-Assisted Videofeedback Exposure-Approach Therapy (CAVEAT) Trial is a feasibility study that aims to determine if the manualized brief psychotherapy Clinician Assisted Videofeedback Exposure-Approach Therapy (CAVEAT) can be administered to violence-exposed mothers and their young children (ages 1-5 years) in the ambulatory care center of a Swiss public hospital (SUPEA, CHUV). The study will assess the feasibility of the recruitment procedures and adherence to treatment among patients, mother, and child therapeutic alliance as well as in terms of the mother and child satisfaction. The study will also assess if CAVEAT evaluation measures (questionnaires and observed interactions) will be found appropriate, adequate, and sensitive by patients and therapists to the outcomes targeted. The study will also assess if CAVEAT for the therapists is feasible to administer in terms of the application of the psychotherapy manual and the psychotherapy procedures involved to the clinic population.

[/INST] The study is a 1-year randomized controlled trial with three years of follow-up. The primary outcome is the incidence of type 2 diabetes confirmed by a 2-hr 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) over a 4-year period. The secondary outcomes are the incidence of impaired fasting glucose and impaired glucose tolerance, changes in cardiometabolic variables (e.g., body weight, HbA1c, insulin, blood lipids, blood pressures) in the women, changes in women's body composition, changes in women's mental well-being (e.g., defined by BDI-II, STAI, WHO-5, PSS-4), changes in the health and wellbeing of their children, and a composite of major adverse events (MAE) comprising fatal and non-fatal events associated with type 2 diabetes. The study is a 1-year randomized controlled trial with three years of follow-up. The primary outcome is the incidence of type 2 diabetes confirmed by a 2-hr 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) over a 4-year period. The secondary outcomes are the incidence of impaired fasting glucose and impaired glucose tolerance, changes in cardiometabolic variables (e.g., body weight, HbA1c, insulin, blood lipids, blood pressures) in the women, changes in women's body composition, changes in women's mental well-being (e.g., defined by BDI-II, STAI, WHO-5, PSS-4), changes in the health and wellbeing of their children, and a composite of major adverse events (MAE) comprising fatal and non-fatal events associated with type 2 diabetes.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of dry heat and dry cold application on pain, anxiety, and fear levels before blood sample collection in school-age children. The study is divided into three groups: control group, dry heat application group, and dry cold application group. The control group received standard care, while the other two groups received either dry heat or dry cold application for 5 or 3 minutes, respectively, before blood sample collection. The study's primary outcome is pain level measured by the Wong Baker Faces Pain Rating Scale one minute after blood sample collection. The secondary outcomes are anxiety and fear levels measured by the Child Fear Scale, Child Anxiety Scale, and Medical Procedures Fear Inventory two minutes before and two minutes after blood sample collection. The study's terms are blood sampling, children, dry heat, dry cold, and pediatric nurse.

[/INST] Melphalan Chemoreduction for Ocular Melanoma is a phase I clinical trial that aims to assess the safety profile of chemoreduction with intra-arterial melphalan, followed by Ru-106 plaque brachytherapy, performed in patients that would otherwise need enucleation due to tumor size. The study will enroll patients with clinically diagnosed choroidal melanoma with tumor thickness equal to or greater than 8.00 mm. IAC with 7.5 mg of melphalan will be performed through selective catheterization of the ophthalmic artery followed by Ru-106 plaque brachytherapy 4±1 weeks after the IAC. The primary outcome measure is the determination of treatment safety through electroretinography (ERG) at 6 months. The secondary outcome measures are reduction of tumor size, best corrected visual acuity (BCVA), signs of intraocular inflammation, and treatment-related adverse events. The study will be conducted in Brazil and is expected to last 12 months.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective observational trial that aims to determine the characteristics of patients admitted to the emergency room due to trauma in a general hospital in Villavicencio, Colombia. The study will collect data on the number of patients admitted to the emergency room due to trauma, the number of patients who died during hospitalization or within 28 days of hospitalization, the number of days of hospitalization, the number of patients who required ICU, the number of days of ICU stay, the number of patients who required mechanical ventilation, and the number of days of mechanical ventilation. The study will also collect data on the type of trauma, the mechanism of trauma, the severity of the trauma, and the type of treatment received. The study will collect data from January to June 2023. The study will be conducted in a general hospital in Villavicencio, Colombia. The study will collect data from medical records and will not involve any interventions or treatments. The study will collect data on the number of patients admitted to the emergency room due to trauma, the number of patients who died during hospitalization or within 28 days of hospitalization, the number of days of hospitalization, the number of patients who required ICU, the number of days of ICU stay, the number of patients who required mechanical ventilation, and the number of days of mechanical ventilation. The study will also collect data on the type of trauma, the mechanism of trauma, the severity of the trauma, and the type of treatment received. The study will collect data from January to June 2023. The study will be conducted in a general hospital in Villavicencio, Colombia. The study will collect data from medical records and will not involve any interventions or treatments.

[/INST] The study is a feasibility trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of non-invasive postural therapy (NIPT) for older adult veterans with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS). The study will involve a single group of participants who will receive DME and training to support continuous maintenance of flexion posture during the 6-week trial. The primary outcome measure is change in mobility by actigraphy, and the study will use a single-arm design. The study will be conducted at the VA Palo Alto Health Care System and will involve 20 participants. The study will evaluate the feasibility of the NIPT and its effectiveness in improving mobility in older adult veterans with LSS.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study to assess the effects of self-administered nitrous oxide (SANO) on urodynamic study (UDS) parameters. The study will be conducted in a randomized crossover design. Participants will undergo urodynamic study (UDS) with two fills. The participant will receive self-administered nitrous oxide (SANO) at a range of 25-50% immediately before and during catheter placements. At this time, a participant-preferred level of SANO will be determined. At the start of the first UDS run, SANO will continue at the participant-preferred level that was determined during catheter placement, ensuring that the patient is relaxed but still conversant through the procedure. At the end of the first UDS run, SANO will be turned down to 0%. Participants will then receive 100% oxygen at 10 liters/minute for the duration of their second UDS run.

[/INST] The study titled "Adverse Childhood Experiences, Adaptation and Breast Cancer" is a prospective cohort study that aims to investigate the relationship between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), resilience, and quality of life in women with breast cancer. The study will include 100 women with breast cancer who have completed their treatment and are in remission. The study will use a combination of self-reported questionnaires and biological measures to assess the participants' quality of life, fear of recurrence, fatigue, anxiety, depression, attachment, ACEs, resilience, and resting heart rate variability. The study will use the Short Form Survey 12 (SF-12 scale) to assess quality of life, the Cancer Recurrence Fear Inventory to assess fear of recurrence, the Multidimensional Fatigue Inventory (MFI) to assess fatigue, the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) to assess anxiety and depression, the Relationship Scales Questionnaire (RSQ) to assess attachment, the Adverse Childhood Experiences International Questionnaire (ACE-IQ) to assess ACEs, the Brief Resilience Scale (BRS) to assess resilience, and resting heart rate variability (RMSSD) to assess cardiac vagal modulation. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including both quantitative and qualitative data analysis. The study will use a combination of descriptive statistics, correlation analysis, and regression analysis to analyze the quantitative data. The study will also use a thematic analysis to analyze the qualitative data. The study will be conducted over the course of one year, with data collection occurring at baseline and at three, six, nine, and 12 months after baseline. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the local ethics committee. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is a single-center, non-randomized, crossover trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of a computer-assisted polyp detection system in clinical practice. The system is based on artificial intelligence and is designed to detect polyps and adenomas during colonoscopy. The study will compare the results between expert and non-expert endoscopists. The primary outcome measures are the adenoma detection rate (ADR) and polyp detection rate (PDR). The secondary outcome measure is the adenoma miss rate (AMR). The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study will enroll patients who are 45 years of age or older and are referred for screening colonoscopy. Patients will be excluded if they are pregnant, have a history of colorectal cancer, or have a history of inflammatory bowel disease. The study will be conducted over a period of three years.

[/INST] The study is titled "Low-Glycemic (LGI) Diet in Pregnant People With Epilepsy" and is a non-randomized controlled trial. The study aims to explore the tolerability, seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolite alterations of the LGI diet in pregnant people with epilepsy. The study will enroll pregnant people with epilepsy up to 20 weeks gestation and will compare the LGI diet group to the control group. The LGI diet group will meet with a dietician to initiate the diet and have ongoing dietician support and food questionnaires, while the control group will follow a standard diet as chosen by participants with ongoing food questionnaires. The primary outcome measure is the tolerability of the LGI diet in pregnant people with epilepsy, which will be measured by the number of participants able to continue the diet in pregnancy with diet questionnaires and dietician follow-up visits. The secondary outcome measures are seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolite alterations. The study will collect data during the intervention and through 3 months postpartum.

[/INST] The study is a feasibility study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells as a neo-adjuvant treatment in patients with resectable pancreatic cancers. The study will be conducted in a single center and will enroll patients with histologically confirmed pancreatic cancer planned for curative resection. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells as a neo-adjuvant treatment in patients with resectable pancreatic cancers. The study will use endoscopic ultrasound-guided injection of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells into the pancreatic tumor. The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of major pathologic response on resected specimen of pancreatic tumor. The secondary outcome measures will be radiological response according to RECIST 1.1 measured on CT 4 weeks after EUS guided MSLN CAR-T injection, rate of R0 surgical resection, and incidence rate of serious adverse events of grade III and above. The study will be conducted in China and will enroll 10 patients. The study will be conducted over a period of 10 years.

[/INST] The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a web-based decision support system (DSS) and machine learning web application in fostering adherence to oral anticancer treatments within a sample of 100 metastatic breast cancer (MBC) patients over a three-month period. The DSS is a web-based solution named TREAT (TREatment Adherence SupporT) that comprises four sections: i) Metastatic Breast Cancer; ii) Adherence to Cancer Therapies; iii) Promoting Adherence; iv) My Adherence Diary. The machine learning web application was designed to focus on predicting patients' risk factors for adherence to anticancer treatment, specifically considering physical status, comorbid conditions, and short- and long-term side effects. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the DSS in fostering adherence to oral anticancer treatments and identify clinical, psychological, and quality of life predictors of adherence. The study will also evaluate risk perception as a predictor for patients' adherence to oral anticancer treatments.

[/INST] The study titled "Effects of Weight Bearing Exercises With and Without Jaffrey's Core Stability Exercise Training on Dynamic Balance and Trunk Muscles Strength in Children With Down Syndrome" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of weight-bearing exercises and Jaffrey's core stability exercises on dynamic balance and trunk muscles strength in children with Down syndrome. The study will include children with a medical diagnosis of Down syndrome, aged 4 to 10 years, who are able to stand and walk. The study will use a parallel assignment model, and the allocation will be randomized. The study will have two arms: the first arm will receive weight-bearing exercises, and the second arm will receive Jaffrey's core stability exercises. The primary outcome measure will be the Pediatric Balance Scale, and the secondary outcome measure will be the Trunk Control Measurement Scale. The study will last for 4 weeks, and the results will be measured at the end of the study.

[/INST] The Effects of Melatonin on Cardiovascular and Bone Metabolism Markers in Peritoneal Dialysis Patients is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of melatonin supplementation on cardiovascular and bone metabolism markers in peritoneal dialysis patients. The study will enroll 40 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the melatonin or placebo group. The primary outcome measures include lipoprotein-a, malondialdehyde, high sensitivity c-reactive protein, and soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1. The secondary outcome measures include fasting glucose, pentosidine, carboxy-methyl lysine, procollagen 1 intact N-terminal propeptide, osteoprotegerin, tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b, receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-Β ligand, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, triglyceride, total cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, quality of life index, Beck depression test, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index questionnaire. The study will last for 10 weeks, and the participants will be given melatonin or placebo three times a day. The study will be conducted in Iran and is currently in the recruiting phase.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to optimize oxygen delivery during cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The study will include patients aged over 18 years who are scheduled for elective cardiac surgery under CPB at the University Hospital of Lille, France. The intervention will be the use of a device that will monitor oxygen delivery during CPB. The primary outcome measure will be the values of DO2 calculated with the CONNECT software (LivaNova, London, United Kingdom) using CPB output and hemoglobin values. The secondary outcome measures will be the incidence of postoperative acute kidney injury, postoperative delirium, and vital status checklist up to 28 days postoperative. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the French Ethics Committee.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, triple-masked, crossover trial that aims to investigate the effect of auricular acupressure on the temperature of the lumbar region in healthy volunteers. The study will be conducted in two stages, with each stage consisting of three sessions. In the first stage, participants will receive auricular acupressure on the left ear, auricular acupressure on the right ear, and sham auricular acupressure on the left ear. In the second stage, participants will receive sham auricular acupressure on the left ear, auricular acupressure on the right ear, and auricular acupressure on the left ear. The temperature of the lumbar region will be measured using an infrared thermal imaging camera during each session. The study will be conducted in a controlled environment, and the temperature, pressure, humidity, and ventilation of the room will be maintained throughout the study. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial with three parallel groups. The study population will consist of patients undergoing cardiac surgery with CPB. The patients will be randomized to one of three groups: 1) Standard MAP group (MAP values between 50-60 mmHg); 2) High MAP group (MAP values between 70-80 mmHg); 3) Patient-tailored MAP group (MAP values comparable to the patient's pre-operative MAP). The primary outcome measure is the serum lactate peak (Lmax) during CPB. The secondary outcome measures are the area under the curve (AUC) of the serum lactate values during CPB, the number of cases with serum lactate peak > 3 mmol/l during CPB, the evaluation of intraoperative cerebral perfusion (through monitoring of NIRS) and the intraoperative pulmonary perfusion (through Pa/Fi ratio, paO2, paCO2 at ABG and VO2R and DO2 of CDI), the evaluation of intraoperative and postoperative low cardiac output syndrome (through the calculation of VISmax), the postoperative and 30-day LVEF (%) and the postoperative and 30-day Acute Kidney Injury (according to AKIN score), the postoperative gastrointestinal ischemia, the hepatic function and coagulation indexes, the evaluation of neurological dysfunction and the in-hospital mortality and at 30 days from surgery.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study of the acute and subacute effects of furosemide in patients with acute heart failure. After inclusion, 80 mg of furosemide is administered IV. Measurements include blood pressure, peripheral oxygen saturation, pulmonary fluid content, ultrasound examination of heart and lungs, and assessment of cardiac filling pressures with doppler and strain analysis. Measurements are repeated at several time points until 6 hours have passed.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a smartphone application in reducing binge drinking in university students. The application will provide personalized feedback based on the results of blood tests for phosphatidylethanol (PEth), a biomarker of alcohol consumption. The study will last for 30 months and will involve two groups of participants: one group will use the smartphone application, while the other group will not use the application. The primary outcome measure will be the number of standard drinks per week, while the secondary outcome measures will be the PEth concentration at various time points during the study. The study will be conducted in France and will involve 1,000 participants.

[/INST] Nitazoxanide as Adjuvant Therapy in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the potential benefit of nitazoxanide in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study will compare the effects of nitazoxanide on glycemic control, insulin resistance, lipid profile, and serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1 and asprosin in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus receiving treatment with metformin and dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors. The study will enroll 70 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus who will be randomly assigned to either the control group or the nitazoxanide group. The control group will receive no intervention, while the nitazoxanide group will receive nitazoxanide 500 mg orally twice daily in addition to metformin and DPP-4 inhibitors. The study will measure the changes in fasting blood glucose, glycated hemoglobin, fasting insulin level with HOMA-IR calculation, serum levels of total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, and triglycerides, serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1, and serum levels of asprosin at 12 weeks.

[/INST] The study titled "Autism Clinical Risk Factors Investigation With Microbiome and Metabolome Profiling" is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the association between autism clinical risk factors and gut microbiome and metabolome profiling. The study will include autistic children aged between 3-9 years and will collect data on prenatal, natal and postnatal history, then regression analysis will be performed to identify autism clinical risk factors. Stool samples will be collected from the participants and intestinal microbiome and fecal metabolome analysis will be performed. The study will be conducted in Egypt and will last for one year. The study will provide valuable insights into the role of gut microbiome and metabolome in autism and may lead to the development of new treatments for the disorder.

[/INST] The study aims to develop an internet-based self-help money management program for adults with severe mental illness. The program will be compared to a wait-list control group. The primary outcome is financial self-efficacy, and the secondary outcomes are financial behaviour, financial attitude, financial well-being, psychological well-being, anxiety symptoms, depressive symptoms, quality of life, treatment adherence, treatment satisfaction, and treatment satisfaction on the internet. The study will be conducted in Hong Kong.

[/INST] The study is titled "Effectiveness of START (Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy) in Enhancing Arm Function Post-Stroke" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of START in enhancing arm function in individuals with stroke. The study will compare the effects of START to a control group on measures of arm function, such as electromyography (EMG) onset, movement onset, movement linearity, and functional reaching task scores. The study will also evaluate the capacity of START to enhance training outcomes in individuals with stroke and the generalizability of START training to untrained tasks. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France and is expected to last for 1 year.

[/INST] The study is a single-arm trial that aims to evaluate the effects of endoscopic lung volume reduction (ELVR) on diaphragm function and conformation in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The study will use endobronchial valves to reduce the volume of the hyperinflated lung and will evaluate the diaphragmatic strength and conformation before and 3 months after the procedure. The diaphragmatic strength will be assessed by transdiaphragmatic pressure measured at the functional residual capacity (FRC) after magnetic phrenic stimulation. Diaphragmatic conformation will be evaluated by high-resolution computed tomography at the FRC, allowing 3D modelling of the diaphragm for measurements of fibers length, length of the zone of apposition and radius of curvature of the diaphragmatic domes.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the clinical performance of three bulk-fill resin composites in Class II restorations. The study will include 30 participants who will receive three Class II restorations with each of the three tested bulk-fill resin composites. The primary outcome measures are esthetic, functional, and biological properties. The study will follow up with participants for two years.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, randomized, open-label, multicenter clinical trial. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of 177Lu-DOTATATE and everolimus in patients with metastatic unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumors. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE vs. everolimus on progression-free survival (PFS). The secondary objectives include the toxicity and safety of 177Lu-DOTATATE and everolimus, the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE vs. everolimus on overall response rate (ORR), overall survival (OS), post progression survival (PPS), and time to second objective disease progression (PFS2). The study will be conducted in two arms. In arm I, patients will receive 177Lu-DOTATATE every 8 weeks. In arm II, patients will receive everolimus orally every day. The study will be conducted in 12 centers in Italy. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the Istituto Oncologico Veneto, Padova, Italy.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of Mulligan techniques versus McKenzie extension exercises for chronic unilateral radicular low back pain. The primary objective is to evaluate the outcome of Mulligan techniques versus McKenzie extension exercises in terms of pain reduction and range of motion. The study will include 32 patients with chronic unilateral radicular low back pain, aged 28-50 years, who will be randomly assigned to either Mulligan techniques or McKenzie extension exercises. The interventions will be performed twice a week for four weeks, and the outcomes will be assessed at baseline and at the completion of the intervention. The study will use the Visual Analogue Scale, Oswestry Disability Scale, and lumbar range of motion as assessment tools. The data will be analyzed using SPSS. The results will be presented as mean and standard deviation.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2, multicenter, long-term, open-label extension trial that aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP administered once weekly in children and adolescents with achondroplasia. The study will enroll participants who have completed a clinical trial with TransCon CNP and meet the inclusion criteria. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events, and the secondary outcome measure is the annualized growth velocity. The study will be conducted over an average of 10 years.

[/INST] The study is an observational study that aims to explore the impact of illness perceptions and coping strategies on the quality of life of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation patients. The study will use correlation analysis and mediation analysis to assess the mediating effects of self-efficacy, coping, depression, and anxiety on the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study will measure the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation using the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12) at the start of the study and up to 24 weeks. The SF-12 is a multipurpose short-form survey that measures generic health-related quality of life (HRQoL). The study will assess the impact of illness perceptions and coping strategies on the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

[/INST] The LORENA trial is a multicenter, prospective, observational study that aims to evaluate the efficacy of local excision for the treatment of early rectal cancer. The study will include patients with clinical staging cT1N0M0 and tumor inferior verge no farther than 2 cm proximal to the anorectal rim. The primary outcome measure is the success rate, defined as the rate of patients with no need of total mesorectal excision after follow-up. The secondary outcome measures include morbidity rate, radicality of resection, histological poor outcome predictor rate, and radical rescue surgery specimen quality. The study will have a follow-up period of 36 months.

[/INST] The study is a prospective multicenter registry that aims to evaluate the impact of the center volume-outcome relationship and that on mortality, which remain poorly understood. The study also aims to evaluate whether precise risk stratification can provide better patient counseling and be used for unit-surgeon benchmarking. Ultimately, the study aims to investigate outcome predictors in patients undergoing surgery for TAAD, including clinical and perioperative variables as well as to evaluate follow up beyond 15 years.

[/INST] Virtual Reality to Cope With Academic Stress is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of virtual reality on stress and academic performance in physiotherapy and nursing students. The study will compare three groups: an experimental group that will receive a 4-week program with virtual reality, an active comparator group that will receive a 4-week program with traditional guided visualization, and a control group that will not receive any intervention. The primary outcomes are academic stress and perceived stress in the last month, and the secondary outcomes are the level of current perceived stress, blood pressure, maximal heart rate, salivary cortisol level, and exam qualification. The study will use the SISCO Inventory version-21 and the Perceived Stress Scale to measure academic stress and perceived stress in the last month, respectively. The level of current perceived stress will be measured by a question asking about the level of stress the student is feeling at that moment. Blood pressure, maximal heart rate, and salivary cortisol level will be measured by a healthcare professional. Exam qualification will be measured by the average qualification of the degree. The study will be conducted in the University of the Balearic Islands, Spain. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the use of remimazolam and propofol as anesthetic induction agents in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The primary outcome is the rate of hypotension events during anesthesia induction. The secondary outcomes are induction time, vasopressor use, and hypotension events during anesthesia induction. The study is conducted in a single center and has a sample size of 44 patients per group. The study is currently in the recruiting phase.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel treatment regimen for patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). The treatment regimen consists of nivolumab, gemcitabine, cisplatin, and radiation therapy. The primary objective of the study is to estimate the rate of immune-related adverse events (irAEs) that are grade 3 or higher during induction chemotherapy. The secondary objectives include estimating the event-free survival (EFS), objective response rate (ORR), and feasibility success of the induction regimen. The study will enroll patients with stage II-IV NPC who are aged 18-21 years and have not received prior radiotherapy or chemotherapy for the treatment of NPC. Patients will receive nivolumab, gemcitabine, cisplatin, and radiation therapy. The study will also collect and bank specimens for future research studies. The study will be conducted at the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, observational cohort study that aims to measure gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function, and liver endpoints in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) aged 6 to 11 years. The study will use a modified version of the protocol used in the GIFT-CF3 study to measure GI physiology in addition to MRI measures of lung and liver structure and function. The aim is to identify whether these measures are changed before and after starting ETI. For the CF participants, to be enrolled in the study they must be homozygous or have at least 1 copy of the Phe508del mutation, which would mean they are eligible for ETI treatment. The modified MRI protocol, taken from NCT04618185, has been shortened to include scans that are taken over three timepoints. These timepoints are determined around the ingestion of a test meal which has been previously described. Participants will arrive fasted before having a baseline scan. After their first scan they will eat their first standardised high fat meal followed by a second standardised high fat meal around 240 minutes after. MRI scans to assess GI function will be taken at baseline (fasted), 240 minutes post ingestion of a breakfast meal (T240) and 300 minutes post breakfast (T300). Liver scans will also be taken at baseline and lung scans taken opportunistically at the T240 timepoint. In total, participants will be asked to remain in the MRI scanner for approximately 30 minutes at a time. For comfort, participants will be able to watch multimedia programmes through the use of a specially adapted television while in the scanner. Participants will also be asked to complete validated gastrointestinal questionnaires throughout the study day and recall their GI symptoms over the previous 2 weeks and complete a 3 day food diary. The study will be split into two phases. The first will be a pilot phase where 3 children with CF aged 6 to 11 years and 3 healthy age and gender matched controls undergo MRI scanning. These scans will be assessed to determine whether the scan protocol can be completed by the participants and assess the quality of the images obtained. If successful, the trial

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center study that aims to compare the analgesic efficacy and safety of caudal methylprednisolone in pediatric patients undergoing hypospadias surgical repair using the duration of analgesia as the primary outcome. The study will compare the analgesic efficacy and safety of caudal methylprednisolone with caudal dexamethasone.

[/INST] The study is a prospective randomized pilot study evaluating the addition of hemodiafiltration (HDF) to ex vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) in marginal donor lungs. The study aims to determine the suitability for transplantation of the lungs after 6 hours of EVLP with HDF and the PGD grade 3 at 72 hours after transplantation. The study will also assess survival, length of mechanical ventilation, length of intensive care unit stay, length of hospital stay, and lung function parameters (MEF50) at 1, 3, 6, 12, and 24 months after transplantation.

[/INST] The study aimed to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants. Retinopathy is a common eye disorder among premature infants that can lead to long-term visual impairments if left untreated. Therefore, finding effective interventions for retinopathy examinations is crucial for improving the overall visual health of these infants. A randomized controlled experimental design was employed, with premature infants as the study participants. The infants were randomly assigned to three groups: the control group, the white noise group, and the multisensory stimulation group. The white noise group received auditory stimulation through the presentation of white noise, while the multisensory stimulation group received additional visual and tactile stimuli during the retinopathy examination. Several outcome measures were used to evaluate the effectiveness of the interventions. These measures included physiological responses (e.g., heart rate, blood pressure), behavioral indicators (e.g., eye movement, crying), and overall examination success rate. The examination success rate was defined as the ability to complete the retinopathy examination without disturbances caused by infant distress or movement. The study employed trained healthcare professionals who performed retinopathy examinations using standardized procedures. Data collection was conducted in a controlled environment to ensure consistency across three groups. Statistical analyses, such as ANOVA and chi-square tests, were employed to compare the outcomes between the three groups. The findings of this study have the potential to contribute to the development of effective and well-tolerated retinopathy examination protocols for premature infants. By comparing the effects of white noise and multisensory stimulation, the study aims to provide insights into the most suitable intervention that can optimize the examination process, improve examination success rates, and minimize potential discomfort or distress experienced by infants. It is anticipated that the results of this study will inform healthcare professionals and researchers about the benefits of auditory stimulation (white noise) and the additional advantages of multisensory stimulation during retinopathy examinations. Ultimately, this research aims to enhance the overall quality of care provided to premature infants, leading to improved visual outcomes and long-term well-being for this vulnerable population.

[/INST] The study titled "A Modified Calculation Formula for Meibomian Gland Grading" is a comparative study that aims to compare the effectiveness of a modified calculation formula for Meibomian gland grading with the previous calculation formula. The study will include participants aged 18 to 80 years who meet the inclusion criteria and do not meet the exclusion criteria. The study will use the area of the Meibomian glands and the whole eyelids, as well as the WTW distance of the cornea, as primary outcome measures. The study will compare the results obtained using the modified calculation formula with those obtained using the previous calculation formula. The study will be conducted in China and will last for 1 year.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to prevent oral mucositis in subjects undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. The study will be conducted as a single-blind randomized clinical trial. The population will be divided into two groups, receiving respectively the medical device and a solution based on Sodium Bicarbonate (5 g/L). The investigational product will be administered for 63 days. The primary outcome measure is the presence of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. The secondary outcome measures are the time of onset of oral mucositis and the severity of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. The study will be conducted in Italy and will involve 100 participants.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional clinical study to determine the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva in healthy and periodontally affected subjects. The study will include participants who are adults (≥18-year-old) and are diagnosed as periodontally healthy, gingivitis, treated periodontitis patient (stable/unstable), periodontitis stages I & II, or periodontitis stages III and IV. The study will measure the combination of C-reactive protein (CRP), triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-1 (TREM-1), interleukin (IL)-1beta, metalloproteinase (MMP)-8, IL-10, IL-6, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), Macrophage Inflammatory Protein-1 Alpha (MIP-1), interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), osteoprotegerine (OPG), Receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa B ligand (RANKL), Tumor Necrosis Factor-Alpha (TNF-alpha) in saliva. The primary outcome measure is the salivary biomarkers, and the secondary outcome measures are age, gender, Hb1Ac, Finn-risk, blood pressure, patient's temperature, drug, alcohol, and smoking history, plaque index, bleeding on probing, suppuration on probing, probing depth, recession, radiographic bone loss, and microbiological analyses.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the effect of white noise, heart sound, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance. The study was a randomized controlled trial with a sample of 84 infants with a gestational age of 28-42 weeks. The infants were exposed to white noise, heart sounds, or the music that the mother listened to most frequently during pregnancy for 10 minutes before the heel lance, during, and 20 minutes after the procedure. The pain of the infants before, during, and after the procedure was measured using the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS). Also, the duration of the procedure and the crying time were evaluated.

[/INST] The study is a comparison of two training and supervision processes for clinicians who will be leading Caregiver Skills Training (CST) groups. One group will be trained and supervised remotely, while the other will be trained and supervised face-to-face. Both groups will receive 15 hours of training and 1 hour of supervision per week for 12 weeks. The study will measure the change in caregiver skills and knowledge related to session content as well as caregiver confidence from baseline to week 12 using the Caregivers Skills and Knowledge Measure. The study will also measure parental distress, parent-child dysfunctional interaction, and child challenges using the Parenting Stress Index, adaptive skills using the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, and social communication abilities using the Social Communication Checklist. The study will also assess the extent to which caregivers are using the strategies they learned using the Caregiver Diary.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) in combination with a strengthening exercise program for the treatment of subacromial pain syndrome (SDPS). The study will include 64 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (strengthening exercises + TES) or the control group (strengthening exercises + sham TES). The intervention will consist of 24 sessions of strengthening exercises and TES or sham TES over a period of 8 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the Spanish version of the Western Ontario Rotator Cuff (WORC) index, and the secondary outcome measures will include pain intensity, shoulder muscle strength, active range of motion, joint position sense, subacromial space width, scapulohumeral rhythm, and scapulothoracic muscle activation. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including qualitative interviews and quantitative data analysis. The results of the study will provide evidence on the effectiveness of TES in combination with a strengthening exercise program for the treatment of SDPS.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective study that aims to evaluate the association between hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) and change in verbal scores in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study included children aged 2 to 17 years, diagnosed with ASD who completed a verbal test every six months (either Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program or the Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills), received applied behavioral analysis at Oxford Recovery Center (ORC) and some of whom had elected to receive HBOT (at least 40 sessions for 60 minutes at 2.0 ATA). The study compared the verbal scores of children with ASD who underwent HBOT to those who did not undergo HBOT. The study found that children with ASD who underwent HBOT had a significant improvement in their verbal scores compared to those who did not undergo HBOT. The study also found that HBOT was safe and well tolerated in children with ASD.

[/INST] The Analgesic Efficacy of Ultrasound Guided Adductor Canal Block Versus 4 in 1 Block in Patients Undergoing Knee Surgeries: A Comparative Randomized Double Blinded Study. The study is a randomized double-blind study that compares the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound-guided adductor canal block (ACB) and 4 in 1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. The study is conducted in a single center and includes 60 patients who are randomly assigned to receive either ACB or 4 in 1 block. The primary outcome measure is postoperative pain score at rest and dynamic using the Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) at 6, 12, 18, and 24 hours postoperatively. The secondary outcome measures include change in blood pressure and heart rate, first time for opioid rescue, and total dose of opioid rescue in the first 24 hours. The study is expected to complete in 2023.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, randomized controlled trial that aims to determine whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) can reduce the risk of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection. The study will compare the occurrence of arm lymphedema in patients who receive ILR with those who receive axillary lymph node dissection alone. The study will also measure the drainage amount from operative wounds, the occurrence of seroma or lymphocele, patient reported outcome measures by LYMPH-Q Upper Extremity Module, and the occurrence of subclinical lymphedema. The study will last for two years.

[/INST] The study is a descriptive study of the cosmetic and functional sequelae of patients who received releasing incisions in the management of acute upper limb burns. The study included adult patients with acute burns (less than 3 days) on one or both hands or finger burns, with skin surface burned less than 40% of the body, and chemical, thermal, or electrical burns of the hand. The study measured functional score, healing time, scar quality, and burn VAS at 3 and 6 months. The study found that the functional score and healing time were significantly improved at 3 and 6 months after the burn. Scar quality was also improved at 6 months after the burn. Burn VAS was also significantly improved at 3 and 6 months after the burn.

[/INST] The Stanford Plant-based Educational Study: Providers Learning About Nutrition Together (PLANT) is a randomized, delayed intervention trial that aims to test a flexible, multimodal Whole Food Plant-Based (WFPB) educational program for 6 weeks for providers at Stanford in any department. The study will utilize a pre- and post-study survey which will include information on current dietary habits and use of Diet ID (assessment of diet type and quality). The educational program will include interactive didactic sessions, cooking classes, and weekly emails with suggested resources and activities including movies, recipes, and websites. The primary outcome measure is the change in Diet ID score from baseline to Week 6. The secondary outcome measures are change in mindset about WFPBD from baseline to week 6 and change in stage of change (motivation and confidence) will be assessed using the validated survey for transtheoretical model of behavior change.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter study that aims to translate and validate the PRO questionnaire survivorship concerns in patients with early breast cancer. The questionnaire consists of 17 items that evaluate the problems of survival, the level of concern about problems related to the care of patients, screening, symptom management, family and genetic problems and the fear of disease recurrence. The questionnaire will be administered twice 15 days apart and the Interclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC) model 3.1 will be applied to identify the levels of agreement between the two assessments.

The study will measure the program's effectiveness through changes in postpartum anxiety, depression, and parenting stress scores, as well as parent-infant bonding and therapeutic group processes. The study will also assess the program's acceptability and feasibility through participant feedback.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the radial and femoral approaches for endovascular recanalization in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion. The primary outcome measure is favorable neurological function (defined as modified Rankin Scale score ≤ 3) at 90 days post-operation. The secondary outcome measure is procedure time of the endovascular thrombectomy at the operation 1 day.

[/INST] The BUNDLE study is a prospective mixed-methods study focused on the early integration of community doulas into prenatal care. The investigators will pursue the following aims using a multidisciplinary team of experts in health disparities, community engagement, qualitative research, maternal-fetal medicine, and doula support: Aim 1: Develop an integrated prenatal care model of medical providers and community doulas in Southeastern Wisconsin Approach: The investigators will conduct six focus groups with 30 Black/AA birthing people (currently pregnant or recently postpartum) and 30 prenatal healthcare providers (obstetricians, midwives, doulas, social workers, prenatal care coordinators, nurses, mental health providers, and obstetric unit leaders) to elicit feedback on models of doula/medical provider integration with the overarching aim of building trust and improving maternal health outcomes. Focus group findings will be reviewed with a community advisory panel (CAP) developed as part of the Community Partnership of the MCW U54 center, to gain the CAP's input on intervention development. Aim 2: Compare the effectiveness of the integrated prenatal care model to standard prenatal care in improving healthcare engagement and trust and reducing adverse maternal outcomes Approach: In a two-arm randomized controlled trial conducted at Froedtert and MCW, the investigators will randomize 412 Black/AA pregnant people to BUNDLE or standard prenatal care. Primary outcome is healthcare engagement (starting prenatal care in 1st trimester, attending at least 70% of the recommended visits, attending the postpartum visit, and receipt of recommended vaccination during pregnancy). Secondary outcomes include medical mistrust measured by trust in provider scale, perceived discrimination, and frequencies of severe maternal morbidity as defined by the Centers for Disease Control. Aim 3: Disseminate findings to scholarly and community-based forums and actively pursue opportunities for systems- and policy-level change Approach: The investigators will disseminate findings regularly in scholarly (conference, grand rounds) and community-based (listening session, town hall) forums. [/INST] IBRX-042 is a therapeutic vaccine that targets HPV-associated tumors. The study is a phase 1 open-label study that aims to determine the maximum tolerated dose of IBRX-042 and its safety profile. The study will enroll up to 60 subjects with HPV-associated tumors, who will receive up to three doses of IBRX-042. The study will also examine the humoral and cellular immune responses to IBRX-042. The study will have a duration of 2 years.

[/INST] Connective Tissue Massage and Classical Massage in Patients with Chronic Non-Specific Low Back Pain: A Randomized Controlled Trial. The study was a 3-arm randomized controlled trial, parallel-group study with blind outcomes assessor. The study adhered to the CONSORT guidelines for rigorous reporting. The intervention duration was 4 weeks, with 3 sessions per week lasting 15-20 minutes per session. Outcome measurements were taken at the beginning and 4 weeks after the completion of the program. An independent physiotherapist, unaware of the research details and participant groupings, conducted the evaluations. The study found that connective tissue massage and classical massage were effective in reducing pain and improving functional status and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of OMNI canaloplasty alone with OMNI canaloplasty and Hydrus microstent in patients with open-angle glaucoma. The study will enroll 80 patients who will undergo cataract surgery and will be randomized to receive either OMNI canaloplasty alone or OMNI canaloplasty and Hydrus microstent. The primary outcome measure is the change in unmedicated intraocular pressure from baseline at 12 months. The secondary outcome measures are the reduction in number of medications needed to control intraocular pressure from baseline and the percentage of patients with greater than 20% reduction in intraocular pressure from baseline.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-arm, comparative, controlled, multicenter study. The study will be conducted in 4 test facilities in Russia. The study will enroll 110 patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) who will be randomized to receive either Dorzotimol eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL or Cosopt eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL compared to Cosopt eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL in patients with POAG. The primary endpoint is the mean IOP change from baseline. The secondary endpoints are the IOP reduction rate to the target level of ≤ 18 mm Hg, the IOP reduction rate greater than 20%, and the IOP reduction rate greater than 30%. The study will have a duration of 12 weeks. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL compared to Cosopt eye drops, 20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL in patients with POAG.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of text messaging in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy in a VA hospital. The study will compare the effectiveness of text messaging in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy with no intervention. The study will use a parallel assignment model and will be conducted in a VA hospital. The study will use a 7-item assessment of participant satisfaction with the Annie text intervention to measure the primary outcome. The study will also measure the percentage of participants who attend scheduled colonoscopy appointments and the percentage of participants who have adequate bowel preparation at colonoscopy appointments as secondary outcomes. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design to evaluate the effectiveness of text messaging in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy.
