[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of hysteroscopy and endouterine aspiration in the management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage. The primary outcome is the uterine vacuity rate at 6 weeks after surgery. The secondary outcomes are the rate of complications, use of second-line surgical management, synechiae, and fertility at 2 years after surgery. The study will include 220 patients, with 110 patients in each arm. The patients will be randomized to either the hysteroscopy or aspiration group. The hysteroscopy group will undergo hysteroscopic removal of the trophoblastic tissue, while the aspiration group will undergo endouterine aspiration. The patients will be followed up for 2 years after the surgery. The study will provide evidence on the efficacy of hysteroscopy and endouterine aspiration in the management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage.

[/INST] The study is titled "On-line Crowdsourcing of Multi-Timescale Inference Strategies" and is designed to investigate the use of online crowdsourcing platforms to study multi-timescale inference strategies. The study involves a behavioral task that requires participants to make short-term, long-term, and multi-timescale inferences based on the information provided. The task is designed to last for approximately 30 minutes, and participants will be asked to provide binary behavioral decision responses. The study is expected to yield valuable insights into the mechanisms underlying multi-timescale inference strategies and their potential applications in various fields.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, double-blind, randomized, multicenter clinical trial that aims to evaluate the therapeutic effect of sinomenine and glucocorticoid on early knee osteoarthritis. The study will include 120 participants aged 40 to 70 years with bilateral knee pain lasting for more than 6 months and X-rays showing that Kellgren and Lawrence had grade 2 or 3 knee osteoarthritis. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either sinomenine or glucocorticoid intra-articular injection. The primary outcome measure is the change in the total WOMAC score from baseline, and the secondary outcome measure is the change in time from baseline in the TUG test and the 20m walking time. The study will last for 24 months after the first injection.

[/INST] The study is a single-blind pre-test post-test parallel group randomized controlled experimental design. The sample size of the study was determined as a result of the power analysis made by taking FEV1% in a study, and considering the losses, it was planned to form the sample of the study of 48 patients, 24 in the experimental and 24 in the control group. In the study, block randomization was chosen to reduce selection bias and distribute patients equally to groups. Patients who accept to participate in the study who meet the inclusion criteria will be pre-tested and assigned to the groups. Since the intervention will be applied in the research, investigator blinding will not be possible, and it is planned to blind the participants, whose consent forms have been prepared separately for the patients in the experimental and control groups. COPD Patient Identification Form, Pulmonary Function Test Evaluation Form, COPD Evaluation Test (CAT), Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) Dyspnea Scale, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), St George Respiratory Questionnaire and Virtual Reality Experience Evaluation Form. Research data will be collected in the pre-test, the fourth week of the research and the post-test (the eighth week of the research). Breathing exercise will be applied to the experimental group with virtual reality glasses. In adapting breathing exercises to virtual reality glasses; The exercise video was first shot by the researcher in front of a green screen. Then, a 3d background design was made by a software developer and it was transformed into a viewable form with these glasses. The exercise video was prepared as 20 minutes. The exercises will be done in the homes of the patients by making home visits. It is planned that the exercises will be done three times a week in a total of 24 sessions. No intervention will be applied to the control group. It is planned to evaluate the research data with the SPSS 26 package program.

[/INST] The study is titled "A Biobehavioral Approach to Understand the Multilevel Determinants of Cardiovascular Health in Black Women" and is a biobehavioral study that aims to evaluate the vascular health of Black women. The study will use a wrist-worn activity tracker and a blood pressure monitor bracelet to monitor participants' physical activity and blood pressure levels. Participants will also complete a series of lab-based assessments that evaluate their vascular health, including heart rate, blood pressure, large blood vessel flow, central aortic blood pressure and pulse wave velocity, brain blood flow, carbon dioxide concentration, flow mediated dilation/blood vessel responsiveness, breathing rate, and cerebral vasomotor reactivity. In addition, venous blood samples will be taken to identify biomarkers associated with elevated blood pressure and decreased blood flow. The study will also collect saliva samples on three consecutive days during the 10-day monitoring period. The primary outcome measure is macrovascular function, which will be assessed as brachial artery vasodilation following a period of suprasystolic cuff occlusion. The secondary outcome measure is physical activity, which will be assessed via a wrist-worn accelerometer. The study will last for 10 days.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, phase 2 trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of RCN3028 in the treatment of drug-induced moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms in breast cancer. The study will enroll postmenopausal women with a history of breast cancer who have completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy and are on a stable dose of tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors for at least 8 weeks at baseline. The primary outcome measure is the mean change in frequency of moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms from baseline to weeks 4 and 12. The secondary outcome measures include mean change in severity of moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms, menopause-specific quality of life questionnaire, 50%, 75%, and 100% responder rates, time to onset of efficacy, subject's and physician's global assessment, change from baseline in weekly weighted severity score, change from baseline in the number of mild, moderate, and severe hot flashes, and change from baseline in the number of nighttime awakenings because of hot flashes. The study will be conducted in Taiwan.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for the prevention of myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study will recruit 120 participants aged 18 to 80 years old who are scheduled to undergo elective surgery under general anesthesia. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: the first group will receive a dose of rocuronium of 0.04 mg/kg, the second group will receive a dose of rocuronium of 0.06 mg/kg, and the third group will receive a dose of rocuronium of 0.08 mg/kg. The study will measure the appearance of myofibrillation, which will be assessed by the presence or absence of myofibrillation within 45 seconds after the injection of succinylcholine. The study will also measure the dose of rocuronium required to prevent myofibrillation.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of dietary phospholipids on cognitive function, mood, and physical health in healthy adults. The study will recruit 220 participants who will be randomized to receive either a placebo or an active treatment containing phospholipids for a period of 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be cognitive function, which will be assessed using a computerized mental performance assessment system. Secondary outcome measures will include mood, physical health, and cognitive domain factor scores. The study will use a parallel-group design and will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. The study protocol has been approved by the Northumbria University Research Ethics Committee.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to investigate the presence of air pollutants and microplastics in the atherosclerotic plaques of patients undergoing carotid endarterectomy. The study will also examine the relationship between the presence of these pollutants and the incidence of a composite outcome of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality. The study will use pyrolysis-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry and transmission electron microscopy to detect the presence of air pollutants and microplastics in the atherosclerotic plaques. The study will also use immunohistochemistry, ELISAs, and Western Blot to quantify inflammatory and plaque stability markers in the atherosclerotic plaques. The study will use Cox regression analysis to examine the association between the presence of pollutants and the incidence of the composite outcome. The study will also examine the relationship between the burden of microplastics and the outcome.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective analysis of patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases who underwent transarterial radioembolization (TARE) with Therasphere microspheres. The study aims to compare the effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose between patients with and without response to TARE. The study also aims to investigate the dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships after TARE. The study will measure the effective tumor dose and dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships at 3 and 6 months after TARE, respectively.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the clinical performance of chemically cured conventional glass ionomer after light-emitting diode radiant heat enhancement. The study will be conducted on 18 patients with 36 second molars. Each patient will have two oclusso-mesial cavities, and each tooth will be restored with chemically cured conventional glass ionomer without any enhancement (M1 group) and chemically cured conventional glass ionomer that is enhanced with radiant heat (LED) (M2 group). The functional and biological criteria of each restoration will be clinically evaluated immediately after restoration (T0), six months later (T1), and after 12 months (T2) using Federation Dentaire International (FDI) criteria for assessment of dental restorations.

[/INST] The FAPO-X study is a single-center, interventional study conducted at the Heart Institute of the Clinics Hospital of the Medical School of the University of São Paulo (InCor - HCFMUSP). The study was divided into six phases: preoperative care, hospitalization, surgical phase, postoperative care, 30-day telemonitoring period, and outpatient visit. The study aimed to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF). The telemonitored group used the SAMSUNGTM Galaxy Watch5 smartwatch for remote monitoring, while the control group followed standard care protocols. The primary outcome measure was the rehospitalization rate, and the secondary outcome measures were scheduled consultations, extra occurrences, technological adherence, treatment adherence, and use of the mobile application by patients. The study was conducted in Brazil.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study of a randomized controlled trial to test whether the adoption of HSMonitor solutions by healthcare professionals and patients improves the management of patients with high blood pressure. The study will compare two digital solutions with standard care. The primary outcome measure is the change in systolic and diastolic blood pressure. The secondary outcome measure is user satisfaction. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

[/INST] The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of screening for liver disease in individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder. The trial will compare the effectiveness of a liver stiffness measurement (Transient Elastography) to a liver stiffness measurement (Fibroscan) in reducing alcohol consumption and improving liver function. The trial will also assess the feasibility of screening for liver disease in individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder.

[/INST] The study is titled "Study of the Value of Trio Exome Sequencing in the Etiological Assessment of Specific Non-syndromic Language and Learning Disorders." The study is designed to assess the value of trio exome sequencing in the etiological assessment of specific non-syndromic language and learning disorders. The study will collect blood samples from index cases and their biological parents and will perform exome sequencing to identify genetic causes of language and learning disorders. The study will also offer interviews to families with positive results and negative results. The primary outcome measure is the identification of a genetic cause defined by the presence of at least one ACMG class 4 or 5 variant. The study will be conducted in France and will last approximately 4 months.

[/INST] The Five Days for Health (FDH) program is a small group-based lifestyle modification program that aims to promote weight loss. The program involves coherent groups of motivated participants in smaller groups of 7-10 persons. The program is led by endocrinologists-diabetologists together with a nutritionist, a psychologist, and a kinesiologist. The program includes lectures on obesity, its consequences, and the importance of lifestyle modification for weight loss. The program also includes physical activity and psychological support. The program is designed to be completed in five days and includes follow-up visits at one month, three months, six months, and one year. The program aims to educate participants on healthy lifestyle habits, including a particular dietary pattern, regular physical activity, psychological support, education, and small group intervention. The program also aims to promote weight loss and improve body composition, metabolic parameters, and other health outcomes.

[/INST] The study is a phase I, open-label, single-arm, dose escalation study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and immunogenicity of Bio-008 in patients with advanced solid tumors. The study will enroll 72 patients, who will be assigned to one of seven dose groups of Bio-008. The primary objective is to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of Bio-008. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and anti-tumor activity of Bio-008. The study will be conducted in multiple centers in Japan. Patients will be administered Bio-008 intravenously over 1 hour on day 1 of each cycle. The study will consist of a dose escalation phase and a dose expansion phase. The dose escalation phase will be conducted to determine the MTD of Bio-008. The dose expansion phase will be conducted to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and immunogenicity of Bio-008 at the MTD. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Ethical Guidelines for Medical and Health Research Involving Human Subjects. The study protocol has been approved by the institutional review board of each participating institution. All patients will provide written informed consent before enrollment.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the effect of different music played during retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) examination on pain and comfort levels of premature infants. The study will compare three different music groups: a rainstick, the Happiest Baby, and no music. The study will use the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) and the Pain, Infant Comfort Scale (PBIC) to measure pain and comfort levels. The study will be conducted in a tertiary care hospital in France and will include 120 premature infants. The study will be randomized into three groups and will be blinded. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is an ambispective cohort study on the prognosis and its influencing factors of borderline personality disorder (BPD). The study is designed to collect demographic data, comorbid psychiatric diagnosis, psychotherapeutive and pharmacotherapeutive data, times of hospitalization and patients' contact information from electronic medical records. After informed consent, prospective follow-up is initiated primarily by telephone interviews and web-based questionnaires, or by in-person assessments at hospital return visits. Enrolled patients will be followed up at 6-month intervals after the first follow-up to assess psychiatric diagnosis, social function, and quality of life. The researchers are senior psychiatrists, all of whom received training on the use of questionnaires and inter-investigator consistency before the follow-up. Cox Proportional Hazard Model is used to analyze the influencing factors of remission of BPD, and Generalized Estimating Equation Model is used to analyze the influencing factors of the patients' social function and quality of life. The primary outcome measure is the remission rate of BPD, and the secondary outcome measures are social disability and quality of life. The study is conducted in China.

[/INST] The study is titled "Management of Dry Eye With Intense Pulsed Light in Combination With Diquafosol" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to assess the management of dry eye by combining intense pulsed light (IPL) and diquafosol eye drops. The study will be conducted in Japan and will include 40 participants who meet the inclusion criteria. The study will use intense pulsed light (IPL) and diquafosol eye drops as interventions. The primary outcome measure will be non-invasive tear break-up time (NIBUT), and the secondary outcome measures will include ocular surface disease index (OSDI), fluorescein and lissamine conjunctival and cornea staining (CFS), meibomian gland function and secretion quality, tear film lipid layer score (TFLL), tear meniscus height (TMH), and conjunctival hyperemia (RS score). The study will be conducted over a period of 28 days, and the results will be analyzed using statistical methods. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Ethical Guidelines for Medical and Health Research Involving Human Subjects.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of two different mental health interventions, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) versus mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT), in improving patient-centered mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment among autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depressive disorders. The study also explores patient characteristics that may moderate the relationship between CBT or MBT and patient outcomes and compares implementation outcomes of acceptability and feasibility of CBT relative to MBT as reported by patients and clinicians using mixed methods. The study will use the Patient Health Questionnaire Anxiety-Depression Scale (PHQ-ADS) as the primary outcome measure. The study will also use the Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI), Outcome Rating Scale (ORS), Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS), Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE), Sheehan Disability Scale (SDS), World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule II (WHODAS II), Negative Effects Questionnaire (NEQ), Client Satisfaction Questionnaire (CSQ-8), Survey of Autism Mental Healthcare Satisfaction (SAMHS), and other measures. The study will use a parallel assignment model with a single masking. The study will be conducted in the United States.

[/INST] The IMPACT 2.1 study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of methotrexate in treating immune-related arthritis or arthralgias (irAA) in patients with cancer receiving immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs). The study will enroll patients with irAA that developed on or after ICI therapy and is felt to be treatment-related. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients who discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without recurrence of grade 2 or higher irAA. The secondary outcome measures include total steroid usage, development of irAEs other than irAA, adverse events, and re-initiation of ICI therapy. The study will use methotrexate as the intervention and will follow patients for 3 years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of general and regional anesthesia on sleep quality in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The study will use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) to assess sleep quality, and the study will also evaluate pain, anxiety, and other factors that may affect sleep quality. The study will be conducted in Turkey and is currently in the recruiting phase.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2/3, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study to assess the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral atogepant for the prevention of migraine in Japanese subjects with episodic migraine. The study will have a 12-week treatment period and a 28-week follow-up period. Participants will be randomized to receive atogepant dose A, dose B, dose C, or placebo once daily for 12 weeks. Participants will be re-randomized at week 12 to receive atogepant dose A, dose B, or dose C once daily for an additional 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in the mean monthly migraine days. The secondary outcome measures include the change from baseline in the mean monthly headache days, acute medication use days, percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in the 3-month average of monthly migraine days, MSQ v2.1 role function-restrictive domain score, and AIM-D performance of daily activities domain score.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2, randomized, double-blind, controlled trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of efgartigimod in patients with Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS). The study will enroll patients with a diagnosis of GBS according to the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke Diagnostic Criteria for GBS. Patients will be randomized to receive either efgartigimod or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) for 5 days. The primary outcome measure is the Guillain-Barre Syndrome Disability Scale (GBS-DS) at 12 weeks. The secondary outcome measures include the number and seriousness of adverse events, Guillain-Barre Syndrome Disability Scale (GBS-DS) at 4, 24, and 48-weeks, Neuropathy Impairment Scale (NIS) at 4, 24, and 48-weeks, Inflammatory Rasch-Built Overall Disability Scale (I-RODS) at 4, 24, and 48-weeks, Forced Vital Capacity (FVC) at 4, 24, and 48-weeks, Maximal Inspiratory Pressure (MIP) at 4, 24, and 48-weeks, and Maximal Expiratory Pressure (MEP) at 4, 24, and 48-weeks.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2b, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel group, dose ranging study to evaluate the virological response and safety of oral PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized symptomatic adults with COVID-19. The study will enroll participants aged 18 to 64 years with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and initial onset of signs/symptoms attributable to COVID-19 within 5 days prior to the day of randomization. Participants will be randomized to receive one of three doses of PF-07817883 or placebo. The primary endpoint is the change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level at day 5. The secondary endpoint is the change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level at day 3, 10 and 14. The study will also evaluate the incidence of treatment related adverse events, incidence of serious adverse events, incidence of clinically significant abnormal laboratory values, incidence of AEs leading to discontinuations, incidence of clinically significant abnormal vital signs, and incidence of clinically significant abnormal ECGs.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the therapeutic effect of adding letrozole to the protocol of combined treatment of cesarean scar pregnancy. The study will compare two arms: MTX monotherapy and MTX + letrozole add-on. The study will measure the blood loss during the procedure expressed as a decrease in hemoglobin concentration, blood loss volume during the procedure expressed in volume units, and conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to due to hemorrhage. The study will also measure the effect of treatment on bone marrow function (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets), liver function (serum total bilirubin, alanine transaminase, aspartate transaminase, and gamma-glutamyltransferase), and kidneys function (urea and creatinine). The study will be conducted in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Centre Hospitalier Valida, France. The study will include 40 women with cesarean scar pregnancy who will be randomly assigned to one of the two arms. The study will have a follow-up period of up to 6 months. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee. The study will be conducted in compliance with the applicable regulatory requirements.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study to evaluate the feasibility of using blood from liver donors for transfusion to liver transplant recipients. The study will recruit adult liver transplant recipients who receive blood from liver donors during the transplantation procedure. The study will collect data on the number and percentage of liver transplant recipients who receive blood from liver donors, the blood product need in enrolled patients, and the rate of graft failure in the prospective sample. The study will compare these outcomes to a control group of liver transplant recipients who did not receive blood from liver donors. The study will evaluate the feasibility of using blood from liver donors for transfusion to liver transplant recipients.

[/INST] The study was conducted in Mansoura University Hospitals, Chest Medicine Department on patients attended to Asthma and Allergy clinic. The study was designed to compare the efficacy of sublingual and subcutaneous immunotherapy in patients with bronchial asthma. The study included 100 patients with asthma who were divided into two groups: one group received sublingual immunotherapy and the other group received subcutaneous immunotherapy. The study measured the total IgE and sputum eosinophil levels before and after 6, 12, and 18 months of treatment. The results showed that both sublingual and subcutaneous immunotherapy were effective in reducing the total IgE and sputum eosinophil levels. However, subcutaneous immunotherapy was more effective in reducing the total IgE levels after 6 and 12 months of treatment, while sublingual immunotherapy was more effective in reducing the sputum eosinophil levels after 18 months of treatment.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, single-center, observational cohort study that aims to determine the minimum number of biopsies required for a reliable diagnosis using contrast-enhanced stereotactic biopsy (CESB). The study will include non-pregnant women who are able to provide written informed consent and have a recombined-only lesion (ROL) recently observed during a regular contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM) examination. The study will use a 9 Gauge vacuum-assisted biopsy (VAB) to collect 18 samples, which will be collected in six separate and numbered cassettes. Each specimen will be histologically analyzed in this chronological order, and the findings will be compared with the final histopathological result after assessment of all 18 specimens. The primary study aim is to calculate the cumulative diagnostic yield per specimen, enabling us to define a minimum number of biopsies required to establish a reliable diagnosis using CESB. The secondary study outcomes will be general parameters of the biopsy procedure itself, such as patient characteristics, histopathological results, pain experienced during the procedure, and complication rates (hematoma, infection).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening and kinesiotaping on gait parameters in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study includes 30 participants who are randomly assigned to one of two groups: a concentric quadriceps strengthening group or a kinesiotaping group. The study measures temporospatial gait parameters, pain, functional status, and strength. The study finds that both concentric quadriceps strengthening and kinesiotaping improve gait parameters, pain, and functional status, but not strength. The study concludes that concentric quadriceps strengthening is more effective than kinesiotaping in improving gait parameters and pain in patients with knee osteoarthritis.

[/INST] The FTTIP supplement study is a qualitative study that aims to gather perceptions and experiences of trainees and agency leaders with the platform. The study will collect qualitative data that will be combined with the parent study's quantitative data to better understand the experiences of trainees and agency leaders with the platform. The study will include 20 trainees and 16 agency leaders from the sample of the parent study. The proposed supplement aims to: 1) gather perceptions and experiences of the trainees about the process of learning and practicing specific CIFFTA competencies from the platform (time 1 interview) and later, about their unique experiences related to implementation of the EBT, delivery of competencies learned, and the application of EBT in a real-world context (time 2); and 2) gain a deeper understanding from leaders of their experiences in facilitating EBTs at their agencies, the identification of barriers that can be addressed by the organizational readiness work (time 1), and later regarding their agencies experience with the platform, consultation process, perceived cost-benefit, and agency readiness (at time 2).

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial of a freshly manufactured 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment in the treatment of pain. The study was conducted in the Department of pain diagnosis and treatment of the affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University and the pain Department of the affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University. The study included 26 patients with shoulder, neck, back and temporal pain and 10 patients with herpes zoster pain. The study was designed as a single-group assignment, open-label clinical study. The study was conducted by mixing high-molecular-weight HA injectable solution and hyaluronidase PH20 injectable solution. The study evaluated the pain scores of all shoulder, neck, back, temporal, and herpes zoster pain. The pain scale is a tool that doctors use to help assess patients' pain. Each patient rated their pain on a scale of 0 to 10. 0 means no pain and 10 means the most painful. The study found that the 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment was effective in reducing pain in patients with shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain and herpes zoster pain.

[/INST] The study is a prospective randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy of hysteroscopic septoplasty using scissors and resectoscope in patients with a uterine septum. The study will include 40 patients who will be randomized into two groups. The scissors group will undergo hysteroscopic septoplasty using scissors, while the resectoscope group will undergo hysteroscopic septoplasty using resectoscope. The primary outcome measure is the operative time, fluid deficit, and complications. The secondary outcome measure is the pregnancy rate and live birth rate. The study will be conducted at Mansoura University Hospital in Egypt. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a breathing control technique on long COVID symptoms. The study will include patients over the age of 18 who have a diagnosis of long COVID and live in Reunion. The intervention group will receive a breathing control technique in addition to the usual care procedure, while the control group will receive usual care only. The primary outcome measure is the mean score on the Long COVID Symptom Tool (ST) scale, and the secondary outcome measures include the decrease in overall symptoms over time, the decrease in specific symptoms such as fatigue, dyspnoea, anxiety and depression, cognitive disorders, and the impact of the disease on daily life. The study will last for 6 months.

[/INST] The study is a single-center cohort study that aims to evaluate the cardiovascular complications of ibrutinib therapy. The study will include patients aged 18 years or older who have an indication for ibrutinib treatment for hematologic reasons. The study will follow the patients for 12 months after the introduction of ibrutinib and will collect data on the rate of patients developing atrial fibrillation (AF), as well as selected biomarkers. The study will compare the values of these biomarkers between patients who have developed AF and patients without AF.

[/INST] The Effect of Bicarbonate Profiling in Dialysis Fluid on Phosphate Removal During Hemodialysis and Blood pH is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of bicarbonate profiling in dialysis fluid on phosphate removal during hemodialysis and blood pH. The study is a non-randomized controlled trial with a single group assignment and a 4-week follow-up period. The study will enroll 20 chronic hemodialysis patients who will receive three hemodialysis treatments per week, each lasting 4 hours. The study will compare three different dialysate bicarbonate levels: 35 mmol/L, 35-30 mmol/L, and 30-35 mmol/L. The primary outcome measure is the change in blood phosphorus concentration in hemodialysis patients. The secondary outcome measure is the maintenance of acid-base balance in accordance with applicable recommendations. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group trial with three arms of treatment, each consisting of 8 sessions, involving the administration of 1) the neurostimulation intervention (tDCS), 2) of the psychotherapeutic intervention alone (MCT), 3) of both techniques in consecution (tDCS-MCT). The effectiveness of these interventions will be assessed by heteroadministered and self-administered at time zero, after treatment, at two follow-ups of 6 and 12 months.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to investigate the influence of hot and cold cognition on prospective memory in HIV+ patients. The study will include 100 HIV+ patients and 100 healthy controls. The patients will be assessed using the Memory for Intentions Screening Test (MIST), Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA), Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI), and Modified Five Point Test (Ruffi et al 1987). The healthy controls will be assessed using the same tests. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

[/INST] The study aims to determine the effects of vertical sitting versus supine lying traction on pain, range of motion, and function in patients with chronic radicular low back pain. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two groups: the experimental group will receive vertical sitting traction, and the active comparator group will receive supine lying traction. The primary outcome measure is the Oswestry Disability Index, and the secondary outcome measure is the Numeric Pain Rating Scale. The study will be conducted over a 12-week period.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of dry needling and lasertherapy in the treatment of lateral hip pain (trochanteric bursitis). The study will include 60 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups: dry needling or lasertherapy. The treatment will consist of 6 sessions, twice a week, lasting 30 minutes each. The primary outcome measure will be pain intensity, measured using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), and the secondary outcome measures will be hip function, measured using the VISA-G questionnaire, and lower limb function, measured using the Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) and the 30-second Sit to Stand Test (SL30). The study will be conducted in the Rehabilitation Department of the Centre Hospitalier Valida, France. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the French Ethics Committee.

[/INST] The study titled "Effects of Cognitive-behavioral Therapy for Insomnia in Nurses With Post Covid-19 Condition" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) in nurses with post-COVID-19 condition. The study will compare the effects of CBT-I to usual care. The primary outcome measures are insomnia severity, sleep quality, and sleep efficiency. The secondary outcome measures are anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life. The study will use the Insomnia Severity Index, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, Fitbit Charge 5, Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item, Patient Health Questionnaire 9 item, and 36-Item Short Form Health Survey to measure the outcomes. The study will be conducted in nurses with post-COVID-19 condition who are not currently receiving treatment for sleep disorders, do not have a history of sleep apnea, narcolepsy, or seizures, and do not have a pacemaker. The study will be conducted in a parallel assignment model with no masking. The study will have a 20-week follow-up period.

[/INST] The RAPID AFib Decision Aid for Stroke Prevention in Atrial Fibrillation is a web-based tool that aims to facilitate shared decision-making between patients and physicians regarding the selection of stroke prevention therapy for atrial fibrillation. The tool estimates an individual's risk for stroke and bleeding, allows patients to interactively compare oral anticoagulation to select one or more therapies that best match their risk profile and individual preferences, and summarizes the risk information and their selected therapy to facilitate discussion with their physician in a Summary Report. The study will evaluate the acceptability of the RAPID AFib decision aid and its impact on the process of shared decision-making for stroke prevention therapy in patients with recent onset AF.

[/INST] The study is a phase I, randomized, placebo-controlled study to assess the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of NNC0491-6075 following single and multiple doses in healthy participants and participants with dyslipidemia.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficiency of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) versus non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure. The study included 100 patients who were randomly assigned to either the HFNC or NIV group. The HFNC group received high-flow oxygen through a nasal cannula, while the NIV group received non-invasive ventilation through a mask. The study found that the HFNC group had a higher rate of treatment failure and mortality compared to the NIV group.

[/INST] The study is titled "ImpleMEntation of a Digital-first Care deLiverY Model for Heart Failure in Uganda". The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: Enhanced HF Clinical Care (Core-HF) and Digital health intervention (Medly Uganda) plus enhanced HF clinical care. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a digital health intervention in improving self-care and clinical outcomes among patients with heart failure in Uganda. The study will use a mixed methods process evaluation to inform iterative adjustments to the implementation processes. The study will also examine cost effectiveness, and sustainability factors for Medly Uganda, including an examination of cost, cost-effectiveness, and equity of Medly Uganda from a financial and societal perspective. The study will use the Self-Care of Heart Failure Index (SCHFI), a composite of the number of participants with mortality and HF hospitalization, and change in blood pressure as primary outcome measures. The study will be conducted in Uganda and will enroll 1,200 patients with heart failure. The study will last for 36 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, crossover, single-dose, two-treatment, two-sequence, two-period, two-way crossover, open-label, pharmacokinetic study of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets. The study is designed to compare the pharmacokinetic parameters of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets with those of ibuprofen tablets and diphenhydramine hydrochloride tablets. The study will enroll 16 healthy subjects who will be randomly assigned to one of two treatment groups. Each subject will receive a single oral dose of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets or ibuprofen tablets and diphenhydramine hydrochloride tablets in a crossover design. Blood samples will be collected at various time points after drug administration, and the plasma concentration of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride will be determined. The pharmacokinetic parameters of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride will be compared between the two treatment groups. The study will provide information on the pharmacokinetic properties of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets and will be used to support the development of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study that aims to evaluate the impact of apalutamide in metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC) patients. The study will assess the undetectable prostate-specific antigen (PSA) rate, fatigue, cognitive function, and health-related quality of life in mHSPC patients receiving apalutamide. The study will be conducted in multiple centers in the United States and is expected to last for 4 years.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial evaluating the hair and scalp benefits of Duobrii lotion in scalp psoriasis. The study will involve 12 weeks of treatment with the lotion applied once daily at bedtime to the scalp afflicted with psoriasis. The primary outcomes of the study are improvement in hair growth and reduction in scalp itch due to scalp psoriasis treatment.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/II clinical trial that aims to determine the safety and efficacy of a combination treatment of idasanutlin and selinexor in children with recurrent or progressive AT/RT or MRT. The study will have a dose-finding/safety phase and an expansion phase. In the dose-finding/safety phase, the study will determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination treatment. In the expansion phase, the study will evaluate the efficacy of the combination treatment in children with recurrent or progressive AT/RT or MRT. The study will use a combination of imaging, clinical, and laboratory assessments to monitor the progression of the disease and the response to treatment. The study will also collect blood and tumor samples to evaluate the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of the combination treatment. The study will have a duration of approximately 7 years from the start of treatment.

[/INST] The study is a comparative study between radial and capitate shortening in ulna minus variance Kienbock's disease. The study is randomized and parallel assignment. The study is open label. The study includes two groups, the first group is treated with radial shortening and the second group is treated with capitate shortening. The study includes 10 participants in each group. The study includes participants aged 18-65 years. The study includes participants with stages II and III of Kienbock's disease. The study excludes participants with stage I and IV of Kienbock's disease, participants with serious medical conditions, and participants with severe osteoporosis. The study measures the modified Mayo wrist score at 1 year. The study is conducted in China.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multimodal prehabilitation program in patients undergoing pancreatic resection for cancer. The program includes exercise training, nutritional therapy, and anxiety reduction techniques. The primary outcome is the incidence of postoperative complications, and the secondary outcomes include functional recovery, length of stay, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in a single center in France and will include 113 patients. The intervention will be provided by a multidisciplinary team, including a physiotherapist, a nutritionist, and a psychologist. The control group will receive standard care. The study will last for 1 year and will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT guidelines.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of dual task exercise training in children with cerebral palsy. The study will compare the effects of conventional rehabilitation with dual task exercise training on balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will use the Pediatric Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go Test, One Leg Standing Test, 3-Meter Backward Walk Test, 6 Meter Walk Test, and the Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire to measure the outcomes. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, with assessments conducted before and after the intervention.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study to monitor influenza virus transmission events from animals to humans in Belgium. The study will recruit participants from four groups: people involved in avian influenza outbreak management, people working in poultry farms, people working in wild bird/life rehabilitation centers, and veterinarians working in the pig industry. The participants will be asked to provide a nasopharyngeal swab every two weeks for the whole duration of the study. The study will measure the number of participants who are positive for a non-seasonal influenza virus and the number of participants with seroconversion against a non-seasonal influenza virus. The study will also monitor influenza virus transmission events from animals to humans.

[/INST] The study is a longitudinal, within-person design with two parallel conditions. In one condition, youth receive a 6-week canine therapy intervention. The other condition consists of treatment as usual. The study aims to evaluate the impact of a canine-assisted therapy program in youth residing in a residential treatment center. The primary outcome measures are emotional regulation, attention and inhibitory control, and self-esteem. The secondary outcome measures are attendance and attrition, positive affect, significant event report, and attitudes towards pets. The study will be conducted at Lawrence Hall Youth Services in Lawrence, MA, USA.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of myofascial release in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity performance in young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks, with 2 groups of young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. One group will receive foot core exercises and the other group will receive myofascial release in addition to foot core exercises. The primary outcome measure is balance, and the secondary outcome measures are flexibility, power, and gait. The study will use the Y balance test, sit and reach test, vertical jump test, and 10-meter walk test to measure these outcomes. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee. The results of the study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study titled "Training of Arms to Reduce Pain With Peripheral Venous Catheter" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of arm training on pain levels in patients undergoing chemotherapy. The study is conducted in the DROP-IN outpatient clinic at the Department of Anesthesiology, Vejle Hospital, Denmark. Patients who are undergoing neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy via an intravenous peripheral venous cannula placed under ultrasound guidance are eligible for the study. The intervention group receives an 8-week daily arm training program, while the control group receives normal care. The primary outcome measure is the level of pain as measured by the Numeric Rating Scale (score 1-10 where a low value defines low level of pain) after insertion of the periphral venous catheter and at general activity. The secondary outcome measure is the number of useable veins (assessed via ultrasound). The study is designed to have a single masking and a parallel assignment. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and has been approved by the Danish Data Protection Agency and the Central Denmark Region Committee on Health Research Ethics.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to compare the immunological and genetic factors in the decidua of women with miscarriage of a trisomy 16 conceptus (47XY+16 or 47XX+16) and a chromosomally normal male conceptus (46XY). The study will use ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) to collect product of conception (POC) and decidua tissues. The POC will be sent for karyotyping analysis, while the decidua will be used for immunohistochemistry staining and low-pass genome sequencing (GS). The study will compare the immunological and genetic factors in the decidua of women with miscarriage of a trisomy 16 conceptus and a chromosomally normal male conceptus. The study will determine whether the immunological and genetic factors in the decidua are different between the two groups. The study will also determine whether the immunological and genetic factors in the decidua are associated with miscarriage of a trisomy 16 conceptus. The POC will be sent for karyotyping analysis, while the decidua will be used for immunohistochemistry staining and low-pass genome sequencing (GS). The study will compare the immunological and genetic factors in the decidua of women with miscarriage of a trisomy 16 conceptus and a chromosomally normal male conceptus. The study will determine whether the immunological and genetic factors in the decidua are different between the two groups. The study will also determine whether the immunological and genetic factors in the decidua are associated with miscarriage of a trisomy 16 conceptus.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, open-label, single-arm trial investigating the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamic properties of Lu AF28996 in Japanese men and women with Parkinson's disease. Participants will receive ascending oral doses of Lu AF28996 for 14 days, followed by down-titration of Lu AF28996. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) from the day of first dose of study drug (Day 1) up to Day 35. The primary pharmacokinetic (PK) outcome measures are the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from zero to last quantifiable concentration (AUC0-tlast), area under the plasma concentration-time curve from zero to 24 hours post-dose (AUC0-24h), maximum observed plasma concentration (Cmax), and oral clearance (CL/F) of Lu AF28996.

[/INST] The study titled "Acceptability, Cost-Effectiveness, and Capacity of a Facility-Based Seasonal Influenza Vaccination: A Study in Selected Hospitals of Bangladesh" is a quasi-experimental study that aims to assess the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and capacity of a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program in Bangladesh. The study will be conducted in two hospitals in Bangladesh, one of which will receive an influenza vaccination campaign before the influenza season, while the other will not receive the campaign. The study will enroll high-risk groups, including children aged six months to eight years, pregnant women (any trimester), adults aged 60 years and older, and adults with chronic diseases. The study will assess the acceptability of influenza vaccination by measuring the proportion of high-risk groups who report their intention to receive the influenza vaccine. The cost-effectiveness of the influenza vaccination program will be assessed by measuring the incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICERs) in terms of the number of DALYs gained or saved. The study will also assess the required capacity related to vaccine doses, self-injection equipment, and storage capacity. The study will provide valuable information on the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and capacity of a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program in Bangladesh, which can be used to inform policy decisions on influenza vaccination in the country.

[/INST] The SUSPECT study is a prospective study that aims to evaluate the technical and procedural performance characteristics of single-use duodenoscopes. The study will include patients who are scheduled to undergo an ERCP or other duodenoscope-based procedure. The study will compare the technical and procedural performance characteristics of single-use duodenoscopes to those of conventional duodenoscopes. The study will follow patients for 24 months after the procedure.

[/INST] The Hybrid Pulmonary Rehabilitation Study is a feasibility study that aims to assess the feasibility of a hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation program. The program combines in-person and remote pulmonary rehabilitation sessions using the Active+me REMOTE app. The study will assess the feasibility of the program by measuring patient recruitment rates, recruitment, patient retention rates, and the availability of data for primary and secondary outcomes of a larger definitive trial. The study will also assess the success of integrating the hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation program into routine practice, patient and staff acceptability of the program, the safety of the program, and the uptake, adherence, and changes in exercise capacity, symptoms, knowledge, skills, and confidence to manage health and wellbeing. The study will use a real-world evidence design drawing on routinely collected data to compare outcomes for patients recruited to a hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation program with a propensity-matched control group that has previously received standard pulmonary rehabilitation. The study will also conduct qualitative interviews with staff and patients to assess the experience of delivering and participating in the hybrid program. The findings of the study will inform the design of a larger definitive trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation program compared to standard pulmonary rehabilitation.

[/INST] This is an observational, cohort study that will use secondary data to describe the baseline demographics and clinical characteristics in patients who received EVUSHELD as PrEP against SARS-CoV-2 infection/COVID-19 in Japan. All patients who have a record of administration of EVUSHELD in the database will be included in the study. The index date will be defined as the date of first EVUSHELD administration in the database (Day 0) and the patients will be followed up to 6 months after the index date (Day 1 to 180). The exposure of interest will be defined as the administration of EVUSHELD for use as PrEP against COVID-19. As the result of feasibility assessment, sample size of the study expected to be approximately 280.

[/INST] The study is a phase 4, multicenter, randomized, double-blind study to assess the safety and efficacy of subcutaneously injected risankizumab in adult participants with genital or scalp psoriasis. The study will have two treatment arms, one for genital psoriasis and one for scalp psoriasis. Participants will receive either risankizumab or placebo for risankizumab. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of participants with achievement of static physician global assessment of genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 or 1 in week 16 for genital psoriasis and percentage of participants with achievement of scalp investigator global assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1 in week 16 for scalp psoriasis. The secondary outcome measures include percentage of participants with achievement of static physician global assessment of genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 in week 16 for genital psoriasis, percentage of participants with achievement of dermatology life quality index (DLQI) of 0 or 1 in week 16 for genital psoriasis, percentage of participants with achievement of clinically meaningful (>= 4-point) improvement from baseline on the genital psoriasis itch numerical rating scale (NRS) [among participants with a baseline score >= 4] in week 16 for genital psoriasis, percentage of participants with achievement of genital psoriasis sexual frequency questionnaire (GenPs-SFQ) item 2 score of 0 or 1 in week 16 for genital psoriasis, percentage of participants with achievement of Psoriasis Scalp Severity Index (PSSI 90) in week 16 for scalp psoriasis, percentage of participants with achievement of PSSI 75 in week 16 for scalp psoriasis, change from baseline in Psoriasis Symptom Scale (PSS) in week 16 for scalp psoriasis, percentage of participants with achievement of PSSI 100 in week 16 for scalp psoriasis, percentage of participants with achievement of PSS of 0 in week 16 for scalp psoriasis, and change from baseline

[/INST] The Prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock Variation in Patients With Symptomatic Thumb CMC Arthritis is a descriptive cross-sectional study that aims to determine the prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock variation (LCV) in patients with symptomatic thumb CMC arthritis. The study will recruit 500 patients over the age of 35 who have been diagnosed with thumb CMC arthritis and are undergoing initial non-surgical intervention. The patients will be asked to perform a clinical examination looking for the LCV, which will take a total of five seconds. The study will take place at the Bone and Joint Center at 1365 Washington Avenue, Albany New York, and satellite offices in Guilderland, Clifton Park, Malta, Saratoga, Schenectady and Catskill. The patients will be informed during clinical examination if they have a LCV. There is no compensation to participants for enrolling in the study.

[/INST] The study is a phase 3, multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of atogepant in the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in pediatric subjects aged 6-17 years. The study will have a 12-week double-blind treatment period, followed by a 12-week open-label period. Participants will be randomized to receive atogepant or placebo once daily. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in the mean monthly migraine days. The secondary outcome measures are the change from baseline in the mean monthly headache days, the change from baseline in the mean monthly acute medication use days, the percentage of participants who achieve at least a 50% reduction in average monthly migraine days, and the change from baseline in the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) total score.
