[/INST] The study aimed to investigate the effect of intensified tactile contact between a mother and her newborn on the emotional transformation of the mother. The study was conducted in a non-randomized quasi-experimental design. The experimental group received the intervention of intensified tactile contact with the newborn in the form of Shantali massage, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The intervention was applied at least twice a day, 10 min each, and started on the 3rd day after delivery and lasted until the end of the 12th week after delivery. The dependent variables were the level of emotions in the designated 'negative' domain (depression, anxiety, negative affects) and the level of emotions in the designated 'positive' domain (satisfaction, sense of effectiveness, positive affects). These were measured with four standardized, self-reported questionnaires. The results showed that the experimental group had a significant decrease in the level of negative emotions and an increase in the level of positive emotions compared to the control group. The study concluded that the intervention of intensified tactile contact with the newborn had a positive effect on the emotional transformation of the mother.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, open-label, randomized controlled trial. The primary objective is to evaluate the efficacy of the combination of atezolizumab, bevacizumab, and paclitaxel in patients with non-squamous NSCLC. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the safety of the combination, the progression-free survival, the overall response rate, the overall survival, and the time until definitive health-related quality of life score deterioration. The study will enroll patients with non-squamous NSCLC who have progressed after treatment with immunotherapy and platinum-based chemotherapy. Patients will be randomized to one of two arms: Arm A will receive paclitaxel and bevacizumab, and Arm B will receive paclitaxel, bevacizumab, and atezolizumab. Patients will receive treatment every three weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The primary endpoint will be the progression-free survival at six months. The secondary endpoints will be the progression-free survival, the overall response rate, the overall survival, the time until definitive health-related quality of life score deterioration, and the incidence, nature, and severity of adverse events. The study will enroll 120 patients and follow-up will continue for three years.

[/INST] The study is a pilot prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the role of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) in the management of persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study will enroll patients who have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have experienced symptoms for at least four weeks after diagnosis. The primary outcome measure is the patient recruitment rate, and the secondary outcome measures are neurocognitive and psychological symptoms, physical symptoms, global health, and return to work. The study will use osteopathic manipulative treatment provided at the discretion of the treating physician and based on the patient's response to previous treatments. The study will measure the neurocognitive and psychological symptoms using the Rivermead Post Concussion Symptoms Questionnaire, physical symptoms using the Long COVID-Household Pulse Survey, global health using the PROMIS SF v1.2 Global Health scale, and return to work using a four-point scale. The study will be conducted through study completion, an average of one year after enrollment.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study comparing the use of indocyanine green (ICG) microangiography and conventional angiography in patients with severe frostbite. The study aims to determine the concordance or discordance of the two imaging modalities in the same patient. The study will compare the ability of the two imaging modalities to demonstrate ischemic tissue present in severe frostbite using the Hennepin Frostbite Score. The study will also assess the safety of ICG when delivered in close association with contrast dye used in conventional angiography. The study will be conducted in a single center and will include 10 patients with severe frostbite. The study will use a prospective, non-randomized, single-blinded design. The study will compare the two imaging modalities in the same patient and will determine the concordance or discordance of the two imaging modalities in the same patient. The study will also assess the safety of ICG when delivered in close association with contrast dye used in conventional angiography. The study will use a prospective, non-randomized, single-blinded design. The study will include 10 patients with severe frostbite. The study will compare the two imaging modalities in the same patient and will determine the concordance or discordance of the two imaging modalities in the same patient. The study will also assess the safety of ICG when delivered in close association with contrast dye used in conventional angiography.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit (GPOU) on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over who underwent colorectal surgery. The study will assess the functional status of patients at baseline and 3 and 6 months after surgery using the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score. The study will also assess patient satisfaction with care, length of hospital stay, the number of medical complications during hospitalization, the distribution of surgical complications, the distribution of patients' destinations on discharge from hospital, the change in the patient's weight, patient quality of life, and the change in the patient's place of abode. The study will also assess overall survival, the rate of early unscheduled re-hospitalizations or admissions to the emergency department, and the rate of immediate mortality during hospital stay.

[/INST] The study is a pilot trial that aims to describe the toxicities of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) positron emission tomography (PET), by evaluating toxicities including type, frequency, severity, attribution, time course, and duration. The study also aims to identify changes in 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) uptake in radiated metastatic lesions pre- and post-stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT).

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized, open-label, multi-country, cohort study to describe the safety of study participants who received RSVPreF3 maternal vaccination (any dose) or control from previous RSV MAT studies during any pregnancy conceived post vaccination/control. The study will follow up participants for 42 days post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination/control. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy outcomes from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination. The secondary outcome measures include the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy related adverse events of special interest (AESIs) from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination, and the percentage of infant participants reporting infant AESIs from birth up to Day 42 post-birth of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination. The study will also assess the percentage of maternal participants reporting selected pregnancy outcomes and pregnancy related AESIs stratified by selected risk factors of those outcomes and events, from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of any pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination/control, and from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination/control. The study will also assess the percentage of infant participants reporting infant AESIs stratified by selected risk factors of those events, from birth up to Day 42 post-birth of any pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination/control.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study that aims to evaluate the feasibility of using 19F MRI to assess lung function in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) and healthy children. The study will compare the results of 19F MRI to traditional pulmonary function tests (PFTs) and assess the acceptability of the 19F MRI procedure to participants and their parents. The study will also evaluate the ability of 19F MRI to detect changes in lung function over time.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of open and closed chain exercises on pain, function, and balance in athletes with patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS). The study will be conducted in Pakistan sports board Lahore, Model town Sports Club Lahore and Sheikh Zaid Hospital, Lahore. Participants will be randomly assigned to two groups: Group A will receive open kinetic chain exercises, and Group B will receive closed kinetic chain exercises. The exercises will be performed 3 times a week for 6 weeks. The subjects will be assessed for pain, function, and balance at baseline and after 6 weeks of treatment. The study will use the Numerical Pain Rating Scale (NPRS), Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS), and Y Balance test to measure the outcomes. The study will use the statistical package for social sciences (SPSS) for Windows software, version 25, for data analysis.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players. The study will include 36 American football players who will be randomized into two groups: the MIND diet group and the control group. The MIND diet group will receive nutritional counseling on the MIND diet and will be provided with the recommended foods. The control group will not receive any nutritional counseling. The study will last for 9 weeks, and the participants will be assessed before and after the intervention. The primary outcome measures will be tau protein, NfL (neurofilament light polypeptide), S100B protein, BDNF (brain-derived neurotrophic factor), telomere length, zonulin, NOX2 (NADPH oxidase), 8-OHdG (8-hydroxy-2-deoxyguanosine), F2-isoprostanes (F2-isoPs), hs-CRP (high-sensitivity C-reactive protein), IL-6 (interleukin 6), TNF-α (tumor necrosis factor alpha), and sleep quality score. The secondary outcome measures will be quality of life score and dietary inflammatory index score. The study will provide valuable information on the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the acute success rate of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) in patients with heart failure with ejection fraction less than or equal to 50%. The study will also assess the incidence of acute procedure-related complications, the incidence of repeat procedures, the incidence of pacemaker upgrade to cardiac resynchronization therapy including biventricular cardiac pacing, the incidence of heart failure hospitalization, the incidence of cardiovascular death, the incidence of all-cause death, left ventricular ejection fraction, left ventricular end diastolic diameter, left ventricular end systolic diameter, left ventricular global strain, capture threshold, sensing, and impedance.

[/INST] The study is a phase 1a, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single-site, single-dose study of the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 injection in healthy adults. The study will enroll healthy male or female subjects, aged 18 to 50 years, inclusive, with a minimum weight of 50.0 kg and maximum weight of 100.0 kg, and a body mass index (BMI) within the range of 18.0 to 32.0 kg/m2, inclusive. The study will have two arms: CSX-1004 and placebo. The primary outcome measure is treatment-emergent adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, and AEs leading to discontinuation. The secondary outcome measures are clinical laboratory assessments, vital signs, 12-lead electrocardiogram, physical examination, and infusion site examination. The study will have a duration of 5 months.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of joint fluid aspiration (JFA) in patients with dysfunctional hip, knee, or shoulder prostheses. The study will compare the bacteriological results of JFA with those of perioperative samples. The study will include patients who have undergone JFA and have been diagnosed with prosthesis infection or prosthesis failure. The study will compare the bacteriological results of JFA with those of perioperative samples. The study will also evaluate the concordance between the results of JFA and perioperative samples.

[/INST] The study is titled "Quantitation and Spatial Registration of Airways Dysfunction With Dynamic 19F MRI in Cystic Fibrosis" and is a clinical trial that aims to use dynamic 19F MRI to quantify and spatially register airway dysfunction in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients. The study will enroll 10-15 participants who are 18 years of age or older, have a diagnosis of CF, and are non-smokers with stable lung function. The study will involve inhaling a biologically inert contrast gas, perfluoropropane, combined with 19F-tuned MRI with image acquisition at breath-hold and during tidal breathing. The primary outcome measures are change in ventilation defect parameter (VDP) over 14 days and change in VDP over 365 days. The secondary outcome measures are change in MRI severity score over 365 days, correlation of MRI severity score with VDP at baseline, and correlation of MRI severity score with FLVlongtau2 at baseline. The study will be conducted at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, open-label, single-dose, two-sequence, two-cycle, double-cross design bioequivalence trial of fasting single oral STI-1558 capsule in healthy Chinese subjects. The study is designed to compare the pharmacokinetic parameters of the test and reference preparations of STI-1558 in healthy Chinese subjects under fasting conditions. The study will enroll 32 eligible subjects who will be randomly assigned to two groups (TR and RT) in a 1:1 ratio. Subjects in the TR group will take the test preparation (T) 200 mg/ pill × 1 pill on day 1 (D1) and the reference preparation (R) 200 mg/ pill × 1 pill on day 8 (D8). The sequence of medication in RT group is reversed from TR group. The study will evaluate the relative bioavailability of the test and reference preparations of STI-1558 by comparing the maximum observed concentration (Cmax), area under the curve from time 0 to last time point (AUC0-t), area under the curve from time 0 extrapolated to infinity (AUC0-inf), t1/2, Tmax, and %AUCex.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of detaching the breathing circuit on the rate of double-lumen endotracheal tube malposition after the change of position in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. The study will include 120 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will have the breathing circuit disengaged when the patient's position is changed from the supine to the lateral decubitus position, while the control group will maintain the normal connection of the breathing line. The primary outcome measure is the malposition rate of the double-lumen endobronchial tube, which will be measured immediately after the change of position. The secondary outcome measures are the effects of lung collapse, blood oxygen saturation, and PACU length of stay. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of personalized comprehensive diabetes support for families of children with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes. The study will compare the effectiveness of the intervention with no intervention. The primary outcome measures are diabetes distress scale and problem areas in diabetes. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial with two parallel arms. The study population consists of patients with a major depressive episode after hospitalization in a medical or surgical department. The intervention group will receive telemedicine sessions in addition to the usual care, while the control group will receive usual care only. The primary outcome is the response rate to treatment at 6 months after inclusion. The secondary outcomes include the quality of life, the number of relapses, the medication compliance and integration into a psychiatric care pathway, the therapeutic efficacy, the satisfaction of depression care, the clinical variables associated with drop out of the care program, the measurement of stigma scale scores and subscores in each group, the evaluation of the possibility of the physicians to require a psychiatric opinion on the care and the identification and frequency of the use of NICT tools (New Information and Communication technologies) in the field of mental health.

[/INST] The study aims to develop an artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm that can differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses. The study will use quantitative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to train the AI algorithm. The study will include two cohorts: an original cohort and a reproducibility cohort. The original cohort will include patients with a soft tissue mass who are undergoing MRI as part of their standard of care. The reproducibility cohort will include a subset of patients from the original cohort who will undergo a second MRI scan to test the reproducibility of the quantitative MRI scans and the machine learning algorithms developed to interpret them. The primary outcome measure will be the diagnostic accuracy of the AI algorithm for distinguishing between benign and malignant soft tissue lesions. The secondary outcome measure will be the classification accuracy of the AI algorithm for classifying malignant lesions into their pathological grade. The study will run for three years.

[/INST] The study is a split-mouth randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the efficacy of microneedling alone and microneedling with hyaluronic acid in increasing gingival thickness in thin gingival phenotype. The study will be conducted in the Department of Periodontics and Oral Implantology, Post Graduate Institute of Dental Sciences, Rohtak, India. The study will include 20 systematically healthy patients with thin gingival phenotypes who will be randomly allocated to one of the two procedures (MN or MN with Hyaluronic acid) using a chit system. The study will have a follow-up period of 9 months, and the primary outcome measure will be the measurement of gingival thickness from the apical 1.5 mm of the gingival margin using a No:15 endodontic spreader with a 3-mm-diameter silicone disc.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of preoperative immunonutrition on patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. The study will compare the effects of a preoperative dietary supplement (Oral Impact Nestle) with a placebo on surgical site infections, anastomotic leakage, length of stay, inflammatory infiltration in the subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissue, and grade of fibrosis in the subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissue. The study will also measure adipocytes cross sectional area in the subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissue. The study will include patients aged 20 to 85 years old with primary colorectal neoplasms eligible for elective surgery, undergoing minivasive resections. The study will be conducted in multiple centers in Italy. The study will begin in 2022 and is expected to be completed by 2025.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the impact and possible additional benefits of adding an oculomotor therapy treatment to a manual therapy protocol of the cervical region in patients with migraine. The study will include 60 participants aged 18-65 years who suffer from migraine with the following characteristics: unilateral, pulsating, of moderate to severe intensity, during the attack, nausea and/or vomiting, with the possible presence of an aura, history of evolution of more than a year, onset and aggravation in the afternoon, and relation to visual work. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the control group or the experimental group. The control group will receive a treatment of the cervical region for 6 weeks, once a week, and will be taught some exercises to do at home. The experimental group will receive the treatment of the control group plus an additional intervention in the oculomotor region together with some specific exercises. The primary outcome measure will be the Headache Impact Test (HIT-6) Questionnaire, and the secondary outcome measures will include the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), the Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) Questionnaire, the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) Questionnaire, the Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-7) Questionnaire, the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) Questionnaire, the Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia (TSK-11) Questionnaire, the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS) Questionnaire, the Central Sensitization Inventory (CSI) Questionnaire, the Neck Disability Index (NDI) Questionnaire, the Head Repositioning, the Grimmer Test, the Smooth tracking test, the Smooth Pursuit Neck Torsion, and the Cervical Range of Motion Instrument. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valada in France, and the recruitment period is expected to be from January 2023 to December 2023. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valada.

[/INST] The Cratos study is a clinical trial evaluating the use of the Cratos stent graft system in the treatment of descending aorta lesions, including aortic dissection type B, intramural hematoma, and penetrating aortic ulcer. [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the efficacy of preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) in reducing stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and improving patient quality of life (QoL) following holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP). The study will compare two groups of patients: one group will start PFPT before surgery, while the other group will start PFPT after surgery. The primary outcome measure is time to continence, and the secondary outcome measures include uroflow, post-void residual, international prostate symptom score, operative time, length of stay, catheter duration, infectious complications, emergency room visits, and QoL. The study will be conducted in the United States and is expected to last for 3 years.

[/INST] The DETECT-IP study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) in reducing the incidence of acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients. The study will compare the intervention group, which will receive the CDSS, with the control group, which will not receive the CDSS. The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse drug events such as acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients. The secondary outcome measures include the presence of an adverse event related to the intervention provided, therapeutic adaptations implemented in case of acute renal failure or hyperkalemia upon hospital admission, relevance of CDSS alerts, number of pharmaceutical interventions accepted, and changes in ADEs (Adverse Drug Event) prevention/management work process induced by the introduction of alerts. The study will use a stepped-wedge design, where the intervention will be rolled out in a sequential manner to the participating hospitals. The study will be conducted in 10 hospitals in Switzerland and is expected to last for 20 months.

[/INST] The study is a case-control study that aims to compare the bacterial microbiome profile of Crohn's disease (CD) patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. The study will also examine the association between genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of CD patients. The study will include 40 CD patients and 20 controls. The study will collect blood, ileal tissue, and mesentery samples from the participants at the time of surgery. The samples will be analyzed for bacterial microbiome profile and genetic polymorphisms related to innate immunity. The study will use next-generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis to analyze the samples. The study will compare the bacterial microbiome profile and genetic polymorphisms between the CD patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. The study will also examine the association between the bacterial microbiome profile and genetic polymorphisms related to innate immunity. The study will provide new insights into the role of the bacterial microbiome profile and genetic polymorphisms related to innate immunity in the pathogenesis of CD.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, open-label, single-dose, single-center, parallel-group, pharmacokinetic study to evaluate the relative bioavailability of a single dose of LY3437943 administered by subcutaneous (SC) or intravenous (IV) injection in healthy participants with a high body mass index (BMI). The study will assess the pharmacokinetic parameters of LY3437943, including the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to infinity (AUC(0-∞)), maximum concentration (Cmax), and time to reach Cmax (Tmax). The study will also assess the safety and tolerability of LY3437943.

[/INST] The study is a research registry on aggressive pituitary tumours. The registry is called RECAPitNETT and is open to all adult patients with pituitary tumours whose file is presented to the national HYPOcare RCP. The registry aims to characterize the aggressiveness of pituitary tumours by transcriptome analysis and predict prognosis over a period of three years. The registry is conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] OPTI-DOSE is a randomized pilot study that aims to investigate the feasibility of a lower starting dose with a step-up approach for older patients with cancer receiving oral anticancer drugs. The study will compare the overall treatment utility of this approach with standard dosing. The study will also assess the feasibility of collecting data and the willingness of patients to participate in the study. The primary outcome measure is the overall treatment utility, which is a measure of the balance of benefits and harms from cancer treatment. The study will also assess progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, and pharmacokinetic parameters. The study will enroll 30 patients aged 65 years or older who are starting treatment with one of the following oral anticancer drugs: pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib, or palbociclib. The study will randomize patients to receive either a lower starting dose with a step-up approach or standard dosing. The lower starting dose will be 200 mg for pazopanib, 200 mg for olaparib, 10 mg for lenvatinib, 25 mg for sunitinib, and 75 mg for palbociclib. The study will collect data on overall treatment utility, progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, and pharmacokinetic parameters at 12 weeks. The study will also collect data on overall treatment utility, progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, and pharmacokinetic parameters at up to 60 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy combined with immunotherapy and total mesorectal excision (TME surgery) in patients with MSS-type advanced middle-low rectal cancer. The primary outcome measure is the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate following short-course radiation then Envafolimab Plus CAPEOX. The secondary outcome measures include tumor regression grade, overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), treatment-related adverse events (TRAEs), surgical complications, and quality of life (QoL). The study will use the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Colorectal (FACT-C) questionnaire to assess QoL.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/III trial of levilimab in patients with active rheumatoid arthritis. The primary objective of the phase I study is to determine the safety profile of levilimab following its single subcutaneous or intravenous administration at ascending doses in healthy subjects. The primary objective of the phase III study is to determine the proportion of subjects with low disease activity of rheumatoid arthritis (DAS28-ESR <3.2) at Week 24 of the study in each treatment group.

[/INST] The Efficacy of White Kidney Bean on Oral Glucose Tolerance Test is a randomized, double-blind, crossover clinical trial that aims to investigate the efficacy of white kidney bean on oral glucose tolerance test. The study will enroll healthy adults aged 25-45 years with a male to female ratio of more than 40% and BMI 24.35. Participants will be randomly assigned to two groups: the Wonderlab Product group and the Placebo group. Each group will receive two tablets of Wonderlab Product or Placebo, respectively, for phase 1 (day 1) and phase 2 (day 4). The primary outcome measure is the change of blood glucose level in mmol/L based on OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test) after intervention. The secondary outcome measure is the change of fast blood glucose level in mmol/L based on OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test) after intervention. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is titled "IMPlementation of Evidence Based Facility and Community Interventions to Reduce the Treatment Gap for depRESSion". The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: a community intervention arm and a facility intervention arm. The community intervention arm involves the implementation of a community intervention strategy delivered by community volunteers (called Sangathis) to enhance demand for the Healthy Activity Program (HAP) treatment and promote engagement with, and completion of, the HAP treatment. The facility intervention arm involves the implementation of the HAP, a manualized and evidence-based psychological treatment based on behavioral activation, delivered by existing healthcare workers (called counsellors) within the health centers who will be trained to deliver the HAP. The primary outcome measure is contact coverage, which is defined as the proportion of eligible individuals who receive at least one intervention session. The secondary outcome measures include effectiveness coverage, sustained effectiveness, remission, response to treatment, client service receipt inventory, WHO Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS 2.0), inventory form for collecting system-level economic costs of delivering interventions, depression awareness, perceived social support, Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (MSPSS), treatment completion, and behavioral activation. The study will be conducted in primary health centers in Goa, India, and the duration of the study is 12 months. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the community intervention strategy in reducing the treatment gap for depression in primary care settings in Goa, India.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of low-intensity resistance training with and without blood flow restriction in normoxia and hypoxia conditions on muscle strength, thickness, catecholamine, and inflammatory responses in physically active adults. The study will use a parallel assignment model and single blinding. The study will have four groups: active comparator group (low-intensity resistance training in normoxia), experimental group 1 (low-intensity resistance training with blood flow restriction in normoxia), experimental group 2 (low-intensity resistance training in hypoxia), and experimental group 3 (low-intensity resistance training with blood flow restriction in hypoxia). The study will use a 6-week training program with two training sessions per week. The training program will consist of four sets of 30/15/15/15 repetitions of leg press exercise with a load of 20-30% of one-repetition maximum. The study will measure muscle strength, muscle thickness, catecholamine, inflammatory responses, and blood pressure. The study will be conducted in Brazil.

[/INST] Mosunetuzumab for Early Relapse of Follicular Lymphoma in the Nordic Countries is a phase II, multicenter, open-label clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of subcutaneous mosunetuzumab monotherapy in follicular lymphoma (FL) patients with early relapse (POD24). The primary objective is to investigate the efficacy of mosunetuzumab in terms of progression-free survival (PFS) 2 years after the initiation of second-line treatment. The secondary objectives include investigating the safety of mosunetuzumab, the prognostic significance of 18F-FDG-PET-CT response to mosunetuzumab, the rate of transformation to higher grade lymphoma following mosunetuzumab, and the patients' self-reported quality of life during and after mosunetuzumab. Mosunetuzumab is administered subcutaneously at a dose of 5 mg on day 1 of cycle 1, 45 mg on day 8 of cycle 1, and 45 mg on day 1 of cycles 2-8. The primary endpoint is PFS from the date of starting treatment to the date of first documented progression of disease or death of any cause, whichever came first. The secondary endpoints include overall response rate (ORR) assessed by PET-CT at the end of 8 cycles, complete response rate (CRR) assessed by PET-CT at the end of 8 cycles, duration of response (DOR) from the date of first documented response to the date of first documented disease progression or death from any cause, time to new lymphoma treatment (TTNT) from the date of starting study treatment to the date of starting third-line therapy due to progression of disease or to death of any cause, whichever came first, overall survival (OS) from the date of inclusion to the date of death of any cause, and the percentage of patients with adverse events from inclusion until 30 days after the last dose of study drug. [/INST] The study is a phase I/II trial of the safety and efficacy of combining PLX2853 and trametinib in patients with advanced uveal melanoma. The study will determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of the combination, evaluate the overall response rate (ORR) and progression-free survival (PFS) of the combination, and characterize the adverse event profile of the combination. The study will also evaluate the pharmacokinetic profile of the combination.

[/INST] The ASCERTAIN study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a new model of care compared to usual care in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated LDL-C. The new model of care includes a nurse-led support call, monthly SMS messages, and education on the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines and Guideline Directed Management therapy (GDMT). The primary outcome measure is the effect of the new model of care on LDL-C concentration at day 180. The study will be conducted in Australia and will include approximately 600 participants.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, controlled, single-blinded study conducted in the urology operating theatre of Al-Azhar University Hospital. The study included 48 patients aged 21-65 years who were scheduled for elective open renal surgeries under general anesthesia. The patients were divided into three groups: the erector spinae plane block group (ESPB), the thoracic paravertebral block group (TPVB), and the control group. The ESPB group received an erector spinae plane block, the TPVB group received a thoracic paravertebral block, and the control group received morphine (0.1 mg/kg iv) before skin incision. The study measured the total morphine requirements 24 hours postoperatively. The results showed that the ESPB group had significantly lower total morphine requirements 24 hours postoperatively compared to the TPVB and control groups. The study concluded that the ESPB is an effective and safe alternative to TPVB and morphine for postoperative analgesia in open renal surgeries.

[/INST] The study is a one-arm prospective observational clinical study that aims to evaluate the value of MRD detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence of high-risk GIST, investigate the effect of drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection on disease recurrence and patient survival, and to explore whether it can delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations. The study will include patients who have undergone R0 or R1 surgical resection of GIST, have been clinically diagnosed with high recurrence risk GIST combined with postoperative pathological results, have received imatinib adjuvant therapy for 3 years after surgery, and no gross lesions are detected by imaging examination. The study will use MRD detection as the primary endpoint, and the results will be compared with the time of disease progression assessed by imaging examination. The study will also evaluate the overall survival of patients and the genetic mutation profiling of ctDNA-MRD.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. The study will include 30 participants who will be divided into two groups: one group will receive Dohsa hou exercises, and the other group will receive standard treatment. The primary outcome measures are the trunk impairment scale and time up and go test, which will be assessed at baseline and after 6 weeks of intervention. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The Supporting Physical Literacy at School and Home (SPLASH) study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to increase children's physical literacy (PL) and physical activity (PA) through a multilevel Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program. The program targets elementary school children from low-income schools and will be delivered at school and at home. The study will test the effects of the RNYRR program on children's PL and PA over one school year. The study will also examine whether the program effects differ by sex or weight status and whether changes in PL mediate changes in daily total PA volume or MVPA.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate the gastric volume of pediatric patients undergoing adenotonsillectomy surgery using ultrasound. The study will include patients aged 1-18 years who are undergoing elective adenotonsillectomy surgery and have given approval from their parents. The study will evaluate the gastric volume of patients in the preoperative and postoperative period using ultrasound in the right lateral decubitus position. The study will also evaluate the presence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) at the first, second, and 24th hours in the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) and at the ward. The study will also evaluate the blood volume in the suction system and the duration of surgery.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to explore the effect of pituitrin on postoperative outcomes in patients with pulmonary hypertension undergoing cardiac surgery. The study will include 120 patients who are scheduled for elective cardiopulmonary bypass heart surgery and have pulmonary hypertension. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the pituitrin group or the normal saline group. The pituitrin group will receive pituitrin at a dose of 1ml/6U, diluted with normal saline to 0.5u/ml, and injected by intravenous pump at the rate of 0.04u/ (kg · h). The normal saline group will receive normal saline at the same dose and speed. The primary outcome measure is a composite endpoint of mortality or severe postoperative complications within 30 days after cardiac surgery. The secondary outcome measures include postoperative infection, septic shock, duration of mechanical ventilation, postoperative pulmonary complications, time to achieve hemodynamic stability, use of dobutamine or other vasoactive drugs, incidence of digital ischemia, acute mesenteric ischemia, gastrointestinal complications, incidence of acute myocardial infarction, new onset tachyarrhythmia, water poisoning, vasodilative shock, incidence of pulmonary embolism, low cardiac output syndrome, acute respiratory distress syndrome, delirium, need for renal replacement therapy (RRT), need for hemodialysis, incidence of readmission to ICU, length of ICU stay, length of stay, levels of serum antidiuretic hormone in patients, levels of copeptin in patients, and secondary endotracheal intubation. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida, France. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a single-site, open-label, randomized controlled trial with a 1:1 allocation ratio. The study will compare the feasibility and safety of home initiation of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) in children with medical complexity (CMC) to the standard of care, which is in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) laboratory-based initiation. The study will enroll children aged 5-17 years old who are newly prescribed NiPPV and tolerate an awake NiPPV trial. The primary outcome is the recruitment and retention rate, and the secondary outcomes are adherence to NiPPV, quality of life, and safety. The study will evaluate the feasibility and safety of an innovative model of care for NiPPV initiation in the home environment utilizing remote telemonitoring compared to usual care, which is in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) laboratory-based initiation. The study will also assess the acceptability of the home initiation of NiPPV model to patients and families.

[/INST] The study is a single-blind randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effects of dry needling on vertical jump performance in female athletes with latent myofascial trigger points in the gastrocnemius muscle. The study will be conducted in the department of invasive physiotherapy of a private physiotherapy clinic in Toledo. The inclusion criteria are healthy female volleyball practitioners, no lower limb injuries in the last 6 months, presence of latent MTPs in gastrocnemius, familiar with performing CMJ tests. The exclusion criteria are needle phobia, presence of active MTPs in the lower limb, any pathology that prevented the use of dry needling, any pathology that prevented the performance of CMJ test. Subjects will be randomly assigned to two groups: intervention group and control group. The intervention group will receive dry needling on latent trigger points diagnosed on the selection phase. The control group will wait on the intervention couch for a similar time. The primary outcome measure is the counter movement jump. The study will be conducted at four time points: T0, T1, T3, and T4. The counter movement jump will be recorded with the iPhone 15 high-speed camera. The best of the three jumps will be recorded. The assessor will be blinded to the allocation group of the participants.

[/INST] The aim of the present study was to investigate the clinical features of refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP) and the clinical outcome of mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) in these patients. The study was a single-arm trial with 20 patients who were resistant to steroid and were treated with MMF. The primary outcome was the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools. The secondary outcome was the count of red blood cells in stool. The results showed that MMF was effective in treating refractory gastrointestinal HSP.

[/INST] The study is a phase II/III safety, feasibility, and efficacy trial of adjunctive electroencephalogram (EEG) enhanced transcranial magnetic stimulation (eTMS) for chronic trauma and stressor-related disorders (TSRD). The study will enroll 30 participants for an initial cohort and an additional 270 participants for a second stage. Participants will receive 6 weeks of daily eTMS as an adjunct to standard of care TSRD treatment. The primary outcome measures are the number of participants with device-related serious adverse events and the rate of participants completing 80% of scheduled visits. The secondary outcome measure is the mean change in Veterans RAND 36-item health survey (VR-36) mental component scores (MCS).

[/INST] The study is a retrospective study of radiotherapy combined with EGFR-TKI for stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer. The study is an open-label, multi-institutional, single-arm retrospective study. The study includes 100 patients who were treated with radiotherapy and EGFR-TKI. The study used three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy (3DCRT) or intensity-modulated conformal radiotherapy (IMRT) at a prescribed dose of 54-66 Gy/27-33 f. The combined TKI includes gefitinib, erlotinib, erlotinib, oseltinib, and ametinib. The specific uses are: gefitinib 250 mg orally once daily; erlotinib 125 mg orally three times daily; erlotinib 150 mg orally once daily; oseltinib 80 mg orally once daily; ametinib 110 mg orally once daily. TKI is taken until disease progression or intolerability. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) at 2 years.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute head and neck infections. The study will include patients over the age of 18 who are suffering from acute head and neck infections of Streptococci. Samples will be collected from Northampton General Hospital. The study will use DNA analysis of ribosomal ribonucleic acid (rRNA) genes and biochemical testing to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute head and neck infections. The study will also collect data on patient characteristics, site of infection, and clinical outcomes. The study will run for 4 years and will include 100 participants.

[/INST] The study was conducted in the period of 07/21/2021-30/10/2021. The study included 48 women 29-49 years old who have complained of stress urinary incontinence for at least 4 weeks, who have given birth and signed the consent form. The study participants were randomly divided into two groups: the I group (n=24), in which participants underwent functional magnetic stimulation (FMS) and the II group (n=24) in which subjects received pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) program. Participants were evaluated before the intervention and repeated after 6 weeks. Subjects responded to a general questionnaire before the intervention, before and after the intervention, the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7) were used to assess the symptoms of urinary incontinence and their impact on quality of life. Pelvic floor muscle strength and endurance were assessed with a Pelvexiser perineometer. Statistical analysis was performed by IBM SPSS Statistics 26.0 and Microsoft Excel software 365.

[/INST] The study is titled "Optimization of Psoriatic and Seronegative Rheumatoid Arthritis Patients Selection and Treatment Outcomes of Biologic Therapies" and is a clinical trial that aims to generate a comprehensive cellular and molecular atlas of psoriatic arthritis (PsA) by single-cell protein and transcriptomics and spatial transcriptomics of synovium of PsO at risk of developing PsA and PsA patients across different disease stages. The study will include five study cohorts: PsO patients at risk of PsA development, naive to treatment PsA, TNF-inhibitor resistant PsA, IL-17-inhibitor resistant PsA, TNF-inhibitor induced remission PsA, IL-17-inhibitor induced remission PsA, c-DMARDs resistant PsA, and c-DMARDs resistant RA. The primary outcome measure is minimal disease activity status achievement, and the secondary outcome measures are PsA development (fulfilment of the CASPAR criteria), remission maintenance, and generation of a comprehensive cellular and molecular atlas of PsA. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of artificial tears in preventing nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) in patients undergoing radioactive iodine therapy for thyroid cancer. The study will compare the incidence of NLDO in patients who receive artificial tears to those who do not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients who develop NLDO after radioactive iodine therapy in each experimental group, as determined by tear duct irrigation by an ophthalmologist. The study will follow up patients for two years to assess the incidence of NLDO. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that aims to compare the efficacy of atorvastatin to placebo in preventing disease recurrence in patients with high-risk stage IIA melanoma. The study will enroll patients who have undergone complete surgical resection of their melanoma and have a class 2B DecisionDx Melanoma test result. Patients will be randomized to receive either atorvastatin or placebo for up to 5 years and will undergo CT and/or MRI throughout the study. The primary outcome measure is recurrence-free survival, which will be assessed using the Kaplan-Meier method and compared between treatment arms using the stratified log-rank test. The secondary outcome measures are distant metastasis-free survival and overall survival, which will be compared between treatment arms using the stratified log-rank test.

[/INST] The ACHIEVE (Advancing Community and Clinical Care for Childbirth-related Hypertension Through Implementation, Engagement, and Valuing Equity) Initiative was designed to improve maternal health outcomes for pregnant people with high blood pressure. The project involves three rural Piedmont Health Services (PHS) clinics that serve mostly White and Latinx patients. The inpatient HTN bundle was adapted to fit the outpatient clinic setting and renamed the O-HTN bundle. The ACHIEVE Nurse Coordinator will provide training, coaching, and facilitation to 20 outpatient clinics in central North Carolina over a 30-month period. The study will use a hybrid type III, multiple baseline design to evaluate the effectiveness of the ACHIEVE multi-component implementation strategy in improving care for pregnant people with high blood pressure. The primary outcome measure is the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible score for blood pressure measurement technique. The secondary outcome measures are the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible score for documentation of delivery of patient education on hypertension and the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible score for recognition and response to simulated episodes of severe hypertension. The study will use a mixed-methods approach to evaluate the effectiveness of the ACHIEVE multi-component implementation strategy in improving care for pregnant people with high blood pressure. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of the ACHIEVE multi-component implementation strategy in improving care for pregnant people with high blood pressure and reducing maternal morbidity and mortality.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of three text messaging programs for reducing alcohol consumption among older adults. The three programs are based on gain-framed messaging, loss-framed messaging, and a combination of gain- and loss-framed messaging. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design to compare the effectiveness of the three programs. The primary outcome measure is the weekly sum of standard drinks, and the secondary outcome measures are the weekly sum of heavy drinking days, percent adherence to daily drinking assessment via text messages, percent adherence to weekly drinking assessment via web, and percent willingness to continue the program for another 8 weeks. The study will use text messaging, behavioral economics, and older adults as keywords.

[/INST] The study is titled "Fluselenamyl - Beta Amyloid PET Imaging for Alzheimer Disease" and is a phase 1 clinical trial. The study is designed to evaluate the safety and pharmacokinetics of the investigational radiotracer [18F]-Fluselenamyl in healthy volunteers and participants with mild cognitive impairment of Alzheimer's dementia. The study will also assess the sensitivity of [18F]-Fluselenamyl to image Amyloid beta in the setting of mild cognitive impairment and conduct comparative analysis of PET imaging data using [11C]-PIB imaging in the same participants. The study will enroll 16 participants, who will receive a single intravenous bolus injection of 10 mCi ± 20% of the investigational radiotracer [18F]-Fluselenamyl and will undergo an [18F]-Fluselenamyl PET/CT scan. The study will last for 2 years and will be conducted in the United States.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the long-term effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in patients with primary progressive aphasia (PPA). The study will compare the effects of TMS active and sham on brain metabolism, language, daily-living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. The study will use theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) over the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. The study will have two arms: an active arm, which will receive TMS active and language therapy, and a sham arm, which will receive TMS sham and language therapy. The study will use the Mini-Linguistic State Examination, trained and untrained words, Interview for Deterioration in Daily living in Dementia Scale, and Neuropsychiatric Inventory scale to assess language, daily-living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. The study will use FDG-PET imaging to assess brain metabolism. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2a, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial of methylprednisolone versus placebo in patients with cognitive deficits in post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS). The study aims to investigate the impact of methylprednisolone on cognitive deficits in PCS patients with suspected autoimmune involvement. The study will be conducted in two phases: a 6-week treatment phase and a 6-week follow-up phase. The primary outcome measure is improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) at week 8. The secondary outcome measures include long-term improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the MMQ, improvement in memory ability and memory strategy as measured by the MMQ, improvement in neurocognitive functions as measured by the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), improvement in neurocognitive functions as measured by the symbol digit modalities test (SDMT), improvement in quality of life (QoL) as measured by the PROMIS questionnaire, improvement in physical and mental fatigue as measured by the Chalder Fatigue Scale, improvement in fatigue as measured by the Fatigue Severity Score (FSS), and improvement in mood as measured by the Becks Depression Inventory (BDI-II). [/INST] The study is a four-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial. The experimental groups will receive composite resin restorations using an alcohol- and water-based solvent universal adhesive in the selective enamel etching strategy with evaporation of solvent for 25 seconds or an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive with solvent evaporation for 25 seconds. The control groups will receive composite resin restorations using an alcohol- and water-based universal solvent adhesive in the selective enamel etching strategy with evaporation of solvent for 5 seconds or an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive with solvent evaporation for 5 seconds. The restorations will be finished immediately with fine diamond burs and polished with discs and polishing gums. The primary outcome measure is the retention of restorations. The secondary outcome measures are marginal adaptation and marginal staining of restorations. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.

[/INST] The study is a phase II/III, randomized, double-blinded, parallel-controlled trial to evaluate the immunogenicity and safety of a heterologous booster dose of COVID-19 mRNA vaccine (SWIM816) in previously vaccinated subjects. The study will enroll participants aged 18 years or older who have completed the primary vaccination regimen of COVID-19 vaccine (2/3 doses) and have completed the follow-up period of 6 to 24 months after the last dose of vaccine. The study will compare the immunogenicity and safety of SWIM816 with those of the control group (Pfizer Bivalent vaccine). The primary endpoint is the geometric mean titer (GMT) of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron and related strain neutralizing antibody levels for SWIM816. The secondary endpoint is the percentage of participants with seroresponse to SARS-CoV-2 Omicron and related strain neutralizing antibody levels for SWIM816. The study will also evaluate the safety of SWIM816 and the percentage of participants with seroresponse to SARS-CoV-2 Omicron and related strain neutralizing antibody levels for Pfizer Bivalent vaccine. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to enroll 1,000 participants. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The Esbjerg Cohort is a cross-sectional study conducted in the municipality of Esbjerg, Denmark. The study aims to investigate the relationship between ergonomic exposure and physical capacity, work ability, and musculoskeletal pain in workers aged 55-70 years. The study population consists of 336 participants divided into 12 groups based on gender, age, and occupational group (white-collar or blue-collar worker). The study includes physical tests, questionnaires, and long-term evaluation of work ability. The study will provide knowledge on the consequences of high physical workload on the musculoskeletal system in the oldest group of workers, which will be used for better treatment and counseling of the oldest group of workers and for improved guidelines on how to optimize the balance between physical work demands and workers' capacity.

[/INST] The study is a phase I clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and feasibility of autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells in treating patients with locally advanced and unresectable or metastatic small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer. The study involves leukapheresis to obtain peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) for T cell product manufacturing and lymphodepleting chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and fludarabine. Patients receive an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion and are followed up for 12 months after the last infusion. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of adverse events, and the secondary outcome measures include dose-limiting toxicity rates, objective response, radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.

[/INST] The study is a before and after study that compares the safety and efficacy of a new technique called Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA) to total pancreatectomy (TP) for the treatment of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDCA). The study group consisted of 40 consecutive patients who underwent WOTSA, and their clinicopathological characteristics and survival were compared with those of a historical control group of 30 consecutive patients who underwent TP. The study found that WOTSA is a safe and effective alternative to TP for the treatment of PDCA.

[/INST] The study aimed to evaluate the effect of breastfeeding education given to fathers via WhatsApp messaging application in the postpartum period on breastfeeding. The study was designed as a randomized controlled trial with a solomon four-group design. The study included 120 couples who were followed up in the postpartum clinic of the hospital. The fathers in the experimental groups were given breastfeeding education via WhatsApp messaging application on the 3rd postpartum day. The fathers in the control groups did not receive any breastfeeding education. Breastfeeding support of fathers was evaluated using the Breastfeeding Support Scale and The Partner Breastfeeding Influence Scale. The results of the study showed that breastfeeding support of fathers in the experimental groups was higher than the control groups. The study concluded that breastfeeding education given to fathers via WhatsApp messaging application in the postpartum period was effective in increasing breastfeeding support of fathers.

[/INST] The study is a non-interventional study that aims to evaluate the biomarker testing and treatment patterns among patients with PIK3CA mutation in advanced breast cancer. The study will collect data on the number of patients with PIK3CA mutation, time from first breast cancer diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation, time from advanced breast cancer diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation, time from initiation of first-line treatment for advanced breast cancer diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation, number of tests for patients with CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment, time from progression on CDK4/6 inhibitor to first PIK3CA evaluation, year of (first, where applicable) PIK3CA evaluation, result of PIK3CA evaluation (negative, positive, unknown), type of biopsy, type of tissue sample, source of tissue sample, analytical method used for PIK3CA evaluation, age at advanced breast cancer diagnosis, stage when patients were diagnosed with breast cancer, number of patients with known metastatic sites, performance as assessed by Karnofsky Performance Scale, performance as assessed by the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status Scale, height, weight, body mass index (BMI), number of patients per stage of cancer, number of patients per line of treatment, time from advanced diagnosis to initiation of lines of treatment, number of patients per systemic therapy, number of patients per treatment sequence, number of patients per supportive treatment.

[/INST] The study titled "The Effects of Melatonin on Sleep Spindles in Children with Autism" is a basic science study that aims to investigate the effects of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study includes 10 participants aged 12-18 years with ASD who are English-speaking and able to understand and respond to questionnaires in English. The study uses 5mg melatonin gummy 30 min before bedtime for 2 consecutive nights. The study is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is titled "Etiological Study of Persistent Velopharyngeal Insufficiency in Children With Operated Velopalatine Cleft by Analysis of Velopharyngeal Motor Skills in Static and Dynamic MRI" and is a non-randomized controlled trial. The study aims to investigate the etiology of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency in children with operated velopalatine clefts by analyzing velopharyngeal motor skills in static and dynamic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The study will include 20 children aged 7 to 12 years with isolated cleft lip, isolated velopalatal cleft without a diagnosis of syndromic cleft or Pierre Robin sequence, and operated with a cheiloplasty (for cleft lip) or an intravelar veloplasty (according to Sommerlad) at the Amiens University Hospital. The study will use dynamic and static MRI to assess velopharyngeal motor skills and will compare the results to those of a control group of children with normal velar anatomy and soft VPI. The study will also assess the ratio between the diameter of the pharynx at rest and during phonation, the closure distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall, and the distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall. The study will be conducted at the Amiens University Hospital and will use a 3T TX DStream Philips® and a 33 channels head and neck coil for MRI. An elastic strap will be fixed to the forehead to limit movement during the scan, and a headset will be used to cancel the loud MRI noise and to communicate with the subjects. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the local ethics committee. The results of the study will contribute to a better understanding of the etiology of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency in children with operated velopalatine clefts and will help to develop more effective treatment strategies for this condition.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of a 16-week remote-delivered exercise program on cognitive and physical function in older adults with multiple sclerosis. The program will be delivered via telerehabilitation and will focus on aerobic and resistance exercises. The primary outcome measures are cognitive function, physical function, and walking speed. The secondary outcome measures are physical activity level, exercise behavior, vascular function, and walking endurance. The study will use the Guidelines for Exercise in Multiple Sclerosis (GEMS) program and the Flexibility and Stretching Program (FLEX-MS) program. The study will be conducted in Canada and will involve 120 participants who are aged 50 years or older, have a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, and have mild-to-moderate cognitive impairment. The study will be conducted over a 32-week period, with 16 weeks of intervention and 16 weeks of follow-up. The study will use a parallel assignment model, with participants being randomly assigned to either the GEMS program or the FLEX-MS program. The study will use double-blinded masking, with both participants and researchers being blinded to group allocation. The study will use a remote delivery model, with participants receiving the intervention via telerehabilitation. The study will use a self-monitoring logbook and newsletters to promote adherence to the program. The study will use a mixed-methods design, with quantitative and qualitative data being collected. The quantitative data will be collected using questionnaires, physical assessments, and accelerometers, while the qualitative data will be collected using focus groups and interviews. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Research Ethics Board.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study, non-interventional research involving the human subjects, category 3, aimed at measuring the clinical and biological the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration hemofiltration membrane. The study will be conducted on critically ill patients with vasoplegic shock (hemodynamic support by noradrenaline). The study will measure the reduction in vasoinotropic score within 24 hours of initiation on oXiris, the evolution of the vaso-inotropic score within 72 hours of management, the quantitative determination of angiotensins (Ang I, II, III, IV, 1-5, 1-7, 1-9, 2-7, 2-10 and 3-7) and regulatory enzymes (renin, angiotensin-converting enzyme, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 and neprilysin), the clearance of endothelial permeability markers (soluble E-selectin, thromboxane A2, endothelium-derived relaxing factor, bradykinin), the markers of sepsis-induced immunosuppression expressed by HLA-DR monocytes in flow cytometry and selected cytokines (IL-1 beta, IL-6, IL-8, IL-10, TNF-alpha), and the 90-day mortality. The study will be conducted in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares two different approaches to urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in cases with previous cesarean section. The first approach is the central urinary bladder dissection, where the bladder is dissected from the cervix and downwards. The second approach is the lateral urinary bladder dissection, where the broad ligament is dissected down till the uterine bundle is identified and the space can be dissected just above these vessels to reach the lateral margins of cervix. The primary outcome measure is the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection. The secondary outcome measures are operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications. The study is currently recruiting participants.

The study will recruit 28 male amateur cricket players aged 20 to 30 years with no history of systemic disease. The training will be performed for 6 weeks, and the training regimen will include exercises for the upper and lower body. The primary outcome measures are the bench press test and leg press test, and the secondary outcome measure is the 30-second sit-to-stand test. The study will use the Functional Movement Screen (FMS) to assess the functional performance of the participants. The study will use the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 25 to analyze the data.

[/INST] The study aimed to evaluate the effect of breastfeeding training given to fathers on breastfeeding, parent-baby bonding, and breastfeeding self-efficacy level. The study was conducted in a hospital in Turkey and included 120 participants. The participants were randomly assigned to three groups: experimental group 1, experimental group 2, and control group. Experimental group 1 received breastfeeding training for both parents, experimental group 2 received breastfeeding training only for the mother, and the control group received routine hospital care. The training was given within the first 24 hours after birth and lasted for 30-45 minutes. The training included breastfeeding techniques, burping, changing diapers, milking by hand or pump, etc. The training was given by the researcher and was face-to-face theoretical and practical. The training was also given by phone in the 1st, 1st, and 3rd months. The primary outcome measures were breastfeeding self-efficacy, mother-infant bonding, father breastfeeding self-efficacy, and paternal infant attachment. The secondary outcome measures were infant evaluation form. The results showed that breastfeeding training given to fathers had a positive effect on breastfeeding, parent-baby bonding, and breastfeeding self-efficacy level. The study concluded that breastfeeding training given to fathers is an effective way to promote breastfeeding and improve parent-baby bonding.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of adding strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises on pain, function, strength of muscles, and knee proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study will include 40-55-year-old patients with knee osteoarthritis who have pain for more than 3 months. The patients will be randomly allocated to the control or experimental group. The control group will receive knee exercises, while the experimental group will receive knee exercises and strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles. The study will measure pain level, functional level, knee proprioception, hip internal and external rotator strength, ankle dorsi flexors, planter flexor, invertor and evertor strength, and quadriceps strength. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 weeks.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent for chronic sinusitis. The study will include patients who are scheduled to undergo primary or revision bilateral endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS) and have evidence of bilateral sinus disease based on computed tomographic (CT) scan. The primary outcome measure is the non-reintervention rate, which is the need for postoperative interventions, medical and surgical, as determined based on review of video endoscopic findings by an independent blinded surgeon. The secondary outcome measures are the Lund-Kennedy score, Lund-Mackay score, VAS score, sinus pain rate, and implantation successful rate. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year, with follow-up visits at 30 days, 90 days, 180 days, and 1 year. The study will compare the bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent with a marketed bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent.

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of providing cancer care closer to home for patients with multiple myeloma. The study will compare the proportion of eligible participants who successfully transfer to the provider at a satellite location between the experimental and active comparator groups. The study will also explore differences in participant experience, satisfaction, and financial toxicity between those that elect to transfer to a satellite site and those who decline to transfer.

[/INST] Virtual Reality vs Nitrous Oxide in Pediatric Dentistry is a prospective, randomized controlled, interventional therapy trial. The study will compare the use of virtual reality goggles as a method of distraction to nitrous oxide in pediatric patients aged 4-12 years who require nitrous oxide sedation to complete dental treatment. The study will use the FLACC, WongBaker, and Houpt scales to assess pain and discomfort in children. The primary outcome measure is the rate of effectiveness of virtual reality goggles in reducing pain compared to nitrous oxide. The secondary outcome measure is the rate of effectiveness of virtual reality distraction compared to nitrous oxide. The study will be conducted over a 12-month period.

[/INST] The study is a prospective study that aims to identify patients with recurrent colorectal lesions risk and try to design an optimal intervals of surveillance colonoscopies, especially in the high-risk group of patients, using mutation and clinical-pathologic phenotype. The study will determine the mutation profile and mutation burden in 200 patients based on examination of all their index and synchronous lesions found during index colonoscopy using an established PCR/DCE-based heteroduplex method. Clinical and histopathological evaluation and mutational profiling of all metachronous lesions found during five-year surveillance period will be done.

[/INST] The SAM Project is a study that aims to characterize malnutrition through the identification of specific biomarkers of the condition. The study will collect clinical, anamnestic and lifestyle data, as well as faecal, blood and saliva samples from patients affected by malnutrition due to deficiency or excess and sex- and age-matched healthy controls not affected by any pathology and/or malnutrition due to deficiency or excess. The study will use untargeted microRNA expression profile in blood samples, plasmatic extracellular vesicles, metagenomic analysis of fecal samples, metabolomicanalysis of fecal samples, untargeted microRNA expression profile in saliva samples, and salivary extracellular vesicles to characterize malnutrition. The study will last for 36 months.
