[/INST] The study is a clinical trial that aims to use a multi-channel time-resolved functional near infrared spectroscopy (tr-fNIRS) device to monitor cerebral oxygenation during shoulder surgery in the beach chair position. The device will be used to gather data on cerebral oxygenation of multiple brain regions for patients undergoing shoulder surgery. The study will assess the impact of intraoperative hemodynamic parameters on regional differences in cerebral oxygenation between brain regions during surgery. The study will also assess regional differences in cerebral autoregulation in the beach chair position under general anesthesia as measured by the tr-fNIRS monitor. The study will also assess the association between cerebral desaturation (or hypoxic injury) events in multiple brain regions to clinical outcomes such as stroke and delirium.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical feasibility trial that aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of mechanical insufflation-exsufflation (MI-E) in critically ill adult patients receiving invasive ventilation. The study will compare the intervention group receiving MI-E to the control group receiving standard airway care. The primary outcome is the proportion of complete MI-E sessions per calendar day. The secondary outcomes include the incidence of pneumothorax, endotracheal tube obstruction, severe hypoxemia, severe hypotension, and severe hypertension. The study will also assess the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of MI-E, as well as the amount of time needed for MI-E, frequency of endotracheal suctioning, and frequency of manual hyperinflation. The study will also evaluate the efficacy of MI-E on ventilator-associated pneumonia, duration of invasive ventilation, mortality at day 28, ventilator-free days at day 28, ICU mortality, hospital mortality, use of supplemental oxygen on ICU delivery after detubation, length of stay in ICU, and length of stay in hospital.

[/INST] The Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT-TR) is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study that aims to evaluate the efficacy of enavogliflozin in patients with functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (HFpEF). The study will assess the effects of enavogliflozin on clinical outcomes, including cardiovascular events, all-cause death, cardiovascular clinical events, renal events, change of TR, and change of right ventricular strain. The study will enroll patients with moderate or severe functional TR, HFpEF, and a history of NYHA class II or III symptoms. Patients will be randomized to receive enavogliflozin or placebo for 18 months. The primary outcome measure is a composite of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for HF, or worsening of TR. The secondary outcome measures are all-cause death, cardiovascular clinical events, renal events, change of TR, and change of right ventricular strain. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of enavogliflozin in patients with functional TR and HFpEF.

[/INST] The study is a proof of concept one aimed at investigating the relation between daily physical activity, measured by mean number of daily steps, and PK variability of infused rec-FVIII concentrate in patients with severe HA under prophylaxis. The study will be conducted at the Haemostasis and Thrombosis Center of the Fondazione Policlinico Gemelli IRCCS Rome (FPG). Patients 12-60 yo with severe HA under FVIII concentrates prophylaxis will be selected. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months. The primary outcome measure is the study of the association between physical activity, measured by mean number of daily steps, with the Area Under the Curve (AUC) PK parameter in patients with severe HA under prophylaxis. The study aims to evaluate whether and how the FVIII PK parameter is significantly associated with the mean number of daily steps in patients with severe HA.

[/INST] The study is titled "Critical Time Window for Rehabilitation After Incomplete Spinal Cord Injury: Early vs Late Locomotor Training" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to compare the effects of early and late locomotor training on walking recovery in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury. The study will use body weight supported treadmill training as the intervention and will compare the effects of starting the intervention within 60 days of injury (early intervention), 3 months after injury (sub-acute intervention), and 6-12 months after injury (chronic intervention) to no intervention. The study will use the 10-meter walk test, 6-minute walk test, and walking index for spinal cord injury to assess walking speed, distance, and physical assistance needed to walk. The study will also use a waist-worn activity tracker to assess daily step counts. The study will enroll participants between the ages of 16 and 75 who have a history of acute and traumatic spinal cord injury, are able to tolerate a harness, and are within 60 days of injury. The study will exclude participants with orthopedic injuries, fractures, surgeries, or other conditions affecting locomotor function or weight bearing, moderate to severe traumatic brain injury or other neurological conditions that impair cognition, uncontrolled orthostatic hypotension, other medical complications such as severe heart failure, pregnancy, and severe pelvic or lower abdominal wounds that may limit the ability to safely don and doff a harness for ambulation. The study will be conducted at two sites in the United States and will follow a parallel assignment model. The study will have four arms: early intervention, sub-acute intervention, chronic intervention, and no intervention. The study will have a double-blind design. The study will have a total duration of 12 months, including a 1-month baseline period, a 1-month intervention period, and 10-month follow-up period. The study will enroll 120 participants and will have a 1:1:1:1 allocation ratio. The study will have a single primary outcome measure, the 10-meter walk test, which will be assessed at baseline and 1-5 days following the intervention. The study will also have three secondary

[/INST] The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of education based on the health promotion model on premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior, and perceived stress. The study was conducted as a randomized controlled trial with a pretest-posttest design. The intervention group received education based on the health promotion model, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The results showed that the intervention group had significant improvements in premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior, and perceived stress compared to the control group. The study concluded that education based on the health promotion model can be effective in improving premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior, and perceived stress.

[/INST] The AMP SCZ® Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC is a study that aims to develop a deep biomarker-informed functional characterization and longitudinal clinical profiling of CHR individuals. The study will use data from two CHR research networks, ProNET and PRESCIENT, to identify and validate biomarkers and predict individual outcome trajectories. The study will also develop powerful and robust stratification tools to identify and validate biomarkers and predict individual outcome trajectories. The study will also develop a flexible infrastructure to accommodate multiple data types and provide rapid data processing and quality assurance and quality control. The study will also assist in archiving data and making it publicly available in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The study will also disseminate information, including tools developed, to the general research community and provide outreach to the community via a website.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of Problem Management Plus (PM+) for prisoners in the Netherlands. The study will include 60 participants who are imprisoned in Dutch prisons and have elevated levels of psychological distress. The intervention will be delivered by trained master students in clinical psychology and supervised by mental health care specialists. The study will evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of PM+ in prisons by assessing factors such as PM+ fidelity, perceptions about PM+ from stakeholders, indicators of intervention delivery, retention rate of PM+ sessions, and recruitment and consent rates. The study will also assess preliminary indications of pre to post-effects on symptoms of depression and anxiety, self-identified problems, quality of life, trauma, and suicidal vulnerability.

[/INST] The study is a phase I clinical trial that aims to determine the best safe dose of xevinapant when given in combination with radiation and chemotherapy for patients with head and neck cancer. The study will enroll patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck that is stages T1-2N1-3 or T3-4N0-3 (AJCC 8th edition). Patients must have a contraindication to cisplatin and be aged 18 years or older. The study will consist of four escalation groups and one dose expansion group. Each group will receive xevinapant at a different dose level in combination with radiation and chemotherapy. The primary outcome measure of the study is to determine the best safe dose of xevinapant when given in combination with radiation and chemotherapy. The secondary outcome measures of the study include progression-free survival, number of side effects seen when xevinapant is given in combination with radiation and chemotherapy, overall survival, locoregional failure, distant failure, and response rate. The study will enroll 100 participants and is expected to be completed in June 2026.

[/INST] The study is a phase 1, open-label, single-arm study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ARV-471 in participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer. The study will enroll participants who have received at least one line of SOC therapy for advanced or metastatic disease. The primary objective of the study is to determine the MTD and RP2D of ARV-471. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the safety and tolerability of ARV-471, the pharmacokinetics of ARV-471, and the pharmacodynamics of ARV-471. The study will use a standard 3+3 design to determine the MTD and RP2D of ARV-471. Participants will receive a single dose of ARV-471 on day 1 of cycle 1 and will undergo safety and tolerability assessments. If no DLTs occur, participants will receive ARV-471 on day 1 of cycle 2 at the RP2D. Participants will undergo safety and tolerability assessments on day 1 of cycle 2 and on day 1 of cycles 3-6. Participants will undergo pharmacokinetic assessments on day 1 of cycle 1 and on day 1 of cycles 2-6. Participants will undergo pharmacodynamic assessments on day 1 of cycle 1 and on day 1 of cycles 2-6. The study will enroll up to 48 participants.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, open-label, randomized, controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of olaparib and alpelisib in patients with PIK3CA-mutated, HER2-negative, advanced breast cancer. The study will have two cohorts: cohort 1 will be a randomized, controlled trial comparing olaparib and alpelisib versus olaparib alone, and cohort 2 will be a single-arm trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of olaparib and alpelisib. The primary endpoint of the study is progression-free survival (PFS) in cohort 2. The study will also evaluate the objective response rate (ORR), overall survival (OS), clinical benefit rate (CBR), and safety of the treatment regimens.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial with two parallel arms. The participants will be randomized to either Schema Therapy or Treatment as Usual. The participants in the Schema Therapy arm will receive up to 30 individual, weekly sessions of Schema Therapy. The participants in the Treatment as Usual arm will receive treatment as usual in the Danish secondary psychiatric sector, which typically consists of psychotherapy, medication, and other interventions. The primary outcome is the change in depression symptoms on the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D) from baseline to 12 months after baseline. The secondary outcomes are change in depression symptoms on the HAM-D from baseline to 6 and 24 months after baseline, change in depression symptoms on the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) from baseline to 12, 6, and 24 months after baseline, change in psychological well-being on the WHO-5 Well-Being Index (WHO-5) from baseline to 12, 6, and 24 months after baseline, change in personal recovery on the INSPIRE-O Brief from baseline to 12, 6, and 24 months after baseline, change in repetitive negative thinking on the Perseverative Thinking Questionnaire (PTQ) from baseline to 12, 6, and 24 months after baseline, change in health-related quality of life on the EuroQol-5D (EQ-5D) from baseline to 12, 6, and 24 months after baseline, and change in schema modes on the Schema Mode Inventory (SMI) from baseline to 12 months after baseline.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III, stepped wedge cluster randomized design. The study aims to evaluate the effect of a paramedical protocol for ventilation in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) on mortality and number of days without mechanical ventilation. The study will include 1,000 patients with ARDS in 10 intensive care units (ICUs) in France. The experimental group will receive a paramedical protocol for ventilation in ARDS, while the control group will receive usual care. The primary endpoint will be a combination of mortality and the number of days without mechanical ventilation at day 28. The secondary endpoints will include tidal volume ventilation, plateau pressure, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), FiO2, oxygenation, number of days without mechanical ventilation, number of days without catecholamine, number of days without continuous sedation, duration of mechanical ventilation, occurrence of mechanically ventilated pneumothorax, duration of acute respiratory distress syndrome, duration of weaning from mechanical ventilation, number of participants with rescue therapy, rate of re-intubation, rate of use of non-invasive ventilation and curative high-flow oxygen therapy, tracheostomy rate, length of stay in ICU and in hospital, number of deaths in ICU and hospital, and number of nurses trained in paramedical protocol per center.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study that aims to test the efficacy of a culturally adapted intervention for Haitian immigrants living with HIV. The intervention is an adaptation of the iENGAGE intervention, which is a behavioral intervention that aims to improve engagement and retention in care and viral suppression among people living with HIV. The study will use a quasi-experimental design, with a sample of 30 participants recruited from two Federally Qualified Health Centers in Miami. The intervention will consist of four individual meetings over a six-month period, and participants will be followed up at baseline, post-intervention, and six months post-baseline. The primary outcome measures will be engagement and retention in care score and viral suppression. The study will also use photovoice to identify multi-level implementation factors contributing to intervention outcomes.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial that compares the effectiveness of three different methods of root canal cleaning and debridement: passive ultrasonic irrigation, Endoclean device, and conventional method. The primary objective of the study is to test the effectiveness of the Endoclean device for root canal debridement up to 12 months follow-up. The secondary objective is to test the extended effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device up to a 24-month follow-up. The study will include 109 subjects who will be randomly assigned to one of the three groups. The Endoclean device uses hydraulic cavitation cleaning to debride the root canal, while the conventional method uses manual or rotary files to shape the root canal and irrigate it with saline solution. The passive ultrasonic irrigation group will receive irrigation with sodium hypochlorite after shaping the root canal with manual or rotary instruments. The study will assess the effectiveness of the three methods through the success of periapical healing and the safety of the methods through the absence of postoperative pain. The study will also assess the extended effectiveness of the Endoclean device up to 24 months follow-up.

[/INST] The study is titled "FRACT-AI: Evaluating the Impact of Artificial Intelligence-Enhanced Image Analysis on the Diagnostic Accuracy of Frontline Clinicians in the Detection of Fractures on Plain X-Ray" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the impact of artificial intelligence (AI)-enhanced image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in the detection of fractures on plain X-ray. The study will involve 18 readers from five clinical specialty groups (emergency medicine, trauma and orthopaedic surgery, emergency nurse practitioners, physiotherapy, general radiology, and radiographers) and from the following level of seniority/experience: consultant/senior/equivalent - >10yrs experience, middle grade/registrar/equivalent - 5-10yrs experience, junior grade/senior house officer/equivalent - <5yrs experience. The readers will review 500 X-rays each time separated by a washout period to mitigate recall bias. The cases will be randomised between the two reads and for every reader. The study will include two sessions (with and without AI overlay), with all 18 readers reviewing all 500 XR cases each time. The study will evaluate the performance of the AI algorithm and the performance of readers with and without AI assistance. The study will also evaluate the mean time taken to review a XR, with vs without AI assistance. The study will use the following outcome measures: performance of the AI algorithm: sensitivity, specificity, area under the ROC curve (AU ROC); performance of readers with and without AI assistance: sensitivity, specificity, AU ROC; reader speed with vs without AI assistance. The study will use the following terms: radiology, XRays, emergency medicine, artificial intelligence, fractures.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to evaluate fine motor function in children with specific learning disorders. The study will compare fine motor function, hand grip strength, and hand and forearm anthropometric characteristics between children with specific learning disorders and healthy children. The study will also examine the relationship between fine motor function and quality of life and participation in activities at home, school, and community environment in children with specific learning disorders.

[/INST] The IM-ZBULLE Study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind, controlled study in 2 parallel groups. The experimental group will be offered an intramuscular injection using the Z-track and Airlock techniques, while the control group will have an usual injection. The primary outcome measure is pain reduction, assessed using a millimeter-scale visual analogic scale (VAS) to measure pain perceived by the patient 5 minutes after the treatment. The secondary outcome measures are drug leakage reduction, impact of the injection, improving participants satisfaction, improving the therapeutic alliance, and identifying the obstacles and levers to changing practices.

[/INST] The trial is a feasibility study of preoperative 5-day hypofractionated radiotherapy (HFRT) for primary soft tissue sarcoma (STS). The trial aims to determine the feasibility of the 5-day HFRT regimen, defined as the proportion of eligible patients who elect to participate in the trial. The trial also aims to assess the rate of favorable pathologic response, rate of major wound complications, local control, acute toxicity, and 1-year late HFRT toxicity. The trial will use a single-group assignment model and will not be masked. The trial will enroll patients with histologically confirmed STS of the extremity or trunk, aged 18 years or older, with an ECOG performance status of 0-3, who meet screening criteria for receipt of radiotherapy, are eligible for wide local excision, and do not have distant metastatic disease, prior radiation therapy in the proposed treatment area, simultaneous treatment of another malignancy, or planned neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy. The trial will use a 5-day HFRT regimen of 30 Gy/5fx once daily over consecutive weekdays, followed by standard of care wide local excision 2-6 weeks later. The trial will assess the feasibility of the 5-day HFRT regimen by calculating the proportion of eligible patients who elect to participate in the trial. The trial will assess the rate of favorable pathologic response by calculating the proportion of patients with extent of tumor fibrosis/hyalinization and infarct > 12.5% as assessed by the pathologist. The trial will assess the rate of major wound complications by assessing major wound complications defined according to the CAN-NCIC-SR2 Multi-center trial within 6 months of surgery. The trial will assess local control by calculating 1-year Local Recurrence Free Survival, calculated from the date of surgery to the date of 12-month follow up. The trial will assess acute toxicity by assessing acute toxicity defined by CTCAE v 5.0 assessed during radiotherapy treatment and 2 weeks following completion of radiotherapy. The trial will assess 1-year late HFRT toxicity by assessing physician assessment using the RTOG/EORTC

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of postoperative analgesia outcomes of pericapsular nerve group block (PENG) combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block (LFCN) to intravenous morphine analgesia via patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) for patients undergoing hip replacement surgery. The study includes 120 patients who are randomly assigned to either the PENG and LFCN group or the PCA group. The primary outcome measure is the average visual analogue scale (VAS) score at rest and on movement of both groups. The secondary outcome measures are the rate of vomiting/nausea, itchy, urinary retention, respiratory failure postoperative of both groups. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Hospital. The study is registered in the Chinese Clinical Trial Registry (ChiCTR1900026331).

[/INST] The study is a retrospective, observational study that aims to evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines in children aged ≥2 and <18 years in England between 2012 and 2020. The study will use the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) data, which includes vaccination, diagnosis, and demographic data. The study will use logistic regression analyses to test for factors associated with vaccine uptake and outcomes between vaccinated and unvaccinated children. The study will provide up-to-date epidemiological evidence on the uptake of LAIV and its impact on HCRU related to ILI in children in England.

[/INST] Reciting Tang Poems to Promote Happiness is a pilot pre-post interventional trial with no controls, with 10-20 South Asian children in primary schools (Grades 1-2, age 6-9) being recruited. In most primary schools, grades 1-2 students have not started learning Tang poems. Students and their parents will be actively approached by Hong Kong Christian Service (HKCS). An information sheet will be provided to the parents of eligible children, and their contact information will be asked. Parents give written consent if they agree for their children to participate. Parents will be invited to join the intervention sessions to show support for students' participation but they will only sit at the back of the room without active interaction or learning requirements. The intervention comprises three 1.5-hour sessions of Tang poem reciting and one session for participant performances. Experienced instructors from Bestreben Drama Association Limited will lead each session, and adherence to the protocol will be assessed by independent reviewers. Participants will recite two poems per session, with adjustments based on performance. Body language, sound, images, and videos will be used, along with engaging games, to enhance motivation and memory. Participants will receive stamp/sticker collection books and be rewarded for their achievements. Parents will complete questionnaires for themselves (Part II) and assisting their children (Part I). Parental presence and support will be acknowledged through supermarket coupon incentives. The feasibility outcomes will be reported descriptively and narratively, including the recruitment rate, duration, and retention rate. Descriptive statistics, mean (standard deviation) for continuous outcomes, will be reported for the secondary outcomes. The investigators will use content analysis method to analyze the qualitative data from the in-depth interviews. It is expected that those fun activities for reciting Tang poems may help promoting happiness and enjoyment in primary school ethnic minority students in Hong Kong.

[/INST] The study is a pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to test the impact of using the Vira platform for patients versus treatment as usual control (TAU; i.e., not using Vira) in the context of an intensive outpatient setting. The study will include adolescent patients (n = 200) aged 13-18-years-old randomized to: (a) Vira group (n = 100) and (b) treatment as usual control group (n = 100). The overarching goal is to test whether using the Vira platform in the context of an intensive outpatient setting improves clinical outcomes. The primary outcome measure is the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) and the secondary outcome measures are the Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI), Screen for Anxiety Related Emotional Disorders (SCARED), Risky Behavior Questionnaire for Adolescents (RBQ-A), Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ), and Anticipatory & Consummatory Interpersonal Pleasure Scale (ACIPS).

[/INST] The study is titled "Impact of Sex and Age on Non-visual Light Input That Affects Sleep and Circadian Rhythms". The study is a basic science study that aims to investigate the effects of non-visual light input on pupil response, circadian timing, and hormones. The study will be conducted on healthy participants aged 18-85 years old. The study will use pupillometry and light box exposure to measure pupil size and melatonin levels. [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a new parent training program for parents with ADHD called Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA). The program is designed to improve parental self-efficacy, parental stress, household disorganization, and child behavior problems. The study will also examine the feasibility of the program and the potential moderating or mediating effects of baseline variables and levels of active participation on efficacy outcomes. The study will use self- and parental report scales to assess the outcomes before and after the intervention, as well as approximately 1.5-3 months after program completion, in connection with an IPSA booster session. The study will also assess the feasibility of the program based on attendance records and parental reports. The study will examine whether IPSA is an acceptable intervention, examine levels of active participation, and monitor potential harms. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with parallel groups, where eligible individuals are block randomized on each clinical site to one of two groups (ratio 1:1): Treatment (IPSA directly) or Control (continued routine services; offered IPSA approximately six months later). Randomization is done using a digital randomization tool. Allocation (treatment or control) is masked to participants and study staff administering the screening/inclusion/assessment procedures until after the baseline assessment (including pre-intervention questionnaires) has been completed. The study will be conducted at the Center of Neurodevelopmental Disorders at Karolinska Institutet (KIND), Karolinska Institutet, Sweden, in collaboration with an ADHD Center run by the publicly-funded Habilitation & Health, Stockholm Health Care Services, Region Stockholm, Sweden. The study will use self- and parental report scales to assess the outcomes before and after the intervention, as well as approximately 1.5-3 months after program completion, in connection with an IPSA booster session. The study will examine whether IPSA is an acceptable intervention, examine levels of active participation, and monitor potential harms. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with parallel groups, where eligible individuals are block randomized on each clinical site to one of two groups (ratio 1:1): Treatment (IPSA directly) or Control (continued routine services; offered IPSA approximately six months later). [/INST] The Substance Use and Health Risk Intervention (SUHRI) for Justice-involved Youth is a 1-arm study that examined preliminary efficacy of the adapted intervention. The study was conducted on youth aged 14 to 18 who are disposed to community supervision (deferred adjudication or probation) and meet eligibility requirements (1+ indicator of substance use, under community supervisions, English-speaking, no indication of suicide risk or thought disorder) from a large urban Texas juvenile probation department. The intervention was a technology-based application (administered via tablet) that addresses the interrelated topics of substance use and risky sex practices, within the context of personal relationships. The study measured problem recognition, decision making, intention to reduce personal risk, service initiation, substance use, and sexual/STI health risk.

[/INST] The study is a phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial. The study will follow the Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies. The intervention consists in Remote Ischemic conditioning (RIC), one session of 40-minutes duration per day for 12 months. The primary endpoint in this study will be the worsening of disability, defined as an increase by 20% or more in the timed 25-foot walk (average of two trials) at 12 months follow-up compared to baseline.

[/INST] The study is titled "Prothrombin Time Predicts Steroid Response in Severe Alcoholic Hepatitis" and was conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study aimed to determine whether prothrombin time (PT) at diagnosis could predict response to standard medical treatment in patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis (SAH) admitted to the hospital. The study included 100 patients with a clinical diagnosis of SAH, who were eligible for corticosteroid treatment. The PT at diagnosis was measured and correlated with the Lille score at day 7 to assess response to standard medical treatment. The primary outcome measure was response to steroid treatment, and the secondary outcome measures were death, early liver transplantation, and infection. The study found that PT at diagnosis was not correlated with the Lille score at day 7, indicating that it was not a reliable predictor of response to standard medical treatment. The study also found that PT at diagnosis was not associated with death, early liver transplantation, or infection. The study concluded that PT at diagnosis was not a reliable predictor of response to standard medical treatment in patients with SAH.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of functional task training versus functional therapy program on gross motor function, range of motion, and balance in children with cerebral palsy. The study will include 30 children with cerebral palsy who will be randomly assigned to either the functional task training group or the functional therapy program group. The functional task training group will receive a program that includes non-walking and walking activities, while the functional therapy program group will receive goal-directed training. The primary outcome measures are gross motor function, range of motion, and balance, which will be assessed using the gross motor function measure scale, goniometer, and pediatric balance scale, respectively. The study will last for 8 weeks, and the outcomes will be assessed at baseline and at the end of the intervention. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective observational study on tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair in National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita between Januari 2020 until December 2022. The preoperative demographic data included were patients' gender, age, weight, oxygen saturation, and associated diagnosis other than ToF. The preoperative data of complete blood count and differential count must be tested from the most recent peripheral blood samples taken no later than 14 days before the surgery. The data obtained were the number of days of the most recent blood test including the leukocyte count, percentage neutrophil, percentage and absolute lymphocyte count, thrombocyte count, as well as the derived variables such as neutrophil lymphocyte ratio (NLR) ratio and thrombocyte lymphocyte ratio (TLR). The intraoperative data included were the use of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), CPB time, aortic cross-clamp (AOX) time, and the total duration of surgery. Patients were evaluated and followed-up for any complications and postoperative mortality during the same hospital stay until discharge. Patients were then followed up for any cause of mortality within 30 days postoperative.

[/INST] This study is a pilot randomized double-blind clinical trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of patient-applied aqueous lidocaine via tampon as a pre-treatment prior to intra-uterine device placement. Subjects will apply the lidocaine or a saline placebo to the end of a standard tampon with a plastic applicator and then place the tampon 1 hour prior to the procedure. The tampon will be removed as the subject prepares for the procedure. The procedure team will measure the procedure time as well as the subject and provider impressions of the procedure. This data will be evaluated to compare the lidocaine to the control group.

[/INST] The study is a low-risk, single-center, interventional study that assesses the feasibility and acceptability of capillary screening for early staging of the most prevalent chronic metabolic, cardiovascular, and autoimmune diseases at a population level. The study will enroll volunteers from Cantalupo, a locality of 3095 inhabitants belonging to the Municipality of Cerro Maggiore (Milan). The main purpose is to assess feasibility and acceptability of using this public intervention. Secondary outcomes are: (i) measurement of the specific disease markers; (ii) estimation of the prevalence of the identified diseases within the population; (iii) estimation of the prevalence of the identified diseases across age classes; (iv) correlation of study disease indicators with demographics, anthropometrics, and clinical data of the population; (v) multiparametric risk assessment. Participants will be offered to undergo a capillary blood sampling to test blood glucose levels, glycated haemoglobin, total cholesterol, HDL-c, LDL-c, triglycerides, Glutamic Acid Decarboxylase (GADA), Insulinoma-Associated-2/Tyrosine Phosphatase (IA-2A), Insulin (IAA), Zinc Transporter-8 Autoantibodies (ZnT8A) for type I diabetes and tissue transglutaminase antibodies for celiac disease. Glucose and lipid blood levels will be detected at the time of the screening. The results of autoantibodies research for celiac disease and type 1 diabetes will be available within a few days. In case a participant screens positive for type I diabetes and/or celiac disease, they will be subsequently invited to undergo a new confirmatory blood draw on venous blood. Blood pressure will be also measured for each participant.

[/INST] The study is titled "SMaRT Mom - Smartphone Management and Responsive Time for Breastfeeding Mothers - An Intervention Study". The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a smartphone intervention in reducing smartphone use during breastfeeding and improving breastfeeding outcomes. The intervention is based on behavioral change techniques and will be delivered through a smartphone app. The study will recruit breastfeeding mothers who report smartphone addiction and will compare the effectiveness of the intervention to a control group. The primary outcome measure is breastfeeding duration, and the secondary outcome measures include breastfeeding frequency, duration of each breastfeeding session, and infant temperament. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including surveys, interviews, and physiological measures to assess the effectiveness of the intervention. The study will be conducted in two phases: a pilot study and a larger randomized controlled trial. The pilot study will test the feasibility of the intervention and the larger randomized controlled trial will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention. The study will be conducted in the United States and will involve a collaboration between researchers at the University of California, Irvine, and the Centre Hospitalier Val-de-Brèlis in Switzerland. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a single-blind randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) for plantar fasciitis. The study will compare the effectiveness of PBMT to usual care with sham PBMT. The study will use a parallel-group design and will randomize participants to one of two groups: the active treatment group or the sham treatment group. The active treatment group will receive PBMT three times a week for three weeks, while the sham treatment group will receive sham PBMT three times a week for three weeks. The study will use a block randomization method to allocate participants to the treatment groups. The study will use a double-blind design, where both the participants and the researchers will be blinded to the treatment allocation until the end of the study. The study will use a self-reported questionnaire to assess the effectiveness of the treatment, as well as ultrasound imaging to measure the thickness of the plantar fascia. The study will also collect demographic and clinical data from the participants. The study will use intention-to-treat analysis to analyze the data.

[/INST] The study is a single-center, open-label, randomized, single-dose, completely randomized, crossover bioequivalence study to evaluate the effects of the test/reference preparation, Entacapone, Levodopa and Carbidopa Tablets (II) in the postprandial state in healthy Chinese subjects.

[/INST] The study is a single-center study that aims to fine-scale mapping of brain anatomy and function with simultaneous EEG-fMRI at 7 Tesla and structural MRI at 7 Tesla in healthy participants and patients with tremor, psychosis, and epilepsy. The study will use non-invasive techniques with no ionizing radiation and no injected contrasts. The study will measure the contrast-to-noise ratio between thalamic nuclei in 7T structural MRI, Pearson correlation between thalamocortical brain regions in 7T functional MRI, and microstate duration in EEG acquired concurrently with 7T functional MRI. The study will publish neuroimaging datasets in fully anonymized form in suitable public data repositories.

[/INST] The study is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of continuous non-invasive electrophysiological monitoring (eCTG) with conventional intermittent cardiotocography (CTG) in high-risk pregnancies. The study will include 1911 pregnant women aged 18 years or older with a singleton pregnancy between 23+0 and 32+0 weeks of gestation who require hospitalization on the obstetric high care (OHC) for maternal or fetal surveillance. The primary outcome measure is perinatal mortality and major neonatal morbidity. The secondary outcome measures include maternal mortality, neonatal morbidity, patient satisfaction, and caregiver satisfaction. The study will use a wireless abdominal electrode patch for measuring fetal heart rate (FHR) and uterine activity (UA) for eCTG monitoring and conventional CTG for the control group. The study will collect data on demographics, medical history, antenatal care, labor, delivery, and postpartum care. The data will be analyzed using descriptive statistics, logistic regression, and survival analysis. The study will be conducted in the Maxima Medical Center in Veldhoven, the Netherlands, and will run from January 2021 to December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a genetic study of rare and severe infections. The study will recruit patients with rare and severe infections and their relatives. The study will use whole genome genotyping and high-throughput sequencing to identify chromosomal regions associated with the disease and candidate genes for genetic susceptibility to infectious diseases. The study will also validate the pathogenic effect of the mutation by functional and complementation tests. The study will be conducted over a period of 10 years.

[/INST] The study aimed to investigate the prevalence, type, and risk factors of urinary incontinence (UI) in married women and its effect on their quality of life. The study included 200 married women who were over 18 years of age and had agreed to participate in the research. All participants were briefed about the research purpose and procedure. They were also informed about the following points: (1) participation is voluntary, (2) they can withdraw from the study at any stage without explanation, (3) the data will be used only for scientific purposes and will not be shared with third parties, and (4) they will remain anonymous throughout the research. Informed consent was obtained from those who agreed to participate. It took each participant 20-25 minutes to fill out the data collection tools. The study found that the prevalence of UI was 38.5% and the most common type of UI was stress urinary incontinence (SUI). The study also found that the most common risk factors for UI were age, obesity, and parity. The study concluded that UI is a common problem among married women and can have a significant impact on their quality of life. The study recommends that healthcare providers should screen for UI in married women and provide appropriate management to improve their quality of life.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of intra-articular injections of bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) and minimally manipulated adipose tissue (MM-AT) in patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis. The study will include 204 patients who will undergo infiltrative treatment after providing informed consent for study participation and master data. Patients will be clinically evaluated at 0-2-6-12 months follow-up. The study will investigate the disease-modifying effects of the two cell products, analyze peripheral blood at 0-2-6-12 months follow-up, and evaluate radiographic and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at 0 and 12 months follow-up. The study will also characterize the portion of BMAC and MM-AT remaining from treatment and analyze baseline assessment of peripheral blood on all patients, and synovial fluid and synovial membrane, where possible, to analyze their influence on clinical outcome.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III clinical study evaluating the efficacy and safety of cannabidiol (CBD) TPM capsules for use in insomnia. The study will enroll adults aged 18 years or older with insomnia who meet the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) criteria for insomnia disorder. Participants will be randomized to receive placebo or one of two doses of CBD TPM capsules (75 mg or 150 mg) for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measures are the change from baseline in the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) score and subject sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of CBD TPM capsules for use in insomnia.

[/INST] The study titled "Pattern of Intestinal Parasitic Infection Among Cirrhotic Patients in Sohag University Hospital" is a cross-sectional study conducted in Egypt. The study aims to determine the prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients and the difference between cirrhotic patients and non-cirrhotic patients with no comorbidity. The study will also identify the most common risk factors of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients. The study will enroll 200 patients, including 100 patients with liver cirrhosis and gastrointestinal tract (GIT) complaints and 100 patients with GIT complaints but not have any comorbidity. The study will use stool analysis to detect intestinal parasitic infection. The study will measure the pattern of intestinal parasitic infection among cirrhotic patients. The study will be conducted over a 12-month period.

[/INST] The REtinal Detachment Outcomes Study (REDOS) is a randomized controlled trial that compares the outcomes of two surgical procedures for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD): pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with scleral buckle (SB) and PPV with perfluoropropane gas tamponade (C3F8). The study aims to determine the anatomical and functional success rates of the two procedures and their associated complications. The study will follow up with patients for one year after surgery.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the differential effects of 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine on the onset time and duration of ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in patients having forefoot surgery for anesthesia and postoperative analgesia. The primary outcome is the difference in the duration of the sensory blocks. The secondary outcomes are the difference in onset time of the sensory block, the postoperative pain scores, and the opioid consumption.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of compression stockings on the complaints, well-being, and sleep quality of pregnant women with restless legs syndrome (RLS). The study will include 100 pregnant women with RLS between the ages of 18 and 40 who are in their 27th gestational week and above. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the compression stocking group or the placebo sock group. The compression stocking group will wear compression stockings for three weeks, while the placebo sock group will wear placebo socks for three weeks. The primary outcome measure is the RLS Severity Rating Scale, which will be assessed at the end of the three-week period. The secondary outcome measure is the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, which will be assessed at the end of the three-week period. The study will be conducted in Iran and is expected to last for one year.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a home-based exercise program for improving physical function in older adults. The program consists of two types of exercises: "exercise snacking" and Tai-chi snacking. The study will assess the effects of the program on physical function, strength, balance, agility, flexibility, quality of life, and mental health. The study will also examine the acceptability and feasibility of the program.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the efficacy of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia with ropivacaine with or without dexamethasone in patients undergoing lumbosacral spine surgeries. The study will be conducted in a single center and will include 60 patients who will be randomized into two groups. The primary outcome measure is the VAS score at immediate postoperative period, 4, 8, 12 and 24 hours. The secondary outcome measure is the time to demand of first dose of supplemental (rescue) analgesic medication. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the study protocol has been approved by the institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a randomised controlled experimental study to determine the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on comfort, care satisfaction and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The study is designed as a single-blind randomised controlled trial. The experimental group will receive care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory and comfort behaviour checklist during their stay in the ICU. The control group will receive standard care. The primary outcome measure is the General Comfort Scale, the Comfort Behaviours Checklist and the Richard Campbell Sleep Scale. The study will be conducted in the intensive care unit of a hospital in Turkey. The study will be conducted with 80 participants, 40 in the intervention group and 40 in the control group. The study will be conducted for 24 hours. The study will be conducted in the intensive care unit of a hospital in Turkey. The study will be conducted with 80 participants, 40 in the intervention group and 40 in the control group. The study will be conducted for 24 hours.

[/INST] The P-KIDs CARE Health Systems Intervention in Tanzania is a study that aims to develop and pilot a health systems intervention to improve the care of injured children in Tanzania. The study will use a mixed methods approach, including formative research, intervention development, and a pilot intervention. The study will use a pre-post design to evaluate the impact of the intervention on mortality, time to definitive care, disposition, and morbidity. The study will be conducted in two health facilities in Tanzania and will include a pediatric injury registry, surveys, and interviews. The study will use the World Health Organization Basic Emergency Care Course and a decision support tool to improve the care of injured children. The study will also use a community-engaged panel to provide feedback on the intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of four years.

[/INST] The study is a preliminary study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education in women with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. The study will compare the effectiveness of this approach with pelvic floor rehabilitation and spinal mobilization. The study will use the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) and the Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) to measure the frequency, severity, and impact on quality of life of urinary incontinence and pain, respectively. The Modified Oxford Scale (MOS) will be used to measure the strength of the pelvic floor muscles. The study will be conducted over a period of 5 weeks, with 10 sessions of treatment and 30 days after the end of the training.

[/INST] The study is titled "Development of a Pharmacodynamic Model for Propofol in Older Adults" and is a single-group assignment study. The study is designed to create a pharmacokinetic-pharmacodynamic (PKPD) model for the administration of intravenous propofol in a population of older adults aged 65 and older. The model will use the pharmacokinetic parameters of the Eleveld model and new pharmacodynamic parameters derived from the frontal EEG in a population of older adults. The study will compare two models: BIS (Eleveld Validation) and EEG Frontal Marker (New model). The primary outcome measure is the difference between the measured (according to Eleveld) and predicted concentrations, divided by the predicted concentration. The secondary outcome measures are the median absolute performance error (MDAPE), median prediction error (MDPE), time of loss of response (LOR), time of burst-suppression (BS), and time of return of response (ROR). The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing two different antibiotic regimens for the treatment of acute cholangitis. The primary outcome is the clinical cure rate by day 14 after ERCP without relapse by day 30. The secondary outcomes include all-cause 90-day mortality, relapse of cholangitis within 90 days, rate of any other subsequent infection requiring antibiotic therapy within 90 days, rate of subsequent infections with MDR bacteria or Clostridioides difficile within 90 days, rate of other adverse drug events within 14 days, length of intensive care and hospital stay for the initial episode of cholangitis, quality of life and health utility, and societal costs and cost-effectiveness/-utility.

[/INST] The study is a prospective randomized clinical trial that will be conducted at the Anesthesiology Department in Tanta University Hospitals. The study will involve 60 morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the conventional group or the ultrasound-guided group. In the conventional group, the recruitment maneuver will be performed by manual inflation with a pressure of 30 cmH2O for 30 seconds. In the ultrasound-guided group, the recruitment maneuver will be performed under the direct real-time guidance of ultrasound if atelectasis is present. The primary outcome measure is the change in the lung ultrasound score, and the secondary outcome measures are the incidence of atelectasis and intra-operative desaturation. The study will be conducted over one year from August 2023 to August 2024.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to optimize the fractionation schedule of low-dose external beam radiotherapy (LD-EBRT) for the treatment of heel spurs. The study will compare the effectiveness of a single fraction of LD-EBRT with a standard fractionation schedule of 6 Gy in 4 fractions. The primary outcome measure is pain relief at 3 months after radiotherapy, as assessed by the Calcaneodynia score. The study will also evaluate the quality of life and VAS score at 1.5, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after radiotherapy, as well as the need for reirradiation.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effectiveness of a behavioral weight reduction program combined with pain neuroscience education and cognition-targeted exercise therapy for people with CLBP and overweight or obesity. The study will compare this intervention to a control intervention consisting of pain neuroscience education and cognition-targeted exercise therapy alone. The study will use a 18-session treatment program over a 14-week period. The primary outcome measure will be pain intensity, and the secondary outcome measures will include pain interference, pain distribution and pain beliefs, body weight and composition, muscle thickness and fat distribution, energy balance-related behavior, sleep quality, dietary intake, and health economics. The study will be conducted in Belgium and Switzerland.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the clinical outcomes and efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy in gastric per-oral endoscopic myotomy (G-POEM) for refractory and severe gastroparesis. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study will enroll 100 participants who will be randomized to either the single or double pyloromyotomy group. The primary outcome measure is clinical success at 3, 6, and 12 months follow-up. The secondary outcome measures are technical success rate, total procedure time for each method, adverse events like pneumoperitoneum, gi bleeding, perforation, infection, and abdominal pain, and recurrence of symptoms at 3, 6, and 12 months follow-up. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The Efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink With SOD on Female Nutritional Anemia, Skin Condition and Qi-blood Deficiency Syndrome is a single-arm, open-label study that aims to evaluate the efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink With SOD on female nutritional anemia, skin condition, and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome. The study will recruit 30 female participants aged 18 to 35 who have a hemoglobin concentration level below 110g/L based on WHO diagnostic criteria for anemia. The participants will be required to refrain from taking any drugs, supplements, or other dairy products during the trial and will be asked to drink one piece of the products each day, for 4 consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change of serum ferritin level in blood, ng/mL. The secondary outcome measures are the change of hemoglobin concentration level in blood, g/L, the change of Superoxide dismutase (SOD) concentration in blood, U/ml, the change of Glutathione (GSH) concentration level in blood, mg/L, and the change of lines/wrinkles on the face by Miravex Antera 3D imaging system. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH) on respiratory and upper extremity muscle function in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (cSCI). The study will compare the effects of AIH alone, AIH with transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS), and SHAM AIH with tSCS. The study will use a crossover design, with each participant serving as their own control. The study will measure respiratory and upper extremity muscle function using a variety of methods, including transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), cervical magnetic stimulation (CMS), forced vital capacity (FVC), and the GRASSP test. The study will also measure cardiovascular response using oxyhemoglobin saturation (SpO2), heart rate (HR), and blood pressure (BP). The study will use a single-blinded design, with the participants being blinded to the intervention. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Val-de-Travers in Switzerland. The study will enroll 20 participants with cSCI, with the inclusion criteria being age between 18 and 65 years, cSCI of at least 12 months duration, and the ability to provide informed consent. The study will exclude participants with unstable cardiopulmonary disease or cardiac symptoms, uncontrolled orthostatic hypotension, severe musculoskeletal injuries, and pregnancy. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the local ethics committee. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of two anesthetic maintenance agents (propofol and sevoflurane) and two vasopressors (phenylephrine and ephedrine) on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism in adult patients undergoing surgery. The study will use a 2x2 factorial design, with each patient receiving one of the four possible combinations of anesthetic maintenance agent and vasopressor. The primary outcome measure is cerebral oxygen consumption (CMRO2), which will be measured using a cerebral oximeter. The study will also measure other cerebral hemodynamic parameters, including cerebral blood flow (CBF) and oxygen saturation (ScO2). The study will be conducted in a single center and will use a block randomization method. The study will be blinded to both patients and investigators. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee. The study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal and will be presented at relevant scientific conferences.

[/INST] The RaDiCo-IDMet study is a national cohort study that aims to collect data on patients with imprinting disorders (IDs) and their metabolic consequences. The study will collect data on the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of patients with IDs, as well as their metabolic phenotype and the prevalence of metabolic abnormalities. The study will also analyze the risk for metabolic complications such as obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease, and the effects of different therapeutic approaches on quality of life. The study will also analyze (epi)genetic mutations transmission in proband and relatives. The study will be conducted over a period of 10 years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of unipolar and bipolar interlocking nails in the treatment of humeral shaft fractures in adults. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of humeral shaft fracture requiring surgical treatment with intramedullary nailing. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months. The study includes patients with a pathologic fracture, post-traumatic brachial plexus injury, or acute or chronic, unstable or poorly controlled disease that may interfere with the evaluation of the study objective. The study includes patients with pregnancy, parturition, or breastfeeding. The study includes patients admitted for revision surgery of a humerus fracture (insufficient healing or complication). [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive training and a mobile app called Personalized Real-time Intervention for Motivational Enhancement (PRIME) in improving cognitive and motivational functioning in individuals with early psychosis. The study will recruit 200 participants aged 18-40 years who have been diagnosed with schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, bipolar disorder, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the treatment group or the control group. The treatment group will receive 20 hours of cognitive training and use the PRIME app for 12 weeks, while the control group will receive treatment as usual. The primary outcome measure will be cognitive function, which will be assessed using the Test My Brain cognitive assessment tool. Secondary outcome measures will include motivation, quality of life, and other measures. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis. The study will be conducted in the United States and will involve multiple sites. The study will have a follow-up period of 18 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of using wearable fitness trackers and eHealth technologies in prehabilitation programs for patients with oesophago-gastric, hepatobiliary, and lung cancer. The study will also assess the effectiveness of using wearable fitness trackers and eHealth technologies in improving physical activity levels, exercise adherence, and patient outcomes. The study will use a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods to collect data from patients and healthcare professionals. The study will also use a mixed-methods approach to analyse the data. The study will be conducted in the United Kingdom and will involve collaboration between multiple hospitals and research institutions. The study will be overseen by an independent data monitoring committee and will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing two minimally invasive treatments for pilonidal disease: pit-picking surgery and pit-picking surgery with sinus laser-assisted closure. [/INST] The study aims to identify sociodemographic, personal characteristics, as well as patterns of illicit drug abuse in patients admitted for addiction treatment. The study will be conducted in the Addiction Management Unit of Assiut University Hospital in Egypt. The study will use a cross-sectional design and will include 160 patients who are admitted to the Addiction Management Unit. The patients will be assessed using a survey that includes questions about their sociodemographic characteristics, previous admissions/trials for detox, medical, psychological, social, financial, and legal aspects of addiction, and adverse life events dating before starting addiction. The study will also use the Symptom Checklist-90-Revised (SCL-90-R), the Five-Factor Model of Personality, the Severity of Dependence Scale (SDS), and the Urine Drug Screen to assess personality traits, patterns of substance abuse, and substance use. The study will provide valuable information about the sociodemographic, personal characteristics, and patterns of illicit drug abuse in patients admitted for addiction treatment. This information can be used to develop more effective treatment programs and policies for substance use disorders.

[/INST] The study is a multi-center clinical trial that aims to establish normal reference values for the structure and blood flow of the extremities of Chinese Han adults using high-frequency ultrasound. The study will recruit healthy volunteers aged 18-79 years who meet the inclusion criteria and do not meet the exclusion criteria. The volunteers will undergo a high-frequency ultrasound examination of the extremity arteries, and the parameters of arterial structure and blood flow will be measured. The primary outcome measure is the intima thickness of the dorsalis pedis artery and the proper palmar digital artery, and the secondary outcome measure is the blood flow velocity of the dorsalis pedis artery and the proper palmar digital artery. The study will establish normal reference values for the structure and blood flow of the extremities of Chinese Han adults, which will be used as a new tool for the early diagnosis and evaluation of arterial diseases.

[/INST] The study is a split-mouth study. The secondary outcome measures are gingival recession, clinical attachment level, plaque index, bleeding index, and furcations. [/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, single-center pilot/exploratory trial. The study is designed to evaluate the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea among renal transplant recipients. The study will enroll patients who have received living or deceased donor kidney and have been on adjusted and/or maintenance dose of calcineurin inhibitors, antimetabolites, and steroid regimen. The study will collect data on the reduction in immunosuppressive drugs-associated diarrhea, analysis of inflammatory biomarkers, and association between inflammatory markers and fecal microbiome. The study will use a Gastrointestinal (GI) questionnaire and Bristol Stool Chart to measure the reduction in immunosuppressive drugs-associated diarrhea. Inflammatory biomarkers including TNF (tumor necrosis factor) superfamily proteins, IFN (interferon) family proteins, Treg cytokines and matrix metalloproteinases (MMP) will be analyzed through Bio-Rad's Multiplex System. Fecal microbial DNA will be analyzed through 16S PCR followed by Next-Gen sequencing. Pearson correlation analysis will be performed.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the outcomes of different treatment modalities for massive rotator cuff tears. The study will include patients aged between 50 to 80 years with massive rotator cuff tendon tears defined as grade III according to Davidson and Burkhart classification. The study will compare the outcomes of arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair with superior capsular augmentation with LHBBT, arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair, and arthroscopic complete rotator cuff repair. The primary outcome measures are change in shoulder strength, range of motion, and functional outcome according to the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) score. The secondary outcome measures are functional outcome according to the Constant-Murley score (CMS), Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH), pain score, integrity of surgically repaired rotator cuff tendons on MRI studies, and change in quality of life and kinesiophobia score. The study will be conducted in Tartu University Hospital Sports Traumatology Centre and rotator cuff repair procedures will be done by three orthopaedic surgeons with long experience in arthroscopic shoulder surgery. [/INST] The Injection-Related InfectionS (IRIS) Program is a novel pathway to optimize treatment of injection-related infections for people who inject drugs (PWID) in Hamilton, Ontario. The program provides a one-stop, low-barrier, combined care model to address injection-related infections, including diagnosis and treatment of infections, substance use treatment, peer support, and care coordination/systems navigation. The program aims to reduce emergency department visits and hospital readmissions within 30 days of initial hospital admission or program enrolment. The program also aims to increase the completion of intended course of treatment for injection-related infections, reduce hospital readmissions specifically for the infection that was the primary reason for program enrolment, reduce emergency department visits, increase the number of new initiations or record of continuation of substance use treatment, and reduce mortality rates within 6 months of hospital discharge or program enrolment. The program also aims to reduce the number of program drop-outs and reasons for discontinuation within 6 months of hospital discharge or program enrolment.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the use of a mobile app for surveillance of adverse events following influenza immunization to a web-based platform. Participants were randomized to the mobile app arm or the web-based notification arm. Participants in the mobile app arm received an email asking them to download the app and activate their account. Participants in the web-based notification arm received an email notifying them of their registration in the study. Eight days following their influenza vaccine, participants in both arms received an email with the survey link asking them to complete their online influenza vaccine safety survey. Participants in both arms received a reminder email on day 11 if they did not complete their survey. Following completion of the safety survey, all participants were sent a separate link by email to complete a user experience survey.

[/INST] Peri-implantitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting implant-surrounding tissues. It is characterized by progressive loss of supporting bone and is a major reason for implant failure. The etiology of peri-implantitis is multifactorial and includes both host and microbial factors. The host factors include smoking, diabetes, and stress, while the microbial factors include biofilm formation and accumulation of pathogenic bacteria. The diagnosis of peri-implantitis is based on clinical and radiographic criteria. The treatment of peri-implantitis involves mechanical debridement, antibiotic therapy, and surgical intervention. The prognosis of peri-implantitis is generally favorable, with a success rate of 80-90%. However, the long-term success of peri-implantitis treatment is still uncertain.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study that aims to investigate the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy in patients with achalasia. The study will compare the wobble of systolic arterial pressure (SAP) during surgery between patients with autonomic dysfunction and those without. The wobble of SAP will be calculated using the median absolute performance error (MDAPE) and the median {|MDPE - PEi|, i = 1, 2, 3…, N} (N, number of measured SAP). The reference SAP will be 120 mmHg. The study will be conducted in Gangnam Severance Hospital, and the study population will consist of patients with achalasia who are scheduled to undergo per-oral endoscopic myotomy. The study will exclude patients who are hemodynamically unstable before surgery, those in whom preoperative heart rate variability (HRV) test cannot be conducted, pregnant women or breastfeeding women, and those unable to read the informed consent form. [/INST] The study was designed to evaluate the use of virtual reality glasses during inhaler treatment in children. Children were divided into three groups: those who used virtual reality glasses with roller coaster images (group 1), those who used virtual reality glasses with wild dolphin images (group 2), and those who did not use any additional equipment (group 3). The children were observed during their 15-minute inhaler treatment and the groups were compared in terms of crying times, changes in RR, SpO2, HR values with pre- and post-treatment physician questionnaires and family questionnaires. [/INST] The PALISA Study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of skin conductance measurement and video recording during less-invasive surfactant administration (LISA) on pain assessment in preterm infants. The study will be conducted in a neonatal intensive care unit in Germany. The study will include 20 preterm infants who will undergo LISA. The infants will be divided into two groups: the intervention group will receive skin conductance measurement and video recording during LISA, while the control group will not receive these interventions. The primary outcome measure will be the median peaks per second at prespecified time-points, adjusted for median peaks per second at baseline. The secondary outcome measures will be the absolute number of apneas, desaturations, bradycardia, arterial hypotension, and blunt surfactant reflux, as well as the difference in maximum and median peaks per second before and after apnea, desaturation, bradycardia, arterial hypotension, and blunt surfactant reflux. The study will also assess the difference in heart rate, oxygen saturation, and SpO2/FiO2-ratio between baseline and prespecified time-points. The study will also evaluate the difference of SpO2/FiO2-ratio compared to skin conductance peaks per second. The study will also assess the incidence of LISA failure, intubation, air-leaks, and intraventricular hemorrhage. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study has been approved by the local ethics committee.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of high-flow oxygen preoxygenation using a nasal cannula (HFNO) and face mask (FM) on oxygen saturation and heart rate during rapid sequence induction in infants and children. The study will randomize patients into three groups: HFNO, FM, and HFNO + FM. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of desaturation (SpO2 < 90%) and the incidence of manual ventilation during rapid sequence induction. The secondary outcome measures are the incidence of desaturation (SpO2 < 80%), time to desaturation (SpO2 < 90% and < 80%), time to reach 100% oxygen saturation, time to intubation, time to relaxation, and the number of intubation attempts. The study will be conducted in a tertiary care center in Switzerland. The study will enroll 120 patients and the follow-up period will be intraoperative. The study will compare the efficacy and safety of HFNO and FM preoxygenation during rapid sequence induction in infants and children.
