[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to examine the predictors of health and fitness app engagement and subscription rates. The study will use data from WayBetter Inc.'s app, which is a wellness lifestyle mHealth app that allows users to improve their overall well-being. The study will examine the primary outcomes of six-month subscription rates and subscription renewal rates at six months. The secondary outcomes are app engagement metrics, including the number of app opens per week, date of joining first game, game adherence, number of games started and won each week, non-usage attrition, and re-engagement. The study will use a variety of statistical methods to analyze the data, including linear regression, Cox proportional hazards regression, and latent class analysis. The study will use data from approximately 400 new users who have entered into a seven-day free trial. The study will be conducted over a 24-week period.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effects of aerobic exercises and pilates exercises on depression and sleep quality in primigravida females. The study will be conducted in children hospital sheikhupura and Mehmooda hospital sheikhupura. The study will be completed in time duration of ten months after the approval of synopsis and convenient sampling technique will be used. Total 42 subjects will be assigned randomly by using lottery method into two groups. Group A will receive Aerobic exercises and Group B will receive Pilate exercises. Warm up (walking) and cool down period of ten minutes will be performed by both groups. Data will be collected from all participants at baseline and after 8 weeks of treatment by using CES-D and PSQI questionnaire. After assessing the data will be analyzed by using parametric or non-parametric test by using SPSS-25.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the effect of swaddling and inhaling breast milk odour on the pain and comfort during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter in term infants. The study was conducted in a neonatal intensive care unit in a hospital in Turkey. The study population consisted of term infants who were hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit. The infants were randomly assigned to four groups: swaddling, inhaling breast milk odour, swaddling and inhaling breast milk odour, and control. The pain and comfort levels of the infants were assessed before, during, and after the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter using the Infant Descriptive Information Form, Neonatal Infant Pain Scale, and Neonatal Comfort Behaviour Scale. The results of the study showed that swaddling and inhaling breast milk odour had a positive effect on the pain and comfort of the infants during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter.

[/INST] The study is titled "Research on the Biological Mechanism of the Efficacy of Psychotherapy for Depression Based on the Near-Infrared Functional Imaging System (fNIRS)" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to investigate the efficacy of psychotherapy for depression using fNIRS. The study will compare the effects of medication therapy, IPT, and the combination of medication therapy and IPT on patients with depression. The study will use fNIRS to measure changes in brain function and will also use standardized psychological assessments to evaluate the efficacy of the treatments. The study will be conducted in China and will include 120 participants. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks and will involve monthly assessments. The study will provide valuable insights into the efficacy of psychotherapy for depression and the potential use of fNIRS as a tool for monitoring treatment progress.

[/INST] The study is titled "Evaluating 111In Panitumumab for Nodal Staging in Head and Neck Cancer". The study is a phase I/II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of 111In-panitumumab as a molecular imaging agent for nodal staging in head and neck cancer. The study will enroll patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma or recurrent head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. Patients will receive a loading dose of panitumumab followed by a single dose of 111In-panitumumab. Patients will undergo SPECT/CT scans between day 1 and day of surgery. During surgery, patients will undergo intraoperative and near-infrared imaging. The primary objective of the study is to assess the safety of 111In-panitumumab. The secondary objective is to compare the sensitivity and specificity of identifying sentinel lymph nodes by systemic injection of 111In-panitumumab prior to day of surgery versus conventional local injection with an optical dye at the time of surgery. The study will also evaluate the sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value of 111In-panitumumab SPECT/CT findings to the sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value of preoperative MRI or 18F-FDG PET/CT in identifying metastatic lymph nodes.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and mechanism of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation (tVNS) in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). The study will compare the effects of tVNS combined with medication to sham stimulation combined with medication. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAMA) score at the second week of treatment. The secondary outcome measures include changes in the Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD) score, Generalized Anxiety Scale (GAD-7) score, and brain function indicators. The study will also evaluate the incidence of adverse events.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective analysis of 100 patients who underwent dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation (DLDI) for nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). The study aimed to identify factors associated with DLDI failure. The study found that the success rate of DLDI was higher in patients with lower NLDO compared to those with higher NLDO. The study also found that the success rate of DLDI was higher in patients with stenosis compared to those with obstruction. The study concluded that the success rate of DLDI was higher in patients with stenosis compared to those with obstruction.

[/INST] The study aimed to investigate the immediate effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) with lower leg kinesiotaping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke. The study was a randomized controlled trial with three groups: lower leg kinesiotaping, PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping, and control. The study included 18 patients with chronic stroke who were randomly assigned to one of the three groups. The intervention was performed for 30 minutes, and the outcomes were measured immediately after the intervention. The results showed that PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping significantly improved ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

[/INST] The study is a mixed, non-randomized, quasi-experimental, before-and-after, open, cross-sectional study with a control and experimental group. The study will be conducted in three phases. Phase 1 will be an observational phase, phase 2 will be an interventional phase with the implementation of the A-DIVA scale, and phase 3 will be an interventional phase with the implementation of the algorithm composed of the A-DIVA scale and the new decision-making tree (the A-DIVA Tool). The primary outcome measure is the number of venipunctures performed per patient after implementation of the algorithm. The secondary outcome measures are the number of participants who approve the co-constructed algorithm, acceptability and feasibility of using the VAD score in isolation and the score in conjunction with the catheter placement algorithm, patient pain score measured immediately after vascular puncture, number of venipunctures performed per patient after implementation of the VAD score, insertion technique used for catheter placement, number of operators required for catheter insertion, frequency of second-line referral to another practitioner, puncture result: success/failure, care strategies implemented in the event of difficulties encountered when inserting peripheral venous lines, and frequency of use of the A-DIVA scale.

[/INST] The study is titled "Evaluation of STARgraft-3 for Hemodialysis" and is a single-arm, open-label study. The study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the STARgraft-3 device as a hemodialysis access. The study will enroll patients with end-stage renal disease who are in need of hemodialysis access. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of subjects without an occurrence of either an access thrombosis or an access procedure performed to maintain patency at 6 months post-implantation. The secondary outcome measures include the percentage of subjects retaining patency after one or more interventions so long as patency was not lost at any point, the percentage of subjects without loss of access at the original implant site, the frequency of interventions related to graft placement and use for dialysis access, ultrasound measurements of flow rates to detect patency trends with time after implantation, and the frequency and severity of adverse events resulting from graft implantation and use for hemodialysis access. The study will enroll patients with end-stage renal disease who are in need of hemodialysis access. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of the STARgraft-3 device as a hemodialysis access.

[/INST] Primary Care Online Emotion-regulation Treatment (POET) is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a digital emotion regulation treatment for adolescents with mental health problems. The treatment will be compared to a supportive treatment. The study will assess the effects of POET on mental health problems, emotion regulation, and other outcomes. The study will also examine the cost-effectiveness of POET.

[/INST] The trial is a phase III, multicenter, randomized, open-labeled, comparative study. The study will compare the efficacy of two modalities of radiotherapy over surgery alone on local tumor control in older patients with non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in terms of local recurrence, progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS). The study will also evaluate the quality of life (QoL) and treatment burden of the patients. The study will include patients aged 70 years or older with a performance status of 0-3 who have completed surgery (R0) for SCC or BCC with at least one unfavorable prognostic factor. The patients will be randomized to one of three arms: surgery alone, surgery followed by moderate hypofractionation radiotherapy (15 fractions), or surgery followed by extreme hypofractionation radiotherapy (5 fractions). The primary endpoint of the study is local tumor control at 3-year follow-up in a time-to-event analysis. The secondary endpoints are QoL and treatment burden. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study protocol has been approved by the ethics committee of the participating centers.

[/INST] The Surveillance Colonoscopy in Older Adults: The SurvOlderAdults Study is a retrospective cohort study that aims to compare the cumulative risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) in older adults with prior polypectomy vs. normal colonoscopy. The study will use qualitative methods to understand the perspectives of patients and providers on CRC risk and surveillance. The study will use a mixed-methods approach to address the aims of the study.

[/INST] The study aims to assess the effect of early bedside cycling exercises on selected physical and psychological outcomes in patients after heart valve surgery. The study will be conducted on 50 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (25 patients) or the control group (25 patients). The intervention group will receive bedside cycling in addition to the medical treatment and physiotherapy protocol, while the control group will receive only routine physiotherapy treatment protocol and the medical treatment. The bedside cycling will be introduced and conducted in the intervention group from being extubated and being relatively stable until discharge from the hospital. The intensity of the exercise will be rated on the Rating of Perceived Exertion scale (RPE) from 11 to 13 (scale 6-20). The primary outcome measures are functional capacity, measured by Six Minutes Walk Test, Forced Vital Capacity, measured by Spirometry Pulmonary function test, and psychological status, measured by Depression Anxiety Stress Scales 42. The secondary outcome measures are functional capacity, measured by Six Minutes Walk Test, psychological status, measured by Depression Anxiety Stress Scales 42, the Quality of Life, measured by Short Form-12 Health Questionnaire, and the incidence of adverse events. The study will be conducted for two weeks from the date of patient admission to the hospital until the date of the surgical operation, an average of 2 weeks. The study will be conducted for two weeks from the date of patient admission to the hospital until the date of the surgical operation, an average of 2 weeks. The study will be conducted for one month from the date of patient discharge, an average of 2 weeks. The study will be conducted for one month from the date of patient discharge, an average of 2 weeks.

[/INST] The Molecular Analysis of the Sloane Project is a study that aims to analyze the molecular characteristics of screen-detected non-invasive breast cancer and atypical breast hyperplasias identified by the Sloane Project. The study will include patients with DCIS, LCIS, atypical ductal hyperplasia, and atypical lobular hyperplasia. The primary outcome measure is the progression of breast disease from diagnosis to the end of 2016. The study will analyze the molecular characteristics of the breast cancer and hyperplasia using genomic sequencing and other molecular techniques. The study will also analyze the relationship between the molecular characteristics and the progression of breast disease.

[/INST] Tirzepatide for the Concurrent Treatment of Obesity and Type 1 Diabetes is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of tirzepatide in patients with type 1 diabetes and obesity. The study will assess the effects of tirzepatide on body weight, glycemic control, and other metabolic parameters. The study will also evaluate the safety of tirzepatide in this population.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of losartan in the prevention of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy in breast cancer patients. The study will enroll female patients aged 18 years or older who are diagnosed with biopsy-confirmed breast cancer and are scheduled to receive paclitaxel 80 mg/m2. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy, and the secondary outcome measure is the grade of neuropathy according to the NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events. The study will use losartan 100 mg as the intervention and will assess the patient's quality of life using the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy/Gynecologic Oncology Group - Neurotoxicity (FACT/GOG-NTX) and the level of nerve growth factor (NGF) in serum. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida and is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets in treating diabetes-related dementia. The study will enroll 370 participants with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment, who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will receive Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets combined with conventional hypoglycemic treatment, while the control group will receive conventional hypoglycemic treatment alone. The study will use the Montreal Cognitive Assessment Basic (MoCA-B) to detect cognitive dysfunction. Neuropsychological testing of cognitive function will be conducted using Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive Scale (ADAS-cog), Auditory Word Learning Test (AVLT-H);Assessment of Daily Living Ability - Functional Activity Questionnaire (FAQ);Shape Connection Test A and B and Symbolic Digital Form Test (SDMT). The study will also collect patients' blood to detect C-reactive protein, interleukin-6, oxidative stress, ApoE4 genotype, phosphorylated tau protein, irisin, β- Amyloid protein before and after the experiment. The study will also detect changes in ankle brachial pulse wave conduction velocity (baPWV)/and ankle brachial blood pressure index (ABI) of patients before and after the experiment.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy and safety of CsA+ATG+AVA and CsA+AVA for the treatment of newly diagnosed SAA in the elderly. The primary outcome measure is the overall response rate, which is defined as the proportion of patients who achieve a partial or complete response. The secondary outcome measures include complete response rate, relapse rate, and adverse event rate. The study will enroll patients aged 60 years or older with newly diagnosed SAA who are refractory to first-line therapy with CsA+ATG+EPAG or CsA+EPAG. Patients will be randomized to receive either CsA+ATG+AVA or CsA+AVA for 6 months. The study will assess the efficacy and safety of CsA+ATG+AVA and CsA+AVA for the treatment of SAA in the elderly.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT for the detection of indeterminate metastatic lesions in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). The study will compare the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT with standard of care imaging modalities, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), CT, and/or fludeoxyglucose F-18 (18F-FDG) PET/CT. [/INST] The study is a phase III, prospective, open-label, multicenter, randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the effect of prophylactic central neck dissection on the excellent response and recurrence-free survival of cN0 low-risk papillary thyroid cancer. The study will enroll patients aged 18-70 years with thyroid nodules measuring 11-40 mm on ultrasound and with FNAB cytology in favor of papillary thyroid carcinoma or with intraoperative frozen section analysis papillary thyroid carcinoma. Patients with a history of malignancy in other sites, tumors > 40 mm, metastatic neck lymph nodes or suspicious neck nodes on preoperative ultrasound, and pregnant or breast feeding women are excluded from the study. Patients will be randomly assigned to the test group or the control group. The test group will undergo prophylactic central neck dissection, while the control group will not undergo central neck dissection. The primary outcome measure is the excellent response, and the secondary outcome measure is recurrence-free survival. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a three-arm superiority, single blinded, cluster-randomized trial with a sample size of 50 children per cluster for 12 months. The study will also measure vector density and entomological inoculation rate. The study will use RDT to diagnose malaria cases and collect mosquitoes for entomological measurements. The study will use a cluster-randomized design with villages as the unit of randomization.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing the risk of root resorption during the correction of deep bite with the help of laser irradiation. The study will be conducted on adult patients with deep overbite who require intrusion movement of the upper anterior teeth using mini-implants. The study will compare the effect of LLLT on root resorption with the control group, which will not receive LLLT. The study will measure the change in root volume and length using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images. The study will be conducted in the Department of Orthodontics, Centre Hospitalier Valida, France. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the Institutional Review Board. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of LLLT in reducing the risk of root resorption during the correction of deep bite with the help of laser irradiation.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter Italian study that aims to evaluate the extent of lymphadenectomy performed during right hemicolectomy. The study will include 788 patients with colon cancer who will undergo right hemicolectomy. The extent of lymphadenectomy will be evaluated based on the number of lymph nodes removed and the number of positive lymph nodes. The study will also evaluate the vascular anatomy of the patients and how it affects the extent of lymphadenectomy. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of Cawthorne Cooksey exercises on balance in children with hearing deficits. The study will include 30 children aged 7 to 12 years with sensorineural hearing deficits (PTA >90db) and normal vision. The children will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (Cawthorne Cooksey exercises) or the control group (Swiss Ball exercises). The primary outcome measure is the Pediatric Berg Balance Scale, and the secondary outcome measure is the Four-step Square Test. The study will last for 12 weeks, and the children will be assessed before and after the intervention. The study will be conducted in Iran.

[/INST] The Psychological Impact of GTN on Women Who Have Completed Chemotherapy Treatment is a qualitative study that aims to explore the experiences of women with GTN following completion of chemotherapy. The study will use semi-structured telephone interviews to collect data and thematic analysis to analyze the data. The study will involve 20 women who have completed chemotherapy treatment for GTN within 6 weeks to 24 months prior to the study. The study will explore the psychological impact of GTN on women who have completed chemotherapy treatment, the support they received, and their suggestions for improving patient care. The study will provide valuable insights into the experiences of women with GTN following chemotherapy and inform the development of interventions to support these women.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the utility of bone grafts in open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation in patients with malunited distal radius fractures. The study will compare the outcomes of patients who undergo open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation with bone grafting from the iliac crest to those of patients who undergo open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation without bone grafting. The primary outcome measures are the number and severity of complications during and after the operation, quality of life using the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire, and time to complete bone healing. The secondary outcome measures are disability of the arm, shoulder, and hand questionnaire, patient-rated wrist evaluation questionnaire, active range of motion, and cost-effectiveness analysis. The study will have a follow-up period of at least one year.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms. The first arm is a brief behavioral teacher training with practice as usual. The second arm is practice as usual only. The primary outcome measure is the severity of four daily rated target behaviors in specific classroom situations. The secondary outcome measures are the severity of the same four daily rated target behaviors in other classroom situations than the specified situation which is used as primary outcome, teacher-reported number of child behavioral difficulties in the classroom which the teacher considers troublesome, teacher-reported child impairment at school associated with behavioral difficulties, teacher-reported quality of the teacher-student relationship, teachers' sense of self-efficacy, teacher-reported frequency of supportive and non-supportive management strategies, and caregiver-reported severity of child behavioral difficulties at home.

[/INST] The study is a mixed-methods pilot study that aims to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and usability of a tele-rehabilitation program combining immersive virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education for chronic non-specific neck pain. The program consists of five virtual reality sessions and one teleconsultation session with a physiotherapist over a six-week period. The primary outcome measures are feasibility (retention rate, adherence, safety), implementation at home, satisfaction with the tele-rehabilitation program, and usability of the virtual reality system and the online consultations. The secondary outcome measures are change in range of motion, neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, and global perceived effect. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Val-d'Amour in Saguenay, Quebec, Canada. The study will recruit 20 participants who will be randomly assigned to the experimental group (virtual reality and therapeutic education) or the control group (usual care). The study will use a mixed-methods design, including quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis. The quantitative data will be collected using questionnaires and scales, and the qualitative data will be collected through semi-structured interviews. The study will use a single-blinded randomized controlled trial design. The study will be conducted in French. The study protocol was approved by the Research Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Val-d'Amour in Saguenay, Quebec, Canada. The study is currently recruiting participants. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a non-inferiority randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of HABIT-ILE therapy at home with and without a follow-up after two weeks of therapy. The study will be conducted in children with bilateral cerebral palsy aged 6 to 18 years old. The primary outcome measure is the GMFM-66, which will be assessed at baseline, 2 weeks, and 12 weeks after baseline. The secondary outcome measures include the BOHA, BBT, 6MWT, ABILHAND-Kids questionnaires, PEDI questionnaire, ABILOCO-Kids questionnaire, JHFT, ESTIMILL-CP questionnaire, PILS-CP questionnaire, physical activity, COPM questionnaire, 3D T1-weighted structural imaging, DTI, RS-fMRI, and MD. The study will be conducted in the Rehabilitation Department of the Centre Hospitalier Valais in Sion, Switzerland. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the use of digital and speculum exams in patients with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM). The study aims to determine the effect of digital exams on pregnancy latency, maternal and neonatal outcomes, and patient satisfaction with the exams. The study will enroll patients between 22 weeks 0 days and 33 weeks 5 days gestation who are admitted to the hospital with PPROM and require a cervical examination. Patients will be randomized to receive either a digital or speculum examination. The primary outcome measure is pregnancy latency, and the secondary outcome measures include maternal and neonatal outcomes and patient satisfaction with the exams. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valadaire in France. The study is currently recruiting patients and is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is a single-center, prospective, single-arm study. The study is designed to evaluate the efficacy of sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) in the treatment of patients with liver cirrhosis with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The study will enroll patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC who meet the enrollment criteria and successfully match the donor liver. The SALT operation plan will be performed, which involves hemihepatectomy combined with left lateral lobe liver transplantation first, and residual liver resection will be performed after the graft grows to a sufficient functional liver volume. The primary outcome measure is overall survival (OS) in patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC treated with SALT. The secondary outcome measure is disease-free survival (DFS) of SALT in the treatment of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC. The study will evaluate the efficacy of SALT in the treatment of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC.

The study will assess the correlation between the dexterity assessment tool and the GRASSP-M tool in patients with DCM to determine concurrent validity. In Phase II, healthy participants will be recruited and their dexterity will be assessed using the dexterity assessment tool at two time points, one hour apart and one week apart. The study will use the dexterity assessment tool to measure finger dexterity in patients with DCM and healthy participants. The study will assess the correlation between the dexterity assessment tool and the GRASSP-M tool in patients with DCM to determine concurrent validity. The study will also assess the correlation between dexterity measurements in healthy participants using the dexterity assessment tool to determine inter-rater and test-retest reliability. The study will use the dexterity assessment tool to measure finger dexterity in patients with DCM and healthy participants. The study will assess the correlation between the dexterity assessment tool and the GRASSP-M tool in patients with DCM to determine concurrent validity. The study will also assess the correlation between dexterity measurements in healthy participants using the dexterity assessment tool to determine inter-rater and test-retest reliability.

[/INST] The study is a non-interventional, single center, observational study to evaluate the effect of intraocular lens (IOL) centration and tilt on visual performance in patients who have undergone Clareon® Vivity® IOL implantation. The study population will include individuals implanted with Clareon® Vivity® and Vivity® Toric IOLs. IOL implantations reviewed will range from the earliest performed (May 2022) onward, until 100 implanted patients (200 eyes) are reached. Potential subjects will be consented, then retrospective chart review of pre-operative and operative implantation data will occur and postoperative data will be collected (1 or more months post-operation) via examination.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, prospective, controlled study that aims to compare the efficacy of ultrasound-guided serratus posterior superior interfascial plane block (SPSIPB) for postoperative analgesia management after mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection surgery. The primary outcome measure is pain scores (NRS) at the postoperative 1st hour. The secondary outcome measures are the need for rescue analgesia, adverse events, and dermatomal coverage. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valadais in France. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study protocol has been approved by the local ethics committee.

[/INST] The study is an exploratory study that aims to conduct another imaging using contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) 4-6 hours after the routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml-enhanced ductography, so as to explore the optimization of the ductography technique and attempt to make a systematic description of the mammary duct structure in the Chinese population of patients with pathological nipple discharge, and thus to assess the clinical value of this delayed imaging protocol, including the effectiveness of the diagnostic dimension of the disease and the safety of the radiation dose and the degree of patient tolerance.

[/INST] The study is a prospective clinical study that aims to investigate the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in transplant patients. The study will include patients who have undergone heart transplantation and are aged 18 years or older. The study will follow the patients for four years and will measure blood lipid levels, graft/patient survival, left ventricular ejection fraction at rest, and other parameters. The study will use a combination of genetic and clinical data to investigate the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in transplant patients.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to compare the effectiveness of a pelvic floor muscle training device (Pelex Upp) with a combination of pelvic floor muscle training device and pelvic floor physical therapy in the treatment of stress urinary incontinence. The study will recruit women aged 18 years or older with symptoms of predominantly stress urinary incontinence. The study will use the ICIQ-UI SF questionnaire to assess the frequency, severity, and impact on quality of life of urinary incontinence symptoms before and after the intervention. The study will also use the UDI questionnaire to assess the impact of urinary incontinence on quality of life. The study will randomize participants into three arms: Pelex Upp only, Pelex Upp and pelvic floor physical therapy, and pelvic floor physical therapy only. Participants will use the device for ten minutes a day, four times a week, for four weeks. Participants in the Pelex Upp only and Pelex Upp and pelvic floor physical therapy arms will also receive educational materials on the use of the device. The study will assess the change in stress urinary incontinence symptoms after the intervention.

[/INST] The study is a 23 full factorial experiment to improve attendance in a multi-level manualized behavioral intervention to decrease alcohol and substance misuse frequency in a population of self-identified men and women with histories of substance use disorder and incarceration. The study will test if different intervention delivery strategies will result in a clinically and statistically important intervention attendance with a minimum of 50% of participants attending at least 50% of the intervention. The study will impact public health as it will improve the potency of an optimized multi-level intervention adaptable to address different health inequities.

[/INST] The study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the efficacy of two regional anesthesia techniques, interpectoral plane block + serratus anterior plane block (IPSA) and erector spinae block (ES), in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of these two methods, which are routinely used in thoracic surgery, in postoperative pain and recovery. The study will include 120 patients who will undergo minimally invasive cardiac surgery. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the IPSA or ES group. The primary outcome measure is pain scores (NRS) up to 48 hours after surgery. The secondary outcome measures are opioid consumption, recovery criteria, intraoperative parameters, and CPOT score until extubation. The study will be conducted at the Namık Kemal University Anesthesia Clinic. The study is expected to contribute to the literature by comparing the efficacy of two regional anesthesia techniques in minimally invasive cardiac surgery.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of Botox injection and internal sphincterotomy in pain relief after hemorrhoidectomy. The study will include patients aged between 18 and 70 years old with grade III and IV hemorrhoids who have failed conservative treatment. The study will have two groups: one group will receive Botox injection in the internal sphincter after hemorrhoidectomy, and the other group will receive hemorrhoidectomy alone. The primary outcome measure will be post-operative pain according to the visual analogue scale (VAS) score. The secondary outcome measure will be the time taken to return to daily activities in days. The study will be conducted in the Department of Surgery, Centre Hospitalier Valida, France.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as a maintenance treatment for advanced colorectal cancer patients who have achieved no evidence of disease (NED) after adjuvant chemotherapy. The study will enroll patients who have completed first-line chemotherapy and have achieved NED, and they will receive fruquintinib maintenance treatment for six months or until tumor recurrence, metastasis, or intolerable drug toxicities occur within six months. The primary outcome measure is the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate, and the secondary outcome measures are the 2-year disease-free survival rate, recurrence-free survival period, and adverse events. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as a maintenance treatment for advanced colorectal cancer patients who have achieved NED after adjuvant chemotherapy.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of methylphenidate for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with associated neurocognitive complaints in Veterans. The study will enroll 70 participants who will receive sequential 4-week periods of methylphenidate and placebo in randomized order and separated by a 1-week washout, in a crossover design. The primary outcome measure is the PTSD Symptom Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5). The secondary outcome measure is the Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function short form (NeuroQoL). The study will assess the efficacy of methylphenidate compared to placebo for reducing PTSD and neurocognitive symptoms in Veterans with PTSD, with or without comorbid TBI. The study will also assess the impact of methylphenidate on neurocognitive functioning in this population. Finally, the study will characterize baseline predictors of treatment response to methylphenidate in this population, including whether Veterans with a history of mTBI show greater average treatment response to methylphenidate versus PBO.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study that aims to validate the capacity of CFRflow as a predictor of the presence of angina measured by SAQ7 in patients with INOCA at 3 months. The study also aims to identify hemodynamic factors related to the persistence of angina at 3 and 12 months, identify clinical factors related to the persistence of angina, establish the prevalence of patients with coronary microvascular dysfunction within the cohort of INOCA patients, identify predictors of major cardiovascular events at 12 months, validate the pathological value of MMR and establish the pathological value of AF measured in ml/min. The study also aims to evaluate the concordance between measures of the coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of ruxolitinib in combination with tacrolimus and methotrexate for the prevention of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in pediatric and young adult patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT) for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). The primary objective of the study is to determine the safety of ruxolitinib in combination with tacrolimus and methotrexate for the prevention of GVHD. The secondary objectives include evaluating the efficacy of ruxolitinib in combination with tacrolimus and methotrexate for the prevention of GVHD, estimating the cumulative incidence of acute GVHD and non-relapse mortality at 100 days after transplant, estimating the cumulative incidence of chronic GVHD at 1 and 2 years after transplant, estimating the probabilities of overall and progression-free survival at 1 and 2 years after transplant, estimating the relapse/progression rate, estimating the rate of infection and development of second malignancies including lymphoproliferative disorders at 1 and 2 years post-transplant, and characterizing and evaluating hematologic recovery, donor cell engraftment, and immune reconstitution by cell count and flow cytometry of lymphocyte subsets. The study will be conducted in a single-arm, open-label, phase 2a design. Patients will receive ruxolitinib orally twice daily from day -1 to day +100, tacrolimus intravenously on day -1, and methotrexate intravenously on days +1, +3, +6, and +11, and undergo HCT on day 0. Patients will be followed up at 30 days after the last dose of ruxolitinib and at 1 and 2 years post-transplant. The study is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a single-group assignment study that aims to assess the willingness of asthma patients to change their inhaler for environmental reasons. [/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to increase the participation of women with physical disabilities in screening methods for breast and cervical cancer, which are common in women. The study will be conducted with 120 women with physical disabilities who are between the ages of 18-65 and who live in the city of Konya. The study will be conducted in two groups, one of which will receive cancer awareness training based on the Health Belief Model and the other of which will receive standard cancer awareness training. The training will be given in the form of home visits and phone calls. The study will be conducted for 3 months. The Gynecological Cancers Awareness Scale will be used to measure the awareness of women's cancers. The Champion's Health Belief Model Scale for Breast Cancer and Screening will be used to measure the barriers to performing breast self-examination and mammography.

[/INST] This systematic review aimed to assess the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab in achieving pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The researchers identified nine clinical trials that met the inclusion criteria. These trials included patients with non-metastatic operable, locally advanced, or inflammatory breast cancer, and they evaluated the pCR as the primary or secondary endpoint. The trials utilized different chemotherapy and targeted therapy regimens, along with varying dosages of Trastuzumab. The primary outcome of interest was the pCR rate, while other survival outcomes were not analyzed. Among the 1,209 patients who received neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab, the overall pCR rate was found to be 42%.

[/INST] The study is a feasibility study to assess the feasibility of a coach-led digital platform using an intelligent coaching assistant (ICA) for 6 months. The study will be conducted in Athy, a town in Kildare, Ireland, with a population of 9,000. The study will involve a close collaboration between the RCSI Centre for Positive Psychology and Health and Empeal in the development and implementation of a coach-led digital support platform augmented by an ICA. The study will examine the feasibility of running a coach-led digital platform in an urban community, using CONSORT guidelines for conducting feasibility/pilot projects. The study will assess the feasibility through recruitment rates, number of logins, engagement, and adherence. The study will also examine changes in mental health of participants using the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS), wellbeing (PERMA-NHL Profiler), and lifestyle medicine vital signs using the American College of Lifestyle Medicine short form assessment. The study will deliver a feasibility study report and dissemination of summary data reports to all stakeholders. The study will be conducted over a 12-month period, with data collection occurring from month 1 to month 6. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative data collection methods. The primary outcome measures will be reach of the recruitment process into the target population (community of 9,000 citizens), adoption of the digital platform by study participants during the project, engagement as behavior with the digital health-coaching platform at the end of the 6-month project, and the experience of a representative number of study participants with the coach-led digital platform, with an emphasis on barriers to and facilitators of engagement using semi-structured interviews. The secondary outcome measures will be changes in the perceived stress of participants using the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS), changes in wellbeing of participants using the Positive emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, Accomplishment - Negative emotion, Health, Loneliness (PERMA-NHL) Profiler, and changes in healthy lifestyle practices, using the American College of Lifestyle Medicine short form (ACLM-SF) assessment. [/INST] The study aimed to investigate the effects of progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing exercises on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with COPD. The study was a randomized controlled trial with two groups: progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing exercises. The progressive muscle relaxation group received training on the application of progressive muscle relaxation exercises twice a day, every weekday, for eight weeks. The deep breathing exercise group received training on the application of deep breathing exercises individually by face-to-face interview. The study found that progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing exercises had positive effects on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with COPD.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, non-randomized, single-center study that aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in assessing the functional significance of de novo coronary artery lesions. The study will enroll patients with stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or after the acute phase of myocardial infarction who have intermediate coronary lesions (diameter stenosis of 30%-80% by visual estimation from coronary angiography). The study will compare the diagnostic accuracy of UFR with pressure wire-based fractional flow reserve (FFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)-based ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in assessing the functional significance of de novo coronary artery lesions. The study will evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level and vessel level, using FFR as the reference standard. The study will also evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level, using FFR as the reference standard. The study will also evaluate the area under the receiver-operating characteristic curve (AUC) of UFR for coronary stenosis with FFR as the gold standard.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Balint group training on burnout and self-efficacy among nurse leaders in China. The study will use the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS) and the General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) to measure burnout and self-efficacy, respectively. The study will compare the effects of Balint group training with those of no intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of three months, with the first assessment of burnout and self-efficacy at baseline and the second assessment after three months of Balint group training. The study will be conducted in China, and the language of publication will be English.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effectiveness of non-pharmacological and TCM-based treatments for cognitive impairment in people with long COVID-19 symptoms. The study will compare the effects of acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management, TCM-based lifestyle management alone, and a wait-list control group. The study will measure the overall status of cognitive function, cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes. The study will last for 8 weeks, with two sessions per week. The primary outcome measure is the overall status of cognitive function, which will be measured at baseline, mid-intervention (4 weeks after baseline), and post-intervention (8 weeks after baseline). The secondary outcome measures are cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes, which will be measured at baseline, mid-intervention (4 weeks after baseline), post-intervention (8 weeks after baseline), and 4-week follow-up (12 weeks after baseline).

[/INST] The myCare-102 study is a survey of physician and molecular tumor board perspectives on the clinical utility and usability of Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports in facilitating patient treatment decisions for pan-cancer patients. [/INST] The study was a prospective, parallel, two-arm (1:1), randomised controlled experimental study. The aim of the study was to examine the effect of counselling and follow-up after education on the risks and prevention methods of breast cancer on early diagnosis behaviours and healthy lifestyle behaviours. The population of the study will consist of female administrative staff working at Mersin University. The sample of the study will consist of 160 people with an effect size of 0.23, 80% power maximum 5% type 1 error and drop out rate of 10%. The sample determined by randomisation A total of 160 personnel in the group will be divided into group A (study) and group B (control) formed by the independent researcher in the computer environment. All participants will be given one-hour training on breast cancer, modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors for breast cancer, symptoms of breast cancer, screening programmes and breast self-examination. Group A will be counselled for 6 months after the training and a reminder message will be sent via SMS on Monday every week as Check your Changeable Risk Factors for Breast Cancer and their feedback will be received. In group B, no additional application will be made except for the training. The data of the study will be collected before and 6 months after the training by using the Descriptive Characteristics Form, Breast Cancer Early Diagnosis Behaviours Form, Counselling Form and Healthy Lifestyle Behaviours Scale II. The data obtained from the study will be analysed in a computer environment. Number, percentage, mean and standard deviation will be used as descriptive statistics in the evaluation of the data.

[/INST] The study aimed to determine the effect of simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management on the application skills, satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy levels of midwifery students. The study was conducted with 39 midwifery students in the third year. The intervention group received simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management training, while the control group received training on a standard adult patient model. The study found that simulation-based training improved the application skills, satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy levels of midwifery students in postpartum hemorrhage management.

[/INST] The Clinical Study on the Mangrove Sword Bean Food Bar Effect for Older People is a non-randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of mangrove sword bean food bars on the weight of older people. The study will be conducted in Cihanjuang Village, Sumedang District, West Java Province, Indonesia. The treatment group will receive 50 g of mangrove sword bean food bars each day for 15 days, while the control group will receive 50 g of sword bean food bars each day for 15 days. Both groups will receive balanced nutrition education once at the first week of the study. The study will measure the weight of older people at the first and second weeks of the study. The study will also measure the change in the knowledge of balanced nutrition of older people at the second week of the study. The study will be conducted by the School of Environmental Sciences at the University of Indonesia.

[/INST] The pAIn-sense study aims to develop a telemonitoring system that uses wearable sensors and digital platforms to monitor and treat patients with pain. The system will collect data on physiological, psychological, and pain-related factors, and use artificial intelligence to analyze the data and provide personalized treatment recommendations. The study will use an observational design to monitor patients with pain and healthy controls for up to one month. The primary outcome measure will be pain level, measured through a digital health platform. The secondary outcome measures will include psychological components of pain experience, physiological components of pain, medication intake, rehabilitation, physiotherapy, sleep, activity, quality of life, and responsiveness to medication. The study will use wearable technology and digital platforms to monitor patients and collect data on physiological, psychological, and pain-related factors. The data will be analyzed using artificial intelligence to identify patterns and provide personalized treatment recommendations. The study will also use questionnaires to assess psychological and clinical factors affecting pain. The primary outcome measure will be pain level, measured through a digital health platform. The secondary outcome measures will include psychological components of pain experience, physiological components of pain, medication intake, rehabilitation, physiotherapy, sleep, activity, quality of life, and responsiveness to medication.

[/INST] The study is a phase 2a/b single-arm open-label study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intracystic administration of TARA-002 in participants between 6 months and less than 18 years of age for the treatment of macrocystic and mixed cystic lymphatic malformations (LMs). Participants will receive up to 4 intracystic injections spaced approximately 6 weeks apart. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants with clinical success after one treatment cycle of TARA-002. The secondary outcome measures include safety, durable response, clinical success by LM type, investigator assessment, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in France and is expected to last for 32 weeks after the last injection.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chiglitazar in combination with metformin and insulin glargine in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in patients who have poor hypoglycemic effect with metformin and insulin glargine. The study will include 128 patients who will be randomly assigned to the Chiglitazar group or the placebo group. The primary outcome measure is the change in HbA1C from baseline at 18 weeks of treatment. The secondary outcome measures are the change in the daily dose of insulin, triglyceride, fasting blood glucose, and fasting C-peptide from baseline. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to validate a pancreatic cancer risk prediction model in a real-world setting. The model uses electronic health record data to predict the risk of pancreatic cancer in the general population. The study will assess the model's performance in identifying high-risk individuals and its ability to predict the timing of pancreatic cancer diagnosis. The study will also evaluate the model's performance in a medium-risk group that can be used for biomarker testing. The study will be conducted using the TriNetX platform, which is a federated network database that allows for the analysis of data from multiple health care organizations. The study will include 44 health care organizations in the United States and will follow individuals for up to 3 years to assess the primary outcome of pancreatic cancer development. The study will use the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC), sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) to assess the model's performance. The study will also evaluate the model's performance in different subgroups, including age, sex, race, and geographical location.

[/INST] The study is a comparative study of autologous adipose tissue graft versus microfracture for the treatment of articular cartilage defects. The study will include 100 patients with knee osteoarthritis, aged 18 to 60 years, with cartilage defect size ranging from 2 to 5 cm2, and outer bridge classification II or III. Patients with advanced knee osteoarthritis, knee range of motion less than 1000, ligamentous injury of the affected knee, recent intra-articular injection of any type within the last 6 months, fracture around the knee, inflammatory joint disorders, tumors, immunocompromised patients, body mass index < 35, valgus deformed knee any degree, and severe varus deformed knee < 100 will be excluded from the study. The study will be randomized and double-blind. The primary outcome measure will be the clinical assessment of the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) scores at one year.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of different recovery strategies during 8 weeks of exercise training on the immune system, cardiometabolic markers, and endocrine response. The primary outcome measures are changes in the immune system, and the secondary outcome measures are changes in aerobic capacity, body composition, and cardiometabolic markers. The study will be conducted in a controlled environment with participants following a regular training volume, a lower exercise volume group, or a longer rest group. The study will assess the changes in health indices at baseline, after 4, and 8 weeks of the intervention.
