[/INST] The study "3D Joint Space Evaluation in Knee Osteoarthritis: The Importance of Weight-bearing and Flexion" is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of weight-bearing and flexion on knee joint space width in patients with osteoarthritis. The study will use a 0.25T scanner to perform four MRI scans with weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing with flexed and extended knee. The primary outcome measure is the medial joint space width, and the secondary outcome measure is the lateral joint space width. The study will measure these parameters in four scan positions. The study will be conducted in the Netherlands and is expected to last for one year.

[/INST] The study is titled "At-Home Skill Training Using Biofeedback for Swallowing Rehabilitation in Parkinson's Disease". The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: the experimental arm, which involves the use of a tablet application for at-home swallowing exercises with biofeedback, and the control arm, which involves traditional swallowing therapy. The primary outcome measure is swallowing safety, assessed using the Penetration Aspiration Scale (PAS), and the secondary outcome measure is swallowing efficiency, assessed using the Total Pharyngeal Residue (TPR). The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, with participants receiving treatment once a week for 12 weeks. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the tablet application for at-home swallowing exercises with biofeedback in improving swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with Parkinson's disease.

[/INST] The Global Burden of Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) is a study that aims to estimate the prevalence and incidence of HPV infection in low socio-economic populations in eight countries. The study will use a combination of cross-sectional surveys and longitudinal studies to collect data on HPV prevalence and incidence, as well as other factors that may influence HPV infection. The study will also collect data on knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding HPV vaccination, cervical cancer screening, and treatment. The study will use a variety of methods to collect data, including urine and self-collected vaginal swab samples for HPV testing, as well as interviews and focus groups. The study will also conduct qualitative sub-studies in five of the eight countries to gain a better understanding of the factors that influence HPV infection and HPV vaccination. The study will provide valuable data on HPV infection and the factors that influence it, which can be used to develop more effective strategies for preventing and controlling HPV infection.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the efficacy of strategic memory training coupled with non-invasive brain stimulation techniques in healthy aging and subjective cognitive decline patients. The study will be conducted in the Neuropsychology/Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Unit and Neurorehabilitation Unit of IRCCS Mondino Foundation. Participants will be randomized to either the experimental group (strategic memory training plus active tDCS) or the control group (strategic memory training plus sham tDCS). The study will use the following outcome measures: Associative learning, List learning, Name-face learning, Place learning, Text learning, Grocery learning. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the protocol has been approved by the Ethics Committee of IRCCS Mondino Foundation.

[/INST] The FIND-HF study is a protocol for a model development and validation study to predict incident heart failure from population-based nationwide electronic health records. The study will use an observational cohort design with anonymized patient-level primary care data linked to secondary administrative data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD-GOLD) and CPRD-AURUM. The primary outcome measure is the development and validation of a model to predict the risk of new onset HF. The study will identify and quantify the magnitude of predictors of new onset HF and extract informative risk factors from EHR data using multivariable Cox proportional hazard models with a backwards elimination approach. The study will use data from 2nd January 1998 to 28th February 2022.

[/INST] The ISHYS study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the impact of the recommended time between hysterectomy and resumption of sexual intercourse on sexual function using the FSFI® score. The study will compare two groups: one, whose postoperative instructions will indicate a resumption of sexual activity from 4 weeks after the operation and the other from 8 weeks postoperatively. The primary endpoint is the FSFI® score. The patients will answer the FSFI® questionnaire preoperatively and then at 3 months after surgery. The study will also describe and compare postoperative complications according to the recommended time between hysterectomy and resumption of sexual intercourse. The postoperative complications studied include dyspareunia, spontaneous pain outside of sexual intercourse, metrorrhagia, infection, and vaginal fundal suture release. The study will also describe the follow-up to the recommendation in terms of time to resume sexual intercourse and describe the reasons for not following the recommendation.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of testosterone on skeletal muscle mass and function in older men. The study will compare the effects of testosterone treatment to placebo treatment, both in combination with resistance training, and resistance training alone. The study will measure changes in skeletal muscle mass and function, as well as changes in DNA methylation, gene expression, myonuclei, satellite cells, and other markers of muscle health. The study will also assess changes in fat-free mass, isometric and dynamic muscle strength, and muscle force-velocity profiling. The study will be conducted over a period of 32 weeks, and will involve 100 older men. The study will provide important information on the effects of testosterone treatment on skeletal muscle mass and function in older men, and will help to determine the potential benefits and risks of testosterone treatment in this population.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional survey to determine the seroprevalence of dengue in the Metropolitan Area of Buenos Aires. The study will use a two-stage stratified design to select a sample of 1,487 participants aged ≥18 years who will undergo a finger prick for the determination of Immunoglobulin G antibodies against dengue performed with ELISA. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of the population with Immunoglobulin G antibodies against dengue. The study will be conducted through study completion, an average of 1 year.

[/INST] The study is titled "Performance Assessment of COVID-19 Antigen Rapid Diagnostic Tests and Algorithms in Low-Prevalence Settings" and is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the performance characteristics of two currently available antigen rapid diagnostic tests (Ag-RDTs) for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 antigens in nasal swabs. The study will also assess the cost estimates of Ag testing compared to PCR testing for COVID-19 case detection. The study will be conducted at ports of entry in Gaborone, Botswana, and will enroll participants aged 18 years or older who are crossing the border into Gaborone. The study will collect data on the sensitivity and specificity of the COVID-19 antigen RDTs compared to the reference standard reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) when used at ports of entry. The study will also collect data on the cost per test performed for each of the Ag RDTs compared to RT-PCR based protocols and the cost per COVID-19 case detected for each of the Ag RDTs compared to RT-PCR based protocols. The study will be conducted over a period of six months.

[/INST] The DESC-HBR trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor to clopidogrel 75mg, prasugrel 5mg or ticagrelor 60mg bid, with full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors, on the proportion of patients with optimal platelet reactivity (OPR). The secondary objective is to explore the effect of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy on clinical events and patients' quality of life. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients in the OPR range measured through the VerifyNow system at peak level after drug maintenance dose (MD) at 14±2 days. OPR is defined as a platelet reactive unit (PRU) between 85 and 208 reactivity units based on international consensus. A key secondary outcome will be major, minor and nuisance bleeding according to the bleeding academic research consortium (BARC) definition up to 5 months. Secondary pharmacodynamic outcomes include platelet reactivity with the VerifyNow and T-TAS system at different timepoints (baseline, 2h after first dose, through levels before MD and peak levels after MD at 14±2 days). Further pharmacodynamic assessment at 1 and 2 weeks after P2Y12 inhibitor discontinuation will be performed in the subset of patients discontinuing P2Y12 inhibitor at study conclusion or in case of P2Y12 discontinuation at anytime during the study. Other secondary endpoints will be explored including all-cause death, major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events (MACCE), a composite of cardiac death, myocardial infarction (MI), target vessel revascularization (TVR) and stroke, net adverse clinical events (NACE), a composite of MACCE and BARC 2-5 bleeding, and each individual endpoint singularly appraised. Quality of life will be evaluated with health mobility and performance scales (i.e. EQ-5D-5L, SF-12), perceived stress scale (i.e. PPS). Cost-effectives analysis will be also carried out by inputting direct and indirect costs in relation to outcomes. Study visits are scheduled at baseline,14±2

[/INST] The Prediabetes Stratification by Multi-omics Profile After Food Intake study is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the effects of different dietary and exercise interventions on blood glucose levels and metabolite responses in individuals with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes. The study will use continuous glucose monitors, Fitbit fitness trackers, and food logging apps to monitor participants' food intake and blood glucose levels. Participants will consume a standard rice meal and perform an exercise intervention on different days. Blood samples will be collected at different time points to measure metabolites and proteins. The study will also use a glucose tolerance test and an intravenous glucose tolerance test to assess participants' glucose tolerance and beta cell function. The study will investigate the effects of different dietary and exercise interventions on blood glucose levels and metabolite responses in individuals with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to test the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention to prevent fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) and adverse infant outcomes. The intervention is designed to reduce alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis use during pregnancy and while breastfeeding. The study will use contingent incentives and text-based support based on educational components. The study will measure the use of alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis during pregnancy and while breastfeeding, gestational incidents, and infant weight, height, and head circumference. The study will be conducted in South Africa.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to reduce phantom limb pain in people with limb amputation by using operant conditioning of sensory brain responses. The study will involve three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by 2 follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive operant conditioning with peripheral stimulation, while the control group will receive peripheral stimulation only. The primary outcome measure is the change in pain as measured by the Short Form-McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ). The secondary outcome measures are the change in somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) amplitude and latency as measured by a tactile event-related potential test, and the change in impact of pain on quality of life as measured by the West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI). The study will use non-invasive scalp electroencephalography (EEG) electrodes to capture the evoked response to tactile stimuli. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Quebec, Canada.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective study that aims to evaluate the accuracy of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization in the trauma intensive care unit (TICU). The study included 100 trauma patients who were admitted to the TICU and received axillary vein catheterization during their stay. The primary outcome measure was the accurate placement of the CVC catheter tip for measuring central venous pressure (CVP) or invasive hemodynamic monitoring. The secondary outcome measures were puncture complications after axillary vein catheterization, thromboembolism events, TICU mortality, TICU length of stay, and ventilator support. The study found that ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization is a safe and effective method for trauma patients in the TICU.
[/INST] Cevostamab Following CAR T Cell Therapy for RRMM

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis (CUSL) on abdominal muscles function in patients with visceral adiposity. The study will compare the effect of CUSL on abdominal muscles function with the effect of RUSI guided core muscle exercise and the effect of a combination of CUSL and RUSI guided core muscle exercise. The study will measure the diaphragm excursion and transverse abdominis contraction ratio using ultrasound imaging. The study will also measure visceral fat thickness and waist circumference using ultrasound imaging and tape measurement, respectively. The study will be conducted over a period of five weeks.

[/INST] The study is a prospective pilot study that aims to investigate the impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients with ischemic stroke of undetermined origin. The study will include patients who have experienced an ischemic stroke within 7 days of inclusion, have no history of AF, and are scheduled for implantable loop recorder implantation within 3 months of ischemic stroke. The study will use cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast agent to measure the atrial fibrosis surface area. The study will also use implantable loop recorders to measure the occurrence of AF at 3-year follow-up. The study will exclude patients who have been diagnosed with AF during stroke assessment, have a contraindication to MRI or gadolinium injection, or have a history of hypersensitivity to gadolinium-based contrast agents and meglumine. The study will not accept healthy volunteers.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, open-label, phase II study to evaluate the efficacy of capivasertib, fulvestrant, and durvalumab in premenopausal patients with ER-positive, HER2-negative, locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer. The study will compare the efficacy of the combination of goserelin, fulvestrant, and capivasertib with the combination of goserelin, fulvestrant, and durvalumab. The primary endpoint is the objective response rate (ORR) of the combination of goserelin, fulvestrant, and capivasertib compared to the combination of goserelin, fulvestrant, and durvalumab. The secondary endpoints include progression-free survival (PFS) and ORR compared between the two arms.

[/INST] The RecuR Score is a risk score that predicts the risk of unplanned hospital readmission for patients both in-hospital and after discharge. The study is a pilot study that aims to test the effectiveness of a new transitional care model for patients with a high risk of readmission using the RecuR Score. The model includes additional educational materials, a focus on the patient's readmission risk during interdisciplinary team huddles, and home health care. The study will use a fallback design with two primary endpoints: 30-day unplanned hospital readmission in the overall study population and 30-day unplanned hospital readmission in the medium-high risk population. The study will randomize patients to either the standard of care or the enhanced care model. The enhanced care model includes additional educational materials, a focus on the patient's readmission risk during interdisciplinary team huddles, and home health care. The study will collect data on patient demographics, admission diagnoses, length of stay, and outcomes data like subsequent hospital encounters in the 90 days post-discharge. The study will use a fallback design with two primary endpoints. The first sequential primary endpoint is 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the overall study population. The second sequential primary endpoint is 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the medium-high risk population. The significance level (0.05) will be divided evenly between the two primary endpoints, for a significance level of 0.025 for the first primary endpoint and a reserved 0.025 significance level for the second primary endpoint.

[/INST] The ANCAR trial is a randomized, open-label, monocenter trial that aims to evaluate the effects of acupuncture on nasal congestion in allergic rhinitis (AR) compared to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). The study will recruit 100 participants with AR and nasal congestion. The acupuncture protocol will consist of 8 treatments over 6 weeks, with 2 treatments per week during the first 2 weeks and 1 treatment per week in the subsequent 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the visual analog scale (VAS) score for nasal congestion after 6 weeks of treatment. The study will also assess the effects of acupuncture on other nasal and ocular signs and symptoms in AR, general health, concentration, and energy level using the adapted nasal obstruction symptom evaluation (NOSE) score. The study will provide evidence on the effectiveness of acupuncture for AR and nasal congestion.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of transcoronary cooling and dilution during percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for patients with STEMI. The study will compare the use of transcoronary cooling and dilution with standard PCI in terms of myocardial salvage index, infarct size, and cardiac function. The study will also evaluate the safety of the procedure by assessing the incidence of adverse events.

[/INST] The study is a feasibility pilot clinical trial that aims to assess the feasibility of recruiting 100 participants within 20 months and successfully randomizing/assigning 25 participants per study arm within 2 years. The study also aims to assess adherence to supplement intake, adherence to dietary protocol, and completion of study visits. The study will use a combination of dietary consults, fish oil, probiotics, and prebiotics to improve the gut microbiome and mental health outcomes in pregnant women with perinatal depression and anxiety. The primary outcome is feasibility, measured by recruitment and retention rates. The secondary outcome is mental health, measured by depression and anxiety scores. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with four arms: (1) Gutopia (dietary consults, fish oil, probiotics, and prebiotics), (2) Gutboost (fish oil and probiotics), (3) Gutless (fish oil and placebo probiotics), and (4) Gutnone (standard care and dietary consult at enrollment). The study will use validated tools to assess dietary intake, mental health, and stool samples. The study will be conducted virtually, with the exception of in-person follow-ups for those who need them. The study will last for 2 years, with six study visits scheduled every 3 months. The study will be conducted in Canada and will be led by Centre Hospitalier Val-des-Pins. The study will be coordinated by the Centre for Research on Stress Disorders and Suicide Prevention at Concordia University. The study will be overseen by an independent Data Safety Monitoring Board. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Tri-Council Policy Statement: Ethical Conduct for Research Involving Humans. The study has been approved by the Research Ethics Board of Centre Hospitalier Val-des-Pins.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors. The study includes a baseline run-in and randomized stage I and stage II studies. In stage I, participants are randomized to one of four arms of the ¡Vida! program, which is a remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss intervention. In stage II, participants who achieve ≥ 2% weight loss at week 4 are continued in their assigned intervention in stage I. Participants who do not achieve ≥ 2% weight loss at week 4 are re-randomized to one of two arms of the ¡Vida! program. The primary outcome measure is body weight percent change at month 12. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors and whether the effectiveness is moderated by baseline patient characteristics.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective study of high-dose follitropin delta in a mixed protocol with human chorionic gonadotropin. The study included women aged 18 to 42 years undergoing IVF/ICSI cycles. The study evaluated the combination of follitropin delta and serial hCG injections at individualized doses, where dosing regimen was determined according to AMH and weight in women undergoing an IVF antagonist cycle. The primary outcome measure was the number of good quality blastocysts up to 6 days.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telemedicine in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study will compare the outcomes of patients who receive telemedicine intervention with those of patients who receive standard care. The primary outcome measure is the change in the quality of life in IBD measured by SIBDQ and WHOQOL-26. The secondary outcome measures include maintaining/achieving clinical remission of Crohn Disease, maintaining/achieving clinical remission of Ulcerative Colitis, maintaining/achieving clinical remission of IBD, Maintaining/achieving endoscopic remission of IBD, Maintaining/achieving histological remission of IBD, Change the number adverse drug reactions in IBD, Change satisfaction with treatment of patients with IBD, Change psychological well-being of patients with IBD measured by HADS, Change psychological well-being of patients with IBD measured by VSI, Change psychological well-being of patients with IBD measured by TAS-26, Change the number of surgical interventions in IBD, Change the number of hospitalizations in IBD, Change the number of outpatient visits in IBD.

[/INST] The SAUNA trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the efficacy of continuing somatostatin analogs (SSAs) versus stopping them in patients with progressive neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) after first-line SSA treatment. The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival (PFS) and time to deterioration (TTD) in patients continuing or stopping second-line therapy with SSAs. The secondary outcome measures include PFS rate, response rate, overall survival (OS), and quality of life (QoL) measurement with questionnaires. The trial will also assess the cost-effectiveness of continuing SSAs. The study will be conducted in two substudies: a targeted therapy substudy and a peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) substudy. The targeted therapy substudy will compare the efficacy of continuing SSAs with everolimus or sunitinib, and the PRRT substudy will compare the efficacy of continuing SSAs with PRRT. The trial will be conducted in 14 centers in the Netherlands and Belgium. The trial is expected to be completed in June 2026.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a peer-mediated pivotal response training intervention in improving socialization experiences and language skills in children with language impairment in inclusive preschool classrooms. The intervention involves training peers to use specific strategies to interact with the target child, and the study will examine the impact of the intervention on the target child's socialization experiences and language skills. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative measures to assess the target child's socialization experiences and language skills, and qualitative methods to gain a deeper understanding of the child's experiences. The study will also examine the impact of the intervention on the peers who are trained to use the strategies. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with children randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The study will be conducted in inclusive preschool classrooms, and the intervention will be implemented by the classroom teacher or teaching assistant. The study will examine the impact of the intervention on the target child's socialization experiences and language skills over a 9-month period. The study will use a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the effectiveness of combining physical therapy with dalfampridine in improving mobility in people with multiple sclerosis. The study will compare the effects of physical therapy alone, dalfampridine alone, and physical therapy plus dalfampridine on mobility and other outcomes. The study will use the Timed 25-Foot Walk test to measure mobility and will use functional connectivity to measure the effects of the interventions on the brain. The study will also explore the factors that are associated with treatment responsiveness.

[/INST] The study titled "Test-Retest Reliability, Responsiveness and Interpretability of CLEFT-Q" is a psychometric study that aims to evaluate the test-retest reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability of the CLEFT-Q questionnaire. The study will include 50 patients with cleft lip and/or palate who will be asked to complete the CLEFT-Q twice with a 1-2 week interval between the first and second completion. The study will also include 50 patients who will complete the CLEFT-Q before and 6 months after secondary nose surgery, 50 patients who will complete the CLEFT-Q before and 6 months after secondary lip surgery, 50 patients who will complete the CLEFT-Q before and 1 year after jaw surgery, and 50 patients who will complete the CLEFT-Q before and 1 year after secondary speech improving surgery. The study will also include 20 health care professionals who will be interviewed about their experiences with using the CLEFT-Q. The primary outcome measure of the study is the change scores of the CLEFT-Q. The secondary outcome measures of the study are photographs from before and after surgery, and recordings of speech before and after surgery. The study will use the CLEFT-Q, photographs, and recordings of speech as test measures, and the CLEFT-Q completed at a second time point as the retest measure. The study will use test-retest reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability to evaluate the psychometric properties of the CLEFT-Q.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of core stabilization and dynamic stretching exercises in reducing the severity of primary dysmenorrhea. The study is conducted on 60 nulliparous women aged 18-25 years who were randomly assigned to either the core stabilization exercise group or the dynamic stretching exercise group. The core stabilization exercise group performed 6 core stabilization exercises for 8 weeks, while the dynamic stretching exercise group performed 6 dynamic stretching exercises for 8 weeks. The study found that both core stabilization and dynamic stretching exercises were effective in reducing the severity of primary dysmenorrhea. However, the core stabilization exercise group showed a greater reduction in the severity of primary dysmenorrhea compared to the dynamic stretching exercise group.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study that aims to determine the relationship between changes in cerebral blood flow velocity (CBFV) and changes in mean arterial pressure (MAP) during controlled MAP variations in patients under general anesthesia. The study will be conducted in patients undergoing scheduled surgery at Lariboisière Hospital. The study will include 100 patients who are 18 years of age or older and are scheduled for surgery under general anesthesia. The patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: a control group or an intervention group. The control group will receive standard blood pressure management, while the intervention group will receive individualized blood pressure management based on the patient's cardiovascular risk factors. The primary outcome measure will be the correlation between changes in CBFV and changes in MAP during controlled MAP variations. The secondary outcome measures will include the correlation between changes in CBFV and changes in mean frontal EEG power, changes in cerebral oximetry, and changes in blood pressure. The study will use non-invasive methods to measure CBFV, cerebral oximetry, and blood pressure. The study will use transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasound to measure CBFV, near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) to measure cerebral oximetry, and continuous blood pressure monitoring to measure blood pressure. The study will use linear regression analysis to determine the relationship between changes in CBFV and changes in MAP, EEG power, cerebral oximetry, and blood pressure. The study will also use a linear mixed model to determine the relationship between changes in CBFV and changes in MAP, EEG power, cerebral oximetry, and blood pressure while controlling for potential confounding factors. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the institutional review board. The study will be registered with the ClinicalTrials.gov registry.

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational study of MRD dynamic monitoring in first-line serplulimab plus chemotherapy in the treatment of extensive small cell lung cancer. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of serplulimab plus chemotherapy in the treatment of extensive small cell lung cancer. The study will enroll patients with previously untreated and confirmed by histological and imaging examinations as extensive small cell lung cancer. The study will evaluate the progression-free survival, overall survival, objective response rate, and disease-control rate. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The Aktivplan Digital Intervention (ACTIVE-CaRe Pilot) is a clinical pilot study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Aktivplan digital intervention for supporting regular heart-healthy levels of physical activity following completion of a phase II rehabilitation program. The study will recruit 100 participants who will be randomized to either the experimental arm (intervention) or the control arm (usual care). The primary outcome measure is the recruitment rate, and the secondary outcome measures include drop-out rate, data completeness, adherence to the intervention, usability and user experience of the intervention, user acceptance of the intervention, technical stability of the intervention, use of alternative and additional strategies for supporting physical activity, experiences and perspectives of patients regarding their study participation, and experiences and perspectives of rehabilitation professionals regarding the intervention and study procedures. The study will use the Aktivplan digital intervention, which is a digital planning calendar for regular heart-healthy physical activity. The intervention will be delivered through a smartphone app, and participants will be followed up for 10 weeks. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative data collection methods. The quantitative data will be collected through automated usage logging of the app, the mHealth App Usability Questionnaire (MAUQ), the AttrakDiff Short Questionnaire, the Mobile Application Rating Scale (MARS), and the EQ-5D-5L Questionnaire. The qualitative data will be collected through semi-structured interviews and focus groups. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study protocol has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study that aims to evaluate the social and repetitive behaviors of youth with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) after four weeks of twice-daily administration of 24IU of intranasally administered oxytocin or placebo. The study will assess the primary outcomes of social behavior and repetitive behavior, as well as secondary outcomes of behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, repetitive cognition, and vagally-mediated heart rate variability.

[/INST] The study is an observational study with longitudinal follow-up regarding the validation of a scale that the investigators have created. The study is conducted in the neonatal intensive care units of the Clermont-Ferrand hospital center. The patients will be evaluated daily from the 3rd day of life by the nurse, the physiotherapist and the resident of the service. The evaluation will be carried out at least 8 times over 21 days. If an abdominal massage is performed, an assessment of the abdominal condition by the scale will be necessary before and after each massage by the physiotherapist. Each assessment (by physio, nurse and resident) will be blinded and within a maximum time window of 30 minutes. The first evaluator clears the patient's abdomen (clothing and diaper removed) and then performs the assessment of the abdomen blindly. A description has been written so that each evaluator can use the ECAP scale under the same conditions and with well-detailed judgment criteria in order to have an evaluation that is as reliable as possible. The time taken to assess the premature baby's abdomen by the ECAP scale is less than 3 minutes. The evaluator fills out the ECAP assessment table, blindly. Within the next 30 minutes (the patient's abdominal condition is considered stable during this time), the second and third assessors have to do the same. These assessments are stored together with each patient's clinical data collection, and then analyzed by statisticians.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Empowered Relief (ER) delivered by ASPMN nurses in reducing pain catastrophizing and pain intensity in adults with persistent pain. The study will compare the effects of ER to a wait-list control group. The study will recruit 170 participants who will be randomized to either the ER or wait-list control group. Participants in the ER group will receive a one-time web-based class delivered by an ER-trained ASPMN nurse, while participants in the wait-list control group will receive the ER class after the 2-month waiting period. The study will use self-report surveys to measure pain catastrophizing and pain intensity at baseline, 2, 4, and 8 weeks after the intervention. The study will also use qualitative methods to assess the feasibility and acceptability of ER delivered by ASPMN nurses.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) for the treatment of poor graft function after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). The study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of MSCs in treating poor graft function. The study will enroll patients who have undergone allo-HSCT and have developed poor graft function. The patients will be treated with MSCs at a dose of 1×10^6/kg weekly for 4 consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measure is the hemogram recovery of patients with poor graft function after treatment. The secondary outcome measures are infection rate, graft-versus-host disease, and survival rate. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and is expected to be completed by 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial of an integrated digital intervention for alcohol use disorder. The intervention is a mobile app that delivers cognitive-behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorder. The control group receives medical management and pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorder. The primary outcome is change in past 30-day alcohol use from baseline to 6-months post-treatment entry.

[/INST] The Seven Trial is a phase I/II trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of combining botensilimab with balstilimab and triplet chemotherapy in patients with previously untreated metastatic pancreatic cancer. The trial will have two parts: a dose escalation part and an expansion part. In the dose escalation part, the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of botensilimab will be determined when combined with balstilimab and triplet chemotherapy. In the expansion part, the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy at the MTD will be evaluated in a larger cohort of patients. The primary endpoint of the trial is the MTD of botensilimab when combined with balstilimab and triplet chemotherapy. The secondary endpoints include safety and tolerability, complete response rate, overall response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, disease control rate, and change in CA 19-9 levels.

[/INST] The study compares the clinical pregnancy rate of frozen embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles. In a substituted cycle, estrogen and progesterone are given and a transfer is planned when the endometrium is ready. In a natural cycle, no hormones are given and a transfer is planned when there is a dominant follicle apparent at the ultrasound. The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate, which is the presence of fetal heartbeat at the viability ultrasound. The study is conducted at Clinique OVO.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease and to develop a protocol to avoid nutritional deficiency and achieve normal growth in these children. The study will include children aged more than one month to 18 years with congenital heart disease who present to Assiut University Hospital Units. The study will use the WHO growth chart to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease. The study will also assess the nutritional history of these children and their feeding practices. The study will also assess the nutritional status of these children using anthropometric measures such as weight, height, head circumference, mid-arm circumference, and BMI. The study will also assess the nutritional needs of these children and develop a protocol to avoid nutritional deficiency and achieve normal growth in these children. The study will also assess the effectiveness of the developed protocol in improving the nutritional status of these children. The study will also assess the feasibility of implementing the developed protocol in clinical practice.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial of surgical resection of glioblastoma using pH-sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer MRI. The study aims to compare the progression-free survival of patients undergoing standard of care resection with those undergoing resection guided by pH-sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer MRI. The study will enroll patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma and will follow them up for 24 months. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and the secondary outcome measures are overall survival and quality of life metrics via the Karnofsky Performance Scale. The study will use pH-sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer MRI to guide resection of glioblastoma. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

[/INST] The study titled "Patterns of Urinary Bladder Cancer in Darfur, Sudan 2020 - 2022" is a cross-sectional, hospital-based study conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital in Darfur, Sudan. The study aims to investigate the patterns of urinary bladder cancer (BC) in Darfur, Sudan, with a focus on understanding the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease. The study will be conducted from 2020 to 2022.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to analyze the relationship between physical and mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. The study will be conducted at the Endoscopy Center of the Department of Gastroenterology, Renji Hospital, from May 2023 to August 2023. A total of 1000 patients who are to undergo colonoscopy will be randomly selected and asked to complete a questionnaire that includes questions about their physical and mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. The quality of bowel preparation will be assessed by the Boston bowel preparation scale (BPS), which is used by colonoscopists to assess the quality of bowel preparation for each patient. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the study protocol has been approved by the Ethics Committee of Renji Hospital.

[/INST] The study is titled "Evaluation of Skillflix for Parents of Youth With ASD" and is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of using the SkillFlix for Parents online video library to improve the sexual health communication skills of parents of teens with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study will recruit parent and youth dyads, including parents over 18 years old and youth aged 13-17 with ASD, reciprocal communication skills, receptive language skills, who are in mainstream classrooms for at least one class during the school day. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with pre- and post-assessment, and a 3-month follow-up assessment (6 months after start of study), each including a survey and audio recording. The intervention group will receive access to the SkillTalk ASD web site and the study mobile app, while the control group will receive written materials with similar content. The primary outcome measure will be the Demonstrated Skill score in communicating with their teens about sexual health. The secondary outcome measures will include Parent reported frequency of discussions with their teens about sexual health and relationships over the course of the last 3 months, Parent Conversation Quality Score, Parent confidence in their ability to use skills in communication with their teen about sexual health and relationships, Teen reported frequency of discussions with their teens about sexual health and relationships over the course of the last 3 months, Youth Conversation Quality Score, Teen confidence in their ability to use Making Connections skills, Family Sex Communication Quotient Score, Teen's Sexual Health Knowledge, Teen's sexual health attitudes, and Teen's sexual health behaviors. The study will be conducted in the United States.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the relationship between the plasma levels of DDX17 and GSDMD and vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis in sepsis patients. The study will collect data on the population information, disease-related information, treatment measures, laboratory examination results, and follow-up of the patients. The study will also collect samples of the patients' peripheral blood on Day1, 3, and 7, and the plasma will be centrifuged and kept at -80 °C. The study will use ELISA to detect the content of DDX17 and GSDMD in the plasma. The study will use the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score to assess the severity of sepsis in the patients. The study will use the 28-day mortality as the primary outcome measure and the correlation between the plasma level of DDX17 and vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis in sepsis patients as the secondary outcome measure. The study will exclude patients who are younger than 18 years or older than 80 years, pregnant women, tumor patients, and patients with diseases that may be complicated with vascular endothelial damage. The study will include patients who have a potential or clear infection and a Sequential organ failure score (SOFA score) that increases by more than or equal to 2 points compared to the baseline value. The study will exclude patients who are younger than 18 years or older than 80 years, pregnant women, tumor patients, and patients with diseases that may be complicated with vascular endothelial damage.

[/INST] The study is a single-center prospective study that aims to evaluate the non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The study will include patients who are eligible for liver transplantation following national and international guidelines. The primary outcome measure is early allograft dysfunction (EAD) based on the Olthoff criteria. The study will evaluate the accuracy of non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of EAD in the first two weeks after liver transplantation.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, randomized, controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Elemene plus Stupp Protocol compared with Stupp Protocol alone for newly-diagnosed GBM patients. The study will enroll patients with newly-diagnosed supratentorial glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype, WHO grade 4, aged 18-70 years, with a KPS score of 60 or higher, and adequate bone marrow function, hepatic function, renal function, and coagulation function. Patients will be randomly assigned to the experimental group or the control group in a 1:1 ratio. The experimental group will receive Elemene plus Stupp Protocol, while the control group will receive Stupp Protocol alone. The primary outcome measure is the overall survival rate in the 12th month (12m-OS). The secondary outcome measures include overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), and progression-free survival rate in the 6th month (6m-OS). Adverse events will also be evaluated. The study will last for 3 years and 11 months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of prone positioning and supine positioning on lung recruitability in infants and children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will enroll 20 patients who will be randomized to receive either prone positioning or supine positioning. The primary outcome measure is the PaO2/FiO2 ratio, which will be measured at the end of the supine and prone positioning periods. The secondary outcome measures include other gas exchange parameters, ventilatory ratio, global and regional impedance-derived end-expiratory lung volume, tidal volume distribution, global and regional impedance-derived lung dynamic strain, and number of displacements of the endotracheal tube and number of oxygen desaturations during prone positioning. The study will use electrical impedance tomography to measure regional lung aeration and ventilation distribution. The study will have a single-blinded design, and the treating intensivist will be blinded to the treatment allocation. The study will have a duration of 2 hours for each positioning period. The study will have a 1-hour washout period between the two positioning periods. The study will have a sample size of 20 patients. The study will have a power of 80% to detect a difference of 10 units in the PaO2/FiO2 ratio between the two positioning periods. The study will have a type I error rate of 5%. The study will have a 95% confidence interval for the difference in the PaO2/FiO2 ratio between the two positioning periods. The study will have a descriptive analysis of the secondary outcome measures. The study will have a statistical analysis of the primary and secondary outcome measures. The study will have a qualitative and quantitative analysis of the adverse events. The study will have a safety analysis of the number of displacements of the endotracheal tube and number of oxygen desaturations during prone positioning. The study will have a feasibility analysis of the number of patients enrolled in the study. The study will have a pilot analysis of the study results

[/INST] The study aimed to investigate the effects of progressive relaxation training on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perception, and social participation in women with tension-type headache and migraine. The study was a randomized controlled trial with two groups: a tension-type headache group and a migraine group. Both groups received progressive relaxation training for 6 weeks, and the results were compared before and after the intervention. The study found that progressive relaxation training was effective in reducing pain intensity and improving activity self-efficacy and social participation in both groups. However, no significant differences were found between the groups. The study concluded that progressive relaxation training may be an effective non-pharmacological treatment for women with tension-type headache and migraine.

[/INST] The Effect of Patient Education on Pain in Orthopedics and Traumatology Patients is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effect of patient education on pain level and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment model and an open label. The study group consisted of 52 patients who underwent elective surgery in the orthopedics and traumatology clinic of the training and research hospital affiliated with the Ministry of Health in Istanbul between December 15, 2021, and March 15, 2022. The intervention group received patient education on pain management the day before and on the morning of the operation. The control group received patient education on the preoperative preparation, operating theatre environment, breathing exercises, cough exercises, etc. to be performed after surgery. The primary outcome of the study was the pain level of the patients, which was assessed by the Visual/Visual Analogue Scale. The secondary outcome was the fear of pain, which was assessed by the Fear of Pain Scale-III. The study found that patient education on pain management can reduce pain and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients.

[/INST] The Patch BRIDGE Trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of a transdermal buprenorphine patch for induction during pregnancy compared to a sham patch. The study will measure the severity of withdrawal during induction and the success of induction, treatment adherence, and recovery success. The study will include female participants who are pregnant, meet diagnostic criteria for opioid use disorder, receive prenatal care through an opioid use disorder-specific clinic, and are not already receiving treatment for opioid use disorder. The study will exclude participants who are already in withdrawal, have medical contraindications to buprenorphine, or require immediate hospitalization. The study will use a parallel assignment model with double masking. Participants will be randomized to receive either a buprenorphine transdermal patch or a sham patch. The buprenorphine patch will be applied at the time of induction initiation and removed at 48 hours. The primary outcome measure will be the severity of withdrawal during induction as measured by the Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Scale (SOWS) scores. The secondary outcome measures will be induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success. The study will be conducted at a single center and will use a parallel group design with a 1:1 allocation ratio. The study will have a total sample size of 100 participants, with 50 participants in each group. The study will have a duration of 4 days. The study will use a double-blind, randomized, controlled design. The study will be conducted at a single center. The study will have a total sample size of 100 participants, with 50 participants in each group. The study will have a duration of 4 days.

[/INST] The study is a single-center, prospective, observational study that aims to evaluate the diagnostic value of transcutaneous oximetry in patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The study will include patients who have undergone additional examinations as part of the diagnostic assessment, including venous and arterial Doppler or dynamic arteriography and venography. The study will compare the TcpO2 values recorded during dynamic maneuvers with the estimated rate of compression of the subclavian and axillary vessels determined on dynamic angiography. The primary outcome measure is the DROPmin, which is the variation in upper limb ischemia estimated by TcpO2 measurement and the calculation of the DROPmin (TcpO2 variation regarding a reference) depending on the type of damage (arterial, venous, or both arterial and venous). The secondary outcome measure is the correlation between the severity of upper limb ischemia by TcpO2 measurement and the degree of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will include 20 patients. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months, and the results will be presented in a scientific journal and at scientific conferences.

[/INST] The study is a feasibility study of a mobile health app for symptom monitoring in people with chronic pancreatitis. [/INST] The study is a retrospective cross-sectional study conducted over three months from the start of September 2020 to the end of November 2020 at Mansoura University Isolation Hospital. The study included 176 patients who were diagnosed with COVID-19 and discharged home safely. The patients were telephoned to check if they experienced anal pain or anal fissure. Those who experienced anal pain or anal fissure were advised to come to the colorectal outpatient clinic (OPC) to be examined. However, no patient came to the OPC. Further telephone calls were conducted to those who were diagnosed with anal fissure to ask about their outcomes, to pick up how many of them were managed medically or their symptoms resolved spontaneously or needed surgical interference. The study found that 10 patients (5.7%) developed anal fissure after recovering from COVID-19 infection. The risk factors associated with the development of anal fissure were constipation, diarrhea, and loss of smell and taste sensation.

[/INST] The study was a randomized controlled trial that aimed to compare the effects of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) membrane and suturing on palatal wound healing after connective tissue harvesting. The study included 20 patients who underwent palatal connective tissue harvesting for gingival recession treatment. The patients were randomly assigned to either the control group or the test group. In the control group, the incision line was sutured with 5/0 synthetic, nonabsorbable, sterile monofilament suture. In the test group, L-PRF membrane was placed to the donor site before suturing. The patients were evaluated using an ultrasonography device on days 0, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30, and 90 for palatal tissue thickness and tissue vascularization. The results showed that the use of L-PRF membrane significantly improved palatal wound healing compared to suturing alone.

[/INST] The ARRC III Trial of Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) is a pilot registry study that aims to collect data on the Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) model of care. The ARRC model of care was shown to provide substantial improvements in patient outcomes, hospital utilization, and costs of care. The study will collect data on the ARRC model of care and its impact on patient outcomes, hospital utilization, and costs of care. The study will also identify which surgical subgroups receive benefit from ARRC and provide a robust mechanism to ensure outcomes are maintained and ideally improved within the institution. The study will be initially piloted at RAH, the subject of this study.

[/INST] The study is a phase 3b, open-label, hybrid type 2 implementation and effectiveness trial that will compare the effectiveness and implementation of oral PrEP and CAB-LA in mobile men in South Africa and Uganda. The study will randomize participants into two groups: Group A will receive oral TDF-FTC PrEP (using either event-driven or daily) and Group B will receive CAB-LA. After 9 months, participants from both groups will be offered a choice of PrEP for a further 9 months, with the ability to change choice as required. The primary user effectiveness outcome will be persistent use of PrEP in the randomized period and throughout the full follow-up period. The primary implementation outcome will be PrEP adoption, assessed as uptake of PrEP in months 0-9 and choice preference of PrEP in months 9-18.

[/INST] The study is a preliminary assessment of the psycho-emotional state of patients with TMD. The study group consisted of 130 patients diagnosed with TMD, while the control group consisted of 130 patients who were excluded from having TMD based on the RDC/TMD questionnaire. The questionnaire survey included a total of 30 questions, regarding the emotional state of the of the respondents over the past 4 weeks. The scores for each question were divided into four sections; A, B, C,D. The study was conducted from 2021 to 2023.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of three different types of touch on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers in preterm infants. The three types of touch are therapeutic touch, affective touch, and static touch. The study will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), electroencephalogram (EEG), and proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H NMR) to measure brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers. The study will also use mass spectrometry to measure urinary metabolites. The study will enroll preterm infants between 32 and 34 weeks of gestational age who are free of comorbidities. The infants will be randomly assigned to one of the three touch groups and will receive the assigned touch for one hour. The study will measure brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers before and after the touch intervention. The study will also measure the infants' vital signs and collect data on their medical history and demographics. The study will use intention-to-treat analysis to compare the effects of the three touch groups on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers. The study will also use mixed-effects models to compare the effects of the three touch groups on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers over time.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/II clinical trial of non-myeloablative haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) with briquilimab and abatacept in patients with sickle cell disease (SCD). The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the regimen success rate, defined as successful engraftment and absence of acute grade 3 or higher graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) or moderate to severe chronic GVHD, at 1 year post-transplant. The secondary objectives include evaluating event-free survival and overall survival, viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications, and other outcomes. The study will enroll patients with SCD who are at high risk for disease-related morbidity or mortality and have failed or are ineligible for other curative therapies. Patients will receive non-myeloablative haploidentical peripheral blood stem cell transplantation with briquilimab and abatacept, in addition to the NIH-established regimen of alemtuzumab, TBI, and sirolimus. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of the regimen in patients with SCD.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of two different sperm preparation methods, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, on the euploid rate of blastocysts in couples undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study will recruit 100 couples and randomly assign them to one of the two groups. The microfluidic chip group will use the Sperm Separation Device to separate spermatozoa from semen samples, while the density gradient centrifugation group will use a discontinuous density gradient centrifugation method to separate spermatozoa. The primary outcome measure is the euploid rate of blastocysts biopsied, and the secondary outcome measures are the live birth rate of the first embryo transfer, positive urine pregnancy test rate per the first embryo transfer, clinical pregnancy rate of the first embryo transfer, ongoing pregnancy rate, miscarriage rate pregnancy, multiple pregnancy rate, DNA fragmentation, ectopic pregnancy rate, and multiple pregnancy rate. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and is expected to be completed by 2023.

[/INST] The study titled "Brain-derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) Single Nucleotide Gene Polymorphism and Nerve Growth Factor as Risk Factors That Increase Severity of Allergic Rhinitis" is a case-control study that aims to investigate the association between BDNF gene polymorphism and nerve growth factor (NGF) levels and the severity of allergic rhinitis. The study will include 100 participants, including 50 patients with chronic allergic rhinitis and 50 healthy controls. The study will measure BDNF gene polymorphism, NGF levels, interleukin-1 (IL-1) levels, and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in the blood of the participants. The study will last for two months.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of mindfulness-based intervention on cognitive and psychological well-being in older adults. The intervention consists of eight weekly group sessions of two hours each, which include mindfulness practices such as body scan, sitting meditation, and yoga practice. Participants are instructed to engage in home practice of these skills for 45 minutes a day for six days a week. The study will measure the change in dispositional mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive mindfulness on the Five Facet Mindfulness (FFM) Scale, California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT), and Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (MAIA) scale, respectively, at week 8. Additionally, EEG alpha power will be measured at week 8.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to determine the prevalence of Mycoplasma genitalium (MG) infection and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected men in Hong Kong. The study will recruit 750 HIV-infected men who attend an HIV specialist clinic in Hong Kong. The participants will self-administer an online questionnaire, and self-collect urine, rectal, and pharyngeal samples for MG, Chlamydia trachomatis (CT), and Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) screening, and MG genotypic resistance mutations detection. Clinical data will be transcribed from medical records of recruited subjects. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence of MG infection, and the secondary outcome measures are the prevalence of CT and NG infections, syphilis, hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The study will provide information on the prevalence of MG infection and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected men in Hong Kong.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, open-label, randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of the combination of Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy in patients with advanced breast cancer after CDK4/6 inhibitor failure. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the progression-free survival (PFS) of the combination of Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS). The study will also evaluate the safety and tolerability of the combination of Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy.

[/INST] The study is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter study of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab regimen conversion therapy for gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab regimen conversion therapy in patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. The primary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS). The secondary endpoint is overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), translational rate, and adverse events (AEs).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of alternative incentives on the physical activity of older adults. The study will recruit 200 older adults and randomize them into two groups: a treatment group and a control group. The treatment group will receive additional incentives for their physical activity, while the control group will not receive any additional incentives. The study will track the step count of the two groups for 8 weeks using Fitbit devices and Fitabase software. The investigators will collect physical activity data for 1 week as the baseline physical activity of the participants. After 1 week, individuals who on average less than 6000 per day will be dropped from the study. The investigators will randomize participants to the treatment group or the control group. The treatment group will receive a meal donation and a monetary incentive for each day they meet the step goal of 7,500 steps. The control group will not receive any additional incentives. The investigators will collect follow-up data for 2 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in step count, which will be measured daily and averaged across a week. The secondary outcome measure is the change in CES-D (Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale) score, which will be measured during baseline and endline survey.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the clinical impact and cost-effectiveness of a wireless vital signs monitor for hospitalized newborns in Kenya. The study will be conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital neonatal ward in Kenya. The study will compare the effectiveness of the wireless vital signs monitor versus the standard-of-care vital signs monitoring. The study will measure the nurse's response time to patients in distress, the percentage of actionable alarms, the incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, and the frequency of key interventions. The study will also assess the user experience and perceptions on feasibility and sustainability of the wireless vital signs monitor. The study will be conducted over a period of 16 months.

[/INST] The study is a phase II clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of pre- or post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy in patients with soft tissue sarcoma of the limbs or trunk. The study will enroll patients aged ≥ 70 years with a performance status of ≤ 2 or patients aged 65 to 70 years with a performance status of 2 and identified by the investigator as fragile. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients free of major surgical complications within 6 months of surgery. The secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, geriatric parameters, and toxicities of radiation therapy. The study will enroll 100 patients and follow them up for 3 years.

[/INST] The study is a retrospective study conducted in the Department of ENT-Head and Neck Surgery of Shree Birendra Hospital, a tertiary health care center of Nepal. The study aimed to determine the prevalence of head and neck cancer in the department. The data was collected from the medical records of head and neck cancer patients who underwent treatment between May 2022 to April 2023. The data considered demographic details of age, sex, diagnosis, subsite specific head and neck cancers, treatment modality, and histopathology. The data was analyzed using Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) version 22. Pearson's chi-square test was applied and p value <0.05 was considered statistically significant.

[/INST] The study is titled "The Role of Health Communication Messaging in Evidence-based Pediatric Obstructive Sleep Apnea Detection" and aims to test the impact of a health communication message designed to educate and activate parents about their child's risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The study will randomize parents of children with OSA symptoms to view the health communication message or usual care. The primary outcome is the rate of completed OSA referral among children who screened positive for OSA. The study will also measure the rate of OSA referral, rate of evidence-based evaluation, rate of OSA diagnosis, and rate of OSA treatment. The study will also measure the rate of parent activation, which is the rate of parents who report planning to speak with their child's provider about OSA.

[/INST] The UPlift study is a prospective, post-marketing, observational study that aims to evaluate the speed of onset and durability of effectiveness of upadacitinib in adult participants with moderate to severe Crohn's disease (CD) in real-world clinical practice. Participants will receive upadacitinib as prescribed by their physician according to local label. The primary outcome measure is time to achieve first clinical response per patient-reported outcome 2 (Daily CR-PRO) up to week 12. The secondary outcome measure is the percentage of participants achieving clinical remission per Harvey Bradshaw Index (HBI) among those with clinical response-HBI at end of induction therapy at week 52.

[/INST] The study is titled "Testing of Online Version of QAPS" and is a study on child development. The study is designed to assess prewriting skills in children aged 3 to 7 years old. The study involves playing a drawing game on a tablet, copying shapes using a pencil in a paper booklet, writing letters, and cutting paper with scissors. The study also includes surveys and questionnaires about the child's development. The study measures include Online QAPS, Beery VMI, functional hand tasks, demographics survey, emotionality assessment, strengths and difficulties questionnaire inattention/hyperactivity subscale, and ego resiliency scale. The study is conducted in the United States.

[/INST] The Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) is a 9-month program that aims to help individuals with psychotic disorders who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities. The program involves two phases: Initiation, Try-Out, and Transfer of Care. The CTI-PS workers collaborate with the participants to identify barriers to their recovery and develop a sustainable plan to engage in and use community supports and resources during and after CTI. The program aims to strengthen the participants' connection to health services and expand their support networks. The program is delivered by Community Mental Health Workers (CMHWs) and Peer Support Workers (PSWs) who are selected, recruited, and trained by members of the research team to deliver mental health care according to the manualized recovery-oriented program. Ongoing regular supervision of PSWs and CMHWs is conducted throughout the study. The primary outcome measure is the WHOQOL-BREF, and the secondary outcome measures are the Camberwell Assessment of Need (CAN), Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS), WHO Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS 2.0), INSPIRE - Research Into Recovery, Internalized Stigma of Mental Illness (ISMI), and WHO Alcohol, Smoking and Substance Involvement Screening Test Schedule (WHO ASSIST).

[/INST] The Registry for Vascular Trauma and Follow-up Examinations is a prospective observational study that aims to collect data on patients with vascular injuries. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older who have experienced vascular trauma and have given written informed consent, except for those who are deceased from trauma sequelae. The study is designed to follow up on patients for a period of 1 year after the trauma, with assessments at 3, 6, and 12 months. The primary outcome measure is the patency of vessels/grafts, which is assessed using ultrasound, ABI-measurement, and clinical evaluation. The secondary outcome measure is the reintervention rate, which is assessed through the treatment of complications such as graft occlusion or stenosis. The study also aims to develop treatment patterns and assess the development of complications. The keywords related to the study include trauma, vascular trauma, bleeding, ischemia, and registry.

[/INST] The study is a prospective randomized control trial that will be conducted to evaluate the effects of blood flow restriction (BFR) rehabilitation after open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) of distal radius fractures. The study will include subjects aged 18 years or older with acute fracture of the distal radius requiring ORIF surgery. The subjects will be divided into two groups based on age, then subsequently be randomly divided into two groups following their inclusion in the study. One group will undergo the normal rehabilitation protocol for the hand and wrist as determined by Dr. Liberman. The study group will undergo rehabilitation protocol for distal radius fractures modified by use of a tourniquet for blood flow restriction during selected exercises. The study will measure the effects of BFR rehabilitation on body composition, bone density, grip strength, pinch grip strength, DASH survey, Michigan Hand Outcomes survey, and Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine the effect of a computer prompt intervention on reducing sitting time, musculoskeletal symptoms, cardiometabolic markers, and physical activity in office workers. The study will use a computer prompt intervention, which will be delivered through a desktop application. The intervention will be compared to a control group that will receive educational information. The study will use a two-arm randomized controlled trial design, with the intervention group receiving the computer prompt intervention and the control group receiving educational information. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, with quantitative and qualitative data collected at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. The primary outcome measure will be sedentary behavior, which will be measured objectively using accelerometers and subjectively using a questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures will include musculoskeletal symptoms, cardiometabolic markers, and physical activity. The study will use a randomized block design to assign participants to the intervention or control group. The study will use a parallel assignment model, with the intervention and control groups receiving the intervention at different time points. The study will use a single-blinded design, with the participants and researchers being blinded to the group assignment.
