[/INST] The study is titled "The Chronic Effects of Low-Load Blood Flow Restriction and Creatine Supplementation in Women" and is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. The study aims to investigate the effects of creatine supplementation and low-load blood flow restriction exercise on strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, endothelial function, and mood states in women. The study will last for 9 months and will involve 4 groups of women: a control group, a creatine and blood flow restriction exercise group, a creatine and no-blood flow restriction exercise group, and a placebo and blood flow restriction exercise group. The study will use creatine monohydrate powder, blood flow restriction cuffs, isokinetic dynamometer, BodPod, flow-mediated dilation, and questionnaires as measures. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Quebec, Canada.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the potential of growth differentiation factor 15 (GDF-15) and neurofilament light chain (Nfl) as biomarkers for anorexia nervosa (AN). The study will involve 8 AN patients with the restricting type, non-exercising subtype, 8 AN patients with the restricting type, exercising subtype, and 16 healthy controls. The study will measure the levels of GDF-15 and Nfl in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of the participants. The study will also assess the body composition of the participants using dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scans and indirect calorimetry. The study will compare the levels of GDF-15 and Nfl in the plasma and CSF of AN patients and healthy controls. The study will also correlate the levels of GDF-15 and Nfl with body composition and energy expenditure. The study will evaluate the potential of GDF-15 and Nfl as biomarkers for AN and set the basis for a follow-up study using neutralizing antibodies or inhibitors against GDF-15 and the respective cytokines for the treatment of AN.

[/INST] The PROSPECT study is a prospective, observational study that aims to collect data on complications and other outcomes from patients undergoing pleural procedures. The study will collect data on demographics, smoking history, pre-procedure observations, radiological findings, and medical history. Complications will be recorded at 1 month after the procedure according to specified criteria. The study will also collect data on patient-reported outcomes of chest pain and dyspnoea before and after the procedure and at a further time interval within 4 weeks. The study will collect data from at least 20 centres, including both district general and tertiary referral centres. The data collected will provide a best practice standard against which new and smaller volume centres can benchmark practice.

[/INST] The study is titled "Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease" and is a single-center, prospective and retrospective study. The study aims to develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-based model for risk stratification of coronary artery disease (CAD) patients. The model will integrate clinical and imaging data to identify and categorize patients at high risk of disease progression and provide a more personalized management approach to improve patient outcomes. The study will use a retrospective cohort of 2500 patients who underwent a clinically indicated coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) examination for CAD evaluation. A prospective cohort of 500 patients undergoing a clinically indicated cCTA for CAD evaluation will also be enrolled. The primary outcome measure is a composite outcome of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction. The secondary outcome measure is a composite outcome of all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization. The study will use artificial intelligence techniques such as machine learning and deep learning to develop the model. The model will be validated using machine learning techniques such as cross-validation and bootstrapping. The study will also develop a platform for the external validation of the algorithm and its integration into the clinical workflow. The platform will be characterized by state-of-the-art security measures, interoperability with current clinical software, and easy-to-use interface. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida. The study will last for 54 months, starting from the beginning of the study (month 0). The study will enroll 2500 patients in the retrospective cohort and 500 patients in the prospective cohort. The study will end at month 54, when the last patient in the prospective cohort will have completed 36 months of follow-up.

[/INST] The SIM0355-201 trial is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled exploratory clinical trial with the main study objective of evaluating the safety and tolerability of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol concentrate for injection combined with conventional medical therapy in patients with cerebral hemorrhage. The subject had a clinical diagnosis of cerebral hemorrhage, within 6-24 hours from stroke onset to start of study treatment, with the bleeding site in basal ganglia and a hematoma volume ≤ 30 ml at the bleeding site. The trial was divided into two periods (Period A and Period B), with Period A being a dose escalation period divided into two dose levels: the first dose level group (Dose 1 group: Synbixin 37.5 mg; placebo group) and the second dose level group (Dose 2 group: Synbixin 62.5 mg; placebo group). Safety was assessed unblinding after the end of study treatment for all subjects in the first dose level group and escalated to the second dose level if the safe dose criterion was met, otherwise the trial was terminated; safety was assessed unblinding after the end of study treatment for all subjects in the second dose level group and the 62.5 mg dose level was selected to enter Stage B if the safe dose criterion was met, otherwise the 37.5 mg dose level was selected to enter Stage B.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. The purpose of the study is to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting body rehabilitation in patients with novel coronavirus infection. The study will recruit middle-aged and elderly outpatients aged 50-80 years with COVID-19 who have entered the convalescence phase. The main clinical manifestations are fatigue, shortness of breath, cough (satisfying at least two main symptoms), and the results of 6-minute walking test are less than 80% of the predicted value (about 450-500 meters). The study will use Manzhi Guben granules as the experimental group and placebo as the control group. The main outcome measures are the results of 6-minute walking test on the 14th and 28th days after treatment. The results of pulmonary ventilation function on the 14th and 28th days after treatment will be the secondary outcome measures. The study will evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting body rehabilitation in patients with novel coronavirus infection.

[/INST] The study is a non-interventional fMRI study on the neural bases of decision-making in healthy individuals. The study aims to provide novel insights into the relationship between executive and decision-making skills, and their possible changes with ageing, in 150 healthy individuals. This goal will be pursued by combining a behavioral assessment of decision-making and executive skills with a multimodal fMRI session including data concerning a) brain activity associated with decision-making and executive functioning in social vs. non-social contexts, b) brain structural morphometry (grey-matter volume/density), and c) brain structural connectivity (diffusion weighted imaging). The behavioral assessment will involve the main metric of decision-making (e.g., risk aversion, loss aversion, delay discounting) and executive functioning (e.g., selective attention and inhibitory control). MRI data will unveil the neural bases of individual differences in decision-making and executive performance in terms of performance-related patterns of brain activity, structure and connectivity. Results will provide an useful baseline for investigating alterations of decision-making and executive functioning, and of their neural bases, in pathological conditions.

[/INST] The Neutrocheck Summative Usability Study is a study that aims to investigate the usability of Neutrocheck among healthy volunteers and healthcare professionals. The study will use paper instructions and app instructions to assess the effectiveness of key information for safety, user satisfaction, and task completion rates. The study will use descriptive statistics and Fisher's exact test to analyze the data collected from the questionnaires and observations. The study will run for two months.

[/INST] The study is titled "Promoting BEST (BEtter, Faster, Longer, STronger) Walking for People With Parkinson's" and is a research program with the global aim of identifying technical, attitudinal, and motivational obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's to use technology to improve gait. The study will use a Heel2Toe sensor to provide real-time auditory feedback to the participants when they take a good step, one in which the step is initiated with a strong heel strike. The study will use a blocked, stepped-wedge design, with half of the participants assigned to receive the sensor immediately and the other half assigned to receive the sensor after a delay of 3 to 4 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the angular velocity of the ankle at heel strike, the angular velocity of the ankle during push-off, and the angular velocity of the ankle during foot swing, all averaged over a walk of at least 50 steps. The secondary outcome measures will include motivation, apathy, walking behavior, health-related quality of life, cognitive ability, and cognitive performance. The study will use a smartphone to collect data on the participants' gait and other metrics, and the data will be analyzed using machine learning algorithms. The study will be conducted in Quebec, Canada, and the participants will be people with Parkinson's who meet the technology readiness criteria. The study will run for 1 year, and the participants will be assessed at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year. The study will be conducted by Centre Hospitalier Valida in Quebec, Canada.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effects of a laughter yoga program on the mood, anxiety, and loneliness of adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities. The study will be conducted in a special school in Hong Kong. The intervention group will receive a 4-week laughter yoga program, while the control group will receive routine care provided by the school. The primary outcome measures are mood, anxiety, and loneliness, which will be assessed using the Mood Scale, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-6), and UCLA Loneliness Scale (ULS-8), respectively. The study will provide preliminary evidence on the feasibility and effectiveness of laughter yoga for adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of decision aids on the participation of South Asian women in cervical cancer screening. The study will compare three different types of decision aids: a printed decision aid, a printed leaflet, and a mobile app. The study will measure the effectiveness of the decision aids in terms of decisional conflict, cervical cancer screening uptake, risk perception, choice predisposition, and choice question. The study will also assess the feasibility of using decision aids in this population.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the additional effect of forward head posture (FHP) correction on myogenic temporomandibular dysfunction (TMD). The primary outcome measure will be the anamnestic questionnaire by Fonseca, and the secondary outcome measures will be craniocervical angle (CVA), Boley Gauge, Visual Analog Scale (VAS), and mandibular opening. [/INST] The SENIOR RCT is a multicenter study conducted in two North Italian Scientific Hospitalization and Treatment Institution in Pavia on older malnourished adults (≥ 65 years old). The estimated duration is 24 months, which include 6 months of nutritional intervention and a follow-up after 6 months, with an preferred starting date on January 2024. The primary objective of the SENIOR RCT is the evaluation of the efficacy of a 6 months sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults participants (diagnosed with the most recent GLIM criteria) in comparison to the hospital standard of care. Therefore, the primary endpoint is the improvement of the nutritional status between pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group measuring the change of body weight and strength (handgrip). Secondary objectives are the change pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group for blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life and evaluation of sarcopenia. Secondary endpoints are the change pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group for blood biomarkers, MEDI-LITE score, SF-12, diet composition, phase angle and gait speed. Participants of this study are older adults over 65 previously enrolled in the SENIOR cross-sectional study and willing to participate to the RCT phase or new enrolled patients from the two hospitals in according to the eligible criteria. Malnutrition will be diagnosed according to GLIM criteria, using Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) as screening tool. The experimental group at the baseline will receive a nutritional assessment followed by the elaboration of a sustainable and personalized nutritional protocol by qualified dietitians. The intervention will last 6 months with a monthly evaluation of the dietary consumption of the previous 24 hour (recall-24h), followed by a final follow-up after additional 6 months. For both groups at the baseline will be measured blood biomarkers, anthropometric variables, Mediterranean diet adherence, quality of life, strength (handgrip) and locomotion (gait speed). At 3 months weight and strength will be evaluated. At 6- and 12-months baseline measurements will be repeated except for the nutritional assessment. Dietary habits

[/INST] The study is a prospective observational cohort study that aims to investigate the dynamic changes of Torquetenovirus (TTV) load in Chinese renal transplant recipients during immunosuppressive therapy. The study will include patients who have received ABO compatible renal allotransplantation, tacrolimus/mycophenolate mofetil/prednisone as maintenance immunosuppression after renal transplantation, and universal prophylaxis for CMV infection and PJP infection. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of biopsy-proven acute rejection and clinical diagnosed acute rejection within 365 days after kidney transplantation. The secondary outcome measures are the incidence of any bacterial, fungal, mycobacterial, or viral infection requiring hospitalization or prolongation of hospitalization, or requiring intravenous antibiotics or therapeutic use of antiviral drugs, or requiring reduction of immunosuppressive drugs within 365 days after kidney transplantation. The study will also investigate the development of de novo DSA or a 30% increase of MFI value in preformed DSA, and an increase in absolute or percent donor derived-cell free DNA from 1 month post-transplant within 365 days after kidney transplantation. The study will be conducted in China and is expected to last for 3 years.

[/INST] The study aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin B12 and B3 on nerve regeneration and functional recovery after pediatric traumatic brain injury (TBI). The study was a non-randomized trial with a sample size of 300 participants aged 6 to 15 years with severe TBI. The participants were divided into two groups, with one group receiving vitamin B3 and the other group receiving vitamin B12. The study used a range of tests to evaluate cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity, and gait analysis. The study found that vitamin B12 was more effective than vitamin B3 in improving functional recovery after TBI. The study concluded that vitamin B12 may be a potential treatment for pediatric TBI.

[/INST] The study is a phase III clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of pyrotinib in women with high-risk early or locally advanced breast cancer. The study will enroll patients who have been treated for early breast cancer with standard of care duration of trastuzumab combined with pertuzumab or T-DM1. The primary outcome measure is invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at year 2. The study will enroll 1,000 participants and the follow-up period is up to 2 years.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the impact of the timing of pasta consumption on multiple health outcomes. The study will be conducted in two phases, with each phase lasting 3 months. In the first phase, participants will be asked to consume pasta at dinner, and in the second phase, participants will be asked to consume pasta at lunch. The primary outcome measure is sleep quality, which will be assessed using actigraphy. Secondary outcome measures include weight change, body mass index, fat mass changes, basal metabolic rate, fasting blood glucose, glycated haemoglobin, total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, triglycerides, homocysteine, aspartate transaminase, alanine transaminase, gamma-glutamyl transferase, urea, creatinine, uric acid, gut microbiota profile, circadian rhythms, TBARS, ROS, leptin, ghrelin, insulin, IL-6, and C-Peptide YY. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee.

[/INST] The study is a phase II trial evaluating 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT in multiple myeloma. The study will enroll 55 participants with multiple myeloma who will undergo 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT at three time points: Timepoint #1, Timepoint #2 (after induction for NDMM or at 6 months for RRMM), and Timepoint #3 (at progression or at 5 years). The results will be compared to 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging at those same time points. The primary outcome measure is the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in participants with multiple myeloma. The secondary outcome measures are the efficacy of 18F-fluciclovine in measuring disease volume as compared to other indicators of disease volume, the ability of 18F-fluciclovine to identify minimal residual disease (MRD) as compared to MRD status determined by bone marrow flow cytometry or next generation sequencing (NGS), and the ability for 18F-fluciclovine to evaluate response after treatment as compared to the IMWG response criteria.

[/INST] The study titled "Arm Swing During Walking in Early Multiple Sclerosis" is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the arm swing amplitude and functional tests in patients with early multiple sclerosis (MS). The study will include 30 patients with early MS and 30 healthy controls. The patients will be evaluated at baseline and 3 months later. The primary outcome measures are arm swing amplitude in the shoulder, elbow, and overall degrees in the flexion-extension direction. The secondary outcome measures are step speed, two-minute walk test (2MWT), timed up and go (TUG), and timed 25-foot walk test (T25FW). The study will use the Kinovea video player to evaluate the arm swing amplitude and the FreeMed foot pressure analysis system to measure the step speed. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France. The study is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of adjuvant pyrotinib and capecitabine in patients with HER2-positive microinvasive breast cancer. The study will compare the efficacy of pyrotinib and capecitabine with that of no adjuvant chemotherapy or targeted therapy. The primary outcome measure is invasive disease-free survival (iDFS), and the secondary outcome measures are distant disease-free survival (DDFS) and overall survival (OS).

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of two interventions, video biofeedback and laryngeal control therapy, in the treatment of paradoxical vocal fold motion (PVFM). The primary outcome measure is the change in Dyspnea Index score before and one month after treatment. The study aims to provide critical data for designing a fully powered trial comparing these two interventions and to advance the investigators' goal of providing clinicians with important evidence for guiding treatment.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter clinical trial with a quasi-experimental design. The study aims to evaluate the implementation of a multifaceted and multidisciplinary protocol to promote an improvement in sleep quality in critically ill patients. The protocol includes behavioral interventions such as adjusting sound intensity, as well as reducing noise, providing earplugs and eye masks, and adjusting thermal comfort. The study will assess the change in the Richards-Campbell Sleep Quality Score before and one month after the implementation of the sleep protocol. The study will also assess the change in the Sleep in the ICU Questionnaire, the Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU, the Questionnaire on the patient's perception of sleep from the family member's point of view, the Questionnaire for the evaluation of the multidisciplinary team regarding prior knowledge of sleep protocol, and the Questionnaire for assessing and perceiving patients' sleep from the point of view of the care team. The study will also assess the change in the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and Epworth Sleepiness Scale at three and six months after hospital discharge.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a community pharmacy-based program to enhance adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy among breast cancer survivors. The program consists of a web-based training for pharmacists and standardized consultation guides, video capsules, and web sheets for women. The program will be evaluated through a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative components. The quantitative component will assess the program's impact on adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy, while the qualitative component will provide insights into the program's acceptability and feasibility. The study will be conducted in 66 community pharmacies in Quebec, Canada, and will involve 132 women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer and are initiating adjuvant endocrine therapy. The study will last for 6 months, and the primary outcome will be the intention to adhere to adjuvant endocrine therapy. The study will provide valuable insights into the feasibility and acceptability of the program and its potential impact on adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy among breast cancer survivors.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, crossover trial that aims to investigate the effects of a formulated Melissa officinalis extract in phytosome form (Melissa Phytosome-based product) on sleep quality and duration. The study will be conducted in Italy and will involve 30 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of two groups. The first group will receive the Melissa Phytosome-based product for 14 days, followed by a placebo for 14 days, and the second group will receive the placebo for 14 days, followed by the Melissa Phytosome-based product for 14 days. The primary outcome measure will be sleep duration, assessed using a sleep monitoring device. The secondary outcome measures will be perceived sleep quality, perceived anxiety levels, quality of life, and adverse symptoms, assessed using questionnaires. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent Data Safety Monitoring Board. The results of the study will contribute to the understanding of the potential benefits of the Melissa Phytosome-based product for sleep quality and duration.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, multicenter, open-label, randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of lenvatinib plus tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy as first-line treatment for advanced gastric cancer or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with positive PD-L1 and low TMEscore. The study will enroll 120 patients who will be randomly assigned to the experimental arm or the active comparator arm. The experimental arm will receive lenvatinib plus tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy, while the active comparator arm will receive tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy. The primary endpoint is progression-free survival. The secondary endpoints are overall survival, objective response rate, disease control rate, and duration of response. The study will have a follow-up period of 3 years.

[/INST] The R61 phase is a single-arm trial of S-ENG plus eCAU (n=30) with 1 week of smartphone-based target assessment at baseline, 8-weeks and 16-weeks. Participants are 30 adults age 60 and older who report clinically significant loneliness and suicide ideation and reside in a senior living community (SLC). We will use ambulatory assessment via smartphones, including both active self-report (ecological momentary assessment, EMA) and passive sensing (audio recordings & GPS) to comprehensively assess indices of social connection. Subjects will complete EMA recordings using a smartphone daily following 3 personally-selected times for prompts (to enhance recall and ease of completion of assessments) for 10-days prior to starting study interventions, beginning the day after the baseline visit. Each EMA instance takes approximately 2-5 minutes to complete. EMA will be integrated with other smartphone technology to passively capture social behavior. The Electronically Activated Recorder (EAR) will passively measure social behavior (i.e., conversation frequency, duration, and valence). GPS- will track time outside the home. Subjects will be given a study smartphone designed for older adults to use during assessment periods. All subjects who successfully complete the smartphone assessment protocol at baseline will be assigned to S-ENG. S-ENG involves 10 individual coaching sessions over (up to) 4 months. S-ENG is a stepped, modular intervention that addresses barriers to action plan implementation and challenges in processing positive outcomes when exposed to socially rewarding activities. Psychoeducational materials address the importance of social connection. Subjects complete a values clarification exercise on aspects of connection most important to participants to inform personalized activities most likely to impact loneliness. Coaches are instructed to focus action plans on activities that foster social connection. The follow-up assessments at 8- and 16-weeks include baseline measures and smartphone measures.

[/INST] The study is a phase IV, open-label, randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with premature ovarian insufficiency. The study will compare the effectiveness of two different doses of estradiol gel (1.5 mg and 2.0 mg) in women with POI. The primary outcome measure is the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms, and the secondary outcome measures are the quality of life and the level of sex hormones. The study will be conducted in two stages, with a 3-month follow-up period for each stage. The study will assess the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with POI.

[/INST] The Symbiont-Restore Study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to investigate the effects of a probiotic, prebiotic, and synbiotic supplementation on the gut microbiome, immune system, and metabolome in adults with a BMI of 30-40 kg/m². The study will last for eight weeks and will involve the consumption of a probiotic capsule containing L. reuteri PB-W1™, a prebiotic blend of 50 % raffinose and 50 % xylooligosaccharide, or a combination of both. The primary outcome measure is the change in the immune profile at eight weeks, and secondary outcome measures include the change in the faecal microbiome composition and diversity, metabolic profile, satiety rating, gastrointestinal tolerance to dietary fibre, and adverse events. The study will be conducted in Australia and Papua New Guinea.

[/INST] The study is a phase I, single-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-escalation study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 in healthy subjects. The study will enroll 48 healthy subjects who will be randomly assigned to one of seven groups to receive a single oral dose of AD16 or placebo. The primary outcome measures are the number of adverse events, serious adverse events, and the number of participants with abnormal laboratory test results, vital signs, 12-lead electrocardiogram readings, and physical examinations. The secondary outcome measures are the number of participants with concomitant medication, the number of participants with abnormal Ae, Fe0-t, renal clearance, and the number of participants with abnormal Tmax, Cmax, t1/2z, AUC0-∞, AUC0-t, CL/F, Vd/F, λz, and MRT.

[/INST] The study aims to measure the effect of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and serum biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. Participants will be randomly assigned to intervention or control group. Those in the intervention group will consume 1,000 mg of urolithin A daily in the form of softgel capsules, whereas those in the control group will consume a placebo. Data collection will occur at baseline (day 0) and endpoint (day 28). The investigators expect that urolithin A supplementation in middle-aged adults with obesity improves endothelial function and cerebral blood flow regulation, and that this improvement is accompanied by changes in biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function.

[/INST] The study aimed to examine the effects of vibration applied at different frequencies with a percussion massage gun on joint range of motion, pain, functionality and kinesiophobia in individuals with cervical disc herniation. The study was a randomized controlled trial with two groups: a control group and a vibration group. The control group received a conventional treatment program consisting of heat and TENS application, joint range of motion exercises, and isometric exercises. The vibration group received the same conventional treatment program in addition to vibration application with a percussion massage gun. The vibration was applied to the trapezius, levator scapula and cervical paravertebral muscles with a percussion massage gun for 3 minutes for each muscle group, 3 days a week for 3 weeks. The primary outcome measure was joint position sense, which was evaluated with the Laser Cursor Assisted Angle Repetition Test (LI-YATT). The secondary outcome measures were neck disability, pain intensity, and kinesiophobia, which were evaluated with the Neck Disability Index (NDI) scale, Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), and Tampa Kinesiophobia Scale (TKÖ), respectively. The study found that vibration application with a percussion massage gun did not have any additional effects on joint position sense, neck disability, pain intensity, or kinesiophobia in individuals with cervical disc herniation.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to adapt and pilot test a group-level intervention called Tele-B6 for HIV-positive Black gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (YB-GBMSM) living in the Atlanta metropolitan area. The intervention is based on the original B6 intervention, which was developed to improve the resilience of YB-GBMSM to HIV and other adversities. The Tele-B6 intervention is designed to be delivered via videoconferencing and will include six weekly group sessions. The study will evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the Tele-B6 intervention by comparing it to a waitlist control group. The study will also assess the impact of the Tele-B6 intervention on the acceptability of HIV prevention and treatment services, retention in care, and viral suppression. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis. The quantitative data will be collected through surveys and interviews, and the qualitative data will be collected through focus groups and interviews. The study will also use a community-based participatory research approach, which will involve engaging community members in all stages of the research process.

[/INST] The Effects of Caregiver Training on Dynamic Temporal and Tactile Cueing (DTTC) Treatment Outcomes in Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS) is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the impact of parent/caregiver involvement on DTTC treatment outcomes in children with CAS. The study will compare two groups of children with CAS who will receive either DTTC treatment alone or DTTC treatment combined with parent/caregiver coaching. The study will examine the effects of the interventions on word accuracy, phoneme accuracy, speech intelligibility, and functional communication. The study will also examine the effects of the interventions on the FOCUS-34 score, a parent survey measure that assesses children's communication skills. The study will use a multifactor whole-word accuracy measure (Multilevel word Accuracy Composite Scale (MACS); Case et al., in press) to calculate a composite score for segmental accuracy, word shape maintenance, prosodic accuracy, and smoothness/fluency of movement transitions. The study will use the Intelligibility in Context Scale (ICS; McLeod et al., 2012) to assess children's intelligibility. The study will use the Functional Outcomes on Communication Under Six (FOCUS-34; Thomas-Stonell et al., 2015) to assess children's communication skills. The study will use the Dynamic Tactile and Temporal Cueing (DTTC) intervention. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design. The study will recruit 40 children with CAS between 2;5 and 7;11 years of age. The study will randomize the children to one of two groups: 1) Direct Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Direct Caregiver Training); 2) Indirect Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Indirect Caregiver Training). The study will administer the interventions over 16 weeks. The study will assess the children's outcomes at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and 1-week and 4-week post-treatment follow-up. The study will use a mixed-effects model to analyze the data. The study will use the following statistical tests: t-tests, ANOVA, and mixed-effects

[/INST] The study is a single-center, non-randomized, controlled trial that aims to evaluate the impact of self-help and support groups on the quality of life of laryngectomized patients. The study will include laryngectomized patients who wish and can participate in these groups. The sessions will take place as follows: 1st: presentation of each, answers to questions; 2nd: intervention of the association of the mutilated of the voice; 3rd: questions / answers with a resource patient (laryngectomized for 13 years in Bichat); 4th: grouping of all participants to assess patient satisfaction. To assess the benefit of these meetings, a global quality of life questionnaire (WHOQOL-BREF) and an ENT-specific questionnaire (EORTC QLQH&n43) will be given to patients before the first session and retrieved beforehand. The patient will be able to participate in the sessions only if the questionnaires are submitted. The number of patients registered and the participation rate at each session will be evaluated.

[/INST] The MS-DETECT study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the MSCopilot® Detect mobile application in detecting disability progression in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients. The study will enroll patients with relapsing-remitting or secondary progressive MS who are aged 30 to 65 years and have an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score of 2.5 to 6.5. Patients will be followed for up to 24 months and will undergo digital tests and standard tests in the clinic at baseline, month 6, month 12, month 18, and month 24. The primary outcome measure of the study is to evaluate the sensitivity of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting disability worsening based on the revised Multiple Sclerosis Composite Score (revised-MSFC) scores. The study will also evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting confirmed disability worsening (CDW) based on the EDSS, the time to progression-free events based on MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores, the association between digital and clinical scores, the reproducibility of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores between in-clinic and at-home digital tests, the reliability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores at-home over time, the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to discriminate between a relapse and a momentary disability worsening, the adherence to the MSCopilot® Detect smartphone application, the satisfaction and user experience with the MSCopilot® Detect smartphone application and the MSCopilot® Detect web dashboard, and the satisfaction and user experience with the MSCopilot® Detect web dashboard.

[/INST] The PCOS Challenge Study is a registry study that aims to collect information to advance research and improve care for PCOS patients. The study is open to individuals who have been diagnosed with PCOS by a healthcare provider, self-diagnosed with PCOS, or who are exhibiting PCOS symptoms and are willing to sign the consent. The study will collect information such as responses to survey questions over a one-year period. The study is conducted by Centre Hospitalier Valida and is not currently recruiting participants.

[/INST] The study is a cluster-randomized trial of low molecular weight heparins (LMWHs) in patients with an indication for LMWHs. The study compares the efficacy and safety of two LMWHs, dalteparin and tinzaparin, in preventing thrombosis and bleeding. The primary outcome is the risk of bleeding requiring blood transfusion during admission or death within 30 days of administering one of the studied drugs. The secondary outcomes include the risk of all-cause mortality within 30 and 365 days of administering one of the studied drugs, blood transfusion during admission, and the risk of pulmonary embolism and deep venous thrombosis within 90 days of administering one of the studied drugs. The study also assesses the risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, liver failure, length of hospital admission, and days alive out of hospital. The study is a cluster-randomized trial, with patients being randomly assigned to receive either dalteparin or tinzaparin. The study is open-label, with the patients and healthcare providers being aware of the treatment received. The study is being conducted in Denmark and Sweden.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effects of inspiratory and expiratory muscle training on respiratory muscle strength, pulmonary volume, and pulmonary flow in patients with acquired brain injury. The study is conducted in Spain and is currently in the recruitment phase. The study is designed to have two parallel arms, with one arm receiving inspiratory muscle training and the other arm receiving expiratory muscle training. The study is expected to be completed by December 2022.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of technological rehabilitation on functional, motor, and cognitive outcomes in patients with multiple sclerosis. The study will be conducted at the Multiple Sclerosis Rehabilitation Unit of the University of Rome "Tor Vergata" and will involve 40 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will receive technological rehabilitation using the Hunova platform, while the control group will receive conventional rehabilitation. The primary outcome measure will be the Berg Balance Scale, and the secondary outcome measures will include the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale, Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Function, Timed Up and Go test, Ambulation Index, 10 Meter Walk Test, Six-minute walk test, Multiple Sclerosis Walking Scale, Modified Barthel Index, Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale, Beck Depression Inventory-II, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, Stroop Colour Word Test, and Symbol Digit Modalities Test. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be monitored by an independent Data Safety Monitoring Board. The results of the study will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and international scientific conferences.

[/INST] The ASARD-TMA study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an automated algorithm in diagnosing and treating thrombotic microangiopathies (TMA). The algorithm is designed to speed up the diagnosis and treatment of TMA in smaller hospitals that do not have a 24-hour hematological guard service available and the same awareness for TMA. The study will run for 24 months and will evaluate the time of diagnosis and treatment of TMA.

[/INST] The study is a feasibility study to test the Access-H2O faucet, which is a sensor-driven smart faucet designed to enable and empower individuals with spinal cord injuries to access water for drinking, rinsing, and grooming. The faucet incorporates electromechanical controls and software programs that adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. A proximity sensor and voice recognition function allow users to control the faucet through a smart speaker. These features enable precise dispensing of water at the desired temperature and volume, while a camera and other sensors enable hands-free operation. The study recruited subjects with spinal cord injuries and controls from an outpatient rehabilitation clinic to test the functionality of the faucet. The subjects were screened to determine their levels of functional independence, and they were also interviewed regarding their current methods of drinking, rinsing, and grooming. The percentage and standard deviation of individuals in each level of independence for each function were calculated. A t-test was conducted to determine any significant differences in the dependence levels between the tested subjects and the control group.

[/INST] The study aimed to evaluate the effect of an intermittent teaching unit on physical activity and its psychological mediators in students. The study was a cluster-randomized controlled trial with two parallel arms: an intermittent teaching unit and a control group. The intermittent teaching unit was designed to promote healthy physical activity habits and consisted of an intermittent teaching unit twice a week for eight weeks. The control group did not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures were perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation towards physical education, and motivation towards physical activity. The secondary outcome measures were intention to be physically active and habitual physical activity. The study found that the intermittent teaching unit had a positive effect on perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation towards physical education, and motivation towards physical activity. The study also found that the intermittent teaching unit had a positive effect on intention to be physically active, but not on habitual physical activity.

[/INST] The study is titled "Continuous and Non-invasive Measurements by Task Force® CORE/CARDIO in Autonomic Function Testing (AFT)" and is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the agreement of blood pressure and heart rate measurements between an investigational device and a reference device. The study will include patients with orthostatic intolerance and will assess the agreement of blood pressure and heart rate measurements during the supine baseline period, during and after the Valsalva maneuver, during the deep breathing test, and during the head-up tilt test. The study will also assess the agreement of cardiac output measurements during the supine baseline period, during and after the Valsalva maneuver, during the deep breathing test, and during the head-up tilt test. The study will use the Task Force® CORE/CARDIO as the investigational device and the Task Force® Monitor as the reference device. The study will use the Bland-Altman method to assess the agreement of the measurements. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The proposed study aims to develop and evaluate a regional mental health hub for post-secondary students in the Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington (KFL&A) region in Ontario, Canada. The hub will offer a comprehensive care model using a stepped-care approach, including online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs. The study will assess the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs by comparing them to treatment as usual. The study will also evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the hub by assessing student needs, preferences, and experiences. The study will use a mixed-methods design, including surveys, focus groups, and clinical assessments. The study will be conducted in English and will target post-secondary students in the KFL&A region. The study will be led by a research team with expertise in online mental health interventions, clinical psychology, psychiatry, and implementation science. The study will use a cloud-based platform co-developed by the principal investigator to deliver the online interventions. The study will use validated clinical assessment tools to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online interventions. The study will use a rigorous approach to guide the implementation of the mental health hub, including a comprehensive needs assessment, a stepped care approach, and a rigorous evaluation plan. The study will use a community-based participatory approach to engage students, health decision-makers, and end-users in all phases of the research, from conception to implementation. The study will use a digital care plan to support the delivery of the mental health hub, including online interventions, clinical assessments, and referrals to community resources. The study will use artificial intelligence to personalize the online interventions and improve the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the mental health hub. The study will use a mixed-methods approach to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of the mental health hub. The study will use a pragmatic approach to ensure the generalizability of the study findings. The study will use a community-based participatory approach to engage students, health decision-makers, and end-users in all phases of the research, from conception to implementation. The study will use a digital care plan to support the delivery of the mental health hub, including online interventions, clinical assessments, and referrals

[/INST] The study is a randomized, quadruple-masked, parallel-group, active-controlled trial to assess the efficacy of a combination therapy of AV2-SA versus standard SA treatment for cutaneous warts. The study will enroll participants who are at least 12 years old and have one or more cutaneous warts. The primary outcome measure is the cure rate of the index warts at 12 weeks after enrollment. The secondary outcome measures are the recurrence rate of the index warts at 6 months after enrollment, the number of participants with treatment-related adverse events in the AV2-SA treatment group versus the standard SA treatment group, time to clearance of index wart, change in size of index wart, and number of verrucae remaining. The study will determine the genotype-specific distribution of wart-associated HPV types in a Belgian population, the prevalence of mucosal HPV types in cutaneous warts, and investigate the efficacy of AV2-SA combination therapy.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficacy of letrozole to methotrexate in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy. The study includes 75 women who are randomly assigned to three groups. The first group receives a single dose of methotrexate, the second group receives letrozole for 10 days, and the third group receives letrozole for 5 days. The study measures the levels of hCG and anti-mullerian hormone on the first day of treatment and 3 months after treatment. The study aims to determine the efficacy of letrozole in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to evaluate the effect of fenestrated closure compared to non-fenestrated closure to the left ventricular size at systole and diastole in patients with ASD secundum and pulmonary hypertension. The study will include patients who underwent surgical closure of ASD with fenestrated or non-fenestrated patch. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole, which will be measured preoperatively and postoperatively. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will include 100 patients. The study will be conducted from January 2017 to October 2021.

[/INST] The study is titled "The Role of Oxidative Stress and Mitochondrial TERT in the Progression and Therapeutic Resistance of Papillary Thyroid Cancer" and aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The study will measure the generation of H202 in papillary thyroid cancer and corresponding normal tissues, TERT mitochondrial localization in papillary thyroid tumors, the effect of exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines, mitochondrial oxidative stress generation in cells lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors, proliferation, apoptosis, migration in cells lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors, genetic characterization of tumor tissues, and expression profile of tumor tissues. The study will use papillary thyroid cancer and corresponding normal tissues, thyroid cancer cell lines, and Src kinase inhibitors. The study will last for 36 months.

[/INST] The study is a phase III randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of whole-body hypothermia to targeted normothermia in infants with mild hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy. The primary outcome measure is the mean cognitive composite score from the Bayley IV examination at 22 to 26 months of age. The study will also assess the number of babies with bloodstream or cerebrospinal fluid positive infection, number of babies exclusively breastfeeding at hospital discharge, and survival without any neurological impairment at 22 to 26 months of age.

[/INST] The study is a phase I/II clinical trial of personalized tumor-trained lymphocytes (pTTL) in patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC). The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the safety of pTTL administration, as determined by the incidence and severity of adverse events (AEs). The secondary objectives are to evaluate the efficacy of pTTL, including objective response rate, time to treatment response, duration of treatment response, time to tumor progression, kinetics of tumor progression/growth (compared to pre-treatment), overall survival, progression-free survival, and disease-specific survival. The study will enroll patients with advanced CRC who have exhausted standard treatment options or who are not candidates for standard treatment. Patients will receive pTTL after pre-conditioning chemotherapy with fludarabine and cyclophosphamide. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of pTTL in a dose-escalation cohort design, with a maximum target dose of 1 billion viable cells per kg body weight. The study will also evaluate the immunological and pharmacokinetic properties of pTTL and the relationship between these properties and clinical outcomes. The study will use a variety of methods to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pTTL, including physical examinations, laboratory tests, radiological examinations, and quality of life assessments. The study will also use next-generation sequencing and bioinformatics to characterize the neoantigens used to generate pTTL and to evaluate the immune response to pTTL. The study will enroll patients with advanced CRC who have exhausted standard treatment options or who are not candidates for standard treatment. Patients will receive pTTL after pre-conditioning chemotherapy with fludarabine and cyclophosphamide. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of pTTL in a dose-escalation cohort design, with a maximum target dose of 1 billion viable cells per kg body weight. The study will also evaluate the immunological and pharmacokinetic properties of pTTL and the relationship between these properties and clinical outcomes. The study will use a variety of methods to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pTTL, including physical examinations, laboratory tests, radiological examinations, and quality

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to determine the diagnostic and prognostic role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The study will include patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis and healthy controls. The primary outcome measure is the correlation of mean serum concentration of SAA in patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis to mean value in healthy controls. The secondary outcome measures are the correlation of SAA at the time of diagnosis of intrathoracic sarcoidosis with serum concentrations of other biomarkers of granulomatous inflammation and pulmonary interstitial disease, pulmonary function test results, radiologic extent of disease, changes in lung function tests and HRCT disease extent after 3 years of follow-up, and the need for recent/ongoing therapy after 3 years of follow-up. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 years for patient enrollment and 3 years for follow-up.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial that aims to evaluate the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first in vitro fertilization. The study will compare the clinical pregnancy rate between the two groups: the experimental group, which will receive a blank culture medium, and the control group, which will not receive any medium. The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate between the two groups, measured on the first-trimester ultrasound at 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The secondary outcome measures are the occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, and live birth. The study will be conducted in France and will involve 10 centers. The study will last for three years, with a one-year follow-up period. The estimated number of participants is 1,000. The study will evaluate the cost-effectiveness of the two strategies.

[/INST] The study is a prospective cohort study that aims to collect baseline information and follow-up information from solid tumor patients who receive immunotherapy for the first time and to build a disease cohort database based on patient reports. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), and the secondary outcome measure is overall survival (OS). The study aims to analyze the risk factors that affect the efficacy and prognosis of immunotherapy and the impact of immunotherapy on health status.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. The study will be conducted in a family health center in Istanbul, Turkey. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the acupressure group or the control group. The acupressure group will receive acupressure treatment twice, once in the first week and once in the fourth week after birth. The control group will not receive any treatment. The primary outcome measure will be the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for assessing back pain. The VAS will be filled in by the participants before and after the application. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the institutional review board.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of two different referral methods for promoting HIV testing among individuals at high risk for HIV infection in Moshi, Tanzania. The two referral methods are: 1) social network referrals using a mobile phone text message-based system (CONSORT referrals) and 2) social network referrals using physical invitation cards (card referrals). The primary outcome measure is the number of referred clients presenting for HIV testing at participating study sites within 30 days of the testing offer, per 100 index clients.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in patients with septic shock. The study will include patients over 18 years of age who have been diagnosed with septic shock for less than 48 hours and are using a minimum dose of noradrenaline (0.01 mcg/kg/min). The intervention will consist of a single dose of paroxetine (40 mg) or placebo, administered orally or through an enteric tube. The primary outcome measure is time to vasopressor discontinuation, and the secondary outcome measures include cumulative vasopressor dose in the first 48 hours after randomization, variation in cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score score, cumulative vasopressor dose for 120 hours after randomization, total sequential organ failure assessment score score variation 24 to 120 hours after randomization, length of stay in the ICU, and mortality during ICU stay. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years, with a follow-up period of 90 days.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a tele-education program on depression in primary care. The program consists of 5 individual remote sessions, each lasting an average of 60 minutes, and is designed to adapt to changes in depressive symptoms over time. The sessions focus on educational diagnosis, personalized hygienic and dietary measures, identifying the symptoms of depression, destigmatization of the illness, mobilization of family and friends, various treatments for depression, and an assessment of what has been learned. The control group will receive usual care from their GP and an educational booklet on depression. The primary endpoint is the rate of maintenance on continuous antidepressant medication at 6 months after inclusion in the study. The secondary endpoints are changes in feelings of self-efficacy and barriers to treatment. The study will be conducted in France and is expected to be completed by December 2023.

[/INST] The study is a pilot observational study that aims to assess the ability of continuous "home" EEG to accurately diagnose narcolepsy and demonstrate response to treatment. The study will recruit participants with narcolepsy type 1, hypersomnia, and age 12 to 25 years. The study will use the Dreem Headband, a home-based EEG device, to collect EEG data from participants. The study will measure the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of the Dreem Headband in diagnosing narcolepsy type 1. The study will also assess the ability of the Dreem Headband to demonstrate response to treatment. The study will collect data for two years.

[/INST] The study is a phase II, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, superiority trial. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida, France. The study will enroll 100 participants who will be randomized to receive either lignocaine-embedded microneedle patch or EMLA patch. The primary outcome measure is the VAS score and skin conductance algesimeter index for pain induced by venepuncture. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference on Harmonization Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study protocol has been approved by the French ethics committee, Comité de Protection des Personnes Sud-Est VI, and has been registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04810133).

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of psychopharmacological intervention, cognitive behavioral couple therapy (CBCT), and their combination in reducing perinatal distress in couples. The study will be conducted in Pakistan and will involve 150 couples who are in the antenatal and postnatal periods. The couples will be randomly assigned to one of the four groups: psychopharmacological intervention, CBCT, combination of psychopharmacological intervention and CBCT, and control group. The intervention will be provided by a gynecologist and a psychologist, and the outcomes will be measured using self-report questionnaires and interviews. The study will be conducted over a period of six months, and the results will be analyzed using intention-to-treat analysis. The study will contribute to the literature on perinatal distress and will provide evidence for the effectiveness of psychopharmacological intervention, CBCT, and their combination in reducing perinatal distress in couples.

[/INST] The study is a phase 1/2, open-label, dose-escalation, and dose-expansion study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of SAR444836, an adeno-associated viral vector-mediated gene transfer of human phenylalanine hydroxylase, in adult participants with phenylketonuria. The study will enroll adult males and females with phenylketonuria due to PAH deficiency. Participants will receive a single dose of SAR444836 on Day 1. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) from baseline to Week 96. The secondary outcome measures are the proportion of participants with sustained plasma level of Phe <360 μmol/L for ≥4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction at Week 24 and Week 96 or End of Study following SAR444836 administration, change from baseline in plasma level of Phe at Week 24 and Week 96 or End of Study following SAR444836 administration, change from baseline in dietary protein intake at Week 24 and Week 96 or End of Study following SAR444836 administration, the proportion of participants with sustained plasma level of Phe <600 μmol/L for ≥ 4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction at Week 24 and Week 96 or End of Study following SAR444836 administration, the proportion of participants with sustained plasma level of Phe <120 μmol/L for ≥ 4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction at Week 24 and Week 96 or End of Study following SAR444836 administration, change from baseline in plasma Phe: Tyr ratio at Week 24 and Week 96 or End of Study following SAR444836 administration, and number of participants with abnormal laboratory chemistry values from baseline to Week 96.

[/INST] The study is titled "Clinical Applicability of pCASL as a Substitute for FDG-PET in MCI and SCD Patients" and is a single-center, prospective, observational study. The study aims to evaluate the clinical applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) as a substitute for fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) in mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD) patients. The study will compare the diagnostic accuracy of pCASL with FDG-PET in detecting cerebral hypoperfusion and hypometabolism in MCI and SCD patients. The study will also evaluate the predictive value of pCASL and FDG-PET for conversion to dementia and the correlation of pCASL and FDG-PET with CSF and blood biomarkers. The study will include 100 patients with MCI or SCD who will undergo pCASL and FDG-PET. The study will have a 1-year and 2-year follow-up. The study will evaluate the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline, the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline according to CSF profile, differences among brain hypoperfusion patterns according to amyloid and tau status, correlations between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological tests, and predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism for conversion to dementia. The study will use the Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM) software to analyze the data. The study will use the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve to determine the optimal cut-off values for cerebral blood flow indices and SUVr to predict conversion to dementia. The study will use the Pearson correlation coefficient to determine the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological tests, CSF and blood biomarkers. The study will use the independent t-test to determine the differences among brain hypoperfusion patterns according to amyloid and tau status. The study will use the Mann-Whitney U test to determine the differences in brain perfusion

[/INST] The study is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter, observational safety surveillance study of VyndaMx® (Tafamidis Capsule 61 mg) in patients with transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. The study aims to assess the safety of VyndaMx® Capsules in patients with ATTR-CM. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the safety of VyndaMx® Capsules in patients with ATTR-CM. The study will collect safety-related data for 6 months from the first dosing of Tafamidis Capsules and will record these data on the Case report Form. The study will be conducted in India.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients undergoing median sternotomy. The study will compare the use of the STERN FIX device in combination with wires to close the sternum to the use of wires alone. The primary outcome measure is sternal stability, which will be assessed using the sternal instability scale (SIS) with grades 0 to 3 where 0 is clinical stable sternum and 3 is completely separated sternum - entire length. The study will also assess safety, sternal wound infections, dehiscence, reinterventions, chest pain, blood loss, upper limb functional index, quality of life, sternal halves union/malunion, sternal halves alignment, sternum integrity, and closure system integrity. The study will be conducted in the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of an active break intervention on low back pain and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting among young people. The study will compare the effects of an active break intervention with self-care recommendations on pain intensity, disability, perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting, and global perceived effect. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with a pre- and post-intervention assessment. The participants will be recruited from students and will be randomly assigned to the intervention group consisting of an active break or the control group. The intervention group will receive an active break intervention with lumbar and hip extension exercises for every 30 minutes of sitting, while the control group will receive self-care recommendations. The primary outcome will be average pain intensity, disability, and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting. The secondary outcome will be the post-intervention questionnaire. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Ljubljana. The study will be conducted in the Slovenian language.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of vaginal administration of tocopherol acetate in pre-peri and postmenopausal women. The study will be conducted in a single center and will include 100 participants. The intervention will be to administer Filme Gyno-V® Vaginal Ovules containing tocopherol acetate for 14 days. The primary outcome measure is the acidity of vaginal secretions. The secondary outcome measures are the rate of vaginal mucosa dryness, rate of vaginal mucosal integrity, rate of mucosa pallor, quantity of vaginal discharge assessment, whiff test, rate of lactobacillus grade according to Ison Hay's classification by bacterioscopic smear, microbiological evaluation by culture examination of the vaginal swab, molecular sequencing-based microbiological analysis of vaginal microbiota by next-generation sequencing (NGS) method, and serious adverse device effects/serious adverse events/adverse device effects/adverse events. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study protocol has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Catania.

[/INST] The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to compare the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in patients with polycythemia vera (PV) and secondary erythrocytosis. The study will collect data on clinical manifestations, history of thrombosis, and investigations such as complete blood picture, JAK2V617F mutation status, bone marrow aspiration, and biopsy. Patients with secondary erythrocytosis will be included as controls. The study will collect data from patients diagnosed with PV between September 2014 and November 2022 at Sohag University Hospital, Department of Internal Medicine, Hematology Unit, and Hematology Outpatient Clinic. The study will collect data from December 2022 to September 2023. The study will compare the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in PV patients to those with secondary erythrocytosis.

[/INST] The study titled "Emergency Classification According to Fingertip Circulation" is a clinical trial that aims to determine the effect of perfusion index (PI) measurement on the emergency triage classification of patients with dyspnea. The study includes adult patients who presented with dyspnea and whose PI values were measured with the Masimo Radical-7 device at the time of admission, at the first hour and the second hour of admission. The study compares the PI and oxygen saturation measured by finger probes and the superiority of their effects on the emergency triage classification is compared. The study is designed as a single-group assignment, open-label study. The primary outcome measure is the use of PI for triage status in patients with dyspnea. The study measures PI at the time of first admission to hospital, at the time of the first hour after admission to hospital and at the time of the second hour after admission to hospital. The study includes patients with dyspnea over the age of 18 who presented to the emergency department. Patients who applied due to the mechanism of trauma, patients with known vascular disease, and patients with COVID-19 PCR positivity whose PI measurement could not be completed due to hospitalization or discharge were excluded from the study. The study is conducted in the emergency department of the hospital. The study is expected to contribute to the literature by determining the relationship between PI and the emergency triage classification of patients with dyspnea.

[/INST] The study is a randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled phase II study. The study is designed to support the use of LSD in palliative care. The primary outcome measure is changes in state anxiety assessed by questionnaire (state anxiety inventory, STAI-S) compared with active placebo. The secondary outcome measures are changes in state anxiety assessed by questionnaire (state anxiety inventory, STAI-S) compared with active placebo, changes in pain levels assessed by questionnaire (numerical rating scale, NRS) compared with active placebo, changes in opioid use (dosages of opioids unified according to equivalent dosages of oral morphine) compared with active placebo, changes in spiritual well-being assessed by questionnaires (Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy - Spiritual Well-Being; The 12-item Spiritual Well-Being Scale (FACIT-Sp-12)) compared with active placebo, changes in demoralization assessed by questionnaires (Demoralization Scale II (DS-II)) compared with active placebo, changes in quality of life assessed with a single-item question compared with active placebo, changes in anxiety, pain levels, quality of life, demoralization, and spiritual well-being shortly after first intervention compared with scores shortly after second intervention, changes in patient's depression, isolation, anxiety, fear and denial of imminence of death, and pre-occupation with pain using investigator-ratings compared with active placebo, changes in patient's behaviour and attitudes rated by community observers compared with active placebo, changes in caregiver burden assessed by questionnaire compared with active placebo, associations between acute LSD effects assessed with questionnaires and long-lasting therapeutic effects assessed with questionnaires, changes in burden of suffering assessed with the Pictorial Representation of Illness and Self-Measure (PRISM) compared with active placebo, qualitative description of subjective changes after intervention assessed with semistructured interviews, changes in vital signs during drug sessions, changes in physical and general discomfort during drug sessions using standardized questions (adapted list of complaints), changes in opioid use (dosages of opioids unified according to equivalent dosages of oral morphine) compared with active placebo

[/INST] SmartMom is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a text messaging program called SmartMom in promoting healthy behaviors during pregnancy. The program is designed to provide evidence-based information to pregnant women to help them make informed decisions about their health and well-being. The study will compare the effectiveness of the SmartMom program to a control group that receives general information about pregnancy. The primary outcomes of the study are weight gain during pregnancy and attendance at prenatal care visits. The secondary outcomes include changes in health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, use of tobacco, vaping, alcohol, or cannabis, planned vaginal birth after cesarean, exclusive breastfeeding at hospital discharge, and rates of adverse pregnancy outcomes. The study will also evaluate the cost-effectiveness of the SmartMom program.
